Back to Top
Wingspan
48–55mm.
Back to Top
Identification
A dark butterfly that, like all of the genus [i]Dira[/i], is usually found swarming in large numbers where its host plants grow. The most widespread of the genus; may be found in suburban gardens and overgrown pastures where Kikuyu Grass [i]Cenchrus clandestinus[/i] is found.
 
[i]D. c. eurina[/i] is larger and paler than the nominate subspecies, with more prominent ocelli. Sexes similar, but female paler. Females are seldom seen because they are reluctant to take to wing. There are two subspecies, geographically separated.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Female upperside. (F) Male underside. (G) Female underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Often very common, especially in thick patches of kikuyu. In Fynbos in
south-western part of range, and Nama Karoo, Grassland and grassy Savanna further
ne. Near sea level in the south, but also at higher altitudes to north and east. [i]D. c. eurina[/i] from E Cape (Gamtoos R to Great Kei R).
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast, hillsides, parks and gardens.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded: [i]D. c. eurina[/i] late Feb to late March.
Back to Top

Poaceae grasses, including [i]Ehrharta erecta, Cenchrus clandestinus, Stipa dregeana[/i] and [i]Stenotaphrum secundatum[/i].

Beaufort Opal
[i]Chrysoritis beaufortia beaufortia[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]beaufortia[/i]
Subspecies: [i]beaufortia[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–36mm female 32–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, bright orange Opal. Closely resembles Pyramus Opal [i]Chrysoritis pyramus[/i]. Upperside orange colour [i]less red[/i]; dark borders and hind wing spotting [i]narrower, more variable[/i] in extent. Male shiny opalescence [i]paler[/i], more [i]greenish[/i] in shade. Forewing dark borders vary from narrow to so broad as to cover one-third of the wing. Cilia boldly chequered. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing [i]pale sandy[/i] colour variegated with darker postdiscal band in both sexes; few silver sagittate marks. Specimens from higher rainfall areas have darker basal markings.
 
Sexes dimorphic; female with basal blue [i]limited[/i], in some specimens only a few scales.
 
4 subspp., geographically or altitudinally distinct. Fast, low flight. Sometimes seen in huge numbers, all over the Karoo, showing no preference for any particular type of habitat, swarming on pink mesembryanthemum flowers. Males are usually found on hilltops, perching on prominent rocks and low plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Nama Karoo, on Nuweveldberge near Beaufort West.
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, flatlands, hill tops, hillsides, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood, Aug–Feb depending on locality.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Dimorphotheca cuneata, Osteospermum moniliferum, Norlindhia amplectens[/i], Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster capensis[/i] ants.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.

Silver-barred Charaxes
[i]Charaxes druceanus druceanus[/i]
alternative common name: Silver-barred Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]druceanus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]druceanus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 55–70mm female 65–85mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium to large sized Charaxes. Superficially similar to Foxy Charaxes [i]Charaxes saturnus saturnus[/i], but upperside is [i]much darker[/i], and has unmistakable [i]silvery underside[/i]. Nominate subspecies [i]C. d. druceanus[/i] male has paler upperside fulvous markings than other subspp. males; female has pale orange bands. It is a pure forest butterfly, as opposed to a Savanna dweller.
 
Sexes similar; female similar to male but larger, paler, with less angular wings.
 
Powerful, high flight in the canopy and around tree tops. Males territorial, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
4 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Nominate in coastal forests from Oribi Gorge, north to Eshowe and Ngoye, KwaZulu-Natal.

Pondo Amakosa Rocksitter
[i]Durbania amakosa penningtoni[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbania[/i]
Species: [i]amakosa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]penningtoni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–35mm female 29–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small black-and-orange/red butterflies; uppersides are black with varying degrees of red/orange spots and blotches. Undersides are beautifully camouflaged against their habitat; intricate patterns of black or dark grey on a white or pale grey ground, with submarginal spots in varying shades of red to orange, yellow or white. There are some similar species to Amakosa Rocksitter; Natal Rocksitter [i]Durbania limbata[/i] upperside has outer half of hind wing [i]broad[/i] red; sexes similar and flies in late summer to autumn, not spring and early summer. And Clark's Rocksitter [i]D. clarki[/i] is much smaller and its range does not overlap with that of [i]D. amakosa[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. [i]D. a. penningtoni[/i] has the palest upperside spots and bands of all the subspecies. It varies from yellow-buff in most males, to almost yellow in the large females, which when they have the broadest bands, can be mistaken for Yellow Pansy [i]Junonia hierta cebrene[/i] on the wing.
 
7 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside. (G) Female upperside. (H) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland in E Cape from Bedford to Grahamstown and Port Elizabeth.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Nov–Jan.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.

Common Opal
[i]Chrysoritis thysbe osbecki[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]thysbe[/i]
Subspecies: [i]osbecki[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 23–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of a large group of [i]Chrysoritis[/i] Opals with [i]blue wing bases[/i] and a [i]shimmering, electric opalescent sheen[/i] over a varying area of the wings. For [i]Chrysoritis thysbe[/i], amount of blue on upperside varies, in some subspecies almost covering the forewing. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside varies from plain sandy tan to dark brown, to [i]variegated[/i] with striae in various shades of reddish-brown, with bands of paler colouring and brassy postdiscal streaks. 'Plain' underside specimens usually have unicoloured cilia; 'variegated' ones dark cilia with pale interneural flecks, appearing 'chequered'.
 
[i]C. t. osbecki[/i] usually has unicoloured cilia and plain underside; may be found flying together with nominate. Sexes differ. Female has [i]rounder wings[/i], upperside blue [i]restricted to basal 25% of wings[/i], no opalescent sheen. The females of the various races are almost impossible to separate on wing patterns and identification usually requires comparison with males seen at the same locality.
 
7 subspp., not always geographically distinct. Rapid, sustained flight, settling on prominent bushes or rocks. Male intensively territorial on hill tops or sand dunes, regularly patrolling and chasing intruders; Females are found more at random, often on flowers.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Female upperside. (G), (H) Male undersides.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos-covered hills and dunes from north of Cape Town (Bloubergstrand) to Lambert's Bay.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, flatlands, mountains, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct and Mar.

African Monarch
[i]Danaus chrysippus alcippus[/i]
alternative common name: African Queen' Plain Tiger
Contents

Classification

Mimic

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Danainae
Genus: [i]Danaus[/i]
Species: [i]chrysippus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]alcippus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–70mm, female 50–75mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium to large butterfly, with weak but sustained fluttering flight, sometimes sailing, at medium height, 2–3m above the ground. Usually found flying alone or in small groups, but may be found in large numbers on wounded plants exuding pyrrolizidine alkaloids. Fond of nectar. This species has complex biogeography; it is widespread across Asia, southern Europe and the whole of Africa. Several subspecies occur across this range, the relationship between these is the subject of several studies.
 
Sexes similar; males have large dark spot in area CuA2 of hind wing; black on upperside, white-centred on underside.
 
[i]Danaus chrysippus alcippus[/i] is the common subspecies in Central and West Africa, and varies as to the extent and depth of the chocolate-brown basal suffusion.
 
It is possible that the appearance of forms resembling [i]D. c. alcippus[/i] among the South African [i]D. c. orientis[/i] population is a result of edge-of-range interbreeding with those races when climatic conditions make this possible.
 
(C) Male upperside. (D) Male underside.
 
Mimic
Female Common Diadem [i]Hypolimnas misippus[/i] is a polymorphic mimic of all forms of this butterfly. Also female [i]Papilio dardanus cenea[/i] forms [i]trophonius, aikeni[/i] and probably [i]salaami[/i]. Forest Beauty [i]Paralethe dendrophilus[/i]. White-barred Acraea, [i]Telchinia encedon encedon[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
Rarely seen in South Africa; usually found in the warmer northern areas.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, hill tops, flatlands, coast, mountains, wetlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round (peak late summer/autumn).

Male 55–70mm female 65–72mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very large, dark grey Skipper. Distinguished by its [i]white hind wing underside band[/i], with [i]one black spot[/i] at the anal angle, and [i]tapers strongly[/i] towards the costa, which it [i]does not touch[/i]. Underside similar to Striped Policeman [i]Coeliades forestan[/i] but ground colour on both wing surfaces is [i]battleship grey[/i], not [i]dark brown[/i].
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger and paler than males.
 
Males show very territorial behaviour; they choose a prominent twig or leaf in the territory. On this they perch and make circular sorties around their territory, a 'beat' from which the common name derives. Females are more sedentary and are usually found near the host plants. May be found swarming in large numbers under suitable conditions.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.

Coast Purple Tip
[i]Colotis erone[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Colotis[/i]
Species: [i]erone[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–45mm female 45–50mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized white Pierid with coloured or black forewing tips. Very similar to Bushveld Purple Tip [i]Colotis ione[/i]. Male upperside always white; black forewing apical tip with [i]three[/i] discrete metallic purple cells and [i]no[/i] grey scaling in the black border. Some specimens have a tiny extra spot of purple on costal edge of tip, [i]never four full-sized spots[/i] as in Bushveld Purple Tip. Also, purple [i]less obviously shiny[/i] and iridescent. Queen Purple Tip [i]C. regina[/i] has a distinct two-tone purple-green 'flop' in the wing tip, and is [i]larger[/i]. Underside varies from pinkish white in all dry season forms, to deep yellow in wet season forms; distinctive dark markings remain the same.
 
Sexually dimorphic; males always have a [i]purple[/i] upperside forewing tip; females
have two colour morphs - [i]orange-tipped[/i] and [i]black-tipped[/i].
Orange-tipped forms have [i]four dark spots[/i] in the orange, compared to
[i]five[/i] in female f. [i]ione[/i] orange-tipped forms. Black-tipped forms [i]three pale spots[/i] compared with four to five in dark-tipped forms of female Bushveld Purple Tip.
 
Fast, erratic flight, jinking in various directions but maintaining a steady course. Settles seldom except to feed at flowers. In cloudy weather may stop to bask in sunny patches. Females are less often seen than males because they are more retiring, but also often come to flowers.
 
Seasonally polymorphic. Male wet season form [i]erone[/i] has black veins on hind wing upperside and on edge of forewing tip. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Female wet season form [i]erone[/i] has [i]orange forewing tips and heavy black margins[/i]. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
 
Most common female wet season form [i]natalensis[/i] has upperside with [i]heavy black markings on forewing tips and margins[/i]. (E) Female upperside. (F) Female underside.
 
Male dry season form [i]jobina[/i] lacks upperside black veins. (G) Male upperside. (H) Male underside.
 
Commoner female dry season form [i]jobina[/i] has black upperside forewing tips containing three pale marks, and marginal black upperside marks reduced to spots. (I) Female upperside. (J) Female underside.
 
Rare female dry season form [i]millari[/i] has orange forewing tips, and marginal black upperside marks reduced to spots. (K) Female upperside. (L) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Coastal Lowland Forest and wooded Savanna from E Cape (Cwebe) along coast to Durban and
north to False Bay.
Back to Top
Habitat
Coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, with two peaks: WSF Dec–Jan, DSF Mar–Jul.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Maerua racemulosa[/i].
Back to Top
Group

Foxy Charaxes
[i]Charaxes saturnus saturnus[/i]
alternative common name: Foxy Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]saturnus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]saturnus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–75mm female 75–90mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, attractive Charaxes. Dark brown upperside ground colour, with tawny orange median band and row of marginal spots; latter whitish at anal corner of hind wing. Underside metallic grey, with white median bands; basal areas patterned in dark red outlined with black-edged white. Similar to Protea Charaxes [i]Charaxes pelias[/i], but not found in same areas. Also [i]larger, paler[/i], underside basal areas patterned in [i]ochre-red[/i], not dark red. The grey areas of the underside are a darker shade of silver.
 
Other similar species are the much larger, darker Giant Charaxes, [i]C. castor flavifasciatus[/i], and White-barred Charaxes, [i]C. brutus natalensis[/i], which is black on the upperside with a white median band. The former has a [i]yellow[/i] upperside median band and no tawny forewing basal patch. Both species have similar undersides to [i]C. saturnus saturnus[/i] but they have far less silver grey and more dark red.
 
Sexes similar, female with tails longer than male.
 
Flight fast and energetic. Males are very territorial, hilltopping and perching on prominent twigs on bushes, and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common, widespread. In Savanna from E Cape (East London), to KwaZulu-Natal thorn belt, and n and w Free State, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces and n N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, hill tops, flatlands, hillsides, parks and gardens.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, but only in warmer months in cooler parts of range. More common late summer to autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Afzelia quanzensis, Schotia brachypetala, Burkea africana, Bauhinia galpinii, Colophospermum mopane, Xanthocercis zambesiaca, Xeroderris stuhlmannii, Guibourtia conjugata, Maytenus senegalensis, Catha edulis[/i] and [i]Croton[/i] spp.

Vari's Brown
[i]Pseudonympha varii[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification

Habitat

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Pseudonympha[/i]
Species: [i]varii[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 46–50mm female 44–48mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Separated from similar False Silver-bottom Brown by [i]P. magoides[/i] having
anally more [i]pointed[/i] hind wing with three submarginal ocelli. The ocelli are never
'blind'. Underside hind wing ground colour also silvery grey, but more or less
covered with [i]brownish markings[/i]. Colouration variable, from pure silver grey with
plain dark marginal border, to having varying amounts of red-brown [i]striation[/i].
Hind wing underside discal band [i]red-brown[/i], prominent to indistinct. Specimens
from lower altitude populations in KwaZulu-Natal tend to have more rounded wings and darker brown underside markings than high altitude specimens from Lesotho and the E Cape. This butterfly is the subject of biogeographical studies and may comprise more than one species or subspecies. The God's Window population is possibly one of these. More information on northern populations is desirable.
 
Similar Swanepoel's Brown [i]P. swanepoeli[/i] has fewer ocelli and differences in the marginal dark lines on hind wing underside.
 
Sexes similar. Female paler with rounder wings, and more extensive orange markings.
 
Frequents marshy areas containing Cyperaceae sedges. Hopping flight deceptively fast; may drop and hide in undergrowth; female flight weak, reluctant to be flushed.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (KwaZulu-Natal population). (D) E Cape population.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland from E Cape (Groot Winterhoekberge to Amatolas), and Malutis and Drakensberg (Lesotho, KwaZulu-Natal and Free State) to KwaZulu-Natal Midlands (and possibly Mpumalanga; God's Window near Graskop).
Back to Top
Habitat
Wetlands, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded; peaks Nov–Dec and Jan–Mar; single midsummer (Dec and Jan) brood at high altitudes.
Back to Top

Probably Poaceae grasses, or Cyperaceae sedges.

Bowker’s Dotted Blue

Identification
Small bright blue lycaenid (in male). Upperside similar to Fynbos Dotted Blue [i]Tarucus thespis[/i], but is a more violaceous deep sapphire blue. Like that species it has conspicuous black-and-white chequered cilia. Underside ground colour [i]creamy white[/i], regular pattern of [i]black spots with buff to brown centres[/i]. Similar to Fynbos Dotted Blue [i]Tarucus thespis[/i] but underside hind wing dark marks [i]rounder and more sharply defined[/i]; submarginal series [i]sharp and black[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic: male upperside [i]blue[/i]. Female upperside pale markings [i]squarer[/i] than Dotted Blue [i]T. sybaris[/i], and compared to Fynbos Dotted Blue [i]T. thespis[/i], not confined to forewing apical area, but more generally across all the discal part of the upperside.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct; a separate population found high on Blouberg Mtns, n Limpopo Province, is deeper blue and possibly a distinct subspecies. Some doubt as to whether populations in the Drakensberg are nominate or [i]T. bowkeri transvaalensis[/i]. Rapid, fluttering flight around host plants, sometimes flying high; settling often.

Mountain Sandman
[i]Spialia spio[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Spialia[/i]
Species: [i]spio[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–29mm female 28–31mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, dark Skipper with black-and-white chequered upperside and forewing underside. One of a group of very similar little butterflies, which are difficult to tell apart from the upperside markings. To be reasonably sure of identification a clear view of the hind wing underside is necessary. Markings very similar to Mafa Sandman [i]Spialia mafa[/i]; white upperside spots larger, [i]more rounded[/i]; upperside forewing costa has [i]pale spot[/i] at base. Hind wing underside white discocellular spot [i]larger and more rounded[/i], white inner spot in Sc+R1 larger, [i]edges smoother[/i]. Cilia chequered.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
Fast, buzzing, low flight, settling often, wings open. Male found on hill tops, lower on slopes or in flat country near host plants. Fond of animal faeces; often found on wet mud.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
All over e side of South Africa but absent from aridest Karoo and Savanna, commonest Cape Peninsula [i]Spialia[/i].
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, hill tops, hillsides, flatlands, coast, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods; year-round in warmer areas, more common in warmer months. In cool areas, Aug–Apr; in W Cape Fynbos mainly Aug–Oct.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hermannia diffusa, H. incana, H. comosa, H. coccocarpa, H. cuneifolia, Hibiscus aethiopicus, H. pusillus, Pavonia burchellii, P. columella, Malva arborea, Sida[/i] spp., [i]Triumfetta[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Sandmen.

Tsomo River Opal
[i]Chrysoritis lyncurium[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]lyncurium[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 21–24mm female 23–26mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small coppery Opal. Upperside [i]bright coppery-red[/i] with black marginal borders and [i]sparse[/i] black forewing spots; largest of which is at the distal end of the cell. Similar to many other Opals with plain copper uppersides but most are not found in the same areas. Very similar to Mooi River Opal [i]Chrysoritis lycegenes[/i], but upperside [i]darker, redder[/i], and hind wing upperside costa [i]heavily marked with black[/i]. Underside forewing has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing is [i]red-brown to greenish-buff[/i] crossed by lines of darker brown.
 
Sexes similar, female paler colour; not as metallic as the male. Has [i]greenish hue[/i] on hind wing underside.
 
Colonies found close to host plants. Male perches on low vegetation, chasing other butterflies. Female more sedentary, usually on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare and localised. Montane Grassland from n E Cape (Tsomo River area, Mbulu) to s KwaZulu-Natal (Bushman's Nek, Kokstad). Threats include livestock grazing and alien plantations.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky slopes, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Usually midsummer (Dec and Jan) but possible earlier brood.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Diospyros, Myrsine[/i] and [i]Royena[/i] spp. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster[/i] ants, including [i]C. liengmei[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Coppers.

Black-tipped Scarlet
[i]Axiocerses coalescens[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Axiocerses[/i]
Species: [i]coalescens[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 25–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, brilliant scarlet-red lycaenid. Male Black-tipped Scarlet similar to Common Scarlet [i]Axiocerses tjoane tjoane[/i] and Dark-banded Scarlet [i]A. croesus[/i] but has [i]totally black forewing tip[/i] with [i]no[/i] discal black spots. Bush Scarlet [i]A. amanga amanga[/i] has a [i]plain hind wing underside[/i] with [i]no brassy spots[/i].
 
The underside ground colour varies from pale sandy buff to a deep reddish brown. The forewing has a similar spotting pattern to most Coppers; the hind wing has rows of dark spots with brassy centres.
 
Sexes differ; females are [i]more orange than red[/i] on the upperside with a varying extent of rows of dark spotting: they are virtually impossible to distinguish from the other two similar species.
 
Males are extremely pugnacious hilltoppers. Rapid flight with very fast wingbeats, especially in males. Male perches at midday on low bushes, often upside down, with half-open wings. Females are more often found on flowers and close to host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Wooded Savanna in n KwaZulu-Natal, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, and Limpopo and NW provinces, and further north.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct–Nov and Mar–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Vachellia[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Scarlets.

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 16–24mm female 19–25mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small coppery brown lycaenid. Cilia chequered in both sexes. Similar to Geranium Bronze [i]Cacyreus marshalli[/i] but the upperside ground colour is [i]more coppery[/i] and underside ground colour [i]darker[/i] brown; albeit still suffused with white; crossed by bands of [i]white-edged darker brown[/i]; underside has [i]two[/i] dark costal blotches. A triangular patch at the anal angle of the hind wing has a [i]double[/i] 'tooth' pointing towards the outer margin, at the apex of the triangle, in area M3. This is broader than that of Geranium Bronze, and [i]contrasts more[/i] against the darker ground colour. Hind wing has a small tail at the end of CuA2.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Rapid, fluttering flight around bushes and shrubs. Does not specialise in wetlands as does Water Geranium Bronze.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.

Fynbos, Nama Karoo, Succulent Karoo, all over W Cape to N Cape (Namaqualand) and Roggeveld Escarpment, over a wide range of altitudes.

Wichgraf's Hillside Brown
[i]Stygionympha wichgrafi wichgrafi[/i]
alternative common name: Wichgraf's Brown

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Stygionympha[/i]
Species: [i]wichgrafi[/i]
Subspecies: [i]wichgrafi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
40–50mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Similar to, but much [i]smaller[/i] than Western [i]Stygionympha vigilans[/i] or Eastern [i]S. scotina[/i] Hillside Browns. Wings of both sexes, but especially female, more [i]angular[/i]. [i]Brown[/i] ground colour varies between subspecies; specimens from higher altitudes, or wetter habitats, become darker on the upperside and more greyish-brown, the hind wing undersides can have distinct reddish discal and postdiscal bands.
 
Hind wing underside sometimes with [i]large ocelli[/i] in apical and anal areas, underside forewing basal rust-red patch reaches as far as apical ocellus; hind wing underside grey-brown ground colour irrorated with tiny short dark red-brown striae grouped into ill-defined bands.
 
Nominate subspecies [i]S. w. wichgrafi[/i] is the largest subspecies. Sexes similar, female heavier, with stouter abdomen, and wings more elongated. Female has more sedentary habits.
 
Slow, jinking flight, settling often on rocks, jerkily opening and closing wings. Visits flowers, where it tends to be less wary.
 
3 geographically distinct subspp.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top

Grassland. Nominate in hills of n Free State, Gauteng, Limpopo Province, NW Province and Mpumalanga.

Back to Top
Flight period
Probably multi-brooded, Aug–Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
Possibly Poaceae grasses.

Grass Browns.

Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–38mm female 36–40mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown butterfly with black markings. Only reliably distinguished from Knysna [i]Thestor protumnus[/i] and Riley's [i]T. rileyi[/i] Skollies by genitalic dissection. Forewing [i]more elongated[/i] than [i]T. protumnus[/i]; underside discal band of spots [i]widened[/i] in areas CuA1 and M3, creating an irregular outline.
 
Sexes similar; male with wings more pointed than female, darker brown. Has pale grey-brown tridentate sex brand, restricted to origin of veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2.
 
[i]T. overbergensis[/i] lives in colonies on the summit of a mountain, in succulent scrub. Little is recorded about its habits, but it probably has fast, low flight, settling on rocks or low plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.

Water Watchman
[i]Parnara monasi[/i]
alternative common name: Water Skipper
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Parnara[/i]
Species: [i]monasi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 30–33mm female 32–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown Skipper with ochreous-yellow underside. Upperside warm grey-brown, with square hyaline discal series of spots on forewing; hind wing has straight series of whitish discal spots in areas M2 to CuA2. Underside [i]dull ochre-yellow[/i], forewing [i]blackish basally[/i], hind wing has dark smudge in cell and a series of dark smudges distal to pale spots that follow the upperside pattern. Cilia plain whitish-cream. Similar to Marsh Swift [i]Borbo micans[/i] but that butterfly [i]lacks hind wing underside spotting[/i]. Underside resembles that of Common Hottentot Skipper [i]Gegenes niso niso[/i] and Marsh Hottentot Skipper [i]G. hottentota[/i]; hind wing has [i]only one row of dark marks[/i], not [i]two[/i] as in those species.
 
Sexes similar; female resembles male, has larger pale markings, rounder wings, a larger abdomen, and an extra forewing hyaline spot in CuA2.
 
Low, fast, erratic flight, settling often on low vegetation. Males perch on grass leaves and low plants, darting out to challenge rivals, returning to their original perch. Females are found more at random, searching for oviposition sites.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside showing hind wing. (C) Female underside showing forewing.
Back to Top
Distribution
Riverine Forest and grassy marshes from Swaziland to E Cape (Port S. Johns), along the eastern littoral to Maputaland, lowveld of Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province; also e NW Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, wetlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Jan–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae wetland grasses.
Back to Top
Group
Swifts.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Anthene[/i]
Species: [i]larydas[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–28mm female 23–29mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Blue Hairtail with striking [i]grey[/i] underside crossed by [i]stripes of white and darker grey[/i], and large basal grey-black spots ringed with white. Similar to Juanita's Hairtail [i]Anthene crawshayi juanitae[/i] but forewing underside submarginal pale stripes are [i]broader and not as wavy[/i]; female much darker. Both sexes' undersides have black-and-orange lunules at anal angle, and [i]short, bristle-like tails[/i] at the ends of the cubital veins.
 
Sexually very dimorphic; male with similar [i]steel-blue[/i] upperside to Common Hairtail [i]Anthene definita definita[/i] but [i]paler, with a 'watered silk' effect[/i]. Female upperside dark [i]grey to black[/i], whitish [i]submarginal lunules[/i] on both wings, usually with some white scaling at basal margin of forewing.
 
Whirling flight around forest edges, usually where there are flowers in bloom. Often found flying with Large Hairtail [i]A. lemnos lemnos[/i].
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Coastal Lowland Forest in KwaZulu-Natal, from south coast to Kosi Bay, inland across the Makhathini Flats, and north into the lowveld of Limpopo Province, Mozambique and Zimbabwe.

Classification

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 60–65mm female 70–80mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, black-and-white butterfly with [i]angular[/i] wings; upperside white markings are repeated on the underside on a marbled brown ground. Resembles one of black-and-white [i]Amauris[/i] Friars (closest to Novice [i]A. ochlea ochlea[/i]). More [i]robust[/i] build, [i]straighter, stiffer[/i] antennae and [i]scalloped wing edges[/i] tell it apart. Could also be confused with Variable Diadem [i]Hypolimnas anthedon wahlbergi[/i] form [i]wahlbergi[/i], but the white markings are [i]narrower and more angular[/i]; forewing discal band [i]separated from inner margin[/i] by black.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Flight high, powerful and direct. Male territorial at edge of forest canopy, perching high on a leaf, chasing other butterflies; female usually at flowers high on trees. Roosts under large trees, rocks and in holes.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Models
Novice [i]Amauris ochlea ochlea[/i]; ; mimicry is not very accurate.
Back to Top

Rare. Lowland and Riverine Forest along east coast, from E Cape (East London) to n KwaZulu-Natal (Kosi Bay). One record from Limpopo Province (e Soutpansberg).

Pearl-spotted Charaxes
[i]Charaxes jahlusa rex[/i]
alternative common name: Pearl-spotted Emperor
Contents

Classification

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]jahlusa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]rex[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 42–56mm female 50–62mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, bright orange Charaxes. Superficially similar to Club-tailed Charaxes [i]Charaxes zoolina[/i] f. [i]neanthes[/i], but with [i]black[/i] spots, not red-brown, and has two tails in [i]both[/i] sexes. Tails are sharply pointed, [i]not clubbed[/i]. [i]C. j. rex[/i] is the largest local subspecies. It has [i]less[/i] well-developed upperside dark markings. Hind wing underside basal area is [i]darker[/i] than [i]C. j. jahlusa[/i] and more orange than [i]C. j. argynnides[/i].
 
Sexes similar, but male has [i]narrower, more triangular[/i] wings.
 
Although this is a small Charaxes it lacks nothing in speed of flight or, in the male, pugnacity. Males form territories on hilltops, or in flat country, around prominent bushes and trees. They pursue any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females are found close to the host plants, or wandering around searching for males.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
7 geographically distinct subspp., 3 in South Africa.
 
(G) Male upperside. (H) Female upperside. (I) Female underside (ovipositing on [i]Pappea capensis[/i].

Distribution
Savanna from n Free State to Gauteng, Limpopo and NW provinces.

Habitat
Hill tops, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round.
Back to Top

[i]Pappea capensis[/i] and [i]Dalbergia melanoxylon[/i].

Very small violaceous brown lycaenid. Cilia chequered in both sexes. Underside similar to that of Geranium Bronze [i]Cacyreus marshalli[/i]; ground colour similarly pale brown suffused with white; crossed by bands of [i]white-edged darker brown[/i]; underside has [i]three[/i] dark costal blotches. Scarlet Tip
[i]Colotis annae annae[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Colotis[/i]
Species: [i]annae[/i]
Subspecies: [i]annae[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
35–55mm; variation in size of seasonal forms.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized white Pierid with red or black forewing tips. Forewing apical tips cover [i]almost half the wing[/i]. Underside of both sexes, all forms, has discal row of [i]brown-centred black spots on both wings[/i]. Only other species to have [i]pure red[/i] wing tips is [i]Colotis antevippe[/i] but that species' apical tips only cover the upper third of the wing, and the underside [i]lacks discal rows of dark spots[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. All male forms have upperside forewing tips [i]broad, brilliant red[/i], with broad basal dark band. Females have two forms, red-tipped with postdiscal row of black spots, and black-tipped with postdiscal row of pale salmon-pink or buff spots. Female basal patches white to grey, reduced discal spots and dark margins.
 
Low, rapid flight direct through bush, settling often to feed at flowers. Where host plant is abundant, it may swarm in large numbers.
 
Seasonally polymorphic. Male wet season f. [i]annae[/i]: upperside has [i]broad[/i] black hind wing margins and basal edge to red forewing tip. Underside as per female. (A) Male upperside.
 
Female f. [i]annae[/i]: upperside ground colour white with very heavy black basal patches, discal spotting and marginal borders, sometimes appearing marbled. Forewing apical tip either a red patch crossed with black spots, or black, with a postdiscal series of pale salmon-pink or buff spots. Underside as per male. (B) Female upperside, red-tipped form. (C) Female upperside, black-tipped form. (D), (E) Female undersides.
 
Male dry season f. [i]wallengrenii[/i]: smaller than f. [i]annae[/i]; black margins reduced to spots, apical patch paler red with narrower black edge. (F) Male upperside.
 
Female f. [i]wallengrenii[/i]: upperside ground colour creamy white or pale yellow with brown-black or orange basal patches, discal spotting and marginal borders, sometimes appearing marbled. Forewing apical tip either a red patch crossed with black spots, or black, with a postdiscal series of pale salmon-pink or buff spots. Underside as per male. (G) Female upperside, red-tipped form. (H) Female upperside, black-tipped form. (I) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Open to wooded Savanna from E Cape (King William's Town area), to KwaZulu-Natal, Maputaland, north to Mpumalanga, and Limpopo and NW provinces, w to n N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands, forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall. WSF Oct–Mar, DSF Feb–Nov. Peaks towards late summer and autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Cadaba termitaria, C. natalensis[/i] and [i]Maerua angolensis[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Tips.
Back to Top






Sabine Albatross White
[i]Appias sabina phoebe[/i]
alternative common name: Sabine Albatross; Albatross White
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Appias[/i]
Species: [i]sabina[/i]
Subspecies: [i]phoebe[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 44–55mm female 44–53mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–large white Pierid. Male resembles that of Diverse Albatross White
[i]Appias epaphia contracta[/i]. but is [i]larger[/i]; the critical difference being the
yellow costal streak at the base of the underside hind wing. In Sabine Albatross White
[i]only the hind wing has a yellow streak[/i]. Both species are sexually dimorphic, but
their females are totally different and easy to distinguish.
 
Sexually dimorphic, male with [i]brilliant white[/i] upperside, dark forewing marginal border [i]broken into spots at vein ends[/i]; black spots at hind wing vein ends. Underside hind wing white with [i]yellow costal edge[/i]. There are two female forms. More common female f. [i]gertrudae[/i] has forewing tips [i]diffuse black[/i], veins black at wing edges, forewing basal patch orange, variable extent of hind wing yellow; underside [i]similar to upperside[/i]. Rarer f. [i]phoebe[/i] has both surfaces of hind wing [i]deep yellow[/i], upperside with heavy marginal sagittate black marks along veins, forewing upperside tip black with yellow streaks between veins. These features tell it apart from Trimen's Dotted Border, [i]Mylothris trimenia[/i], which has [i]no dark marks along veins[/i].
 
Flies fairly rapidly along the edges of forests, settling often on low vegetation or on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides.
 
Female form [i]gertrudae[/i]: (D) Female upperside. (E), (F) Female undersides.
 
Female form [i]phoebe[/i]: (G) Female upperside. (H) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Scarce, but may be locally common. Lowland Forest at E Cape (Port St. Johns), n KwaZulu-Natal (Eshowe and Maputaland - Manguzi and Kosi Bay area), Riverine Forest in eastern foothills of Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province Drakensberg (such as Lekgalameetse), lower Afromontane Forest at Woodbush in Magoebaskloof.

Gullies, forest edges.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]strutti[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 25–27mm female 26–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, bright cream to cartridge-buff butterfly. Lightest coloured of the Mountain Skolly group. Male has two distinct colour morphs - cream-buff and cartridge-buff. Underside hind wing of both sexes has [i]contrasting[/i] basal and discal bands of darker grey marks over grey ground colour; lower half of discal band [i]much larger[/i] than upper half. Submarginal row of 'V'-shaped marks [i]reduced[/i], as in [i]T. montanus[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. Female sometimes [i]much larger[/i] than male but both sexes variable in size. Male forewing has grey-brown sex brand in basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2.
 
[i]T. strutti[/i] lives in colonies, usually on high, (usually) north-facing mountain slopes, between large rocks and in shallow gullies. The females fly more slowly than the males. Flight is low, fast and sustained, dodging between rocks. They settle often on low vegetation or rocks, but are wary and difficult to approach. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.

Classification

Back to Top

Male 32–41mm female 34–42mm.

Identification
Small bright yellow Pierid. Differs from African Clouded Yellow [i]Colias electo electo[/i] in upperside ground colour [i]yellow, not orange[/i], and Spiller's Sulphur Yellow [i]Dixeia spilleri[/i], in that it has [i]broad black borders[/i]. Black forewing upperside marginal band [i]scalloped[/i], which sets it apart from other [i]Eurema[/i] species except Common Grass Yellow [i]E. hecabe[/i]. This is a very similar species but Malagasy Grass Yellow can be told from it as follows: underside hind wing cell spot [i]strongly widens towards the apical end[/i], to more than [i]twice the width of the narrow portion[/i]. The hind wing margin is [i]continuously black[/i], or if it is reduced as in dry season individuals, the [i]marks at the end of the veins are discrete spots, not linear smudges[/i]. Best identifying feature is where the scalloped edge of forewing upperside black border bends inwards halfway up area M2, not along vein M3 as in Common Grass Yellow (see arrow in (A)).
 
Sexes similar, female [i]paler yellow[/i] than male, has grey scaling at upperside wing bases.
 
Flies rapidly along thick forest vegetation, settling occasionally on flowers or vegetation.
 
Seasonally dimorphic.
 
Dry season form has dark smudges at the hind wing upperside margin vein ends; underside forewing tip carries a [i]square dark patch[/i]: (A) Female upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Wet season form [i]solifera[/i] has a [i]continuous dark hind wing upperside marginal band[/i] and the underside forewing tip is [i]plain yellow[/i]. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Eastern South Africa from Limpopo south to KwaZulu-Natal. This butterfly was until recently confused with Common Grass Yellow, so its distribution map is an estimate, as opposed to being based on actual observations.

Habitat
Flatlands, coast, Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods, year-round, depending on rainfall. WSF Sept–May, DSF Mar–Oct. Peaks in late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
Not known in South Africa.

Yellows.

One of the largest [i]Aloeides[/i] coppers. [i]pallida[/i] means pale, but that only refers to the nominate subspecies; the others are more deeply coloured. [i]Bright orange[/i] upperside with wide dark marginal bands; cilia chequered in whitish grey and black; forewing costal band widens at apex. Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]marieps[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 48–60mm female 65–70mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to medium-sized Charaxes, females can be large. Male velvety black, with strong gloss visible from an oblique angle, and irregular, wavy, green metallic hind wing submarginal band. The forewing has a marginal series of short, metallic green interneural streaks, and the hind wing has a full series of large, whitish submarginal lunules. Female upperside suffused orange on all wings, deep orange discal bands and strong purple gloss overall. Both sexes have deeper chestnut-brown underside and blunter, thicker tails than similar Karkloof Charaxes [i]C. karkloof[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic, only one female form, unlike [i]C. ethalion ethalion[/i].
 
Fast, agile, high flight. Males territorial in forest canopy, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly more slowly, low along the fringes of forests where they settle on tree leaves.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.

Identification
Medium–large, conspicuous, brilliant [i]turquoise and black[/i] swordtail with long straight tails. Upperside ground colour black with turquoise bands and spots. Resembles Small Striped Swordtail [i]Graphium policenes policenes[/i] but transverse bands in forewing cell are [i]wavy and the same shade of turquoise as the other upperside markings[/i]. Underside similarly marked to upperside, but black replaced by grey-brown and turquoise markings paler, less saturated. Other similar species are Cream-Striped Swordtail [i]G. porthaon[/i], which has pale cream markings, and Mamba Swordtail [i]G. colonna[/i], whose upperside stripes are [i]narrow[/i], with [i]wider black spacing[/i] in between.
 
Sexes very similar. Male slightly smaller; has white hair pencils in a pouch on the inner hind wing margin. These are only exhibited when he is fluttering before a female during courtship.
 
Flight high and rapid. Both sexes visit flowers, males may be found in hundreds on wet mud.

Battling Glider
[i]Cymothoe alcimeda alcimeda[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Limenitidinae
Genus: [i]Cymothoe[/i]
Species: [i]alcimeda[/i]
Subspecies: [i]alcimeda[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–50mm female 45–55mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized butterfly. Battling Glider is the smaller of South Africa's two [i]Cymothoe[/i] species; the other being Blonde Glider [i]Cymothoecoranus coranus[/i]. Compared to that species, apart from size, [i]C. alcimeda[/i] has [i]more angulate[/i] wings and, usually, a more [i]heavily marked[/i] underside. Nominate subspecies [i]C. a. alcimeda[/i] male upperside is distinctive with big dark mark at end of forewing cell. Sexually dimorphic: there is only one female form of the nominate subspecies, but there is more than one subspecies and those females are polymorphic. Male upperside creamy white; both sexes' underside cryptic.
 
Both sexes have the typical Limenitidinae gliding flight with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Males perch high up on forest edge trees and shrubs, and sally forth to chase away all other insects. When there is more than one male in a forest clearing, constant aerial battles take place, hence the common name. Females are found close to the host plants. Both sexes regularly drink at wet mud, and nectar from flowers. They are also attracted to fruit bait.
 
5 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside, light form. (C) Male underside, dark form. (D) Male underside, brown form. Female upperside has one form; white bands on a brown-black ground; white varies from pure white to cream, occasionally with a tinge of ochre. (E) Female upperside. (F) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Coastal and moist Afromontane Forest from W Cape (Grootvadersbosch, Swellendam) to Knysna.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, mainly summer from Oct; peak Nov and Mar–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Kiggelaria africana[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Gliders.

Back to Top
Identification
Common, widespread and familiar small to medium-sized butterfly. Pattern of yellow blotches and hind wing blue patches is unmistakable in South Africa. Dry season individuals tend to have paler grey hind wing underside colouration.
 
Slight sexual dimorphism. Female has dark forewing cell bar and black ocelli in yellow postdiscal band on hind wing, [i]lacking[/i] in male.
 
Low flight, short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats, Males establish territories close to patches of open ground, and patrol these, settling often with wings slowly fanning. Fond of damp earth and wet sand near streams, and rotting fruit; also flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common, widespread. From W Cape through warmer, moister Karoo areas into Grassland and Savanna of Free State, Gauteng, KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, and N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Parks and gardens, flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peaks Oct and Nov, and Feb–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
Many Acanthaceae including [i]Justicia[/i] spp., [i]Dyschoriste depressa, D. setigera, Adhatoda densiflora, Asystasia gangetica, Barleria[/i] spp., including [i]B. pungens[/i], and [i]Ruellia cordata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Pansies.

Scarce Ranger
[i]Kedestes nerva nerva[/i]
alternative common name: Scarce Skipper

Classification

Subfamily: Hesperiinae

Species: [i]nerva[/i]
Subspecies: [i]nerva[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 27–31mm female 33–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brightly coloured Skipper. Upperside dark brown with white and orange spots, underside patterned in yellow and cream with black spots. Similar to Fulvous Ranger [i]Kedestes mohozutza[/i] but has [i]pale spots present[/i] in upperside forewing areas M1 and M2, and underside has [i]three[/i] rows of black spots, submedian and discal, on yellow hind wing ground colour, separated by cream veins. Marginal black line on both wings is [i]narrower[/i] than that of (larger) Chaka's Ranger [i]K. chaca[/i]; underside ground [i]yellow, not orange[/i]; submedian hind wing pale band [i]absent[/i]. White discal underside hind wing band not as elongated, black-edged white spot in cell, two sub-basal black dots in Sc+R1, and one in 1A+2A. Cilia chequered.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Female upperside forewing discal spots [i]cream[/i] (white in male); female has [i]full series[/i] of buff submarginal spots - in male, faint, red-orange, only on forewing.
 
Flight extremely rapid and erratic; very hard to follow, and wary. Found in open grassy country; male territorial around patches of long grass, perching on tall grass stems. Female seldom seen. Fond of flowers, particularly white Scabious.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Scarce, local. Savanna, Grassland and open woodland, from ne KwaZulu-Natal across e Mpumalanga to extreme s Limpopo Province (Waterberg), Gauteng and adjoining areas of e NW Province, also n N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded; weak brood Oct–Nov, stronger brood Feb–Apr.
Back to Top

No data.

Twin Swift
[i]Larsenia gemella[/i]
Contents

Classification

Identification

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Larsenia[/i]
Species: [i]gemella[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–37mm female 40–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small brown Skipper. Forewing [i]elongated, pointed[/i]. Upperside ground colour [i]dark brown[/i] with [i]paler ochre scaling and hairs along inner margin and at base[/i]. Forewing has large hyaline spots in discal and subapical areas; [i]double[/i] spot in cell. Hind wing upperside has no spots. Underside ground colour grey-brown, [i]3 white hind wing spots[/i] in areas R5, M3 and Rs. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Similar to Rusty Swift [i]Borbo detecta[/i], but upperside [i]duller ochre[/i] and has well-defined white hind wing underside spots. Similar to Olive-haired Swift [i]B. borbonica[/i], whose underside is the [i]ochre-yellow[/i] and has underside series of [i]black-ringed white spots[/i]. Can be told from Black-branded Swift [i]Pelopidas mathias mathias[/i] and White-branded Swift [i]P. thrax[/i] by the three well-defined white hind wing underside spots.
 
Sexes similar, female paler with rounder wings and larger pale markings.
 
Low, swift flight, settling often on low vegetation or the ground. Males visit hill tops early in the day; in forests they can be found defending territories in clearings. Females fly more slowly and at random, searching for oviposition sites.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Lowland and Riverine Forest and wooded Savanna, especially near rivers, from E Cape (East London) to Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal (Maputaland), Mpumalanga, and Limpopo Province to Thabazimbi area, n Gauteng, e NW Province and n Free State.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Mar–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
Grasses including [i]Triticum sativum[/i] (wheat), [i]Ehrharta erecta, Saccharum[/i] spp. and [i]Zea mays[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Swifts.

Distinctive small orange butterfly; cannot be mistaken for any other lycaenid in South Africa. Superficially resembles male Small Orange Acraea; probably a Muellerian mimic. [i]Bright orange colour[/i] on both surfaces, conspicuous in flight.

Identification
Unmistakable butterfly with almost totally [i]hyaline wings[/i]. They develop a rainbow sheen when sun shines through them. Underside is virtually identical to upperside.
 
Sexes very similar. Female larger than male.
 
Slow, high, sailing flight, wings almost motionless; settles on canopy leaves and twigs. May fly lower at forest edges and in windy weather; sometimes seen early in the morning, nectaring at flowers. Roosts communally.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Female underside.

Marginal in South Africa; regular breeding populations in Lowland Forest east of Lebombo Mtns (Tembe Elephant Reserve), and coastal forests (Emanguzi, near KwaNgwanase) of Maputaland, KwaZulu-Natal. Occasional stragglers as far south as the Tugela River.

Spotted Velvet Skipper
[i]Abantis tettensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Models
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Abantis[/i]
Species: [i]tettensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–40mm female 35–45mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Conspicuous medium-sized Skipper. Upperside has white-spotted black forewing, and hind wing with [i]black spots[/i] in large, white discal patch, with submarginal row of white spots. Underside has generalised '[i]Acraea[/i]' pattern of black lines and spots on a pink, white and buff ground. Differs from Paradise Skipper [i]Abantis paradisea[/i] which has [i]no black spots[/i] in the hind wing upperside white discal patch, instead having [i]strong black lines[/i] along the veins and [i]red-orange spots and bands[/i] on the body. The only other Skipper to have the ' [i]Acraea[/i]' hind wing underside pattern is Variegated Acraea Hopper [i]Fresna nyassae[/i], which has a [i]much darker[/i] upperside, resembling one of the [i]Platylesches[/i] Hopper species.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger and paler than males, with [i]more elongated wings[/i].
 
Males show strong territorial behaviour; perching on a prominent twig or leaf, usually high on a hilltop tree; with forelegs raised, exposing black scent hairs. They fly rapidly around their territory, with buzzing wings a blur. Other butterflies are attacked. Females are more sedentary and are usually found near the host plants. Both sexes perch wings-open.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Models
Generalised Bitter Acraeas, [i]Acraea[/i] and [i]Telchinia[/i] species.
Back to Top
Distribution
Savanna and Arid Savanna, from Maputaland area of KwaZulu-Natal, extreme n Free State, lowveld in Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, n Gauteng, and extreme e N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood, Sept–Apr, peak Oct–Nov.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Grewia flava, G. flavescens, G. hexamita[/i] and [i]G. monticola[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Paradise Skippers.

Identification
Smaller than [i]Serradinga bowkeri, S. kammanassiensis[/i]. White postdiscal markings small and not always distinct. Ground colour [i]shiny, coppery brown[/i]. Usually found on hillsides with coarse [i]Merxmuellera[/i] grasses. Flight low, slow, fluttering; sometimes found in huge numbers. 4 subspp., geographically distinct.

Natal Bar
[i]Cigaritis natalensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Cigaritis[/i]
Species: [i]natalensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 25–32.5mm female 26.5–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Of the Bars, genus [i]Cigaritis[/i] this is on average the largest, and the most
widespread. Like Mozambique Bar [i]Cigaritis mozambica[/i] the underside dark bars are
[i]straight[/i], which sets them apart from the other three species found in South Africa.
Compared to that species the underside ground colour is [i]paler[/i] and the bars
[i]brown[/i], not orange. Each hind wing carries a pair of thin tails with white tips at
the anal angle. There are two forms; the nominate, with prominent orange and black
forewing upperside bars, is commoner. f. [i]obscurus[/i], which has the orange more or
less obscured by dark grey or black, is usually found in KwaZulu-Natal and the lowveld, in the dry season.
 
Sexes similar. Females are larger with more rounded wings. The upperside usually has pale whitish patches in the forewing discal area, and hind wing apical area.
 
Rapid flight with very fast wingbeats, especially in males. Male perches at midday on prominent hill top bushes, often upside down, with half-open wings. Both sexes are found on flowers and at mud puddles.
 
Nominate form: (A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside (both forms same on underside). F. [i]obscurus[/i]: (D) Male upperside. (E) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread and common, but densities usually low. Wooded Savanna and wooded hill tops in Grassland from E Cape (Port Edward) along coast to KwaZulu-Natal (Kosi Bay), to Swaziland, Free State, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, Limpopo and NW provinces, and parts of the N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Sept–Oct and Mar–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Canthium inerme, Clerodendrum glabrum, Mundulea sericea, Sphenostylis angustifolia[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Bars.
Back to Top

Identification
One of the largest [i]Aloeides[/i] coppers. [i]pallida[/i] means pale, but that only refers to the nominate subspecies; the others are more deeply coloured. Bright orange upperside with wide dark marginal bands; cilia chequered in whitish grey and black; forewing costal band widens at apex. Dark scaling from marginal bands penetrates edges of the orange areas along veins. Underside colouration varies from fawn to crimson with [i]well-defined[/i] basal, discal and submarginal rows of dentate spots merged to form silver-grey bands edged black.
 
Sexes similar, female has rounder wings.
 
6 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fairly fast, close to the ground; settling often, usually on the ground or on low vegetation. Found in colonies. Reluctant to open wings.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male upperside (fawn-brown morph). (C) Male underside (pink morph).

Widespread but localised in Grassland and Nama Karoo from W Cape (Matjiesfontein) to E Cape (Graaff-Reinet), north to Free State (Springfontein).

Small, yellow-orange Pierid. Superficially resembles Veined Tip [i]Colotis vesta argillaceus[/i] but dark discal band on hind wing upperside [i]very[/i] faint. Very distinct dark [i]stripes[/i] along hind wing upperside veins; interneural pale marginal spots larger than Veined Tip, giving hind wing a 'rayed' appearance. In both sexes, hind wing underside much more faintly marked than upperside.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Female resembles Veined Tip, but hind wing upperside has [i]streaky appearance[/i] and the wing bases are [i]not white[/i].
 
Rapid flight up and down hills, circling bushes and settling on flowers. Only found in sheltered semi-desert gullies near host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

White-banded Swallowtail
[i]Papilio echerioides echerioides[/i]
Contents

Classification

Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Papilionidae
Subfamily: Papilioninae
Genus: [i]Papilio[/i]
Species: [i]echerioides[/i]
Subspecies: [i]echerioides[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
65–75mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized black Swallowtail with white markings. Both sexes completely [i]tailless[/i]; hind wings [i]rounded[/i]. Only other butterfly resembling the male is White-barred Charaxes, [i]Charaxes brutus natalensis[/i], but the undersides are distinctly different; both sexes have similar underside to Wanderer [i]Acraea aganice[/i] in the red-brown hind wing with a discal white band. [i]White forewing patch[/i] and [i]hind wing underside white marginal spots[/i], missing in Wanderer. Female upperside has similarities to that of some [i]Amauris[/i] species.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male [i]upperside[/i] has [i]white median bands[/i] on black ground colour. Female upperside resembles that of Chief [i]Amauris echeria[/i] or Layman [i]A. albimaculata[/i]; white to cream forewing upperside spots and [i]broad creamy white hind wing upperside discal band[/i]. Hind wing upperside white marginal spots [i]much bigger[/i] than those on Chief or Layman.
 
Has distinctive [i]low fluttering flight[/i] along paths, and edges of clearings. Male often found on flowers of [i]Impatiens[/i]. Female near host plants, seen less often.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside. (E), (F) Female undersides.
Models
Chief [i]Amauris echeria[/i] or Layman [i]A. albimaculata[/i] (female upperside); Common Wanderer (underside, male and female).
Back to Top
Distribution
Only in suitable Afromontane Forest areas from E Cape (Stutterheim area, Port St. Johns) into KwaZulu-Natal Midlands, Mpumalanga along Drakensberg and Wolkberg chains, Limpopo Province on Soutpansberg/Blouberg massifs.

Habitat
Forest edges.
Back to Top

Double-brooded, Jan–Mar and Sept–Nov.

[i]Clausena anisata, Vepris lanceolata, Zanthoxylum capense, Z. delagoense[/i].

Swallowtails.

Small plain orange-copper Opal. Upperside markings [i]more extensive[/i] than Namaqua Opal [i]Chrysoritis aridus[/i]; [i]narrower[/i] dark margins. Similar to Western Hillside Brown [i]Stygionympha vigilans[/i], with which it shares the status of the largest [i]Stygionympha[/i]. Medium–large, dark grey-brown Skipper. [i]Lacks pale markings[/i] of other [i]Coeliades[/i] spp. and One-pip Policeman [i]Pyrrhiades anchises[/i], both wing surfaces are dark. [i]Largest and darkest[/i] diurnal all-brown Skipper. By comparison, Strelitzia [i]Moltena fiara[/i] and Palm-tree [i]Zophopetes dysmephila[/i] Night-fighters, which have [i]pale antennae[/i], are crepuscular.

(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.

Uncommon in South Africa. Scattered records from E Cape (Mbashe River), along coast and coastal rivers to Swaziland and KwaZulu-Natal (coast, Midlands, Maputaland), lowveld Savanna of Mpumalanga, Limpopo Province (also Waterberg) and further north.

Smallest Playboy. Resembles [i]small, dark[/i] Brown Playboy [i]Virachola antalus[/i]. Sexes differ on the upperside. The female has [i]bright, pale blue[/i] discal patches, edged with [i]grey[/i], not brown as in female Brown Playboy. Small size also distinguishes it.
 
Rarely seen because of its small size and because it keeps to the tree tops. Males are occasionally found at hill tops. Females are found on flowers, or near the host plant.

Bowker's Marbled Sapphire
[i]Stugeta bowkeri bowkeri[/i]
alternative common name: Bowker's Sapphire
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Stugeta[/i]
Species: [i]bowkeri[/i]
Subspecies: [i]bowkeri[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–32mm female 29–41mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium to large (for a lycaenid), showy sapphire with distinctive pattern of black-and-white postdiscal blotches and basal violaceous blue on the forewing, and streaked pattern of white, violaceous blue and grey-black on the hind wing. The only similar species in South Africa is Dusky Sapphire, [i]S. subinfuscata reynoldsi[/i], but the upperside violaceous blue colouring tends to be [i]lighter[/i]. The major difference is on the underside, where the marginal bands and the area basal to the hind wing dark median band are [i]pale grey or white[/i], not dark grey.
 
The sexes are very similar; females tend to have [i]more extensive[/i] white in the apical area of the forewing upperside. Nominate subspecies [i]S. b. bowkeri[/i] is variable in the extent of the white upperside areas, and the width and shade of the dark brown lines crossing the underside. The white upperside forewing marks tend to be elongated and 'streaky' in appearance compared to the other subspecies, and the underside more or less suffused with dull grey.
 
3 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fast, but slower than other sapphires. Males perch alert on or in prominent bushes on low rocky ridges, chasing intruders; female more sedentary, more usually found near host plants. Both sexes attracted to flowers, such as Puzzlebush [i]Ehretia rigida[/i], sometimes in numbers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread in Savanna and Nama Karoo in W Cape and E Cape (Worcester to Leipoldtville), as well as Savanna in KwaZulu-Natal.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods, Sept–May, peaks Oct and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Viscum rotundifolium[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Sapphires.

Identification
Small, brightly coloured Opal. Upperside ground colour deep red-orange as in Pyramus Opal [i]Chrysoritis pyramus[/i]; similar to that butterfly and to Plutus Opal [i]C. plutus[/i] but male basal blue [i]darker and not as extensive[/i]; some orange at end of cell. Upperside dark margins broad, merging with submarginal forewing spots. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside [i]strongly variegated[/i] with buff and dark brown; well-defined silvery sagittate marks.
 
Sexes differ. Female has [i]less blue, no[/i] shifting lustre, wings [i]rounder[/i] than male.
 
Lives in large, sparse colonies high up in steep rocky gullies above big cliffs; males fly rapidly from gully to gully, making them difficult or hazardous to follow.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
W Cape, in Fynbos high on southern slopes of Kammanassie Mtns.

Mountains, gullies, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood Nov–Feb, peak Dec.

[i]Thesium[/i] spp. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster liengmei[/i] ants.

Common widespread and familiar medium-sized butterfly. Upperside pattern of salmon-pink, black and white is unmistakable.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Low flight, short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats, Male territorial, defending hill tops and small bare areas among vegetation. Sometimes swarms in Fynbos and Karoo in winter and spring. Often the only active butterfly in cold areas in winter. Strongly migratory.

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 31–37mm female 31.5–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Slightly smaller than the other two [i]Capys[/i] found in South Africa. Most widespread Protea butterfly in South Africa; the only one to show dimorphism in sexes. This distinguishes it from the rare Pennington's Protea, [i]C. penningtoni[/i], whose underside is very similar and males can be difficult to tell apart from photographs.
 
Sexes differ. In general, Russet Protea males are a [i]redder, brighter[/i] shade of bronze on the upperside, and the dark margins are [i]more sharply defined[/i], but this is not always the case, especially in worn individuals. Female upperside varies from [i]brown to dove-grey[/i] with russet edges, sometimes a buff forewing apical streak.
 
Males frequent hilltops, They perch on the ground, on rocks or on vegetation; sometimes on prominent specimens of the host plant. The females are found lower down, on flowers sometimes but usually around the host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top

Grassland and Savanna from E Cape (Amatolas) to KwaZulu-Natal (close to sea level), inland to Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Gauteng (Witwatersrand and Magaliesberg) and Limpopo Province.

Habitat
Hill tops, mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, Aug–Oct and Jan–Mar, sometimes as late as Apr.
Back to Top

Small Hairtail with grey-brown and blue upperside, and pale grey-buff underside crossed by irregular stripes of darker grey, outlined in white.
 
Sexes dimorphic. Female almost impossible to distinguish from others of Trimen's Hairtail group. Male upperside mid-blue to pale violet-blue [i]visible at all angles[/i], unlike Mashuna [i]Anthene dulcis dulcis[/i], or Talbot's [i]A. talboti[/i] Hairtails, in which it is only visible from certain angles. Underside of both sexes similar, [i]lacks forewing basal black stripe[/i] of Black-striped Hairtail [i]A. amarah amarah[/i], with which it often flies.
 
Rapid flight; small size makes it difficult to follow. Whirls around tree tops with other small lycaenids; also around low-growing flowers.

Knysna Skolly

alternative common name: Seaside Skolly
Contents

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]brachycera[/i]
Subspecies: [i]brachycera[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 27–36mm female 29–39mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small grey-brown butterfly with a small whitish apical patch, a black spot at the distal end of the cell, and in most individuals, a pair of white streaks just distal to the cell. It has rows of prominent discal black spots on both wings. Underside marked in grey and black. Forewing has black spots corresponding to those on upperside, on a pale grey ground. Hind wing has darker grey spots, outlined in black, corresponding to the upperside black spots. Hind wing ground colour mid grey irrorated with dark grey.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male has more distinct whitish streaks distal to forewing upperside cell. Has pale grey-brown tridentate sex brand, restricted to origin of veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Female with [i]more prominent[/i] forewing white patch on upperside, wings more rounded than male. Nominate [i]T. brachycera brachycera[/i] is paler on the upperside than [i]T. brachycera dukei[/i], and white upperside postdiscal streaks [i]always present in both sexes[/i]. Forewing underside line of discal spots narrower, and angled inwards from areas M3 to CuA2, with a break at M2.
 
[i]T. brachycera[/i] lives in small colonies. Fast, low flight, settling on rocks or low plants. Males form territories in open areas. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers. [i]T. brachycera brachycera[/i] is found close to the coast at low altitude. [i]T. brachycera dukei[/i] is found inland at higher altitude, on gentle rocky slopes covered in rocks and small plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.

Confined to The Heads; at Knysna.

Larvae found inside Pugnacious Ant [i]Anoplolepis custodiens[/i] nests, but no data on food.

Amakosa Rocksitter
[i]Durbania amakosa amakosa[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbania[/i]
Species: [i]amakosa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]amakosa[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–30mm female 29–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small black-and-orange/red butterflies; uppersides are black with varying degrees of red/orange spots and blotches. Undersides are beautifully camouflaged against their habitat; intricate patterns of black or dark grey on a white or pale grey ground, with submarginal spots in varying shades of red to orange, yellow or white. There are some similar species to Amakosa Rocksitter; Natal Rocksitter [i]Durbania limbata[/i] upperside has outer half of hind wing [i]broad[/i] red; sexes similar and flies in late summer to autumn, not spring and early summer. And Clark's Rocksitter [i]D. clarki[/i] is much smaller and its range does not overlap with that of [i]D. amakosa[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. In most subspecies, male has small red-orange to red spots on jet-black ground colour, female with upperside more orange-red. Far southern subspecies [i]D. a. amakosa[/i] has narrow, broken buff-orange bands on the upperside. As one goes further north, as in [i]D. a. ayresi[/i], the orange areas are more extensive, in some, almost covering the upperside.
 
7 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
Nominate subspecies [i]D. a. amakosa[/i] has the dullest red markings and the female has the least extent of red. In some colonies the female has rows of spots like the male; in others the red marks are fused into bands. (A) Male upperside. (B) Female underside. (C), (D) Male undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland. Nominate in KwaZulu-Natal (Kokstad) and E Cape (Amatolas); [i]D. a. ayresi[/i] along Drakensberg from Swaziland to Mpumalanga (south of Olifants R); [i]D. a. sagittata[/i] e Drakensberg and Maluti foothills, Free State; [i]D. a. natalensis[/i] KwaZulu-Natal Midlands and Drakensberg foothills; [i]D. a. flavida[/i], rare and localised in lower KwaZulu-Natal hills (Shongweni to Nkandla Forest); [i]D. a. albescens[/i] highly localised, from E Cape (Mkambati area) to Vernon Crookes NR, s KwaZulu-Natal; [i]D. a. penningtoni[/i] E Cape from Bedford to Grahamstown and Port Elizabeth.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Nov–Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.
Back to Top

Medium-sized brilliant [i]turquoise and black[/i] Swordtail with long straight tails; smaller than the very similar Large Striped Swordtail [i]Graphium antheus[/i]. The bars crossing the upperside forewing cell, [i]wavy[/i] in Large Striped Swordtail, are [i]straight[/i] in Small Striped Swordtail. Other similar species are Cream-Striped Swordtail [i]G. porthaon[/i], which has pale cream markings, and Mamba Swordtail [i]G. colonna[/i], whose upperside stripes are [i]narrow[/i], with [i]wider black spacing[/i] in between.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger and paler than males, which have white hair pencils in a pouch on the inner hind wing margin. These are only exhibited when he is fluttering before a female during courtship.
 
Flight high and rapid. Both sexes visit flowers, males may be found in hundreds on wet mud.

Large, brightly coloured Bitter Acraea, particularly in the male. Very similar to its mimic, Boisduval's False Acraea [i]Pseudacraea boisduvali trimenii[/i] f. [i]colvillei[/i]. Elegant Acraea, [i]Acraea egina areca[/i] is very rare in SA and has [i]red[/i] forewing tips with a [i]hyaline[/i] patch, missing in Acara Acraea.

F. [i]barberina[/i]: forewing margin black band wider, completely surrounding orange submarginal spots. (G) Male upperside. (H) Male underside. (I) Female upperside.

Identification
Very distinctive, small Copper butterfly. Underside has a complicated pattern of [i]sagittate brown and buff[/i] marks on a silvery white ground. Underside forewing has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Extent of upperside spotting [i]variable[/i], sometimes only single spots in forewing and hind wing cells. This is more often seen in males than in females.
 
Sexes similar, female with less extensive dark upperside markings.
 
Very rare and local. Lives in small colonies high up on grassy mountain slopes. Flight of flushed male slow, jinking; soon returns to original perch. May dive into a tuft of grass in high winds. Female flight more random, usually seen on small flowers.

Angled Grass Yellow
[i]Eurema desjardinsii regularis[/i]
alternative common name: Desjardin’s Grass Yellow

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Coliadinae
Genus: [i]Eurema[/i]
Species: [i]desjardinsii[/i]
Subspecies: [i]regularis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–38mm female 37–40mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright yellow Pierid. Differs from African Clouded Yellow [i]Colias electo electo[/i] in upperside ground colour [i]yellow, not orange[/i], and Spiller's Sulphur Yellow [i]Dixeia spilleri[/i], in that it has [i]broader black borders[/i]. The diagnostic feature is the hind wing outer margin, which is [i]sharply angled outwards[/i] at M3.
 
Sexes similar, female [i]paler, more greenish yellow[/i] than male, with grey scaling at wing bases.
 
Fluttering flight, fairly low. Inhabits more heavily wooded country than other [i]Eurema[/i] spp. Settles often on flowers or vegetation.
 
Seasonally dimorphic; wet season form [i]pseudoregularis[/i] has [i]broader black wing margins[/i] on upperside than dry season form [i]marshalli[/i]; latter has hind wing margin broken into a series of black spots. In extreme dry season individuals, there is only a tiny edge of black at apical margin of forewing on upperside. Undersides of the seasonal forms very similar; dry season individuals tend to have [i]paler, redder[/i] dark markings.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (Both form [i]marshalli[/i]).
