False Dotted Border
[i]Belenois thysa thysa[/i]
alternative common name: False Dotted Border White
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Belenois[/i]
Species: [i]thysa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]thysa[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–60mm female 48–62mm, varying with seasonal forms.
Back to Top
Identification
Large white or yellow-buff Pierid with dark margins. Often mistaken for very similar Common Dotted Border [i]Mylothris agathina[/i] in both sexes, but the distinguishing factor is the [i]row of black hind wing marginal dots[/i]. In Common Dotted Border these are [i]confined to the margin[/i]. In [i]Belenois thysa thysa[/i] there is an [i]extra row of submarginal black dots[/i]. There are other differences; the flight pattern is more robust and some female forms of False Dotted Border have [i]extensive dark basal patches[/i], which is never the case with the Common Dotted Border. The hind wing underside is [i]always bright canary yellow[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic; males are always [i]white[/i] on the upperside with [i]dark marginal and submarginal marks[/i] varying in extent according to seasonal form. Females' upperside patterns also vary according to seasonal form, and have [i]varying amounts of colour and dark shading[/i].
 
Male flies fast, high along forest edges, occasionally settles on flowers; female slower, settles more often.
 
Seasonally polymorphic. Wet season form is [i]thysa[/i]; male upperside has [i]large, extensive[/i] dark marginal markings; submarginal series always visible on hind wing upperside. Female variable; always has [i]pale orange blush[/i] at forewing upperside base. Some specimens have [i]extensive basal and discal dark grey-black patches[/i]. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside, light form. (D) Female upperside, dark form. (E) Female underside.
 
Dry season form [i]vansoni[/i] is smaller than wet season form; male has [i]more restricted[/i] dark marginal markings; submarginal series always [i]not always visible[/i] on hind wing upperside. Female upperside [i]bright buff[/i]; there may be some variation in shade but [i]never has the dark wing bases of the wet season form[/i]. (F) Male upperside. (G) Male underside. (H) Female upperside. (I), (J) Female undersides.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Edges of coastal Lowland and Riverine Forest, from E Cape (Port St. Johns) into KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland and Mozambique.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas; WSF Oct–Mar (peak Dec–Jan), DSF Apr–Sept (peak Apr–May).
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Boscia[/i] sp., [i]Capparis[/i] spp., [i]Maerua cafra[/i] and [i]M. racemulosa[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Dotted Borders.

Schlosz's Opal
[i]Chrysoritis thysbe schloszae[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]thysbe[/i]
Subspecies: [i]schloszae[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 23–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of a large group of [i]Chrysoritis[/i] Opals with [i]blue wing bases[/i] and a [i]shimmering, electric opalescent sheen[/i] over a varying area of the wings. For [i]Chrysoritis thysbe[/i], amount of blue on upperside varies, in some subspecies almost covering the forewing. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside varies from plain sandy tan to dark brown, to [i]variegated[/i] with striae in various shades of reddish-brown, with bands of paler colouring and brassy postdiscal streaks. 'Plain' underside specimens usually have unicoloured cilia; 'variegated' ones dark cilia with pale interneural flecks, appearing 'chequered'.
 
[i]C. t. schloszae[/i] in the male, solid blue covers forewing cell spot and usually extends slightly beyond. Outer margin usually has [i]narrow orange border[/i]; may be limited to the cilia, which are only weakly chequered. Hind wing underside is consistently light brown variegated with striae and silvery white streaks. Sexes differ. Female has [i]rounder wings[/i], upperside blue [i]restricted to basal 25% of wings[/i], no opalescent sheen. The females of the various races are almost impossible to separate on wing patterns and identification usually requires comparison with males seen at the same locality.
 
7 subspp., not always geographically distinct. Rapid, sustained flight, settling on prominent bushes or rocks. Male intensively territorial on hill tops or sand dunes, regularly patrolling and chasing intruders; Females are found more at random, often on flowers.
 
(P) Male upperside. (Q) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Very rare and localised; fynbos-covered hills in Moorreesburg area, W Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Roepera[/i] spp. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster capensis[/i] ants.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.

Saffron Sapphire
[i]Iolaus pallene[/i]

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Iolaus[/i]
Species: [i]pallene[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 30–35mm female 34–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
A sapphire in wing shape only, and by virtue of its membership of the genus [i]Iolaus[/i]. Black tails, antennae, legs and underside median lines unmistakable when at rest; resembles a yellow-buff Pierid in flight, so its common name is contradictory.
 
Sexes identical. Male has no hind wing upperside sex brand.
 
[i]Weaker, slower[/i] flight than other [i]Iolaus[/i] spp. Male defends territories in bush clearings, patrolling slowly as opposed to high speed of most [i]Iolaus[/i] spp. Females seen on flowers and host plant. Seldom seen in numbers. Both sexes favour perches among yellowed leaves, which offer protection via camouflage.
 
(A) Female upperside on Smooth Tinderwood [i]Clerodendrum glabrum[/i] blossom. (B) Female underside, perching on dead, yellowed River Bushwillow [i]Combretum erythrophyllum[/i] leaves.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread in wooded Savanna from thorn belt of KwaZulu-Natal (Estcourt to Weenen area, north to Tongaland), Swaziland to Mpumalanga, Gauteng (near Pretoria in Magaliesberg), Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peaks spring and late summer; Sept–Feb in the cooler, south-western part of range.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Ximenia caffra[/i] and [i]X. americana[/i].

Identification
[i]Aloeides[/i] copper with red upperside. Markings variable - upperside dark veins sometimes reduced, underside hind wing ground colour varies from grey-brown through red-brown, to purplish crimson on underside. Hind wing underside discal spots large and partly joined into roughly X-shaped discoidal fascia. The outer edge of this is uneven and not parallel to the outer margin. Submarginal serrated row of spots present but broken and discontinuous.
 
Sexes similar, female with wings rounder, orange marks penetrate post-cell area of forewing upperside.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fairly fast, fluttering close to the ground; settling often, usually on the ground or on low vegetation. Lives in large, scattered colonies on hillsides, beach margins and flatlands. Reluctant to open wings.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female underside (brown morph). (C) Male underside (grey morph). (D) Male underside (crimson morph).

Identification
Large Skipper, brightly and attractively marked. Unmistakable in South Africa. Upperside forewing [i]chocolate brown, with series of hyaline median and apical spots[/i]. Hind wing brown-black, with thin orange [i]discal band[/i]. Underside unmistakable. Forewing cilia plain greyish white; hind wing cilia orange.
 
Sexes alike, female has longer, more rounded wings.
 
Males are territorial near host plants, female fly more at random. Crepuscular, or seen on dull warm cloudy afternoons; buzzing flight, hovering in front of nectar plants like a Hawk Moth (Sphingidae), with which it is sometimes confused.

Identification
Unmistakable medium-sized Pierid. Upperside black or brown-black, with conspicuous white to cream-yellow zebra stripes and spots. Underside pale patches mirror the upperside stripes.
 
Sexes similar, but seasonally dimorphic; dry season form f. [i]nyassae[/i] has paler upperside bands; underside more uniform, cryptically patterned in pinkish grey and dark buff, irrorated with dark scaling that may obscure the striped pattern.
 
Flight rapid, fluttering and direct, usually found near food plants and feeding at flowers.

Bicoloured Skipper
[i]Abantis bicolor[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat

Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Abantis[/i]
Species: [i]bicolor[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 36–41mm female 35–45mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Conspicuous, distinctive medium-sized, [i]striking deep golden yellow[/i] Skipper with [i]black forewing upperside blotches and marginal bands[/i] on both wings. The only Skipper it may be confused with is Veined Skipper [i]Abantis venosa[/i], which is a duller ochreous colour and has [i]hyaline, not black[/i] forewing spots and [i]has a hind wing underside white patch[/i].
 
Sexes similar; female larger than male, wings more elongated, yellow ground colour [i]duller[/i], abdomen stouter. Males are variable as to the size and extent of the upperside forewing black spotting. It can vary from sparse to very heavy.
 
Males show strong territorial behaviour; perching on a prominent twig or leaf, usually high on a hilltop tree. They fly rapidly around their territory, with buzzing wings a blur. Other butterflies are attacked. Females are more sedentary and are usually found on flowers. Both sexes settle wings-open. Large emergences occur very rarely, with both sexes common on flowers close to forests.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Restricted to Lowland Forest from E Cape - East London, Xora Mouth and Port St. Johns to KwaZulu-Natal south coast (Durban area and Ngoye Forest near Eshowe).
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded; spring peak Oct–Nov, stronger autumn peak Mar–Jun.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data, but females are often seen near large specimens of [i]Grewia lasiocarpa[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Paradise Skippers.

Pondoland Widow
[i]Dira oxylus[/i]
Contents

Classification

Identification

Habitat

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Dira[/i]
Species: [i]oxylus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–60mm, female 55–65mm.
Back to Top
Identification
With [i]Dira swanepoeli[/i], one of the two largest [i]Dira[/i] species. The most widespread of the two, found over a large area of the E Cape and into s KwaZulu-Natal. Smaller individuals are the same size as large specimens of [i]Dira clytus eurina[/i] but having [i]three or four ocelli[/i] in the forewing apex, not two. [i]Dira oxylus[/i] is also more localised in its habits and is found in discrete colonies.
 
A large colony of [i]Dira oxylus[/i] flying in the cool of the morning is an unforgettable sight. The sailing, floating fight of the males close to the tall grasses is sustained and graceful. Later, in the heat of the day, they shelter in the shade of large rocks and trees. Females are far less active and stay low.
 
The sexes are similar but the male has a distinctive bronze-green sheen. Females have larger, brighter hind wing upperside ocelli than the male.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland. Lower Drakensberg foothills from E Cape (Queenstown, Stutterheim) to KwaZulu-Natal (Kokstad).
Back to Top
Habitat
Grassy slopes of hillsides, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, from late Dec to early Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae grasses. Has been reared in captivity using [i]Ehrharta erecta[/i], but in the wild is only found near large stands of a tall, wiry, unidentified grass.
Back to Top
Group
Widows.

Boisduval's Tree Nymph
[i]Sevenia boisduvali boisduvali[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Biblidinae
Genus: [i]Sevenia[/i]
Species: [i]boisduvali[/i]
Subspecies: [i]boisduvali[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–40mm female 38–45mm.
Back to Top
Identification
[i]Smallest[/i] and most abundant South African Tree Nymph. Compared to [i]Sevenia natalensis[/i] and [i]Sevenia morantii[/i], underside is more heavily mottled with pale grey and buff, submarginal row of prominent black spots always present.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside flat brown, with [i]reddish-ringed black submarginal spots on hind wing[/i]. Female has apical black patch with orange blotches. Prominent submarginal row of black spots on both sexes' uppersides.
 
Fond of sitting on tree bark, also roosts under leaves. Flipping, short flight from tree trunk to tree trunk. Very wary and hard to approach closely. Sometimes in swarms of many thousands in late summer. The gregarious larvae may totally defoliate even large specimens of the host plant, and when the adults emerge they give the impression that the tree has brown leaves. Drinks from wet mud. Strongly attracted to fermenting fruit and sap leaking from wounded trees; may totally fill baited traps.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Coastal Forests from E Cape (Alexandria Forest to Port Alfred, and Port St. Johns, Embotyi Forest), north along KwaZulu-Natal coastal plain to Lowland Forest in Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province (Soutpansberg).
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Dec–May.
Back to Top

[i]Sclerocroton integerrimum[/i] and [i]Shirakiopsis elliptica[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Tree Nymphs.

Small, dull blue and brown 'blue'. Underside of both sexes [i]darker grey[/i], with [i]small, indistinct black spots[/i] in hind wing discal area and forewing postdiscal area; white postdiscal bands have [i]indistinct edges[/i] and [i]spread into the submarginal area[/i]. When worn, female appears identical to Restless Blue, genitalic dissection being required to distinguish them where they fly together.
 
Low, fluttering flight. Males fly up and down steep grassy slopes. Females are found lower down, are more sedentary. Both sexes found feeding on flowers, often of host plant.

Male 26–31mm female 28–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized, brightly coloured [i]Aloeides[/i] copper. Forewing upperside dark borders of [i]even width[/i], cilia [i]uniformly coloured[/i]. Underside hind wing red-brown to scarlet with [i]well-defined[/i] serrated silver discoidal fascia and submarginal band of dentate spots. Underside markings similar to Roodepoort Copper [i]Aloeides dentatis[/i] but the dentate markings are [i]less well-defined[/i] and less heavily outlined in black.
 
Sexes similar, female with wings rounder, upperside [i]paler orange[/i] than male.
 
Found in large, diffuse colonies. Males congregate on hill tops and rocky ledges at midday; flight rapid, close to ground. Settles on rocks with closed wings. Female on flat areas below the rocks where male flies.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside (brown morph). (C) Male underside (red morph). (D) Female underside (red morph).
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland, Riverine Forest, Afromontane Forest from Swaziland to Mpumalanga (Barberton); (often close to Afromontane Forest) and along Drakensberg and Wolkberg to Polokwane and Tzaneen, and Soutpansberg (Limpopo Province).

Habitat
Hillsides, hill tops, mountains, forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Several broods through warmer months, Sept to as late as Jun, peaks Nov and Feb.

Common Hottentot Skipper
[i]Gegenes niso niso[/i]

Classification

Back to Top

Male 29–33mm female 29–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown Skipper with yellow underside. Upperside [i]brown or khaki[/i] with markings depending on sex. [i]Yellow-ochre[/i] underside of both sexes conspicuous at rest, when wings closed. Hind wing underside has [i]two series of dark spots[/i], and a dark spot in the cell. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Similar to Water Watchman [i]Parnara monasi[/i] but upperside very different, and hind wing underside has [i]only one series of postdiscal dark marks[/i]. Underside identical to that of Marsh Hottentot Skipper [i]Gegenes hottentota[/i], as is the female upperside. The male Marsh Hottentot Skipper has a [i]conspicuous black sex brand[/i] on a [i]yellow ground[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside olivaceous khaki with small buff subapical spots and a varying amount of yellow streaking along the forewing costa and wing base. Female upperside [i]dark brown[/i] with discal series of creamy buff spots on [i]both wings[/i]. Spots shifted distally from the rest of the series in areas M, and R5.
 
Flight rapid and erratic; low down, no more than 1m above the ground, settling often on grass, rocks and low vegetation. Males form territories along grassy verges and stream edges; females are found more at random.
 
(A) Mating pair uppersides, male to L, female to R. (B) Female underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Very common and widespread. From sea level to over 2 000m, in Fynbos, Nama Karoo, Grassland, woodland and Savanna. From Saldanha area (W Cape), along littoral and seaward side of mountains through W Cape, E Cape, KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland, n Free State, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, Limpopo Province and e NW Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, wetlands, flatlands, hill tops, parks and gardens, mountains, coast.

Orange Small Fox
[i]Teniorhinus harona[/i]
alternative common name: Arrowhead Orange
Contents

Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Teniorhinus[/i]
Species: [i]harona[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 25–30mm female 25–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright orange Skipper. Upperside dark brown with prominent [i]orange bands[/i]; the entire discal area of the forewing is orange, totally enclosing an 'arrowhead'-shaped mark in the cell and the area distal to it. Cilia plain yellowish white. Underside orange-yellow; forewing has [i]black spot at end of cell[/i], and [i]dark blotch near the tornus[/i] that extends to the inner margin in the darker forms. Hind wing has [i]distinct pale buff streaks edged with dark brown[/i] on an orange ground. This is unique in Skippers found in South Africa. Upperside similar to Axehead Orange [i]Acada biseriata[/i] but the forewing upperside costal orange streak [i]joins the apical orange patch[/i] to form a [i]continuous band around the dark 'arrowhead' mark[/i] in the cell. Also similar to Morant's Orange [i]Parosmodes morantii[/i], but forewing upperside orange cell spot is [i]merged with postdiscal orange band[/i]. Upperside also resembles that of larger Orange-spotted Hopper [i]Zenonia zeno[/i] but the forewing base is [i]not solid orange[/i] and the orange discal band is [i]not fused[/i].
 
Further north there are three forms - nominate, form [i]ruso[/i] and form [i]merops[/i]. The specimens found to date in South Africa appear to be form [i]ruso[/i], which is paler than the nominate, which has wider upperside dark margins and 'arrowhead' markings. Form [i]merops[/i] has [i]more extensive upperside orange[/i], with narrower upperside dark margins and very slender 'arrowhead' markings.
 
Sexes similar, female has rounder, more elongated wings, abdomen stouter.
 
Flight low, not fast; skipping and erratic; flies around shady clearings in woodland, settling often.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Found small patches of [i]Brachystegia[/i] (miombo) woodland at eastern end of Soutpansberg, Limpopo Province. Also in riverine forest at nearby Mpaphuli Cycad Reserve, and further south at Lekgalameetse Nature Reserve. Common in forested areas of Zimbabwe and Mozambique.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, hillsides, wetlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks in September and March in Zimbabwe and Mozambique, so far only in April and June in South Africa.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Brachystegia boehmii[/i] in Zimbabwe and Mozambique.
Back to Top
Group
Rangers.

Buquet's Vagrant
[i]Nepheronia buquetii buquetii[/i]
alternative common name: Green-eyed Monster; Plain Vagrant; Desert Vagrant.
Contents

Distribution
Habitat

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Nepheronia[/i]
Species: [i]buquetii[/i]
Subspecies: [i]buquetii[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–50mm female 48–56mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large greenish-white Pierid. Forewing [i]pointed and falcate[/i], dark [i]discocellular spot[/i] on underside hind wing. Other [i]Nepheronia[/i] species have green compound eyes but those of the Green-eyed Monster are particularly brilliant. Immediately distinguished from male Large Vagrant [i]Nepheronia argia[/i] by the smaller size, and [i]lack of dark square spot[/i] on underside forewing. Appears similar on the wing to African Migrant [i]Catopsilia florella[/i] because of the green underside. However, the [i]green eyes[/i] are not seen in African Migrant, and the dark wing tips of [i]N. buquetii[/i] are [i]much broader[/i].
 
Sexes similar, female upperside forewing tips paler than male.
 
Rapid, sustained flight, stopping seldom, unless at flowers (usually orange or red, but they are fond of [i]Plumbago[/i]) to nectar. Any bright red object will attract them.
 
Nominate dry season form [i]buquetii[/i] has wide dark upperside forewing tips: (A) Female upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Dry season, southern [i]f. capensis[/i] (predominates from KwaZulu-Natal southwards), dark tips absent or reduced to a thin black line around the margin of the apex: (C) Male upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Found in more arid areas than its congeners. Savanna and woodland from Knysna, W Cape (sometimes as far west as Cape Town), along coast, inland to Swaziland, along riverine bush in thorn belt of KwaZulu-Natal, north to Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces. Stragglers reach Gauteng in years that mass migrations of Brown-veined White occur.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall; f. [i]capensis[/i] usually only seen in the dry season, and summer in the W Cape. More common in winter months in warmer areas.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Azima tetracantha[/i] and [i]Salvadora persica[/i].
Back to Top

Medium–large olive-brown Skipper. Forewing [i]elongated, acutely pointed[/i]. Upperside ground colour [i]dark brown[/i] with [i]paler olive scaling and hairs along inner margin and at base[/i]. Forewing has large hyaline spots in discal and subapical areas; [i]single[/i] spot in cell. Hind wing upperside has no spots. Whitish Amakosa Rocksitter
[i]Durbania amakosa albescens[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbania[/i]
Species: [i]amakosa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]albescens[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–35mm female 29–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small black-and-orange/red butterflies; uppersides are black with varying degrees of red/orange spots and blotches. Undersides are beautifully camouflaged against their habitat; intricate patterns of black or dark grey on a white or pale grey ground, with submarginal spots in varying shades of red to orange, yellow or white. There are some similar species to Amakosa Rocksitter; Natal Rocksitter [i]Durbania limbata[/i] upperside has outer half of hind wing [i]broad[/i] red; sexes similar and flies in late summer to autumn, not spring and early summer. And Clark's Rocksitter [i]D. clarki[/i] is much smaller and its range does not overlap with that of [i]D. amakosa[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. [i]D. a. albescens[/i] has extensive white irroration on the forewing upperside apex, and the hind wing underside has no coloured spots, only white where other subspecies have red, yellow or orange. Females have [i]narrow[/i] pale orange upperside bands.
 
7 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(I) Male upperside. (J) Female upperside. (K) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Highly localised, in Grassland from Margate and Port Edward, s KwaZulu-Natal.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Nov–Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.

Identification
Blonde Glider is the larger of South Africa's two male [i]Cymothoe[/i] species; the other being Battling Glider [i]Cymothoe alcimeda[/i]. Compared to that species, apart from size, [i]C. coranus coranus[/i] has [i]more rounded[/i] wings and, usually, a less [i]heavily marked[/i] underside. Sexually dimorphic: there is only one female form and there are no subspecies.
 
Sexually dimorphic; only one male and one female form. Male upperside creamy white; both sexes' underside cryptic. Female upperside dark grey to black; median band [i]broad, white[/i].
 
Both sexes have fast, sustained gliding flight with short bursts of rapid wingbeats. Males form territories at medium to high altitude on forest edges and in clearings, and chase away intruders. Females fly low along the forest edges, or close to the host plants. Difficult to approach; only comes to mud patches early in the day.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane, Lowland and Riverine Forest from E Cape (Mbashe R, Port St. Johns) to KwaZulu-Natal (Eshowe), north into lower Mpumalanga escarpment forests. Absent from Lowland Forest of Zululand and high Afromontane areas.

Drakensberg Forest King Charaxes
[i]Charaxes xiphares penningtoni[/i]
alternative common name: Drakensberg Forest King Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]xiphares[/i]
Subspecies: [i]penningtoni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–80mm female 70–95mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, dark Charaxes. In certain parts of its range, males can be confused with Blue-Spotted Charaxes, [i]Charaxes cithaeron cithaeron[/i]. However, that species has [i]much broader[/i] hind wing upperside pale patch, almost totally white. The postdiscal series of forewing royal blue marks are [i]smaller[/i] in [i]C. xiphares[/i]. Females are distinctive. [i]C. x. penningtoni[/i] male is distinguished by blue spot in area M3, which is longer than either neighbouring race [i]C. x. draconis[/i] or [i]C. x. thyestes[/i]. The female has particularly [i]large, clear white[/i] forewing discal spots. The normal female form has a yellow hind wing upperside discal patch; in rare f. [i]luminosa[/i] it is lavender-blue.
 
Sexes strongly dimorphic, male with [i]royal blue[/i] spots and bands on metallic navy ground, female with [i]white discal forewing band[/i] (of variable width) sometimes invaded by yellow-ochre. Most females have a pale yellow hind wing upperside patch, but in some populations, it is blue-white or pale mauve. Differences between females is usually of more value than subtle differences between the males in distinguishing subspecies.
 
Powerful, high flight in the canopy and around tree tops. Males territorial, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly rapidly along the fringes of forests where they settle on tree leaves. In [i]C. x. penningtoni[/i], the females are much commoner than males, possibly due to a male-killing pathogen. In its haunts the females adopt the same tree-topping habits as males.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
8 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(M) Male upperside. (N) Male underside. (O) Female upperside f. [i]penningtoni[/i]. (P) Female upperside f. [i]luminosa[/i]. (Q) Female underside (both forms the same).
Back to Top
Distribution
Pockets of Afromontane Forest from low altitude at Kloof to Drakensberg foothills.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, weak peak Oct–Nov, stronger Mar–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Cryptocarya woodii, Scutia myrtina, Rhamnus prinoides[/i] and [i]Chaetachme aristata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Charaxes.
Back to Top






Green-veined Charaxes
[i]Charaxes candiope[/i]
alternative common name: Green-veined Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]candiope[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–75mm female 78–95mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, distinctive Charaxes. Can appear similar to Pearl Charaxes [i]Charaxes varanes varanes[/i] on the wing, but the wing bases are [i]yellow and orange[/i], not pearly white. Forewing [i]green veins[/i] on underside very conspicuous. Underside markings seasonally variable between two extremes: in wet season specimens, mottled fawn crossed by wavy median and submarginal lines of black and darker brown; in dry season specimens, flat red-ochre with restricted dark lines.
 
Sexes similar in colour and pattern; female with two tails equally long, male with anal tail longer.
 
Powerful, high flight in the canopy and around tree tops. Males territorial, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside (dry season). (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside (wet season).
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread. Coastal, Lowland, Afromontane and Riverine Forest, and wooded Savanna from E Cape (Port St. Johns) to KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga, Gauteng and Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, gullies, hillsides, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round; a weak peak Sept–Nov, stronger peak Jan–Jun.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Croton[/i] spp., including [i]C. sylvaticus, C. gratissimus[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Charaxes.
Back to Top






Southern Purple
[i]Aslauga australis[/i]

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Aslauga[/i]
Species: [i]australis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–25mm female 25–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small grey butterfly with [i]bluish-violet[/i] sheen on upperside. Underside plain grey speckled with black scales; both wings crossed by a darker grey stripe. [i]Pointed forewing tips[/i] and [i]falcate[/i] anal angle of hind wing are unique in South African lycaenids.
 
Sexes similar; male darker than female.
 
Flight slow, moth-like, sometimes hovering; circles shrubs and bushes. What little information is available states that the males are territorial.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare; less than 20 records. Savanna and coastal forest in E Cape (below Amatolas, Port St. Johns and Embotyi). Also from Durban, KwaZulu-Natal.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Uncertain; South African records spring to autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data.
Back to Top
Group
Purples.

Soldier Pansy
[i]Junonia terea elgiva[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Junonia[/i]
Species: [i]terea[/i]
Subspecies: [i]elgiva[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–55mm female 52–60mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to medium-sized brown butterfly with orange-buff upperside discal bands and 'dead-leaf' mimic underside. Similar to Dead-Leaf Commodore, [i]Precis tugela[/i], but [i]less robust[/i], upperside discal bands [i]paler[/i], hind wing postdiscal row of ocelli [i]distal[/i] to discal band, and [i]lacks spots[/i]; also, flight [i]slower[/i]. Seasonal forms not named but summer specimens (wet season form) have broader, deeper orange discal bands than winter ones (Dry season form), which have [i]flat-brown[/i] underside with [i]yellow[/i] median 'leaf midrib' stripe, as opposed to [i]buff[/i] with [i]brown[/i] stripe of wet season form.
 
Sexes similar. Females larger with broader wings.
 
Low flight, short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats, settling often on the ground or on plants, slowly fanning wings. Male patrols paths and clearings, periodically patrolling these small territories, but settling often, wings slowly fanning.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside (wet season form). (C) Male underside. (Dry season form).
Back to Top
Distribution
Inland Lowland Forest, and along rivers in Riverine Forest at foot of escarpments. Coastal n E Cape to Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Two main broods, peaks early summer (Oct and Nov), and autumn to winter (Apr–Jul).
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Ruellia patula, Asystasia gangetica, Dyschoriste depressa[/i] and [i]Phaulopsis imbricata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Pansies.

Common Orange Tip
[i]Colotis evenina evenina[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Colotis[/i]
Species: [i]evenina[/i]
Subspecies: [i]evenina[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 38–45mm female 35–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small white Pierid with orange wing tips and varying degree of black wing
markings. Difference to Smoky Orange Tip [i]Colotis euippe omphale[/i] is [i]lack of bulge
in basal dark edge of orange tip[/i]; paler orange wing tip colour. Neither species has a
[i]white-edged dark diagonal stripe[/i] running from base to middle of the hind wing underside margin at M3. Differs from Red Tip [i]C. antevippe gavisa[/i] in the [i]distinct orange[/i] colour of the forewing tips, and both sexes [i]lacking black spot at end of cell[/i] on upperside of forewing.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside resembles small Red Tip [i]Colotis antevippe gavisa; has paler, pure orange forewing tips[/i]; female with distal edge of forewing basal patch on both surfaces forming [i]three square blocks[/i]. Female orange forewing tip [i]crossed by dark stripe[/i].
 
Fast, low flight. Both sexes fly at random, often seen on flowers.
 
Seasonally polymorphic. There are many forms of both sexes, varying according to the seasons. There are many intermediates and the forms shown here only approximate the 'type' for each; the variation is gradual and no two individuals are exactly alike.
 
Wet season male nominate f. [i]evenina[/i] is similarly marked to Red Tip, except for [i]orange colour of forewing tip[/i]. Underside hind wing white to yellow, faint diagonal stripe and orange patches in extreme wet season form; veining [i]never dark[/i]. Female often [i]heavily marked in black[/i], to the point where she is a black butterfly with white bands and a [i]orange tip largely obscured by black[/i]. More lightly marked specimens have less black in the orange tip but still have heavy black stripes across the white areas. Underside may have [i]extensive orange bands[/i] corresponding to upperside black bands. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.(C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
 
Dry season male f. [i]deidamioides[/i] lacks dark scaling and basal edge to orange forewing upperside tip. Female has [i]brighter colouring and reduced dark marks[/i]; where nominate has black, [i]deidamioides[/i] is [i]grey or white speckled with black[/i]. Both sexes' underside is pinkish white irrorated with pinkish brown to grey. Underside hind wing has [i]prominent white-edged dark diagonal stripe[/i] running from base to middle of margin. (E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside.(G) Female upperside. (H) Female underside.
 
Specimens from the driest areas have almost no dark markings, and are described as f. [i]lerichei[/i]. (not illustrated).
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Succulent Karoo from N Cape coast (northern Namaqualand) east across Arid Savanna and Nama Karoo to Swaziland, Free State, Gauteng, Limpopo and NW provinces, Mpumalanga and n KwaZulu-Natal.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands, forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall. WSF Oct–Apr in bushveld, year-round on east coast; DSF Feb–Nov in bushveld, in arid areas after rains. Peaks towards late summer and autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Boscia albitrunca, B. salicifolia, Capparis[/i] sp., [i]Cadaba[/i] sp., and [i]Maerua parvifolia[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Tips.
Back to Top






Clark's Rocksitter
[i]Durbaniella clarki phaea[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbaniella[/i]
Species: [i]clarki[/i]
Subspecies: [i]phaea[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 18–24mm female 18–26mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very small butterfly with patterns of orange or orange-red and black on the upperside;
 has a greater or lesser amount of black in the centre of the forewing depending on sex and
subspecies. Underside irrorated with black, grey and white with tiny submarginal spots on
the hind wing. The other Rocksitters that fly in the same areas are Boland Rocksitter
[i]Durbaniopsis saga[/i] and two of the races of Amakosa Rocksitter, [i]Durbania amakosa
amakosa[/i] and [i]D. a. penningtoni[/i]. [i]Durbaniella clarki[/i] is generally smaller
than either, although small males of [i]D. saga[/i] can be in the same size range. It can
immediately be distinguished from that species by the underside; [i]D. clarki[/i] lacks
the [i]conspicuous dark and light bands[/i] of [i]D. saga[/i]. Compared to [i]D.
amakosa[/i], the differences are sex-related. Females of [i]D. amakosa[/i] are always much
larger and have more extensive, better defined patterns of orange or orange-red and black
on the upperside. [i]D. a. amakosa[/i] males have [i]discrete[/i] orange-red spots on the
upperside. [i]D. a. penningtoni[/i] males have very similar upperside markings to [i]D.
clarki[/i] but they are more of a [i]yellow-buff[/i] colour and the hind wing base is
[i]dark[/i].
 
Variable degree of sexual dimorphism depending on subspecies.
 
[i]D. c. phaea[/i] is a dark subspecies; upperside apical pale spots [i]reduced or absent[/i]; male forewing postdiscal band broken into spots. Upperside colouration varies from dull orange-buff to brick red; discal black patch extensive in both sexes.
 
4 subspp., geographically distinct; varying in markings and colour.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Female upperside. (F) Male underside. (G) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos, Nama Karoo in Riviersonderend Mtns, hills between Worcester and Montagu, W Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, rocky ledges, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Sept–Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.
Back to Top

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Crudaria[/i]
Species: [i]wykehami[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 20–32mm female 25–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to medium-sized, dull coloured lycaenid. Very similar to Silver-spotted Grey [i]Crudaria leroma[/i] but tail [i]always absent[/i]; series of forewing postdiscal spots on underside form a [i]line parallel to the outer margin[/i]. Similar to Cape Grey [i]Crudaria capensis[/i] but has less contrast between underside pale marks and ground colour.
 
Sexes similar; male [i]darker[/i] than female, wings more pointed.
 
Flies rapidly over open ground between thorn trees, settling often on low plants or on the ground. Resting posture with wings open and forewings held proud.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
E Cape, from Willowmore to Bedford and Grahamstown.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, rocky slopes.
Back to Top
Flight period
Probably year-round; found in Nov, Jan and Feb.
Back to Top
Larval food
Probably [i]Vachellia karroo[/i].
Back to Top
Group

Topaz Babul Blue
[i]Azanus jesous[/i]
alternative common name: Topaz-spotted Blue
Contents

Classification

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Azanus[/i]
Species: [i]jesous[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 17–26mm female 22–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright 'Blue'. Similar to other 'Babul Blues' such as Velvet-spotted Babul Blue [i]Azanus ubaldus[/i]; forewing tip [i]more rounded[/i] than that species. Underside typical [i]Azanus[/i] pattern but has [i]broad, straight, white-edged forewing apical bands; hind wing carries prominent series of postdiscal white-edged brown spots, and squarish submarginal series of white spots, centred with black[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside [i]shiny pinkish blue[/i], marginal borders [i]black[/i], cilia [i]prominent white[/i]. Female upperside [i]brown[/i], paler basal areas [i]suffused with blue[/i], variable white discal forewing patch, [i]conspicuous brown spot[/i] at end of forewing cell. Some specimens have overall suffusion of pinkish-mauve iridescence.
 
Flight relatively slow and fluttering. Often found in the swarms of small lycaenids around flowering trees, which include other [i]Azanus[/i] spp.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread over the east and north of South Africa. Largely absent from Fynbos, Succulent Karoo and the highest mountains, but there have been scattered records from Cape Town and Namaqualand.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides, parks and gardens, forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods from Sept–May in cooler areas; in warmer areas, year-round, peak late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
Flowers, buds and fresh shoots and stem galls of [i]Vachellia[/i] spp., including [i]V. karroo[/i], and [i]Adenopodia spicata[/i]. Probably also [i]Acacia cyclops[/i] and other exotic Australian [i]Acacia[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Babul Blues.

Topaz Tip

alternative common name: Topaz Arab

Classification
Family: Pieridae

Genus: [i]Colotis[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–35mm female 34–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, yellow-orange Pierid. Upperside ground colour [i]salmon[/i] pink, Seasonal dimorphism mostly evident on underside; hind wing green-yellow in wet season form [i]f. calais[/i], in dry season form [i]f. dynamene[/i], pinkish cream. Most similar to Veined Tip [i]Colotis vesta argillaceus[/i] but upperside wing bases [i]are not white[/i] and hind wing upperside [i]postdiscal band[/i] is [i]broken into spots[/i]. Underside hind wing [i]lacks[/i] solid dark bands crossing the wing. Also close to Doubleday's Tip [i]Colotis doubledayi[/i] but that species has [i]strongly marked black stripes[/i] along postdiscal half of upperside wings.
 
Sexually dimorphic; female has postdiscal [i]cream-yellow bands[/i], absent in male.
 
Flight slow, weak, close to ground; flies at random feeding on flowers; settles often.
 
Wet season (nominate) form [i]calais[/i]: (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
 
Dry season form [i]dynamene[/i]: (D) Female underside.

Savannas and woodland from Swaziland, north-east along coast to KwaZulu-Natal (only in northern thorn country), Mpumalanga, and Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall; peak Feb–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Salvadora persica[/i].

Kammanassie Opal
[i]Chrysoritis pyramus balli[/i]
Contents

Classification

Identification

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]pyramus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]balli[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–36mm female 32–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, red-orange Opal. [i]Deeper red-orange[/i] upperside ground colour than Beaufort Opal [i]Chrysoritis beaufortia[/i], male basal silvery blue covered by [i]electric blue sheen[/i] stretching at forewing base as far as margin. [i]Broad, black[/i] marginal borders, merging with submarginal spots in some specimens, making shifting blue lustre more prominent. Cilia strongly chequered with white. Occasional specimens from the Swartberg have [i]narrower[/i] dark borders and are closer to the Kammanassie subspecies, [i]C pyramus balli[/i]. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing variegated in [i]deep red- or ochre-brown[/i], with [i]conspicuous[/i] brassy sagittate markings.
 
Sexes dimorphic; female has typical [i]Chrysoritis[/i] markings, noticeably [i]deep, rich colouring[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Found in large scattered colonies. Frequents bare rocky ribs on fynbos-covered hillsides and summits. Males perch on prominent rocks or plants and patrol their territories, chasing away intruders. Females are more sedentary.
 
[i]C. p. balli[/i] is paler than nominate, with narrower dark margins, but has the same deep red-orange upperside colouring. (D) Male upperside. (E) Male underside. (F) Female upperside. (G) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos in Kammanassie Mtns, and Langeberg, above Grootvadersbosch.
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, rocky ledges, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood, Oct–Jan, peak Nov.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Dimorphotheca montana[/i]. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster capensis[/i] ants.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.

Identification
Small, dull blue and brown 'blue'. Similar to Restless Blue [i]Orachrysops lacrimosa[/i], but both sexes [i]paler on both surfaces[/i] and hind wing upperside submarginal lunular marks [i]better defined[/i] in female. Underside [i]pale grey[/i], forewing and hind wing dark spots [i]with black centres, very conspicuous[/i]. Black spot at hind wing tornus [i]tiny or absent[/i]. Cilia pale grey to white.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male is dark violaceous blue with dark marginal borders; [i]narrower[/i] than Restless Blue, female brown with basal blue [i]more extensive[/i] than Restless Blue.
 
Found in colonies; male flight fast, zigzagging and evasive. Female slower, more sedentary; usually on flowers.

Large Blue Charaxes
[i]Charaxes bohemani bohemani[/i]
alternative common name: Large Blue Emperor, Divebomber Charaxes
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]bohemani[/i]
Subspecies: [i]bohemani[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–75mm female 80–100mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, powerfully built Charaxes, very conspicuous in flight. Male superficially resembles female Demon Charaxes [i]Charaxes phaeus[/i], but [i]much larger[/i], body larger in proportion to the wings.
 
Sexes dimorphic, female has characteristic white band distal to the forewing basal blue patch. Male lacks this.
 
Fast and powerful flight; males are very territorial, hilltopping and perching on prominent twigs on bushes, and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly lower down, around clumps of bush, settling on leaves. Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees. More-or-less restricted to wooded Savanna and forest, absent from arid and cool areas.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Wooded lowland Savanna in Limpopo Province and Mpumalanga lowveld from Zimbabwe border to Nelspruit.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Oct and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Afzelia quanzensis, Lonchocarpus capassa, Xeroderris stuhlmannii, Dalbergia nitidula, Brachystegia spiciformis[/i] and [i]Schotia brachypetala[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Charaxes.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae

Genus: [i]Trimenia[/i]
Species: [i]argyroplaga[/i]
Subspecies: [i]argyroplaga[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 25–34mm 9 29–41mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Powerfully built lycaenid; upperside [i]black-and-orange with conspicuously black-and-white chequered cilia[/i]. Very similar in this respect to Wallengren's Silver-spotted Copper [i]Trimenia wallengrenii[/i]. Hind wing has short bristly tails at the anal angle. Underside differs from [i]T. wallengrenii[/i] in having [i]wider, enlarged[/i] silvery marks that are a purer tone of white, on a ground colour of dark brown shot with lighter tan.
 
Sexes similar, but female larger, heavier bodied with broader wings, and wider orange patches.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Rapid flight with fast wingbeats, low down, but not sustained; settling often on the ground or on rocks. Both sexes are occasionally seen on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.

Widespread and abundant in Nama and Succulent Karoo; in Great Karoo and Little Karoo from W Cape to E Cape; grassy Savanna near Grahamstown; also in N Cape (Namaqualand).

Dead-Leaf Commodore
[i]Precis tugela tugela[/i]
alternative common name: African Leaf Butterfly
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Precis[/i]
Species: [i]tugela[/i]
Subspecies: [i]tugela[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 55–60mm female 58–64mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized brown butterfly with orange bands. It has two seasonal forms, which are different in wing shape. Both forms have a brown upperside ground colour with a broad orange median to postdiscal band. Wet season (summer) form lacks the long, hooked forewing apex of the dry season (winter) form, and has shorter hind wing tails. In its habitat the only butterfly likely to be confused with it is Soldier Pansy [i]Junonia terea elgiva[/i], but that is generally [i]smaller[/i] and the orange bands [i]lack[/i] the small interneural spots that are always present in [i]P. tugela[/i]. One of the finest dead-leaf mimics; no two undersides are ever exactly alike.
 
Sexes similar, female larger with broader wings and less dramatically hooked wing tips.
 
Wet season form f. [i]aurorina[/i] smaller than nominate dry season form f. [i]tugela[/i], with both sexes' wing tips [i]less prominently hooked[/i].
 
Flies along lanes and edges of clearings in deep forest. Short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Flies away rapidly if disturbed; males strongly territorial, sitting on prominent point, chasing away intruders. and if chased away, usually returning to where first seen. Very wary; heads for the canopy when disturbed.
 
(A) Male upperside f. [i]tugela[/i]. (B) Female upperside f. [i]tugela[/i]. (C) Male upperside [i]tugela[/i]. (D) Male upperside [i]aurorina[/i]. (E) Female upperside [i]aurorina[/i]. (D) Female underside [i]aurorina[/i].
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane Forest on escarpment from KwaZulu-Natal Midlands (Oribi Gorge) to Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province. May swarm in Wolkberg in Jun.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Two main broods: DSF f. [i]aurorina[/i] Sept–Mar, nominate WSF Apr–Aug; winter brood usually more numerous than summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Plectranthus[/i] spp. and [i]Englerastrum scandens[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Commodores.

Identification
One of the largest [i]Aloeides[/i] coppers. [i]pallida[/i] means pale, but that only refers to the nominate subspecies; the others are more deeply coloured. [i]Bright orange[/i] upperside with wide dark marginal bands; cilia chequered in whitish grey and black; forewing costal band widens at apex. Dark scaling from marginal bands penetrates edges of the orange areas along veins. Underside colouration varies from fawn to crimson with [i]well-defined[/i] basal, discal and submarginal rows of dentate spots merged to form silver-grey bands edged black.
 
[i]A. p. littoralis[/i] is similar to [i]A. p. grandis[/i]; upperside ground colour [i]paler shade of orange[/i] and veins [i]more heavily picked out in black[/i]. Underside ground colour varies from fawn-brown to bright crimson. Sexes similar, female has rounder wings.
 
6 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fairly fast, close to the ground; settling often, usually on the ground or on low vegetation. Found in colonies. Reluctant to open wings.
 
(P) Make upperside. (Q) Female upperside. (R) Female underside (fawn-brown morph). (S) Male underside (crimson morph).

Southern Sapphire
[i]Iolaus silas[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Iolaus[/i]
Species: [i]silas[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–37mm female 34–41mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of the larger sapphires; upperside [i]intense metallic blue[/i] with broad black margins and [i]shiny white[/i] underside, and conspicuous red lunules at the hind wing anal angle. Underside hind wing crossed by submarginal [i]thin red line[/i] that is usually, but not always, curved toward the body. In Straight-line Sapphire [i]I. silarus silarus[/i], the line is (usually) straight and in Trimen's Sapphire [i]I. trimeni[/i] it is [i]black[/i] and usually [i]jagged[/i]. The upperside black margins of [i]I. trimeni[/i] and [i]I' silarus silarus[/i] are narrower (especially on the hind wing).
 
Sexes differ slightly; female duller blue than male, [i]very broad[/i] hind wing upperside red to orange marginal band, stretching to area M1, compared to [i]I. silarus silarus[/i] and [i]I. trimeni[/i], in which it is narrower and confined to the anal angle, as it is in male [i]I. silas[/i] or both sexes of [i]I. silarus silarus[/i] or [i]I. trimeni[/i]. Distal part of forewing upperside blue patch [i]suffused with white[/i] to a greater or lesser degree, more so than in [i]I. silarus silarus[/i], whose females are often free from white in the upperside blue. Male has conspicuous [i]sex brand[/i] at hind wing upperside costa.
 
Males perch atop tall trees during midday hours, preferring those with glossy leaves against which their white underside is not easy to spot. But the white and blue combination is conspicuous in flight. Females are found closer to host plant, and nectaring at low flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
From Nama Karoo in E Cape, along the eastern littoral from Addo Elephant NP to Somerset East and Bedford, along coastal Savanna and Lowland Forest into KwaZulu-Natal (to Eshowe).

Forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas. Sept–Jan in cooler, southern part of range.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Moquinella rubra, Erianthemum dregei[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Sapphires.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae

Back to Top

Male 21–26mm female 23–29mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, dull coloured Hairtail. Both sexes have [i]brown[/i] uppersides, and unique underside [i]black streak[/i] at forewing base. This is not always visible, and the underside can closely resemble that of several other small Hairtails (such as Mashuna Hairtail [i]Anthene dulcis dulcis[/i]) that may be found flying around flowering trees and bushes. The [i]dark, black[/i] series of three basal and three costal spots tell it apart. Both sexes' undersides have black-and-orange lunules at anal angle, and [i]short, bristle-like tails[/i] at the ends of the cubital veins.
 
Sexes differ. Male upperside a [i]paler, greyish olive-brown[/i] than female, with a distinctive [i]brassy sheen[/i].
 
Flight fast and whirling; very fond of [i]Vachellia[/i] blossoms where it feeds with other [i]Anthene[/i] species and [i]Azanus[/i] Babul Blues. Males perch on hilltop bushes and chase intruders; females usually on flowers and close to the host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.

Widespread and common throughout South Africa excluding the driest central and western parts, and the highest mountains.

Identification
Distinctive small sapphire; upperside blue has [i]violet[/i] shade, [i]broad black margins[/i] and [i]dark streak across postdiscal pale area of forewing[/i]. The thin brown lines crossing the pale grey underside make it superficially resemble Purple-brown Hairstreak [i]Hypolycaena philippus philippus[/i], or the rare Coastal Hairstreak [i]H. lochmophila[/i], with which it flies. It also resembles Azure Hairstreak [i]Hemiolaus caeculus caeculus[/i], but that insect [i]lacks upperside white patches[/i] and has [i]more brown lines crossing the underside in the basal area[/i].
 
Sexes similar, male has less white and more blue distal to upperside dark transverse streaks of both wings.
 
Flight slow, settling on low bushes and flowers in thick bush where it is difficult to approach closely.

Dickson's Skolly
[i]Thestor dicksoni dicksoni[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution

Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]dicksoni[/i]
Subspecies: [i]dicksoni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 34–37.5mm female 43–45mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small butterfly, largest of Brauns's Skolly group. Upperside ground colour buff. Both sexes have wings more pointed than Boland Skolly [i]Thestor protumnus[/i] group. Upperside and forewing underside widely bordered with [i]grey-brown[/i] and having [i]conspicuous dark-and-light[/i] chequered cilia. Upperside and forewing underside have [i]heavy black spotting[/i]. Hind wing underside has cryptic pattern of basal, postdiscal and marginal bands of darker scaling on a grey-brown ground. Has a characteristic [i]squarish hind wing underside dark discal mark[/i] containing a hooked pale line.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male smaller than female and [i]much darker[/i], with shorter, more pointed wings. Male forewing has [i]heavy sex brand[/i] coloured dark brown to grey-brown in basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Nominate subspecies [i]T. d. dicksoni[/i] generally has a [i]duller[/i] buff colouration than the other two subspecies. The inner margin of the male's forewing is a darker colour.
 
3 subspp., geographically distinct. The males show more differences than the females.
 
[i]T. dicksoni[/i] lives in large colonies, usually in terrain dotted with low 'bossies' or large rocks. Flight is low, fast and sustained, dodging between rocks and plants. They settle often on low vegetation or rocks, but are wary and difficult to approach. The females fly more slowly than the males.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C), (D) Female underside.

Dusky Acraea
[i]Telchinia esebria[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Heliconiinae
Genus: [i]Telchinia[/i]
Species: [i]esebria[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–55mm female 53–60mm.
Back to Top
Identification
A distinctive but very variable small Bitter Acraea. Forms [i]protea[/i] and [i]monteironis[/i] may be mistaken for Common Wanderer [i]Acraea aganice[/i] but that species is [i]larger[/i] and [i]lacks[/i] the pale patch on the inner margin of the forewing.
 
There is slight sexual dimorphism, depending on form. F. [i]esebria[/i] has rich tawny orange basal patches, subapical pale patch ochre in male, white in female. In both sexes of f. [i]ertli[/i], similar to f. [i]esebria[/i], the white apical patches are broader and white, and the forewing submarginal patch is a paler tawny orange than the hind wing.
 
Both sexes of f. [i]jacksoni[/i] have all pale markings pale tawny orange. F. [i]swynnertoni[/i] resembles f. [i]jacksoni[/i] but the apical patch is white. These forms are rare and normally only found in Zimbabwe. F. [i]protea[/i] male (common in South Africa) has ochreous cream forewing patches; female has subapical patch white. In f. [i]monteironis[/i] (both sexes), the patches are all white.
 
The undersides are generally similar in colour to the uppersides; some examples are shown here.
 
Flight slow, easy to approach. Common along forest paths and edges of clearings.
 
As the colour of the underside pale markings tends to follow that of the upperside, not all the undersides are illustrated.

Long-tailed Admiral
[i]Antanartia schaeneia schaeneia[/i]
Contents

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Antanartia[/i]
Species: [i]schaeneia[/i]
Subspecies: [i]schaeneia[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–48mm female 45–50mm.
Back to Top
Identification
A medium-sized butterfly, this is one of three 'Admirals' having a black upperside ground colour, orange postdiscal transverse forewing band and hind wing marginal band, and hind wing tails. Compared to Southern Short-tailed Admiral [i]Vanessa hippomene hippomene[/i] and Northern Short-tailed Admiral [i]V. dimorphica dimorphica[/i], it is larger and has [i]longer tails[/i]. The hind wing underside markings are also different. The ground colour is a redder shade of brown and the pale markings are [i]blue[/i] as opposed to white.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Flight fast, typical nymphaline short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Males occupy territories on forest edges and along paths and streams, and perch quite high up (>3m), sallying forth to challenge any other insect invading their domain. May also be found on the ground drinking from wet mud or on animal dung. Shy and wary; if disturbed, will hide in undergrowth or take off into the canopy. Occasionally found in large numbers. Attracted to traps baited with fermenting fruit.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane Forest from E Cape (Amatolas) and along escarpment to KwaZulu-Natal Midlands, Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province (Wolkberg).

Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Jan–Jun.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Laportea peduncularis, Boehmeria nivea[/i] and [i]Pouzolzia parasitica[/i].

Large, blue or white/yellow Pierid. Male upperside unmistakable, [i]pale blue[/i]; both sexes with dark forewing upperside margins and hind wing marginal spots. Rapid flight but not as fast or sustained as other [i]Nepheronia[/i] spp., often found fluttering around the edges of forests, feeding on flowers. Although they prefer red or orange blossoms they are often found on other colours.

Male 20–32mm female 25–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to medium-sized, dull coloured lycaenid. Similar to Cape Grey [i]Crudaria capensis[/i] but has less contrast between underside pale marks and ground colour. Similar to Wykeham's Grey [i]C. wykehami[/i] but series of postdiscal spots on forewing underside in zigzag pattern, [i]not a straight line[/i]. Very variable, especially underside, whose ground colour varies from pale sandy buff to grey-brown; series of spots on both wings vary from strongly outlined in black to being almost invisible. Upperside varies from pale grey to olive-brown. Hind wing carries short tail. There is possibly more than one subspecies within the range, as the size (or presence) of the tail varies, and the forewing shape varies from rounded to pointed.
 
Sexes similar, female larger, wings rounder.
 
Fast flight, usually settling on flowers, bushes, or lower branches of trees. Resting posture with wings open and forewings held proud. Usually in bare rocky areas; also fond of flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

Widespread in Nama Karoo, Savanna, from W Cape (Great Karoo) to E Cape, KwaZulu-Natal, Free State, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, Gauteng and N Cape.

Bright, shimmering reddish small Copper butterfly. Upperside [i]bright, deep metallic copper[/i], broad black margins, well-defined square black 'spots', cilia [i]not chequered[/i]. Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]nigricans[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–33mm female 23–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, dark Opal. Very angular wing shape as in Brauer's [i]Chrysoritis braueri[/i], Brooks's [i]C. brooksi[/i] and Adonis [i]C. adonis[/i] Opals. Forewing outer margin strongly angled outwards at vein M3. Male upperside forewing apex [i]black[/i], sometimes with small orange-red spots, hind wing orange-red [i]restricted to submarginal band[/i]. Silvery blue covers basal half of male upperside forewing and much of hind wing; suffused with [i]electric royal blue to blue-green[/i] opalescent glow. Strongly chequered cilia. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Both sexes have underside hind wing variegated in dark- and red-brown, with cream discal and costal spots; silver-gold sagittate streaks.
 
[i]C. n. zwartbergae[/i] is a much darker butterfly than the other subspp., particularly in the male, which has [i]broader[/i] marginal black on both wings and [i]reduced[/i] orange-red spots; hind wing underside is [i]deeper and more prominently red-brown[/i] than nominate. Sexes dimorphic; female with rounder wings, [i]deep orange ground colour, little[/i] basal blue, [i]heavy[/i] black spots and [i]wide dark margins[/i].
 
3 subspp., geographically distinct. Found in large scattered colonies, at a range of altitudes; from the high slopes or summits of mountains to low altitude near the coast. Males have rapid, whirling flight, usually close to the ground, patrolling their territory and settling often on prominent rocks or plants. Females are found at random on flowers and near host plants.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Male underside. (F) Female upperside.

Bright orange [i]Aloeides[/i] copper with [i]well-defined[/i] narrow black borders. Underside ground colour from fawn-brown to bright crimson-pink. Serrated discal fascia well marked; lines of basal spots and distinct scalloped submarginal line of merged spots all [i]silver, distally edged black[/i]. Rossouw's Copper [i]A. rossouwi[/i] has [i]more rounded wings[/i] and a [i]broader forewing costal dark margin[/i], forming a dark apical patch which usually contains small orange spots.

2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fairly fast, fluttering close to the ground; settling often, usually on the ground or on low vegetation. Lives in small, concentrated colonies; found in flat country or on mountain slopes. Reluctant to open wings.

Male 30–34mm female 38–42mm.

Identification
Small butterfly, intermediate in size between Brauns's Skolly [i]Thestor braunsi[/i] and Dickson's Skolly [i]T. dicksoni[/i]. Upperside ground colour buff with basal suffusion with [i]dark grey-brown[/i], similar to, but duller than, [i]T. braunsi[/i]. Both sexes have wings more pointed than [i]T. dicksoni[/i]. Upperside and forewing underside widely bordered with [i]grey-brown[/i] and having [i]dark-and-light[/i] chequered cilia. Upperside and forewing underside have [i]heavy black spotting[/i]. Hind wing underside has cryptic pattern of basal, postdiscal and marginal bands of darker scaling on a grey-brown ground. Has a large, squarish hind wing underside dark discal mark with [i]anvil-shaped[/i] white patch at lower centre.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male smaller than female and [i]much darker[/i], with shorter, more pointed wings. Male forewing has [i]heavy sex brand[/i] coloured dark brown to grey-brown in basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2.
 
[i]T. calviniae[/i] lives in large colonies, usually in terrain dotted with low 'bossies' or large rocks. Flight is low, fast and sustained, dodging between rocks and plants. They settle often on low vegetation or rocks, but are wary and difficult to approach. The females fly more slowly than the males.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.

Small, bright orange Charaxes. Superficially similar to Club-tailed Charaxes [i]Charaxes zoolina[/i] f. [i]neanthes[/i], but with [i]black[/i] spots, not red-brown, and has two tails in [i]both[/i] sexes. Tails are sharply pointed, [i]not clubbed[/i]. [i]C. j. argynnides[/i] has [i]reduced[/i] underside silvery markings and [i]more extensive[/i] orange-tawny colour in the submarginal band.
 
Sexes similar, but male has [i]narrower, more triangular[/i] wings.
 
Although this is a small Charaxes it lacks nothing in speed of flight or, in the male, pugnacity. Males form territories on hilltops, or in flat country, around prominent bushes and trees. They pursue any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females are found close to the host plants, or wandering around searching for males.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
7 geographically distinct subspp., 3 in South Africa.
 
(C) Male upperside. (D) Female upperside. (E) Male underside. (F) Female underside.

Medium–small bright orange-and-black Skipper. Upperside blackish-brown with postdiscal bands of large orange spots on both wings. Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Virachola[/i]
Species: [i]diocles[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–36mm female 29–41mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of the larger [i]Virachola[/i] Playboys. The male is distinctive with his bright orange hind wing upperside and black forewing carrying an orange band at the inner margin. The black is shot with purple which is only visible at very acute angles. The species closest to this one is Black-and-orange Playboy, [i]Virachola dariaves[/i], which lacks the strong orange forewing bar.
 
Underside of both sexes is grey, varying in shade from cool to warm; there are submarginal and postdiscal rows of darker grey and white lines that are 'cut' into segments by the wing veins, and a single darker grey and white mark at the end of the cell in both wings. Unlike other South African [i]Virachola[/i] Playboys there are NO dark basal spots on the underside of either wing. Both sexes have a single white-tipped tail at the hind wing anal angle.
 
Sexes differ on the upperside. The female is brown with large discal patches of [i]dove-grey[/i] and not [i]pale-blue[/i] as in [i]V. antalus[/i] or [i]V. dinomenes[/i]; female [i]V. dariaves[/i] is more [i]blackish[/i] and [i]V. dinochares[/i] has smaller pale discal patches; [i]V. vansoni[/i] females are smaller.
 
Males perch on prominent twigs and leaves on forest edges; conspicuous when chasing other butterflies; usually returns to same perch. Females are found on flowers and close to the host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside.(E), (F) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread. Lowland and Riverine Forest along east coast from E Cape (Coffee Bay) to KwaZulu-Natal, to Lebombos, north along foothills of escarpment to Mpumalanga, Limpopo Province and Zimbabwe.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Sept and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
Fruits and seeds of [i]Bauhinia galpinii, Milletia grandis, Philenoptera sutherlandii, Caesalpinia pulcherrima, Elephantorrhiza goetzei, Macadamia integrifolia[/i], and [i]Baphia racemosa[/i]; also peaches, plums ([i]Prunus[/i] spp) and [i]Schotia, Combretum, Syzygium[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Playboys.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Euchrysops[/i]
Species: [i]barkeri[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–32mm female 27–33mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Colourful small 'Smoky Blue'. Similar to Osiris Smoky Blue, [i]Euchrysops osiris[/i] but slightly [i]larger[/i], only a [i]single[/i] black spot and orange lunule In CuA1, with short tail at end of vein CuA2. Underside of both sexes a pale fawn-grey ground colour, with paler-edged, slightly darker [i]squarish[/i] spots in cells and postdiscal and marginal series, submarginal series of white sagittate marks and 3 to 5 basal white-edged black spots. Underside black spot In CuA1 is edged with metallic blue-green. Hind wing carries small tails at the anal angle.
 
Sexually dimorphic as in Osiris Smoky Blue, both surfaces [i]paler[/i] in both sexes; male upperside [i]powder blue[/i], not pinkish mauve, [i]broader[/i] grey marginal borders. Female blue [i]powder blue[/i], not sky blue. Underside as Osiris Smoky Blue but paler.
 
Slow, fluttering flight close to ground, settling often on flowers. Female seen more often than male.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Edges of wooded coastal Savanna from E Cape (Port St. Johns) along KwaZulu-Natal coast to Mozambique; also in Limpopo Province north of Polokwane.
Back to Top
Habitat
Coast, flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods; DSF Apr–Sept, WSF Oct–Mar. Most often seen Nov–Jul.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Sphenostylis angustifolia, Crotolaria[/i] spp., [i]Rhynchosia[/i] spp.; [i]Vigna unguiculata[/i] and [i]V. triloba[/i].

Tiny, brown and black 'Blue'. Usually slightly [i]smaller[/i] than related Rayed Blue [i]Actizera lucida[/i]. Upperside black-brown with pattern of [i]tiny white arcuate spots[/i]. Identification
Small brown Skipper with darker brown patterning on upperside, pattern varies depending on seasonal form. Characteristic [i]bright yellow-ochre underside[/i], mottled with brown.
 
Sexes similar, female has larger, stouter abdomen. Low flight among leaf litter on the ground, fast moving and well camouflaged against the background. Can be very difficult to spot when it sits wings open among dead leaves.
 
Dry season form [i]varia[/i] forewing upperside dark discal and apical patches [i]have contrasting, countershaded edges[/i], forewing hyaline spots [i]small[/i], closely follow distal edges of dark patches. Hind wing upperside has [i]poorly contrasted[/i] dark basal, discal and submarginal bands. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Wet season form [i]phidyle[/i] upperside dark markings [i]more broken, mottled[/i]. (C) Female upperside.

Common and widespread. In wooded Savanna and Lowland Forest, edges of Riverine Forest, from E Cape (Port Elizabeth) to Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal (Maputaland), Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province (to Waterberg), NW Province and Gauteng (Magaliesberg).

Maluti Amakosa Rocksitter
[i]Durbania amakosa sagittata[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbania[/i]
Species: [i]amakosa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]sagittata[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–35mm female 29–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small black-and-orange/red butterflies; uppersides are black with varying degrees of red/orange spots and blotches. Undersides are beautifully camouflaged against their habitat; intricate patterns of black or dark grey on a white or pale grey ground, with submarginal spots in varying shades of red to orange, yellow or white. There are some similar species to Amakosa Rocksitter; Natal Rocksitter [i]Durbania limbata[/i] upperside has outer half of hind wing [i]broad[/i] red; sexes similar and flies in late summer to autumn, not spring and early summer. And Clark's Rocksitter [i]D. clarki[/i] is much smaller and its range does not overlap with that of [i]D. amakosa[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. [i]D. a. sagittata[/i] is similar to [i]D. a. ayresi[/i] and [i]D. a. natalensis[/i] but the underside is more [i]yellowish[/i] than other subspecies. The male hind wing upperside orange patch is serrated at the distal edge due to the orange colour being extended along the veins.
 
7 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(O) Male upperside. (P) Female upperside. (Q) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland in e Drakensberg and Maluti foothills, Free State.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Nov–Jan.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.

Calitzdorp Opal
[i]Chrysoritis pan henningi[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
