Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]pan[/i]
Subspecies: [i]henningi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 20–26mm female 22–30mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright orange Opal. Smaller than Common Opal [i]Chrysoritis thysbe[/i]; habits more colonial. Male upperside opal-blue covers [i]smaller[/i] area of wing, but variable - some spring specimens very dark. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside variable depending on subspecies; pale buff to almost black, darker spots vary from indistinct to streaky marbling of russet brown with brassy sagittate streaks.
 
[i]C. pan henningi[/i] is larger and more strikingly marked on upperside than nominate; male basal blue [i]brighter, more extensive[/i]. Underside hind wing varies from weakly marked, as in nominate, to strongly variegated in brown and tan with red streaks and silvery sagittate postdiscal marks. Sexes similar. Female upperside [i]lacks[/i] opal sheen, basal blue [i]restricted[/i] to basal 25% of wings.
 
3 subspp., geographically distinct. Low flight, usually not as fast as other Opals. Habits more colonial than [i]C. thysbe[/i], and more likely to be found in gullies and riverbeds than on hill and dune tops. Males perch on prominent rocks and bushes, chasing intruders away. Females more sedentary, usually near flowers and host plants.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Male underside (weakly marked form). (F) Female upperside. (G) Female underside (variegated form).
Back to Top
Distribution
Nama Karoo in Klein Swartberg to Langeberg and Little Karoo (Huis River Pass to Garcia's Pass); east as far as Willowmore, E Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, gullies, dry riverbeds.
Back to Top
Flight period
Several broods Aug–May, peaks Oct/Nov and Feb/Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Tetraena retrofracta[/i]. No ant association records.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]methymna[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–40mm female 33–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
[i]Lepidochrysops methymna dicksoni[/i] has [i]variable[/i] upperside blue. In the male usually more extensive than the female. Underside typical of brown [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]; dark spots large and well-defined on both wings; hind wing postdiscal sagittate marks large but slender.
 
The only species that may be mistaken for it is Peninsula Blue [i]L. oreas[/i], but that is much paler blue and is not found in the same localities (or [i]was[/i] not, because [i]L. methymna dicksoni[/i] is officially extinct.).
 
Sexes similar.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Rapid, whirling flight. Male territorial on mountain tops, circling around, chasing other Blues and perching on low vegetation. Female scarcer, slower flying, found near host plants.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside. (G) Female upperside.

Thought to be Extinct. Only from Tygerberg Hills, Bellville (W Cape).

Classification

Wingspan
Male 25.5–29.5mm female 26–29mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small sapphire. Upperside very similar to Red-line Sapphire [i]Iolaus sidus[/i], but blue [i]not as bright[/i]. Underside unique in South Africa; has [i]conspicuous orange-yellow bands, that lack black edges[/i], crossing underside of both wings, and submarginal rows of black spots on a bright white ground.
 
Sexes differ; female with wings more rounded, upperside blue [i]paler, less intense[/i]. Hind wing crossed by dark discal line following orange line on underside. Lacks hind wing upperside sex brand of the male.
 
Male flies in the shelter of large trees, usually quite slowly. Also found around prominent bushes and trees at the summit of dunes, usually only after 13h00. Female closer to host plant. Both sexes are fond of flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

Wooded hills and dunes, along E Cape coast (East London) to KwaZulu-Natal (Burman Bush, Durban), and as far as Ndumu in Zululand.

Back to Top

Year round, mainly Sept–May, peaks Nov and Feb/Mar.

Classification

Genus: [i]Cacyreus[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–27mm female 22–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small dull blue lycaenid. Very similar to Mocker Bronze [i]Cacyreus virilis[/i]; only certain distinguishing feature the orientation of the inner edge of the central of three costal blotches on hind wing underside(see arrow). The basal edge of this is angled so that it appears to [i]lean towards[/i] the body. Cilia chequered in both sexes. Underside variegated in shades of light and dark brown, with an irregular hind wing discal band of black-ringed brown spots [i]edged with white[/i]. Hind wing carries a small tail at the end of CuA2.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside [i]soft metallic violaceous blue[/i]; female [i]variegated grey[/i] with [i]blue and white[/i] marks.
 
Slow, fluttering flight around forest edges and along paths. Males perch on prominent leaves or twigs and set off to patrol territory. Both sexes are often found on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane, Lowland and Riverine Forest from W Cape (Cape Peninsula), along wet side of mountains to E Cape, KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Free State and Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, gullies, wetlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Oct–Feb; seldom in winter months in cooler areas.
Back to Top

Large Vagrant
[i]Nepheronia argia varia[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Nepheronia[/i]
Species: [i]argia[/i]
Subspecies: [i]varia[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–65mm 48–70mm.
Back to Top
Identification
South Africa's largest Pierid. Male appearance is constant across seasons and subspp., [i]size of black forewing tip[/i] being the main variable character. Like Buquet's Vagrant [i]Nepheronia buquetii[/i] it has conspicuous green eyes, but the male has a [i]creamy white, not green[/i] underside hind wing, and there is a [i]large square spot[/i] in the forewing underside tip.
 
Sexually dimorphic in that the female is never greenish white like the male, and always has [i]dark marks[/i] along the upperside margins, but not to the same extent as females of Cambridge Vagrant [i]N. Thalassina[/i]. There are several female forms. Wet season form females are larger, marginal upperside dark spots larger, hind wing upperside [i]white[/i]. Variable extent of basal orange-red on upperside forewing. Dry season form females are smaller, hind wing upperside varies from white, to patches of orange-yellow, to yellow and deep yellow-orange. Yellow hind wing forms rare at coast. F. [i]aurora[/i] most typical female form.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fast and direct, stopping seldom, unless at flowers (usually orange or red, but they are fond of [i]Plumbago[/i]) to nectar. Any bright red object will attract them.
 
[i]N. argia varia[/i]: Male has smaller black forewing tip than [i]N. a. variegata[/i]. Nominate form [i]varia[/i]; female has [i]yellow[/i] upperside hind wing and [i]red[/i]-orange forewing base: (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.(C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
 
Female form [i]oraria[/i] resembles f. [i]varia[/i] but has [i]bright orange[/i] upperside hind wing. (D) Female upperside. (E) Female underside.
 
Female form [i]giara[/i] has [i]white[/i] forewing bases, and [i]light orange[/i] (not yellow) upperside hind wing. (F) Female upperside. (G) Female underside.
 
Female form [i]hemicrocea[/i] resembles f. [i]giara[/i] in having [i]white[/i] forewing bases, but has [i]deep orange[/i] upperside hind wing, and forewing costal and outer margins tinged with orange. (H) Female upperside. (I) Female underside.
 
There is an unnamed form that resembles f. [i]varia[/i] but has [i]white[/i] upperside hind wing: (J) Female upperside. (K) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Lowland Forest from E Cape (Cwebe) along coast, inland along Riverine Forest into KwaZulu-Natal to Oribi Gorge.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall; peaks late summer and autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Pristimera longipetiolata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Vagrants.
Back to Top

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Stygionympha[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
32–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very small brown butterfly; with Gerald's Brown [i]S. geraldi[/i], the smallest [i]Stygionympha[/i] species. Wings [i]more rounded[/i] than Robertson's Brown [i]S. robertsoni[/i], with which it flies. It [i]lacks[/i] hind wing ocelli on underside. Hind wing underside brown, [i]irrorated with tiny off-white to yellow[/i] speckles; row of [i]submarginal spots[/i] in same colour.
 
Sexes similar, female more heavily built, with stouter abdomen, and wings more elongated and rounder.
 
Flight fastest of genus (along with [i]S. geraldi[/i]); flies close to ground, where small size makes it difficult to follow. Settles seldom, opens wings for an instant before closing them.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female underside.

Single-brooded, Sept–Nov in winter-rainfall areas. In summer-rainfall areas, possibly double-brooded, Sept–May.

Male 19–24mm female 21–25mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small pied lycaenid. One of several small lycaenids with stark white undersides dotted with black. Distinguished from White Pie [i]Tuxentius calice calice[/i] by [i]large gap between the apical and discal black costal spots[/i] on the underside hind wing (see arrow). Distinguished from Dotted Blue [i]Tarucus sybaris[/i] and Hintza Pierrot [i]Zintha hintza hintza[/i] by [i]total lack of blue scaling[/i] on upperside.
 
[i]Tuxentius melaena griqua[/i] has white upperside markings [i]reduced and suffused with grey[/i]; underside ground colour [i]dirtier white[/i] than nominate. Sexes similar.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Rapid, fluttering flight, often high up on flowering trees with hordes of other small lycaenids. Difficult to separate on the wing from [i]Tuxentius[/i], [i]Zintha[/i] or [i]Tarucus[/i] spp.
 
(C) Male upperside. (D) Male underside.
Back to Top

Rare in Arid Savanna and riverine bush in N Cape, along Vaal River from Windsorton to Barkly West, and nw to Kuruman and Witsand area.

Small Hopper
[i]Platylesches tina[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Platylesches[/i]
Species: [i]tina[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 25–27mm female 27–29mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny dark Skipper. Upperside blackish brown with pale spots. Forewing [i]more elongated and narrower[/i] than other South African [i]Platylesches[/i] Hoppers. Forewing has [i]three hyaline subapical spots[/i]; small double hyaline spots in the cell, [i]faint or absent hyaline spots[/i] in M2 and M3, and larger spot in CuA1. Cilia plain whitish grey. Hind wing upperside discal band [i]faint and broken into spots[/i]. Underside ground colour [i]dark brown basally, pale grey at margins[/i]; covered by [i]strong violaceous sheen[/i]. Hind wing underside has [i]faint series of postdiscal spots[/i]. Not easily confused with any other South African [i]Platylesches[/i] Hopper due to its small size, pointed wings and plain underside hind wing.
 
Sexes similar. Female slightly more robust than male.
 
Rarely seen, probably due to small size and high-flying behaviour. Male territorial around trees, whirling in aerial 'combat' with other Skippers, resembling small flies on the wing. Also on flowering canopy trees, and in Riverine Forest on wet mud and bird droppings. Female on flowers, usually low-growing or coppiced specimens of the host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare and localised. Dense Riverine Forest at eastern end of Soutpansberg, and vicinity of Thohoyandou hospital, Limpopo Province. Also records from near Tzaneen, Limpopo, Hoedspruit and Hazyview, Mpumalanga.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, gullies, flatlands, hillsides.

Large, powerfully built lycaenid; upperside [i]orange with broad black borders[/i] and with [i]conspicuously black-and-white chequered cilia[/i]. Hind wing has short bristly tails at the anal angle. Small yellow butterfly. When doing this it resembles a tiny yellowed leaf waving in the breeze. Occasionally found roosting communally in undergrowth. Female flies lower, searching for oviposition sites on tree trunks. Brown-veined White
[i]Belenois aurota[/i]
alternative common name: Caper White
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Belenois[/i]
Species: [i]aurota[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–45mm female 42–50mm.
Back to Top
Identification
This is the familiar little white butterfly that migrates across the country in vast numbers almost every year. Upperside similar to Meadow White [i]Pontia helice helice[/i], but can be told apart by the forewing cellular spot, which is bar- or dumbbell-shaped. Forewing upperside pattern similar to other [i]Belenois[/i] species such as Forest White [i]B. zochalia zochalia[/i], and African Veined White [i]B. gidica[/i] that have [i]dumbbell-shaped[/i] bars at the distal end of the cell. It differs from the Forest White in the [i]lack of pearlescence in the white[/i], and from African Veined White in that it is [i]smaller[/i]. The hind wing underside [i]does not have a postdiscal row of sagittate dark marks[/i]; the veins are [i]clearly delineated[/i] in grey-brown, without the 'streaky' interneural marks. Unlike the Meadow White, the underside dark marks are [i]not a mix of black and yellow scales[/i], and there may be yellow marks but they do not invade the dark areas. Also, females never have yellow wings, as do both the similar [i]Belenois[/i] species.
 
Sexes similar, female dark markings [i]brown, black[/i] in male. Female with dark marginal borders much broader than male, containing [i]no white marks[/i], dumbbell-shaped dark mark at distal end of forewing upperside cell larger, merges with costal stripe. There are no clear seasonal forms; dry season specimens tend to have [i]reduced dark markings[/i].
 
Flight medium fast, direct, stopping often to feed on flowers. Males are fond of congregating on wet mud. Often found close to the host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside. (E), (F) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Arid Savanna and Savanna in n N Cape, arid areas of Limpopo and NW provinces, and n Gauteng. Found almost everywhere during migrations, late summer.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands, parks and gardens, forest edges, coast, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in home areas, numbers grow until overcrowding triggers lemming-type migration, usually Dec–Feb, in southerly and easterly direction. Large numbers may be seen in Limpopo Province, late summer and autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Boscia albitrunca, B. foetida, B. oleoides, Maerua angolensis, M. cafra, M. rosmarinoides[/i], and [i]Capparis[/i] spp., including [i]C. fascicularis, C. sepiaria[/i], and [i]C. tomentosa[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Whites.

Small, brightly coloured Opal. Upperside margins very [i]broad and dark[/i], cilia [i]strongly chequered[/i] in orange, black and white. Hind wing anal angle [i]extended to form small tail[/i]. Forewing outer margin strongly angled outwards at vein M3, more so than others of the Common Opal group except Brook's [i]Chrysoritis brooksi[/i], Dark [i]C. nigricans[/i], and Adonis [i]C. adonis[/i], Opals; male hind wing basal blue blends with postdiscal black spots on upperside, the black forming a border around blue. Underside hind wing variegated in shades of [i]brown, ochre, and cream[/i], with [i]conspicuous[/i] brassy sagittate markings.
 
Sexes very different. Male orange markings restricted to forewing upperside apex and hind wing submarginal band, female orange ground colour extensive, basal blue patches small but bright.
 
Very fast and elusive flight, hard to follow among its favoured habitat of rocky outcrops on grassy hills. Found in scattered colonies. Males defend territories around hollows in the outcrops, patrolling regularly. Females found more at random. Often found near remnant patches of Afromontane Forest.

Table Mountain Beauty

Contents

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Aeropetes[/i]
Species: [i]tulbaghia[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 70–78mm, female 75–90mm.
Back to Top
Identification
South Africa's, and one of the world's, largest Satyrines. An iconic butterfly of upland Grasslands and fynbos areas; a candidate for South Africa's national butterfly. Unusually for the subfamily it has a powerful, acrobatic flight more reminiscent of the [i]Charaxinae[/i]. They patrol a section of hillside or a high valley and chase away all rivals. They settle on the shady side of rocks or overhung stream banks. Fond of red or orange flowers, and is the only known pollinator of the Red Disa [i]Disa uniflora[/i].
 
Sexes similar, male darker than female; latter has longer, more rounded wings.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos, Nama Karoo, Grassland, from W Cape (Cape Town) into N Cape (southern Namaqualand), and along southern and eastern mountain ranges into Lesotho, KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, and Limpopo (Soutpansberg) and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, rock-strewn hillsides, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Nov–Apr (peak Dec–Mar).
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae grasses, including [i]Hyparrhenia hirta[/i] and [i]Ehrharta erecta[/i]. Bred on [i]Cenchrus clandestinus[/i].

White's Opal
[i]Chrysoritis thysbe whitei[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]thysbe[/i]
Subspecies: [i]whitei[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 23–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of a large group of [i]Chrysoritis[/i] Opals with [i]blue wing bases[/i] and a [i]shimmering, electric opalescent sheen[/i] over a varying area of the wings. For [i]Chrysoritis thysbe[/i], amount of blue on upperside varies, in some subspecies almost covering the forewing. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside varies from plain sandy tan to dark brown, to [i]variegated[/i] with striae in various shades of reddish-brown, with bands of paler colouring and brassy postdiscal streaks. 'Plain' underside specimens usually have unicoloured cilia; 'variegated' ones dark cilia with pale interneural flecks, appearing 'chequered'.
 
[i]C. t. whitei[/i] has upperside solid blue paler than in [i]C. thysbe thysbe[/i] or [i]C. thysbe mithras[/i] and seldom extends beyond the forewing cell spot. Cilia orange with small pale interneural spots and black vein ends, giving dentate appearance to wing edges. Hind wing underside is variegated in dark brown and cream, with silvery white streaks. Sexes differ. Female has [i]rounder wings[/i], upperside blue [i]restricted to basal 25% of wings[/i], no opalescent sheen. The females of the various races are almost impossible to separate on wing patterns and identification usually requires comparison with males seen at the same locality.
 
7 subspp., not always geographically distinct. Rapid, sustained flight, settling on prominent bushes or rocks. Male intensively territorial on hill tops or sand dunes, regularly patrolling and chasing intruders; Females are found more at random, often on flowers.
 
(U) Male upperside. (V) Male underside. (W) Female upperside. (X) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos-covered hills and dunes in E Cape, near Port Elizabeth.
Back to Top
Habitat
Coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Osteospermum moniliferum[/i]. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster capensis[/i] ants.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.

African Monarch
[i]Danaus chrysippus dorippus[/i]
alternative common name: Dorippus Tiger
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Mimic
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Danainae
Genus: [i]Danaus[/i]
Species: [i]chrysippus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]dorippus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–70mm, female 50–75mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium to large butterfly, with weak but sustained fluttering flight, sometimes sailing, at medium height, 2–3m above the ground. Usually found flying alone or in small groups, but may be found in large numbers on wounded plants exuding pyrrolizidine alkaloids. Fond of nectar. This butterfly has complex biogeography; it is widespread across Asia, southern Europe and the whole of Africa. Several variants occur across this range, the relationship between these is the subject of several studies.
 
A form resembling [i]Danaus chrysippus dorippus[/i], the common subspecies in the arid northern and eastern side of Africa, is the rarest in South Africa. The wing tip is orange, lacking the white-spotted black pattern. Typical [i]D. c. dorippus[/i] has the orange spreading all the way from the wing bases; form [i]klugii[/i] has chocolate-brown basal suffusion and form [i]transiens[/i] is similar to [i]klugii[/i] but in addition has traces of the white forewing spots seen in [i]D. c. orientis[/i] and [i]D. c. alcippus[/i].
 
Further north in Africa, all the forms of [i]D. c. dorippus[/i] may be found with the white hind wing patch of [i]D. c. alcippus[/i], but these are not found in SA.
 
It is possible that the appearance of forms resembling [i]D. c. dorippus[/i] among the South African [i]D. c. orientis[/i] population is a result of edge-of-range interbreeding with those races when climatic conditions make this possible.
 
(E) Male upperside (f. [i]dorippus[/i]). (F) Female upperside (f. [i]klugii[/i]). (G) Female underside (close to f. [i]transiens[/i]). Undersides of (E) and (F) resemble that of (G). Upperside of (G) resembles that of (F) but has the white spots in the forewing apex.
Mimic
Female Common Diadem [i]Hypolimnas misippus[/i] is a polymorphic mimic of all forms of this butterfly. Also female [i]Papilio dardanus cenea[/i] forms [i]trophonius, aikeni[/i] and probably [i]salaami[/i]. Forest Beauty [i]Paralethe dendrophilus[/i]. White-barred Acraea, [i]Telchinia encedon encedon[/i].

Sooty Blue
[i]Zizeeria knysna knysna[/i]
alternative common name: African Grass Blue
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Zizeeria[/i]
Species: [i]knysna[/i]
Subspecies: [i]knysna[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 18–23mm female 21–26mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny, dull 'Blue'. Underside [i]warm brownish-grey[/i], with basal and postdiscal series of black spots ringed in creamy-white. Resembles Dark Grass Blue [i]Zizina antanossa[/i], but that butterfly is [i]silvery, steel blue[/i] on the upperside; the most obvious difference is the hind wing underside postdiscal series of black spots. In [i]Z. knysna[/i] the spots are arranged in an even oval pattern, parallel to the outer margin. In [i]Z. antanossa[/i] the spot in area RS is set more basad (towards the body), creating an 'elbow' in the pattern. May also be confused with Gaika Blue [i]Zizula hylax[/i]; compared to which the wings are [i]only slightly elongated[/i], and the abdomen is [i]shorter[/i] in comparison to the hind wing.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside [i]dull violaceous-blue[/i], female upperside [i]dark fuscous-brown[/i] with variable amount of [i]brighter basal blue[/i].
 
Low, fluttering flight just above the ground, settling often on grass stems or the ground. Most common small Blue, most often on suburban lawns infested with its host plant, a common weed.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Throughout South Africa, from sea level to highest mountains and wet forests to Arid Savanna, but absent from the driest Nama Karoo and Desert areas.
Back to Top
Habitat
Parks and gardens, flatlands, wetlands, forest edges, mountains, hillsides, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct–Dec and Feb–Apr.
Back to Top

Delagoa Sandman
[i]Spialia delagoae[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Spialia[/i]
Species: [i]delagoae[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 21–24mm female 24–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very small, dark Skipper with black-and-white chequered upperside and forewing underside. One of a group of very similar little butterflies, which are difficult to tell apart from the upperside markings. To be reasonably sure of identification a clear view of the hind wing underside is necessary. Compared to Dwarf Sandman [i]Spialia nanus[/i] and Common Sandman [i]S. ferax[/i], underside hind wing median band [i]straight, not wavy or curved[/i]. Underside hind wing median band [i]constant in width[/i], which sets it apart from Boland Sandman [i]S. sataspes[/i] and Wandering Sandman [i]S. depauperata australis[/i]. Band [i]not jagged[/i] as it is in Confusing Sandman [i]S. confusa confusa[/i] or Forest Sandman [i]S. dromus[/i]. Star Sandman [i]S. asterodia[/i] and Wolkberg Sandman [i]S. secessus[/i] also have non-tapering hind wing underside median band, but they have [i]more prominent white banding and spotting[/i] in the basal area. Cilia chequered.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
Fast, buzzing, low flight, settling often, wings open. Wary and difficult to approach closely. Male establishes territories on small rocky prominences. Also on flowers, wet mud, and fresh animal droppings.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Savanna, Lowland Forest, and thorn belt from Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal (Maputaland area), Mpumalanga lowveld, n Gauteng and Limpopo and n NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, rocky ledges, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, peaks Feb/Mar and Aug/Sept, occasionally seen between broods.
Back to Top

[i]Melhania prostrata[/i].

Identification
Small, bright orange Opal. Similar to Pan Opal [i]Chrysoritis pan[/i] and Common Opal [i]Chrysoritis thysbe[/i]. Forewing apex [i]far more pointed[/i]. Upperside with very [i]narrow, smooth[/i] dark marginal bands, and [i]few, well-defined[/i] black spots on [i]pale orange[/i] ground colour. As with Common Opal, cilia vary from plain grey-brown to black with [i]varying degree of small white interneural spots[/i]. Sexes differ; female has less upperside blue than male, and it is silvery with [i]no opalescent sheen[/i].
 
Male territories in sand dunes; very fast flight close to ground, settling on the sand or low vegetation. Female more often found on flowers.

Bashee River Buff
[i]Deloneura immaculata[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Deloneura[/i]
Species: [i]immaculata[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Female 34–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small buff butterfly. Pale buff with [i]no[/i] markings on either wing surface. Similar wing shape and size to Millar's Buff, [i]Deloneura millari[/i]. Nothing else is known about this species.
 
Three were taken near Fort Bowker in December 1863 by Col. JH Bowker. Two were females and these are usually figured as here; Trimen stated a male to have been taken but its whereabouts are uncertain. The forests near the putative type locality have largely been destroyed so it is unlikely this butterfly will be rediscovered. However, lepidopterists still search, hopefully, for it.
 
Habits unrecorded but likely to be similar to other [i]Deloneura[/i] Buffs; shy and retiring habits, slow flight with rapid wingbeats, but making little progress. They gather in groups of several specimens, feeding on honeydew secreted by scale insects quite high in the canopy, 3 to 6metres up. The butterflies walk slowly around these insects, their camouflaged undersides making them almost impossible to spot. They hardly ever fly unless deliberately flushed, and the best way to see them is to patiently tap the foliage of suitable trees in the habitat. If a group is disturbed they will fly out, with peculiar fast flapping wingbeats. Although the flight is slow, if chased they can put on a respectable turn of speed.
 
(A) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Only known from the Mbashe (Bashee) River, EC, near Fort Bowker.
Back to Top
Habitat
Probably heavy riverine forest.
Back to Top
Flight period
Unknown.
Back to Top
Larval food
Unknown.
Back to Top
Group
Buffs.
Back to Top

Identification
Small brown Skipper. Upperside dark brown; hind wing plain, forewing has small discal whitish spots, which may be absent in the male of the nominate subspecies. Underside golden to ochreous red-brown with veins picked out in paler ochre. Resembles Dark Ranger [i]Kedestes niveostriga[/i] but upperside [i]darker[/i], forewing spots [i]much smaller or absent[/i]; underside ground colour [i]darker, a more reddish shade[/i]; pale streak along hind wing underside vein M2 [i]fainter[/i]. Can be distinguished from Wallengren's Ranger [i]K. wallengrenii[/i] by the position of the hind wing underside white stripe, which follows the inner margin. Cilia plain ochreous cream to greyish white.
 
[i]Kedestes lenis alba[/i] is smaller than nominate; upperside not so red a shade of brown; underside ground colour a more ochreous red brown; upperside pale spots [i]larger[/i]. Sexes similar, female larger and paler than male, rounder, more elongated wings, abdomen stouter, forewing upperside spots [i]better developed[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fast and skipping. Male does not hilltop, stays close to host plants in wet places, perching and patrolling, chasing away any other male. Female slower flying, also found among host plants, seldom on flowers.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Female upperside. (F) Female underside.

Unlike Natal Bar [i]Cigaritis natalensis[/i], Mozambique Bar [i]Cigaritis mozambica[/i] and Ella's Bar [i]Cigaritis ella[/i], this butterfly, like the similar Namaqua Bar [i]Cigaritis namaquus[/i] has an underside with [i]silvery white[/i] bands on a darker ground colour. Female upperside orange-buff with dark bars covering whole surface; silvery blue colour is confined to wing bases; [i]lacks[/i] blue upperside flush of male.
 
Male territorial on flat ground or hillsides, perching on low thorny bushes and shrubs, but not noticeably colonial as in Mozambique Bar. Sometimes swarms with Whites and Tips around [i]Vernonia[/i] flowers in winter.

Back to Top
Identification
Large, bright blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Upperside [i]pale, pearlescent mauve-blue[/i]; underside ground colour of both sexes warm fawn-grey, with well-defined rows of white-edged, darker grey spots and basal hind wing black spots. Underside similar to Rossouw's [i]Lepidochrysops rossouwi[/i] and Silvery [i]L. glauca[/i] Blues, but upperside of both sexes is a deeper, more violaceous blue. Both surfaces of both sexes' hind wings have [i]prominent[/i] orange lunules above large black spots at the anal angle. The largest spot is in area CuA1; sometimes the black spot in area 1A+2A is absent but the orange lunule still present. Hind wing carries a small tail at end of vein CuA2. Cilia plain whitish grey.
 
The shade of upperside blue is somewhat variable. Specimens from arid areas tend to be a paler shade of mauve-blue but are never ice-blue as in [i]L. glauca[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic; male upperside plain blue with [i]thin fuscous-grey margins[/i]. Female upperside has variable extent of basal and discal [i]mauve-blue[/i] on a [i]fuscous-grey[/i] ground, [i]whitish[/i] sagittate hind wing submarginal marks. Female also has [i]larger dark spot at the distal end of the cell[/i] than the male, and in some specimens there is a postdiscal row of faint white-edged grey spots corresponding in position to those on the underside.
 
Most males fly rapidly, erratically and randomly over Grassland or bushveld, colonies not concentrated, males congregating near prominent trees. Where the larval host plant is [i]Salvia[/i], they exhibit more colonial behaviour, and are found at high density in relatively small areas.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread in Nama Karoo from W Cape (Oudtshoorn) to E Cape, through Grassland, Savanna, Arid Savanna and lowland woodland to KwaZulu-Natal, Free State, Gauteng, Mpumalanga and Limpopo and NW provinces, and N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Two broods, Sept–Dec and Jan–Apr, with some overlap.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Salvia[/i] spp., [i]Lantana rugosa[/i] and [i]L. camara[/i]. From third instar, brood of [i]Camponotus maculatus[/i] ants.
Back to Top
Group
Ant Blues.

Identification
Large Opal with extensive upperside red-orange and limited basal blue colouring. Basal blue patches [i]small[/i] as in Swanepoel's Opal [i]Chrysoritis swanepoeli[/i], but female has more basal blue, albeit very small patches. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside variegated; more [i]brightly marked[/i] than Swanepoel's Opal.
 
Sexes differ; female has [i]opalescent lustre[/i] and has [i]more extensive[/i] black spotting on hind wing upperside.
 
Flight fast, low among rocks and boulders. Found in small, concentrated colonies at summits or ridges of huge mountains. Females are sometimes found higher up than males.

W Cape, in high Fynbos on Du Toit's Kloof mountains and Mont Rochelle above Franschhoek, and Jonah's Kop and Die Galg in Riviersonderendberge. Protected in W Cape.

White-branded Swift
[i]Pelopidas thrax[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Pelopidas[/i]
Species: [i]thrax[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 42–46mm female 49–51mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small dark Skipper. Upperside blackish brown with greenish yellow hairs and pale spots. Upperside ground colour brown. Has [i]three tiny hyaline subapical spots[/i], and small hyaline spots in areas M2, M3 and CuA1. Always has [i]two small hyaline spots in forewing cell[/i]. Sexes differ in markings in CuA2. Underside olive-green; [i]five small white discal spots[/i] on hind wing in areas CuA1 to Rs. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Similar to some of the [i]Borbo[/i] Swifts that have yellow or green hairs on the upperside. Rusty Swift [i]Borbo detecta[/i] has distinctly [i]reddish yellow ochre[/i] hairs. Olive-haired Swift [i]B. borbonica[/i] has olive-green hairs but the hind wing underside black-ringed white spots are distinctive. Twin Swift [i]Larsenia gemella[/i] has yellowish to greenish ochre hairs, but has [i]only three[/i] hind wing underside discal spots.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male has [i]white[/i] forewing discal sex brand diagonally crossing CuA2. Female [i]lacks sex brand[/i]; larger than male, wings more elongated, forewing upperside has [i]hyaline discal spot[/i] in CuA2, [i]white spot[/i] in CuA1. Apart from the different colour of the male sex brand, the number of discal hind wing underside spots distinguishes this species from the very similar Black-branded Swift [i]Pelopidas mathias mathias[/i].
 
Males are territorial on hilltops, at edges of forest, along roads, paths or streams, chasing intruding males. Flight rapid, but settling often on low shrubs, grass stems or rocks; fairly easy to approach. Females are more sedentary, around flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Very widespread. Afromontane, Lowland and Riverine Forest, wooded Savanna and Grassland from W Cape (Somerset West) to Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, Limpopo Province, e NW Province, and further north.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, gullies, flatlands, coast, hill tops, parks and gardens.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, scarcer in winter.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Zea mays, Ehrharta erecta, Imperata cylindrica, Megathyrsus maximus, Cenchrus clandestinus[/i] and other Poaceae grasses.
Back to Top
Group
Swifts.

Dull small 'Smoky Blue'. Identification
Medium–small white Pierid, often seen in the same migrating swarms as Brown-veined White [i]Belenois aurota[/i]. Superficially similar, but the sexual dimorphism is much more marked.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside resembles Brown-veined White, but [i]forewing has spot in upperside cell instead of a bar[/i], hind wing underside ground colour is [i]yellow[/i]; black veining distinctive. Female upperside has very broad dark marginal borders on both surfaces of both wings. There is some seasonal polymorphism in the female. In dry season specimens the upperside ground colour is creamy white, becoming [i]lemon-yellow[/i] in wet season specimens. Marginal borders are broadest and darkest in wet season form [i]infida[/i], on whose underside forewing a discocellular bar replaces the spot.
 
Fluttering flight around trees and shrubs; both sexes fond of flowers; usually found congregating near the host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside. (E) Female underside.

Mottled-green Nymph

Classification

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Limenitidinae
Genus: [i]Euryphura[/i]
Species: [i]achlys[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 48–55mm female 55–65mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Unmistakable medium-sized dark green butterfly, with red-brown 'dead leaf' underside. South Africa's only [i]Euryphura[/i] species. Upperside has black mottling, hence common name. The only species that could be confused with it (habits are similar) is Guineafowl, [i]Hamanumida daedalus[/i], but that butterfly has a [i]grey[/i] upperside covered in [i]white[/i] dots.
 
Sexually dimorphic; female [i]larger, bluer[/i] than male, upperside and underside forewings with [i]white apical spots[/i].
 
Low, fast, gliding flight a few centimetres above the ground, wings open with occasional rapid wingbeats. Usually seen on shady forest paths. Jinks into undergrowth to avoid pursuit. Reddish underside conspicuous as wings flicker in flight. Usually encountered singly. They settle readily, wings-open but are very wary and difficult to approach.
 
Seldom seen on flowers; both sexes fond of rotting fallen fruit and wads of chewed sugar cane discarded by people. They come to fruit baited traps.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Marginal in South Africa, in Lowland and Riverine Forest of n KwaZulu-Natal (Ngoye Forest to Kosi Bay and Pongola R) and further north.

Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, but usually only seen Mar–Jun.

Upperside has a marginal black spot in CuA1, in female edged with orange basally; on underside this spot is edged with metallic blue-green. Similar in size to Ashen Smoky Blue [i]Euchrysops subpallida[/i] but both wing surfaces [i]darker in shade[/i]; underside pale markings [i]less well-defined[/i]. Underside of both sexes dull, warm brownish-grey, with paler-edged, slightly darker [i]rounded[/i] spots in cells and postdiscal and marginal series; submarginal series of white sagittate marks and five basal white-edged dark brown spots. Cilia grey, with darker grey chequering at vein ends.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male upperside [i]dull steel blue[/i], female upperside [i]grey-brown[/i], basal and discal areas blue; hind wing with [i]submarginal blue lunules[/i].
 
Flight very low, weak and erratic, settling on flowers or the ground. Found in colonies close to concentrations of the host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassy areas in Savanna from E Cape (Mbashe R) to KwaZulu-Natal, e Free State, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, and Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Several broods, Aug–Mar, depending on spring rains; later in n KwaZulu-Natal. Peaks Oct and Feb.

[i]Salvia[/i] spp. and [i]Ocimum[/i] spp.

Identification
Medium–large white Pierid. Invasive alien species that was first seen in the W
Cape in the early 1990's and has spread northwards since. The only similarly sized Pierid
that may fly with it is Buquet's Vagrant [i]Nepheronia buquetii[/i]. Can be told apart by
eyes [i]not bright green[/i]; upperside colour [i]pure white with no green tinge[/i]; 
forewing underside has [i]black discal spots[/i]; and [i]lacks hind wing cell spot[/i]. Underside hind wing may appear green but this is as a result of fine mix of black and yellow scales; the colour appears more [i]grey-green[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic; male upperside white, black marginal band apically sprinkled with grey scales, small black spot at end of hind wing costa. Female has [i]two large upperside discal spots[/i], one below the other, in lower middle forewing, where male only has underside spots. Late summer and winter specimens have more grey scaling in black forewing apical band.
 
Low flight, settles often on flowers, fond of nectar.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.

Parks, gardens and farmland in Cape Peninsula and immediate vicinity, Bellville and Somerset West, spreading to E Cape.

Back to Top

Male 50–58mm female 55–62mm.

Identification
Medium-sized bright orange butterfly with dark bands and spots on upperside. Could be mistaken on the wing for one of the Jokers [i]Byblia[/i] spp., or Gaudy Commodore [i]Precis octavia sesamus[/i] f. [i]natalensis[/i]. Distinguished by [i]deep violet-blue sheen[/i] over upperside, and [i]row of blue spots[/i] in [i]broad, black[/i] submarginal band on hind wing upperside. A 'hairy' butterfly with [i]long, untidy[/i] cilia edging the wings. The [i]plain[/i], buff to brown underside is also distinctive.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Flies low with short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Flies away rapidly if disturbed; males strongly territorial, sitting on prominent patch of bare earth, chasing away intruders. and if chased away, usually return to where first seen. They are often seen close to streams and springs. One of the earliest Highveld butterflies seen in spring.
 
Dry season form f. [i]obscurior[/i] has a [i]dark[/i] ground colour and [i]chocolate-brown[/i] underside; nominate wet season form has [i]golden brown[/i] underside, with more conspicuous submarginal eye spots.

African Migrant
[i]Catopsilia florella[/i]
alternative common name: Common Vagrant; African Emigrant
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Coliadinae
Genus: [i]Catopsilia[/i]
Species: [i]florella[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 54–60mm female 56–66mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of the larger 'whites'. Plain upperside, and usually plain underside. Pointed forewing tips and rounded hind wings; dark forewing upperside margin, if present, is [i]narrow[/i], unlike similar Buquet's Vagrant [i]Nepheronia buquetii[/i]. Eyes never [i]bright green[/i] as in that species, and hind wing underside discal spot, if present, is [i]pale[/i], not brown.
 
The male has only one form, the pale blue-green nominate. Females have three forms; the bright yellow nominate, pale yellow f. [i]hyblaea[/i] and male-like f. [i]pyrene[/i].
 
Flight sustained and powerful, covering large distances, restless and seldom settling for long in the same place. Migrating swarms may occur with many millions of individuals all flying in the same direction. Thousands may be seen drinking from mud puddles in hot weather, and both sexes are often seen nectaring at flowers. They show a distinct preference for red and orange blooms. In the dry season, they may be found hibernating between the leaves of bushes and creepers. The yellow nominate females show are often found resting among yellowed leaves.
 
Nominate form: (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside. F. [i]pyrene[/i]: (E) Female upperside. (F) Female underside. F. [i]hyblaea[/i]: (G) Female upperside, trapped by Bark Spider. (H) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Throughout South Africa; core distribution in Arid Savanna in nw; absent from Succulent Karoo and parts of Nama Karoo.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, flatlands, coast, mountains, wetlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods, year-round. Migrations usually occur from summer to autumn
(Nov–Jun, most often Feb and Mar), flying in a north-easterly direction.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Bauhinia galpinii, Cassia abbreviata, C. fistula, Chamaecrista mimosoides, Senna corymbosa, S. didymobotrya, S. italica. S. occidentalis, S. petersiana, S. septemtrionalis[/i], and [i]S. singueana[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Vagrants.

Medium–small dark Skipper. Upperside blackish brown with pale spots. Similar to Flower-girl Hopper [i]Platylesches neba[/i] but [i]larger with a very robust thorax[/i]; underside has similar pattern of spots but ground colour [i]darker and more contrasty[/i] with [i]strong violaceous sheen[/i].

Identification
Similar to, but much [i]smaller[/i] than Western [i]Stygionympha vigilans[/i] or Eastern [i]S. scotina[/i] Hillside Browns. Wings of both sexes, but especially female, more [i]angular[/i]. [i]Brown[/i] ground colour varies between subspecies; specimens from higher altitudes, or wetter habitats, become darker on the upperside and more greyish-brown, the hind wing undersides can have distinct reddish discal and postdiscal bands.
 
Hind wing underside sometimes with [i]large ocelli[/i] in apical and anal areas, underside forewing basal rust-red patch reaches as far as apical ocellus; hind wing underside grey-brown ground colour irrorated with tiny short dark red-brown striae grouped into ill-defined bands.
 
[i]S. w. williami[/i] is smaller than [i]S. w. wichgrafi[/i] but larger than [i]S. w. grisea[/i]. Ground colour darker brown. The upperside red patches are a deeper red, and usually smaller. Ocelli ringed with greyish-ochre with reduced encircling ring. The hind wing underside is more closely striated giving a darker appearance. Sexes similar, female heavier, with stouter abdomen, and wings more elongated. Female has more sedentary habits.
 
Slow, jinking flight, settling often on rocks, jerkily opening and closing wings. Visits flowers, where it tends to be less wary.

Identification
Small, bright orange Charaxes. Superficially similar to Club-tailed Charaxes [i]Charaxes zoolina[/i] f. [i]neanthes[/i], but with [i]black[/i] spots, not red-brown, and has two tails in [i]both[/i] sexes. Tails are sharply pointed, [i]not clubbed[/i]. Nominate [i]C. j. jahlusa[/i] is [i]paler[/i] than the other two subspp., particularly in the female, with comparatively heavy dark markings. The underside hind wing has little to no orange-tawny colour in the submarginal band.
 
Sexes similar, but male has [i]narrower, more triangular[/i] wings.
 
Although this is a small Charaxes it lacks nothing in speed of flight or, in the male, pugnacity. Males form territories on hilltops, or in flat country, around prominent bushes and trees. They pursue any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females are found close to the host plants, or wandering around searching for males.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
7 geographically distinct subspp., 3 in South Africa.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Eicochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]messapus[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 17–22mm female 17–24mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny blue or black butterfly. Underside resembles that of Common Smoky Blue
[i]Euchrysops malathana[/i] but a [i]much smaller butterfly[/i]; orange anal lunule in
 CuA1 and sometimes CuA2 has a marginal black spot [i]edged with
 pale metallic blue-green on both wing surfaces[/i]. The orange may spread
 into M3 and 1A+2A, but is not well-defined. On the underside the basal
 black spots are [i]smaller than in Common Smoky Blue[/i], the white-edged spots in the
 cell are reduced to [i]white-edged lines[/i], and the postdiscal series of marks are
 [i]narrower[/i] and appear as a [i]broken white-edged line[/i]. Where
 [i]Euchrysops[/i] have a well-defined row of postdiscal white sagittate marks,
 Cupreous Blue has blunt white arches. Females resemble both sexes of Grass Jewel,
 [i]Chilades trochilus[/i], but that butterfly has [i]three well-defined orange lunules
 with black spots[/i] in M3, CuA1 and CuA2, and sometimes a fourth in M2.
 
Sexually dimorphic. [i]Eicochrysops messapus mahallakoeana[/i] is blue on upperside with [i]pinkish-copper[/i] blush. Female upperside [i]black[/i], hind wing has [i]black and orange[/i] anal lunule varying in size. Underside of both sexes and both subspp. grey with black spots.
 
Flight slow among grass and low vegetation; settles often on flowers and stems, but is wary and difficult to approach closely.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside. (G) Female upperside. (H) Female underside.
Back to Top

Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands, mountains.

Year-round in warmer areas, peaks Oct and Mar, absent from cooler areas Apr–Sept.

[i]Thesium[/i] spp.

Small dark Skipper. Wings shorter and more rounded than other [i]Borbo[/i] Swifts. Upperside blackish brown. Underside also blackish brown; hind wing discal area [i]paler brown than the margins[/i]. Cilia plain dark brown.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male is [i]uniform dark brown on both upperside wings[/i] Unique among [i]Borbo[/i] Swifts. The only other South African Skippers to have uniform dark brown uppersides are the male Dark Hottentot Skipper, [i]Gegenes pumilio gambica[/i], which has a [i]pale underside[/i], and the Sylphs. Marsh [i]Metisella meninx[/i] (male) Dismal [i]Tsitana tsita[/i], Uitenhage [i]T. uitenhaga[/i] Tulbagh [i]T. tulbagha[/i], and Dickson's [i]T. dicksoni[/i] Sylphs, which have much more [i]slender bodies[/i] and different habitats. Female has [i]small subapical and discal hyaline spots[/i], and a [i]paler[/i] ground colour than the male.
 
Low, slow flight with rapidly beating wings, in grassy clearings or stream beds close to or inside forests. May be found in dense shade with Males defend territories from perches on prominent twigs or grass leaves, and chase away intruders. Females are more sedentary, found near the males but flying more at random.

Emperor Swallowtail
[i]Papilio ophidicephalus transvaalensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Papilionidae
Subfamily: Papilioninae
Genus: [i]Papilio[/i]
Species: [i]ophidicephalus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]transvaalensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 90–140mm female 100–160mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very large, conspicuous black and yellow butterfly with well-developed spatulate tails. Largest South African butterfly. Closest in markings to Citrus Swallowtail [i]Papilio demodocus[/i] but [i]much larger and has hind wing tails[/i]. Constantine's Swallowtail [i]P. constantinus[/i] and Bush Kite [i]P. euphranor[/i] are both superficially similar but [i]lack large blue hind wing postdiscal lunules on both wing surfaces[/i]. The forewing discal band of spots varies in shape and width between the subspecies.
 
The nominate subspecies is not found in South Africa. [i]P. ophidicephalus transvaalensis[/i] has [i]wider forewing discal spots than in P. o. ayresi[/i]; more curved forewing discal band than in [i]P. o. phalusco[/i] or [i]P. o. zuluensis[/i]. Spots in areas CuA2 and CuA3 are [i]distinctly enlarged[/i]. Sexes similar; male has [i]bands of shiny scent scales[/i] on forewing between postdiscal and submarginal yellow spots. Females have varying degrees of irroration with yellow scales in these areas.
 
5 subspp., geographically distinct. Flies fast with powerful wingbeats; may stoop low
to investigate flowers. Follows gullies and roads in thick forest. Males are often seen
mud puddling; females on flowers and host plants.
 
(H) Male upperside. (I) Male underside. (J) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane and Riverine Forest in Drakensberg and Wolkberg north of Olifants River, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded; spring brood (Aug–Dec) less abundant and smaller specimens than summer brood (Jan–Apr). Broods may overlap in summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Clausena anisata, Zanthoxylum capense, Z. davyi, Z. delagoense[/i] and [i]Calodendron capense[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Swallowtails.

Brenton Blue
[i]Orachrysops niobe[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Orachrysops[/i]
Species: [i]niobe[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–38mm female 22–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Dull blue and brown 'blue'. Upperside dull violaceous blue with fuscous-brown margins. Dark hind wing upperside anal lunule [i]faint or absent[/i]. No forewing upperside cell spot. Underside of both sexes pale, warm shade of brownish-grey; postmedian series of black spots in forewing are [i]circular to slightly oval[/i], thinly outlined in white; small spots on edges of discal area of hind wing, and [i]indistinct[/i] pale hind wing postdiscal band running parallel to outer margin. Distal to this is a series of darker grey sagittate marks. Has a very small black anal spot in area CuA1, with some metallic blue scaling and a small orange lunule. This distinguishes it from Brinkman's Blue [i]Orachrysops brinkmani[/i], in which this spot is [i]always absent[/i]. Cilia plain brownish grey. Size variable, autumn brood often has dwarfs.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside dull violet-blue, marginal borders [i]broad, grey-brown[/i]. Female marginal borders much wider, blue variable in extent, tending to be brighter, [i]less violet[/i] than male.
 
Flight erratic, fairly slow and close to the ground, but fast if disturbed. Males patrol a 'beat' along a contour or line of taller bushes in the fynbos, setting occasionally but wary and difficult to approach. Females are more sedentary, found on flowers or close to the host plants; may sit sunning themselves wings open during sunny intervals on cloudy days.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.

Only at Brenton-on-Sea (W Cape) in Fynbos. Was until recently found at Nature's Valley to the east.

Habitat
Hillsides, coast.
Back to Top

Two broods, Oct–Nov and Feb–Mar; occasional stragglers in summer.

Identification
Medium-sized, dull grey Skipper with [i]conspicuous white hind wing underside[/i]. On the wing it may be mistaken for female Rufous-winged Flat [i]Eagris nottoana nottoana[/i], with which it flies, but it is [i]larger[/i] and the lacks the large hyaline blotch in forewing area CuA2.
 
Sexes similar; females have larger abdomens and more rounded wings. Rapid, dancing flight, usually 1–3m above ground level. Male defends territories around forest clearings. Several may circle around the same spot. May settle precipitately on underside of leaves, apparently disappearing into thin air. Also found on flowers, particularly those of Dune Soapberry, [i]Deinbollia oblongifolia[/i].
 
There are two seasonal forms. Wet season form [i]flesus[/i] hind wing upperside suffused with greyish white and spotted with black. (A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. Dry season form [i]ophelia[/i] upperside [i]more brownish[/i], markings [i]sparser[/i]. (C) Male upperside. (D) Female upperside. Undersides same for both forms. (E), (F) male undersides.

Coastal Lowland and Riverine Forest from E Cape (Somerset East) to KwaZulu-Natal, spreading into Afromontane Forest and heavily wooded Savanna in Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province, and further north.

alternative common name: Victor's Nimble Blue, Victor's Giant Cupid

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]victori[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 31–35mm female 32–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Brown [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Underside resembles Ketsi Blue, [i]Lepidochrysops ketsi[/i] but upperside [i]darker grey-brown[/i], margin [i]more rounded[/i], resembling Loewenstein's Blue [i]L loewensteini[/i]. As in the latter species, cilia [i]less obviously chequered[/i]; upperside forewing costa base dusted with yellow.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Found in colonies. Male flies rapidly but erratically over hillsides in restricted areas. More sedentary female flies in the same limited territory.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare and localised; only known from four small areas high up on the Groot Winterberg near Bedford, E Cape (Nama Karoo).
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, mid-Feb to end Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Selago corymbosa[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Ant Blues.

Mozambique Bar
[i]Cigaritis mozambica[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Cigaritis[/i]
Species: [i]mozambica[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–25mm female 25–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Brightly coloured Bar, the only one in South Africa to have [i]straight[/i] underside bars besides Natal Bar [i]Cigaritis natalensis[/i]. The main differences are that Mozambique Bar has [i]darker, yellower[/i] underside ground colour with [i]orange[/i] bars. Each hind wing carries a pair of thin tails with white tips at the anal angle. The male's upperside lacks the iridescent blue flush of Natal Bar, and there is no dark dry season form.
 
Sexes very similar. Females are larger with more rounded wings.
 
Unlike other Bars, found in [i]concentrated colonies[/i] on hillsides and at base of hills. Males do not hilltop but fly rapidly around grassy hillside territories, never far from host plant. Both sexes attracted strongly to flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread but localised. Grassland, and grassy Savanna, from KwaZulu-Natal coast to Drakensberg, to Swaziland, Free State, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, but more common Sept–May; peaks late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Fadogia tetraquetra[/i] and [i]Sphenostylis angustifolia[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Bars.
Back to Top






Coastal Hairstreak
[i]Hypolycaena lochmophila[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Hypolycaena[/i]
Species: [i]lochmophila[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–28mm female 23.5–31mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Similar to a sapphire but upperside [i]brown[/i], with [i]blue sheen[/i] in male. Underside superficially resembles certain [i]Iolaus[/i] species such as White-spotted and Mimosa Sapphires [i]I. lulua, I. mimosae[/i], but lines narrower. And of course the upperside is not sapphire blue. Upperside [i]darker, bluer[/i] and underside [i]paler[/i] grey than in Purple-brown Hairstreak [i]Hypolycaena philippus philippus[/i]. Forewing underside postdiscal stripe [i]bends towards body[/i] in areas M2 to CuA1 and towards outer margin in CuA2, unlike Purple-brown Hairstreak, in which it runs [i]parallel[/i] to submarginal stripe.
 
Sexes differ on upperside. Female has greater tendency to [i]pale[/i] forewing upperside discal area than female [i]H. philippus philippus[/i].
 
Shyer than [i]H. philippus philippus[/i], seldom far away from thick bush. Males perch on prominent leaves and twigs, and chase off other butterflies. Females are found on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Records exist from lowland wooded areas of KwaZulu-Natal (Hluhluwe/False Bay area to Kosi Bay and further north, inland to Makhathini Flats). The map shows where suitable habitat exists, but it is based on historical records and there has been much confusion between this species and Purple-brown Hairstreak, so it may show a wider distribution than actually exists. Current opinion has it that they are only found in the vicinity of False Bay and along the coast to the north. The species requires more study.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Nov and Mar/Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Deinbollia oblongifolia[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Hairstreaks.
Back to Top






Eyed Pansy
[i]Junonia orithya madagascariensis[/i]
alternative common name: Ox-Eyed Pansy
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Junonia[/i]
Species: [i]orithya[/i]
Subspecies: [i]madagascariensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–42mm female 40–48mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Widespread small to medium-sized butterfly, this beautiful pansy has much of the outer edges of the upperside covered in iridescent royal blue. Dry season individuals tend to have paler undersides and more extensive white markings on the upperside, but there is no marked seasonal dimorphism.
 
Slight sexual dimorphism. Female has wings more rounded, much [i]more prominent[/i] upperside ocelli. Underside cryptic.
 
Low flight, short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats, Males establish territories close to patches of open ground, and patrol these, settling often with wings slowly fanning. Fond of flowers. Under certain conditions huge numbers may emerge at one time, and hundreds may be visible on the wing.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread but usually uncommon. Mostly inland Savanna and Grassland from E Cape (Port St. Johns) to KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, Gauteng, Free State and N Cape. Has spread south and west in recent years due to a host plant shift; found as far as Cape Town.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peaks Aug–Nov, and Feb–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hygrophila[/i] spp., [i]Thunbergia alata, Plectranthus[/i] spp., [i]Antirrhinum[/i] spp., [i]Graderia subintegra[/i]., and [i]Plantago lanceolata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Pansies.
Back to Top






Swanepoel's Widow
[i]Dira swanepoeli isolata[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Dira[/i]
Species: [i]swanepoeli[/i]
Subspecies: [i]isolata[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 58–65mm, female 60–68mm.
Back to Top
Identification
The largest [i]Dira[/i] species; similar in flight pattern and habits to [i]D. oxylus[/i] but the huge gap in range between the two species makes it unmistakable. Compared to [i]D. oxylus[/i] it is fairly inactive; flight (only in the morning) low, slow, ponderous, sailing. Small groups fly together on ledges between rocky ridges among clumps of suitable tussocky grass; males circle the clumps; females are shy and inactive.
 
[i]Dira swanepoeli isolata[/i] described as having [i]extra ocellus[/i] in upperside hind wing marginal row, but individuals of nominate sometimes also exhibit this. Sexes similar, female with basal suffusion of red-brown on upperside.
 
2 subspp., geographically isolated.
 
(C) Male upperside. (D) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Only in Grassland/Afromontane forest ecotone in stunted forest interspersed with grass, on massifs in n Limpopo Province. [i]D. s. isolata[/i] on southern slopes of Blouberg.
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, late Feb and early Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae grasses, including [i]Eragrostis aspera[/i]. Bred on [i]Ehrharta erecta[/i] and [i]Cenchrus clandestinus[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Widows.

Brauer's Copper

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Aloeides[/i]
Species: [i]braueri[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–28mm female 28–32mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Pale orange [i]Aloeides[/i] copper. Has a 'washed out' appearance due to the [i]grey-brown[/i], as opposed to black, upperside markings; [i]narrow, even[/i], dark margins. Cilia chequered with white. Underside fawn to pink-brown; silver discal 'tooth' markings appear [i]faded[/i]; less well-defined than Mbulu Copper [i]A. mbuluensis[/i] or Pringle's Copper [i]A. pringlei[/i].
 
Sexes similar, female paler than male with wings rounder.
 
Found on rough, rocky hill slopes where they fly rapidly up- and downhill, settling occasionally on rocks or bare ground. Reluctant to open wings.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside (brown morph). (D) Male underside (pinkish morph).
Back to Top
Distribution
Highland hillsides covered in sour grassveld in E Cape (Cathcart area to Matatiele). Single record from n Lesotho.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, Oct–Nov and Jan–Feb.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data.
Back to Top
Group

Natal Rocksitter
[i]Durbania limbata[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbania[/i]
Species: [i]limbata[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–27mm female 24–33mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small black-and-red butterfly; upperside black with marginal band of elongated red spots. Outer half of hind wing is red. Underside cryptic, well camouflaged among pink granite rocks. [i]Smaller[/i] than similar Amakosa Rocksitter [i]Durbania amakosa[/i], with forewing red band [i]closer to margin[/i]. Male upperside has [i]glossy sheen[/i].
 
Sexes very similar. Female larger than male with broader wings and a larger abdomen.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside (female is essentially identical). (B) Male underside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland in KwaZulu-Natal Midlands (between Estcourt and Greytown, south to Balgowan), ne Free State (Harrismith) and sw Mpumalanga (Hele Mtn, near Wakkerstroom).
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Mar–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.
Back to Top

Male 23–26mm female 24–26mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, dark, blackish-brown [i]Aloeides[/i] copper. Has more [i]squarish wings[/i] than others in the Almeida Copper [i]Aloeides almeida[/i] group. Upperside of both sexes almost entirely [i]velvety dark brown with very small paler markings[/i]. Upperside fuscous colouration restricted to [i]submarginal band[/i] of small buff lunules, in male forewing apex and female hind wing. Underside darker than Susan's Copper, but spot pattern similar.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Very rare and local. Low flight, slow, close to ground. Lives in small, [i]highly concentrated[/i] colonies on hillsides.

Barber's Acraea
[i]Acraea barberi[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Heliconiinae
Genus: [i]Acraea[/i]
Species: [i]barberi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 55–66mm female 60–72mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, brightly coloured Bitter Acraea. Over part of its range it flies with Acara Acraea, [i]Acraea acara[/i], but it is easily told apart by the more extensive magenta pink (in the male). The females are more similar to each other; [i]A. barberi[/i] usually being [i]paler and more brightly coloured[/i], with more restricted dark markings and more extensive hyaline areas.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male bright magenta pink, highly conspicuous against green leaves. Female variable, duller, darker ground colour than male, more distinct yellow forewing apex on upperside, which may spread across all the wings. Forewing hyaline to variable degrees.
 
Sailing flight through or over bush as in [i]Acraea acara[/i]. Fond of flowers, eg [i]Clerodendrum glabrum[/i] and [i]Ozoroa[/i] spp.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C), (D) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Hilly, wooded Savanna in Gauteng, Limpopo (Magaliesberg, Waterberg, Blouberg and surrounding hills) and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continually brooded from Sept–Dec, peaks Oct and Feb. Stragglers may be seen as late as Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Adenia glauca[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Bitter Acraeas.

Boland Rocksitter
[i]Durbaniopsis saga[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbaniopsis[/i]
Species: [i]saga[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–39mm female 29–40mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to very small Rocksitter. Upperside brown, markings [i]dull cream[/i] or [i]buff[/i]. Underside is [i]more variegated[/i] than other Rocksitters, marbled grey, brown and black colouration forming [i]distinct bands[/i], which sets it apart from the other Rocksitter that flies in the same areas, Clark's Rocksitter [i]Durbaniella clarki[/i]. Like other Rocksitters, the underside resembles lichen on rock, and provides camouflage.
 
Sexes similar; females usually much larger than males and [i]paler[/i] on the upperside, with [i]pale basal suffusion[/i] on all wings.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C), (D) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
In Fynbos, Nama Karoo, and Succulent Karoo over a wide area of inland W Cape and N Cape mountains, from Nieuwoudtville Mtns south to Cederberg, Koue Bokkeveld, Hex River and Hawequas Mtns. Also low-altitude sites from Lambert's Bay inland to Het Kruis.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Oct–Dec, as early as Sept at lower altitudes.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.
Back to Top






Purple Gem
[i]Chloroselas mazoensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chloroselas[/i]
Species: [i]mazoensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 20–24mm female 22–25mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny lycaenid; when examined close up the only species that can be confused with it is Brilliant Gem, [i]Chloroselas pseudozeritis pseudozeritis[/i]. Apart from the differences in the male uppersides, the undersides of both sexes can be told apart by the [i]pale, grey-buff[/i] colour of Purple Gem, carrying [i]smaller, less well-defined[/i] brassy centred spots. Each hind wing carries a pair of thin tails with white tips at the anal angle.
 
Sexually dimorphic. The male upperside has a [i]deep purple sheen[/i] over a dark brown ground colour. This is less metallic than the blue-green of Brilliant Gem, but as in that species, the colour is only visible when viewed under light coming from the correct acute angle. Female is plain [i]dull-brown[/i] above, [i]lacking the buff or blue scaling[/i] of Brilliant Gem.
 
Habits similar to Bars, High-fliers and Scarlets but small size and rapid flight makes them difficult to spot amongst the hordes of tiny Babul Blues ([i]Azanus[/i] sp.) and Hairtails ([i]Anthene[/i] sp.) with which they habitually fly. Occasionally in strong colonies, but more often found singly.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rarer, more localised than Brilliant Gem. Wooded Savanna in n KwaZulu-Natal (Lebombo foothills and Makhathini Flats), Mpumalanga, and Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Main brood Sept–Dec, small May/Jun emergence in n KwaZulu-Natal.
Back to Top
Larval food
Possibly young shoots of [i]Vachellia[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Gems.

Autumn-leaf Vagrant
[i]Afrodryas leda[/i]
alternative common name: Orange-and-Lemon Butterfly
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Afrodryas[/i]
Species: [i]leda[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–50mm female 48–56mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Brightly coloured, large Pierid. Bright yellow, male with orange wing tips that can only be mistaken for the male of the [i]much smaller[/i] Sulphur Orange Tip, [i]Colotis auxo[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic; the female lacks the pure solid orange tip of the male, and there
are three seasonal forms, as shown, with varying amounts of orange in the forewing tip, 
which has a narrow black margin and four to five submarginal black spots. Females usually
have a row of postdiscal silvery white spots on the hind wing underside; there is a large
one in area M2.
 
Flight fast and direct, stopping seldom, unless at flowers (usually orange or red, but they are fond of [i]Plumbago[/i]) to nectar.
 
Nominate wet season form [i]leda[/i]; female has no trace of orange in the forewing tip: (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
 
Intermediate form [i]pupillata[/i] female has a trace of orange in the forewing tip: (D) Female upperside.
 
Dry season form [i]trimeni[/i] has full orange tip in the female, and silvery-white hind wing underside spots: (E) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Wooded Savanna and Lowland Forest from E Cape (East London) along coast and inland to Swaziland, through thorn belt in KwaZulu-Natal and dry Savanna forests along base of escarpment, and edges of riverine bush in Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall. Peaks late summer and autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Capparis tomentosa[/i] and [i]C. tomentosa[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Vagrants.

Kalahari Orange Tip
[i]Colotis lais[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Colotis[/i]
Species: [i]lais[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
30–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small white Pierid with dull brownish orange upperside forewing tips. Both sexes resemble forms of Bushveld Orange Tip [i]Colotis pallene[/i], but upperside apical orange has [i]brownish[/i] tinge, male always lacks 'moustache', female apical orange patch [i]not broken into cells[/i]. Underside similar to Bushveld Orange Tip in all forms.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male upperside plain white with dark-edged orange tip and black hind wing upperside marginal spots. Female upperside has [i]wider dark border[/i] around forewing orange tip; dark 'moustache' mark (in wet season form) and dark marks in the discal area of the hind wing.
 
Fast, low flight, seldom settling, wary and difficult to approach. Both sexes fly at random, often visiting flowers. Not found in large numbers.
 
Seasonally dimorphic; wet season f. [i]lais[/i] has heavy dark markings in both sexes and resembles Bushveld Orange Tip. Hind wing underside plain white, or faintly irrorated with grey scales. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
 
Dry season f. [i]felthami[/i] male has [i]almost no[/i] upperside dark markings; those of female [i]much reduced[/i], to spots on the hind wing. Hind wing underside ground colour pale pink, irrorated with grey scales. (E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside. (G) Female upperside. (H) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Arid Savanna in N Cape from Richtersveld to Windsorton and Vryburg, north into Kalahari region and Botswana; also NW Province near Carletonville, and Limpopo Province on northern side of Waterberg from Thabazimbi to Marken.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall. WSF Oct–Mar. Scarcer DSF Apr–Sept.
Back to Top
Larval food
Probably Capparaceae.
Back to Top
Group
Tips.
