Long-horned Swift
[i]Borbo fatuellus fatuellus[/i]
alternative common name: Long-horned Skipper
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Borbo[/i]
Species: [i]fatuellus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]fatuellus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 33–42mm female 40–43mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small dark Skipper. Upperside blackish-brown with small hyaline spots on forewing. Has [i]no spots in the forewing cell or on the hind wing[/i]. Hind wing underside ground colour brown; has [i]white spots[/i] in areas CuA1 M3 and Rs. There is some seasonal variation; dry season form [i]cinerea[/i] has pale grey scaling in hind wing underside discal area. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Very similar to False Swift [i]Borbo fallax[/i] but that species has [i]two well marked hyaline spots in forewing cell[/i].
 
Sexes similar; female has more rounded wings and stouter abdomen.
 
Very rapid, zooming flight no more than 1–2metres above the ground. Males form territories along forest edges and paths, in clearings and along stream beds. They vigorously pursue intruders. They can be very numerous and groups of up to a dozen can be seen chasing one another. Females fly near the males but are slower; found more at random, searching for places to lay their eggs.
 
Wet season form [i]fatuellus[/i]: (A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. Dry season form [i]cinerea[/i]: (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread and common in coastal Lowland Forest and wooded Savanna from E Cape (East
London) to Swaziland and along coast to n KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga and Limpopo
Province lowveld, far ne Gauteng, and further north.

Habitat
Forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Nov–Feb; f. [i]cinerea[/i] peak Jun–Aug.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Ehrharta erecta[/i] and [i]Setaria sulcata[/i].

Boland Skolly
[i]Thestor protumnus aridus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]protumnus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]aridus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–37.5mm female 24–42.5mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small butterfly conspicuously [i]buff[/i] upperside and forewing underside, bordered with [i]grey-brown[/i] and having chequered cilia, the amount of contrast varying. Colour varies between subspecies, and within populations can range from bright cartridge-buff to a darker tawny-buff. Upperside and forewing underside carry variable number of dark spots, depending on subspecies and varying within populations. Hind wing underside has cryptic pattern of basal, postdiscal and marginal bands of darker scaling on a grey-brown ground; depth of colour varies between subspecies.
 
Slight sexual dimorphism. Male smaller than female. Male upperside buff with grey-brown margins and rows of black spots; forewing carries [i]prominent sex brand[/i], coloured dark brown to grey-brown in basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Female usually brighter buff than male, with [i]rounded[/i] not [i]pointed[/i] wings. [i]T. p. aridus[/i] is paler than nominate with [i]more extensive[/i] upperside buff; desert form f. [i]mijburghi[/i] is very pale buff with black spots restricted to cells in female; male also has faint black apical spots. Amount of white in cilia varies.
 
3 subspp., geographically distinct; varying in size and colour.
 
id.
 
[i]T. protumnus[/i] lives in discrete colonies in flat country and on hillsides. These probably coincide with colonies of the host ant, a Pugnacious Ant, [i]Anaplolepis[/i] sp. Flight is low and fluttering but can be fast and sustained. Males are territorial and congregate around patches of bare gravelly or sandy soil; females fly around inspecting plants for the presence of their host ants. Should she find this she will lay one or two eggs.
 
(F) Male upperside. (G) Female upperside. (H) (I) Male undersides. (J) (K) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widely distributed. Nama and Succulent Karoo in W Cape and N Cape (Burgersdorp to Vanrhynsdorp, Namaqualand, Garies, Steinkopf n to Namibian border), e to N Cape (Kimberley area).
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Aug–Oct.
Back to Top
Larval food
Recorded on coccids (Homoptera), but full life history unknown.
Back to Top
Group
Skollies.

Common Diadem
[i]Hypolimnas misippus[/i]
Contents

Identification
Models

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Hypolimnas[/i]
Species: [i]misippus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 60–65mm female 70–80mm.
Back to Top
Identification
The most widespread Diadem in Africa. A large, conspicuous Nymphaline, the male is unmistakable with his jet-black upperside with iridescent violet-blue ringed white discal blotches.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Females are orange-tawny with black margins and markings similar to those of various forms of the African Monarch, [i]Danaus chrysippus[/i]. She is easy to tell apart on close inspection; her build is more robust; her antennae are carried more stiffly and are [i]straight[/i], not angled downwards. And the wings' outer margins are [i]scalloped[/i], not smooth as in [i]D. chrysippus[/i].
 
There is more than one female form, mimicking the three [i]D. chrysippus[/i] subspecies found in South Africa, and ones found elsewhere. Form [i]misippus[/i] resembles [i]D. chrysippus orientis[/i]. F. [i]alcippoides[/i] resembles [i]D. chrysippus alcippus[/i]. F. [i]inaria[/i] resembles D. [i]chrysippus dorippus[/i], and f. [i]dorippoides[/i] resembles D. [i]chrysippus dorippus[/i] but has the white hind wing patch of D. [i]chrysippus alcippus[/i].
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside f. [i]misippus[/i]. (D) Female underside f. [i]misippus[/i]. (E) Female upperside f. [i]alcippoides[/i]. (F) Female underside f. [i]alcippoides[/i]. (G) Female upperside f. [i]inaria[/i]. (H) Female underside f. [i]inaria[/i]. (I) Female upperside f. [i]dorippoides[/i]. (J) Female underside f. [i]dorippoides[/i].
 
Models
African Monarch females. [i]D. chrysippus orientis, D, chrysippus alcippus and D. chrysippus dorippus[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
Common in warmer areas of all biomes; rare in fynbos and Karoo regions.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak late summer (winter in tropical areas).
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Asystasia gangetica, Portulaca[/i] spp. (including [i]P. foliosa[/i] and [i]P. oleracea), Talinium[/i] spp. and [i]Ageratum houstonianum[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Diadems.

Identification
The male of this Bitter Acraea is a very conspicuous deep, pure red, making him one of our most noticeable butterflies.
 
Sexually dimorphic; female duller, varying from blackish ochre-brown to brown-red, with white forewing upperside subapical patches. Flight slow and fluttering.

Large brown lycaenid with chequered fulvous orange-and-black discal panel on forewing upperside. Short double tail at hind wing anal angle. Underside hind wing silvery white markings [i]smaller and more rounded[/i].
 
Sexes similar, female [i]larger, paler[/i] than male.

Duke's Skolly
[i]Thestor brachycera dukei[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]brachycera[/i]
Subspecies: [i]dukei[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 27–36mm female 29–39mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small grey-brown butterfly with a small whitish apical patch, a black spot at the distal end of the cell, and in most individuals, a pair of white streaks just distal to the cell. It has rows of prominent discal black spots on both wings. Underside marked in grey and black. Forewing has black spots corresponding to those on upperside, on a pale grey ground. Hind wing has darker grey spots, outlined in black, corresponding to the upperside black spots. Hind wing ground colour mid grey irrorated with dark grey.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male has more distinct whitish streaks distal to forewing upperside cell. Has pale grey-brown tridentate sex brand, restricted to origin of veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Female with [i]more prominent[/i] forewing white patch on upperside, wings more rounded than male. [i]T. b. dukei[/i] is darker than nominate on the upperside, and the forewing underside line of discal spots is [i]not[/i] broken at M2.
 
[i]T. brachycera[/i] lives in small colonies. Fast, low flight, settling on rocks or low plants. Males form territories in open areas. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers. [i]T. brachycera brachycera[/i] is found close to the coast at low altitude. [i]T. brachycera dukei[/i] is found inland at higher altitude, on gentle rocky slopes covered in rocks and small plants.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Female upperside. (G) Male underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Karoo and Fynbos, along Langeberg from Die Koo to Montagu; along Swartberg and Elandsberg to Outeniqua Mtns, and along s W Cape coast from Kogelberg to Stanford.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges, hillsides, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Dec–Jan.
Back to Top
Larval food
Larvae found inside Pugnacious Ant [i]Anoplolepis custodiens[/i] nests, but no data on food.

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Dira[/i]
Species: [i]clytus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]clytus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
45–52mm.
Back to Top
Identification
A dark butterfly that, like all of the genus [i]Dira[/i], is usually found swarming in large numbers where its host plants grow. The most widespread of the genus; may be found in suburban gardens and overgrown pastures where Kikuyu Grass [i]Cenchrus clandestinus[/i] is found.
 
Sexes similar, but female paler. Females are seldom seen because they are reluctant to take to wing. There are two subspecies, geographically separated.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Often very common, especially in thick patches of kikuyu. In Fynbos in
south-western part of range, and Nama Karoo, Grassland and grassy Savanna further
ne. Near sea level in the south, but also at higher altitudes to north and east. Nominate from W Cape (Cape Peninsula, where common in autumn) to E Cape (Humansdorp).
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast, hillsides, parks and gardens.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded: nominate late Feb–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae grasses, including [i]Ehrharta erecta, Cenchrus clandestinus, Stipa dregeana[/i] and [i]Stenotaphrum secundatum[/i].

Identification
A dark brown butterfly that may appear black in flight, but the pale forewing apical patch is prominent. May fly close to, and at same time of year, as Cape Autumn Widow [i]Dira clytus[/i] but is usually found higher up and is more localised.
 
Usually found within stands of coarse [i]Merxmuellera[/i] grasses. Flight slow, fluttering and sailing short distances. Settles often, but wary of close approach.
 
Nominate [i]Torynesis mintha mintha[/i] has similar hind wing underside markings to other [i]Torynesis[/i]. Sexes similar, but female has longer wings and stouter abdomen, pale markings more distinct. Female reluctant to fly, less often seen. 2 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.

Fynbos, Nama Karoo. In W Cape, in grass patches in Fynbos/Karoo vegetation. Nominate in sw W Cape, from mountains to sea level (Cape Peninsula across the Cape Flats to Riebeek-Kasteel and Sir Lowry's Pass, down to Cape Agulhas).

Grassveld Sandman
[i]Spialia agylla agylla[/i]
Contents

Classification

Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Spialia[/i]
Species: [i]agylla[/i]
Subspecies: [i]agylla[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 20–22mm female 22–24mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very small pied Skipper with black-and-white chequered upperside and forewing underside. One of a group of very similar little butterflies, which are difficult to tell apart from the upperside markings. To be reasonably sure of identification a clear view of the hind wing underside is necessary. Similar to Star Sandman [i]Spialia asterodia[/i], but upperside and underside [i]more heavily marked with white[/i]. Irregular hind wing underside white median band, unlike Star Sandman, [i]does not run parallel[/i] to basal spots. Hind wing underside median band connected to large submarginal spot by [i]thin white line[/i] in cell, similar to the much smaller Mite Sandman [i]S. paula[/i]. Cilia chequered.
 
Nominate subspecies [i]S. agylla agylla[/i] has restricted pale upper and underside markings; hind wing underside essentially [i]brown with white bands and spots[/i]. Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Fast, buzzing, low flight, settling often, wings open. Male more often on ledges and ridges than hill tops, female near host plants. Both sexes fond of flowers, particularly [i]Mesembryanthemum[/i] vygies.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassy hillsides in Nama Karoo, from W Cape (but not extreme south) to s N Cape, across w E Cape, Grassland of Free State, e Lesotho, s Gauteng, sw Mpumalanga, Arid Savanna in NW Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, mountains, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Several broods, Aug–Apr, peaks midsummer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hermannia[/i] spp. and [i]Pavonia burchellii[/i].

Species: [i]dulcis[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 19–23mm female 21–24mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small Hairtail with grey-brown upperside. Pale grey-buff underside crossed by irregular stripes of darker grey, outlined in white.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male identified by upperside brassy violet-blue forewing patch, only visible from certain angles. It covers inner margin and basal part of cell, areas 1A+2A and CuA1 [i]but not[/i] CuA2. Female upperside almost impossible to distinguish from other females of Trimen's Hairtail [i]A. otacilia[/i] group. As with female Trimen's and Talbot's [i]A. talboti[/i] Hairtails, amount of upperside basal blue varies from none at all, to a small basal patch. Underside of both sexes similar, [i]lacks forewing basal black stripe[/i] of Black-striped Hairtail [i]A. amarah amarah[/i], with which it often flies.
 
Rapid flight; small size makes it difficult to follow. Whirls around tree tops with other small lycaenids; also around low-growing flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

Mithras Opal
[i]Chrysoritis thysbe mithras[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]thysbe[/i]
Subspecies: [i]mithras[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 23–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of a large group of [i]Chrysoritis[/i] Opals with [i]blue wing bases[/i] and a [i]shimmering, electric opalescent sheen[/i] over a varying area of the wings. For [i]Chrysoritis thysbe[/i], amount of blue on upperside varies, in some subspecies almost covering the forewing. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside varies from plain sandy tan to dark brown, to [i]variegated[/i] with striae in various shades of reddish-brown, with bands of paler colouring and brassy postdiscal streaks. 'Plain' underside specimens usually have unicoloured cilia; 'variegated' ones dark cilia with pale interneural flecks, appearing 'chequered'.
 
[i]C. t. mithras[/i] has upperside solid blue darker than in [i]C. thysbe thysbe[/i] or [i]C. thysbe whitei[/i] and seldom extends beyond the forewing cell spot. Cilia orange with small pale interneural spots and black vein ends. Hind wing underside is variegated in dark brown and cream, with silvery white streaks. Sexes differ. Female has [i]rounder wings[/i], upperside blue [i]restricted to basal 25% of wings[/i], no opalescent sheen. The females of the various races are almost impossible to separate on wing patterns and identification usually requires comparison with males seen at the same locality.
 
7 subspp., not always geographically distinct. Rapid, sustained flight, settling on prominent bushes or rocks. Male intensively territorial on hill tops or sand dunes, regularly patrolling and chasing intruders; Females are found more at random, often on flowers.
 
(R) Male upperside. (S) Female upperside. (T) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos-covered hills and dunes, Stilbaai to Brenton-on-Sea, W Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, flatlands, mountains, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Osteospermum moniliferum[/i]. No ant association recorded.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.

Medium-sized dark swordtail with [i]greenish[/i]- to lemon-cream stripes and spots, and long straight tails. Pondo Charaxes
[i]Charaxes pondoensis[/i]
alternative common name: Pondo Emperor

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]pondoensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–55mm female 48–60mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to medium-sized Charaxes. Male upperside jet black, [i]more sombre[/i] than Satyr Charaxes [i]Charaxes ethalion ethalion[/i], forewing costal spot often absent. Has no iridescent sheen over the black on the hind wing. Hind wing marginal band narrow and brown changing to ochre towards the anal angle. Underside distinguished from [i]C. ethalion ethalion[/i] and Karkloof Charaxes [i]C. karkloof[/i] by having [i]silvery grey[/i], not brownish, underside, with more marbled appearance. Female resembles [i]C. ethalion ethalion[/i] f. [i]aurantimaculata[/i], hind wing has [i]less extensive[/i] bluish iridescence surrounding white median band.
 
Sexually dimorphic, only one female form, unlike [i]C. ethalion ethalion[/i].
 
Fast, agile, high flight. Males territorial in forest canopy and nearby hilltops, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly more slowly, low along the fringes of forests where they settle on tree leaves.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees. They are also often seen drinking from wet mud.
 
(A) Male showing upper and underside. (B) Female showing upper and underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare. Riverine Forest and dense Lowland Forest in coastal lowlands of E Cape (Mazeppa Bay to Embotyi).

Back to Top

Identification
Large, conspicuous black and yellow butterfly. The only black Papilionid with pale yellow spots found in South Africa with [i]no hind wing tails[/i]. This distinguishes it from other butterflies such as Constantine's Swallowtail [i]Papilio constantinus[/i], Emperor Swallowtail [i]P. ophidicephalus[/i] and Bush Kite [i]P. euphranor[/i].
 
Sexes very similar. A pale crescent, distal to the hind wing costal upperside eye spot, [i]yellow[/i] on male, is [i]suffused with red[/i] on the female.
 
Common garden butterfly; has fast, fluttering flight, attracted to flowers, particularly red ones. Male also circles hill tops, floating around, seldom perching.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.(C) Female underside.

Common and widespread throughout South Africa, particularly in wooded areas and gardens; absent from extremely arid areas.

Scarce Mountain Copper
[i]Trimenia malagrida cedrusmontana[/i]
alternative common name: Cederberg Copper
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification

Habitat

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Trimenia[/i]
Species: [i]malagrida[/i]
Subspecies: [i]cedrusmontana[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–27mm Female 29–33mm.
Back to Top
Identification
[i]More dainty[/i] than other [i]Trimenia[/i] species. The wings are less [i]acutely pointed[/i], especially in the male; there is less difference between the sexes. The typical [i]Trimenia[/i] upperside pattern of more or less bright fulvous-orange on the upperside with dark borders, and black-and-white chequered cilia, is continued in this species. The undersides are slightly different, in that the hind wing silvery marks are [i]cursive[/i] as in Wallengren's Silver-spotted Copper, but form a more coherent pattern with a [i]large '3'- or 'W'-shaped postdiscal line[/i] and a central roughly triangular blotch. There are two underside colour morphs, brown-and-tan, and wine-red.
 
[i]T. malagrida cedrusmontana[/i]: has no dark veining and the dark upperside margins are [i]extensive and well-defined[/i]; the orange is a deep red shade. Sexes very similar, females generally larger, paler orange, heavier bodied.
 
4 subspp., geographically distinct, all rare. Found in small, discrete colonies; flight rapid but not sustained; males select a prominent perch on a low plant or rock and chase away intruders. Females are found more at random, often on flowers.
 
(G) Male upperside. (H) Male underside (red morph). (I) Female underside (red morph). (J) Male underside (brown morph).

W Cape Fynbos in Cederberg and Skurweberg.

Single-brooded, late Jan–Mar.

No data.

Overberg Skolly

Contents

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]overbergensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 33–38mm female 44mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small charcoal-grey butterfly with a hint of brown. Compared to Knysna Skolly [i]Thestor brachycera[/i], larger (largest of group) with [i]darker[/i] upperside, more conspicuous white cilia chequered with black at the vein ends. Underside forewing discal band [i]lacks[/i] prominent break at M2. Upperside darker than Claassens' Skolly [i]T. claassensi[/i], lacking the prominent golden brown markings of that species. Underside of both sexes cryptic, forewing carries prominent submarginal sagittate marks.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male has more distinct whitish streaks distal to forewing upperside cell. Has pale grey-brown tridentate sex brand, restricted to origin of veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Female is [i]plainer[/i] and more uniformly dark than that of [i]T. brachycera[/i]. Underside [i]more brown[/i] than that of the male.
 
[i]T. overbergensis[/i] lives in colonies on limestone ridges in fynbos. Fast, low flight, settling on rocks or low plants. Males form territories in open areas. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Tarucus[/i]
Species: [i]sybaris[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–26mm female 20–27mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright blue lycaenid (in male). The only member of the [i]Tarucus[/i] genus [i]in[/i] South Africa to carry a hind wing tail. Underside (both sexes) stark white, [i]polka-dotted[/i] with black. Distinguished from White [i]Tuxentius calice calice[/i] and Black [i]T. melaena[/i] Pies by underside having [i]regular rows of black apical spots separate[/i] where the Pies have a bar. Distinguished from Hintza Pierrot [i]Zintha hintza hintza[/i] by [i]even[/i] pattern of black dots on the underside, and dots where Hintza Pierrot has a [i]submarginal row of short bars[/i]. Cilia are [i]not conspicuously chequered[/i].
 
Sexes dimorphic; male upperside brilliant sky-blue, female dark grey-brown with [i]white discal areas[/i] spotted with grey-brown, [i]only blue at wing bases[/i]. [i]Tarucus sybaris linearis[/i] has upperside dark marginal band [i]reduced[/i]; blue ground colour in male separated from margin by [i]thinner black marginal line[/i] than nominate.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight slow, low, usually close to host plant.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Female upperside. (F) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common in grassy Savanna and Grassland. Nominate in E Cape, KwaZulu-Natal, e Free State, Gauteng, Mpumalanga and Limpopo and NW provinces. [i]Tarucus s. linearis[/i] in Arid Savanna in N Cape and w Free State.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Nov–Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Ziziphus[/i] spp., including Z [i]zeyheriana[/i] and [i]Z. mucronata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Blues.

Blouberg Forest King Charaxes
[i]Charaxes xiphares staudei[/i]
alternative common name: Blouberg Forest King Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]xiphares[/i]
Subspecies: [i]staudei[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–80mm female 70–95mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, dark Charaxes. In certain parts of its range, males can be confused with
Blue-Spotted Charaxes, [i]Charaxes cithaeron cithaeron[/i]. However, that species
has [i]much broader[/i] hind wing upperside pale patch, almost totally white. The
postdiscal series of forewing royal blue marks are [i]smaller[/i] in [i]C. xiphares[/i].
Females are distinctive. [i]C. x. staudei[/i] male smaller than [i]C. x. bavenda[/i] with
shorter tails, forewing upperside postdiscal spots [i]larger[/i]. Forewing underside pale
discal marks [i]larger[/i] than in [i]C. x. bavenda[/i]. Hind wing underside markings
generally more reduced and obscured than in [i]C. x. bavenda[/i]; basal black lines
usually absent. Female [i]smaller[/i] than [i]C. x. bavenda[/i] with larger forewing
upperside discal spots, particularly that in area CuA1 which is greatly elongated. The hind wing discal patch is generally smaller than in [i]C. x. bavenda[/i]. There are three female forms. Nominate upperside has white forewing discal spots and hind wing discal patch white suffused with lavender. In f. [i]arikae[/i] the hind wing discal patch is with yellow, and in [i]louisae[/i] the hind wing patch is blue.
 
Sexes strongly dimorphic, male with [i]royal blue[/i] spots and bands on metallic navy ground, female with [i]white discal forewing band[/i] (of variable width) sometimes invaded by yellow-ochre. Most females have a pale yellow hind wing upperside patch, but in some populations, it is blue-white or pale mauve. Differences between females is usually of more value than subtle differences between the males in distinguishing subspecies.
 
Powerful, high flight in the canopy and around tree tops. Males territorial, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly rapidly along the fringes of forests where they settle on tree leaves.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
8 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(AH) Male upperside. (AI) Male underside. (AJ) Female upperside f. [i]staudei[/i]. (AK) Female upperside f. [i]arikae[/i]. (AL) Female upperside f. [i]louisae[/i]. (AM) Female underside (all forms the same).
Back to Top
Distribution
Pockets of Afromontane Forest on Blouberg massif Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Cryptocarya woodii, Scutia myrtina, Rhamnus prinoides[/i] and [i]Chaetachme aristata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Charaxes.
Back to Top

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Harpendyreus[/i]
Species: [i]notoba[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–27mm female 27–29mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small dull blue or brown lycaenid. Both sexes have chequered dark grey and white cilia. Underside of both sexes pale brown, with series of joined spots of same colour, edged in white, giving a 'netted' appearance. In its range there are few butterflies with similar colouring and markings.
 
Sexes dimorphic; male upperside [i]dull violaceous-blue[/i], female [i]grey-brown[/i] with [i]mauve[/i] basal colouring.
 
Found in scattered colonies, wherever host plant grows. May be locally numerous. Female never strays far from host plant except to mate. Male defends territories on nearby koppies.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Nama Karoo, Savanna, Arid Savanna, Grassland. From n E Cape (Cradock area), through central Karoo and s Free State, to s Gauteng, s NW Province and further north; also in N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Aug–May, peak Sept/Oct.
Back to Top
Larval food
Flowers and immature seeds of [i]Salvia radula[/i] and [i]S. verbenaca[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Blues.

Variable Diadem
[i]Hypolimnas anthedon wahlbergi[/i]
Contents

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Hypolimnas[/i]
Species: [i]anthedon[/i]
Subspecies: [i]wahlbergi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 75–80mm female 75–90mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large butterfly with wings-shaped like those of Common Diadem [i]Hypolimnas misippus[/i]. Upperside black with pale markings, which are repeated on the underside, on a brown ground. Two distinct forms. They both mimic [i]Amauris[/i] Friars. Can be told apart by More [i]robust[/i] build, [i]straighter, stiffer[/i] antennae and [i]scalloped wing edges[/i].
 
Sexes are similar in both forms.
 
Flight high, powerful and direct. Male territorial at edge of forest canopy, perching high on a leaf, chasing other butterflies; female usually at flowers high on trees. Often found along forest streams where there is a break in the canopy. Roosts in holes under tree roots.
 
Form [i]wahlbergi[/i] has large discal white patches on both wings, and broad white forewing apical patches. F. [i]mima[/i] has series of [i]white[/i] discal, subapical and apical dots on the forewing. Hind wing has a [i]yellow[/i] discal patch with [i]white[/i] submarginal spots.
 
(A) Male upperside f. [i]mima[/i]. (B) Female upperside [i]mima[/i]. (C) Female underside [i]mima[/i]. (D) Male upperside f. [i]wahlbergi[/i]. (E) Male underside f. [i]wahlbergi[/i].
Models
Friar [i]Amauris niavius dominicanus[/i] (for f. [i]wahlbergi[/i]); Layman [i]Amauris albimaculata albimaculata[/i] (for f. [i]mima[/i]).
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread from E Cape (East London) to n KwaZulu-Natal coast (Kosi Bay). Lower-escarpment Afromontane and Riverine Forest into Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, gullies, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Laportea peduncularis, Urera cameroonensis[/i] and [i]U. hypsilodendron[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Diadems.
Back to Top






Lemon Traveller
[i]Teracolus subfasciatus[/i]
alternative common name: Lemon Tip; Lemon Traveller Tip
Contents

Classification
Wingspan

Distribution

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Teracolus[/i]
Species: [i]subfasciatus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–52mm female 48–55mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Distinctive medium–large white Pierid. Yellow ground colour and [i]falcate forewing tip[/i] is unique; there are other yellow Pierids with orange upperside forewing tips. Autumn-leaf Vagrant [i]Afrodryas leda[/i] is larger and [i]deeper yellow[/i] with [i]rounded wings[/i]. Male Sulphur Orange Tip [i]Colotis auxo[/i] is smaller, has [i]no brown in the tip colour[/i], and also has [i]rounded wings[/i]. There is some seasonal dimorphism; in the wet season form [i]subfasciatus[/i] predominates (as illustrated). In the dry season, or in arid areas, form [i]ganymedes[/i] is found, which has [i]reduced dark markings in the forewing tip[/i]; the basal band not reaching the margin. Underside [i]pale green finely striated with pale grey-brown[/i]; white-edged darker line [i]crosses hind wing[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male ground colour [i]deep lemon-yellow[/i]; has grey-black tip centred with yellow, flame-like blue sheen covers the tip; deep black mark runs along basal edge towards margin. Female [i]paler lemon-yellow[/i], with wing tip [i]brown where male is black or grey[/i], apical patch [i]burnt-orange[/i].
 
Male patrols open country with [i]very rapid[/i], sustained flight, settling seldom. Female more sedentary, less often seen, usually on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare in thorn belt and Maputaland of n KwaZulu-Natal; commoner in Savanna of Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, Arid Savanna in N Cape and Savanna/Grassland ecotone of Gauteng and ne Free State.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas; WSF Oct–Mar, with peaks Dec–Feb; DSF Apr–Sept.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Boscia albitrunca[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Tips.

Compassberg Skolly
[i]Thestor compassbergae[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]compassbergae[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–29mm female 27–30mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small buff butterfly. Male upperside forewing tips least heavily marked of the Compassberg Skolly group. Underside hind wing of both sexes pale grey with indistinct basal band and faint submarginal row of 'V'-shaped marks joined into a line. Has a dark, zigzag median line bent towards the margin between veins M1 and M3.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male has [i]very broad[/i] marginal borders. Tridentate sex brand is grey-buff; restricted to veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Underside hind wing pale grey with darker grey basal and postdiscal bands; median line darker, better defined than female (cf. [i]T. pringlei[/i], Female is a more typical buff [i]Thestor[/i] type, with more pale colouring on wings. Dark bands heavy; shade of buff varies from dull buff to bright orange-buff.
 
[i]T. compassbergae[/i] lives in colonies, usually on high, north-east facing mountain slopes, between large rocks and on ridges. Fast, low flight, settling on rocks or low plants. Males form territories in areas of gravel. Difficult to follow in flight; when settled, superbly camouflaged underside hard to spot. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassy inclusions in Nama Karoo on mountain slopes of Kompasberg, above Nieu-Bethesda, E Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, mid-Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data.
Back to Top
Group
Skollies.

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Sarangesa[/i]
Species: [i]ruona[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–42mm female 40–43mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small mid brown Skipper with darker brown or grey-brown markings on upperside, Upperside closely resembles Forest Elfin [i]Sarangesa motozi[/i] form [i]pertusa[/i]; hyaline spot in hind wing cell [i]replaced by squared-off pale spot[/i]. Underside [i]less contrasting[/i] than Forest Elfin; ground colour ochre-yellow with darker ochreous brown bands of discal and submarginal spots.
 
Sexes similar, female has larger, stouter abdomen.
 
Low flight among leaf litter on the ground, fast moving and well camouflaged against the background. Can be very difficult to spot when it sits wings open among dead leaves. Occasionally found roosting in numbers in caves and aardvark holes in hot dry Savanna.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Marginal in South Africa. Only in thickly wooded Savanna and Lowland Forest in nw parts of Limpopo Province lowveld east of Wolkberg, n and e of Soutpansberg. Single record from Maputaland (KwaZulu-Natal).

Twin Dotted Border
[i]Mylothris rueppellii haemus[/i]
alternative common name: Rueppell’s Dotted Border
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Mylothris[/i]
Species: [i]rueppellii[/i]
Subspecies: [i]haemus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 48–55mm female 50–56mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–large white and orange Pierid. As common name implies, wing edges have black spots at the end of veins - variable in appearance, less prominent in dry season specimens. Can be told apart from other [i]Mylothris[/i] Dotted Borders by the orange basal forewing flush [i]on both surfaces of both sexes' forewings[/i]. Certain female forms of False Dotted Border [i]Belenois thysa[/i] also have basal forewing upperside colour flush, but they can immediately be told apart by the [i]double row of hind wing black spots[/i] on upper and undersides. Other white Pierids with white wings carrying a basal orange flush are certain female forms of Large Vagrant [i]N. argia[/i], but those are [i]much larger[/i] and have [i]more extensive dark marginal marks[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic, female upperside orange is paler and of a more yellow hue than the male, and covering at least the basal half of both wings, not just the basal third of the forewing.
 
Slow, fluttering flight, often high in forest canopy near host plants; both sexes fond of flowers; may also be found low down along forest paths and rides.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside. (E), (F) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Wooded Savanna, coastal Lowland and Riverine Forest from King William's Town (E Cape) to Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal, Limpopo Province, Mpumalanga, NW Province and n Gauteng (Magaliesberg and Witwatersrand - Krugersdorp).
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast, hillsides, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct and late Feb–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Erianthemum dregei, Tapinanthus oleifolius[/i] and [i]T. rubromarginatus[/i], [i]Ximenia caffra[/i].
Back to Top

Dotted Borders.

[i]Warm bright red-orange[/i] Opal. Squared-off forewing tips similar in shape to many of the 'blue' Opals such as Brooks's Opal [i]C. brooksi[/i]; outer margin strongly angled outwards at vein M3. Underside hind wing heavily marked with bands of [i]dark red-brown and cream[/i], streaked with brassy metallic spots; again similar to the 'blue' Opals.
 
[i]C. palmus margueritae[/i] is [i]darker[/i] on both wing surfaces than nominate. Sexes similar, female larger, wings rounder.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Occurs in large numbers in small areas. Both sexes fond of yellow [i]Compositae[/i] flowers; settle often on bracken. Fast flight but usually not sustained.

Distinctive dark blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. In both sexes the black upperside markings are heavier than other Blues in this group. Underside ground colour is [i]darker brown[/i], with distinctive [i]deeply sagittate[/i] white submarginal marks.

Identification
Markings similar to Dark Opal [i]Chrysoritis nigricans[/i], but wings [i]less angular[/i]; shape similar to Common Opal [i]C. thysbe[/i]; Forewing outer margin angled at vein M3 but not strongly. Male forewing [i]silvery blue more extensive[/i] than Dark Opal; shifting electric blue even [i]more extensive, more[/i] apical red-orange marks. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing variegated; [i]less[/i] finely marked than Dark Opal; [i]redder[/i] in colour with [i]more prominent[/i] pale striae.
 
Sexes dimorphic, female markings similar to Dark Opal.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Found in large scattered colonies. Males on hill tops and ridge summits, whirling around tall rocks, settling often on the ground but wary. Female slower flight, below where males fly.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

Classification

Genus: [i]Cigaritis[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–25mm female 24–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Similar to Silvery Bar [i]Cigaritis phanes[/i], but [i]smaller[/i] and [i]darker[/i], underside silvery hind wing bars broken into spots, not wavy bars. Like that butterfly it can be told from Natal Bar [i]Cigaritis natalensis[/i], Mozambique Bar [i]Cigaritis mozambica[/i] and Ella's Bar [i]Cigaritis ella[/i] by the [i]silver underside markings[/i]. Each hind wing carries a pair of thin tails with white tips at the anal angle.
 
Sexes dimorphic; male upperside orange apical patch [i]almost obscured[/i] by purple-blue basal colour. Female upperside [i]lacks[/i] whitish-blue wing base scaling on the upperside.
 
Rapid flight around low, dry bushes on lower slopes of hills and in gullies. Fond of flowering 'vygies' (Mesembryanthemaceae) which are common in their habitat.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.

Restricted to Succulent Karoo, from extreme N Cape (Namibian border) to n W Cape (Namaqualand).

Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]frederikeae[/i]

Male 28–36mm female 32–39mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Dark brown [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Upperside [i]dark grey-brown[/i], cilia [i]less conspicuously chequered[/i] than Monkey Blue [i]Lepidochrysops methymna[/i]. Underside hind wing has [i]well-developed basal white-edged black spots[/i] and [i]conspicuous white submarginal sagittate markings[/i]. Similar to Badham''s Blue [i]Lepidochrysops badhami[/i] but forewing tips [i]more rounded[/i] and upperside colour has a [i]greyish[/i] sheen, not coppery. Hind wing upperside has a [i]submarginal spot[/i] in area CuA2[i] lacking or indistinct[/i]. Underside differs in that the forewing postdiscal series is strongly curved outwards from M3 to Rs; hind wing costal black spots [i]more widely spaced[/i].
 
Sexes similar, female larger with stouter abdomen.
 
Fast, low, dodging flight around bushes in flat country and on low hills. Settles on low bushes; flies up suddenly when approached and disappears rapidly.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos covered Inselberg in Tankwa Karoo area of southern N Cape.

Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top

December.
Back to Top

[i]Pelargonium[/i] sp., including [i]P. pachypodium[/i], and unknown ant species.

Boland Skolly
[i]Thestor protumnus protumnus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]protumnus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]protumnus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–37.5mm female 24–42.5mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small butterfly conspicuously [i]buff[/i] upperside and forewing underside, bordered with [i]grey-brown[/i] and having chequered cilia, the amount of contrast varying. Colour varies between subspecies, and within populations can range from bright cartridge-buff to a darker tawny-buff. Upperside and forewing underside carry variable number of dark spots, depending on subspecies and varying within populations. Hind wing underside has cryptic pattern of basal, postdiscal and marginal bands of darker scaling on a grey-brown ground; depth of colour varies between subspecies.
 
Slight sexual dimorphism. Male smaller than female. Male upperside buff with grey-brown margins and rows of black spots; forewing carries [i]prominent sex brand[/i], coloured dark brown to grey-brown in basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Female usually brighter buff than male, with [i]rounded[/i] not [i]pointed[/i] wings. Nominate subspecies [i]Thestor protumnus protumnus[/i] is the darkest and has the heaviest upperside spotting, and the most prominently white chequered cilia. Occasional males have very dark buff colouring.
 
3 subspp., geographically distinct; varying in size and colour.
 
[i]T. protumnus[/i] lives in discrete colonies in flat country and on hillsides. These probably coincide with colonies of the host ant, a Pugnacious Ant, [i]Anaplolepis[/i] sp. Flight is low and fluttering but can be fast and sustained. Males are territorial and congregate around patches of bare gravelly or sandy soil; females fly around inspecting plants for the presence of their host ants. Should she find this she will lay one or two eggs.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) (E) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widely distributed in Fynbos of W Cape (Cape Peninsula n to Tulbagh and Yzerfontein).
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Sept–Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data.
Back to Top
Group
Skollies.
Back to Top

Male 26–30mm female 28–32mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, brightly coloured Opal; [i]smaller[/i] than Beaufort Opal [i]Chrysoritis beaufortia[/i], with which it is often found. Male silvery blue is restricted to [i]basal third[/i] of upperside. Silvery blue has [i]violet cast; electric violet[/i] iridescence over upperside orange ground colour. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing distinctive, variegated with dark basal area and postdiscal band.
 
Sexes dimorphic; female very difficult to distinguish from Turner's Opal.
 
Found in small colonies along rocky ridges on the upper slopes of escarpments. Flight fast and elusive.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.

Aug–Dec, but possibly more than one brood.

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Coliadinae
Genus: [i]Eurema[/i]
Species: [i]brigitta[/i]
Subspecies: [i]brigitta[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
30–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright yellow Pierid. Differs from African Clouded Yellow [i]Colias electo
 electo[/i] in upperside ground colour [i]yellow, not orange[/i], and Spiller's Sulphur
Yellow [i]Dixeia spilleri[/i], in that it has [i]broad black borders[/i]. Black forewing
upperside marginal band [i]evenly curved; only lightly scalloped[/i]. Differs from Common
[i]Eurema hecabe[/i] and Malagasy [i]E. floricola[/i] Grass Yellows in that the forewing
upperside marginal band is [i]not strongly scalloped[/i]; from Angled Grass Yellow [i]E. desjardinsii[/i] in that the hind wing outer margin is [i]evenly curved, not square[/i].
 
Sexes similar, male [i]deeper, brighter yellow[/i] than female, lacks basal dusting of grey scales.
 
Fluttering flight, fairly low, in open country. Settles often on flowers or vegetation.
 
Seasonally dimorphic. Wet season form [i]zoe[/i] male upperside [i]bright yellow, broad, sharp edged marginal upperside black borders on both wings[/i]; female hind wing upperside dark margin is [i]not sharp edged[/i], black penetrates yellow along the veins. Underside [i]plain yellow[/i], more or less speckled with black scales, crossed by [i]faint black postdiscal and submarginal transverse bands[/i]. (A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
 
Dry season form [i]brigitta[/i] has [i]narrower dark borders in both sexes[/i]; yellow [i]not as deep a shade as in wet season form[/i]; underside suffused with pink to buff; crossed by [i]pale brown postdiscal and submarginal transverse bands[/i]. (D), (E) Male undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
More common and widespread than other [i]Eurema[/i] species; tolerates drier conditions and frost-prone Grassland. Found all over eastern South Africa; absent from Namaqualand and the more arid Karoo.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods, all year - appearance of forms depends on rainfall. WSF from Sept–May, DSF Mar–Oct. Peaks in late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hypericum aethiopicum[/i] and [i]Chamaecrista mimosoides[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Yellows.

Large, brightly coloured Bitter Acraea. Where it flies there are no similar species.

Classification
Family: Pieridae

Back to Top
Identification
Small white Pierid. Unlike other white [i]Dixeia[/i] spp., hind wing costal edge carries a [i]yellow streak[/i]. Underside resembles upperside, hind wing dark markings smaller or absent except for row of [i]postdiscal black spots[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic; males have [i]plain white upperside[/i] with [i]fine black-edged forewing tip[/i]. Female with prominent rows of [i]postdiscal dark spots on[/i] upperside.
 
Flight fairly slow. Large numbers may be found in riverine bush, and congregating on mud puddles.
 
Seasonally polymorphic. Wet season form [i]pigea[/i] male has [i]black hind wing marginal spots and underside submarginal spots[/i]. Female has [i]marginal and postdiscal spots on all wings[/i] and a variable amount of upperside and underside hind wing yellow. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female underside. (D), (E) Female undersides.
 
Wet season female form [i]rubrobasalis[/i] has upperside creamy yellow, underside resembling small female False Dotted Border; [i]strong forewing underside basal orange flush[/i]. (F) Female upperside. (G) Female underside.
 
Female form [i]luteola[/i] is deep yellow to apricot, carrying a varying amount of dark marking in dry and wet season forms. (H) Female upperside. (I) Female underside.
 
Dry season form [i]alba[/i] has reduced dark markings in both sexes, and the female upperside is [i]cream or white[/i], although the hind wing underside is often [i]bright yellow[/i]. (J) Male upperside. (K) Male underside. (L) Female upperside. (M) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common in wooded Savanna, Riverine and Lowland Forest from E Cape (Cape St. Francis) to Swaziland, along KwaZulu-Natal coast to Maputaland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province lowveld as far as Soutpansberg, following rivers into dry Savanna areas.

Hillsides, flatlands, forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, more common in late summer and autumn (Dec–May).

Classification

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 27–31mm female 30–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown Skipper. Upperside dark brown, hind wing plain, forewing has discal white spots in CuA2, CuA1 (a large square spot) and M3; a double white spot in the cell and three small subapical white spots in R4, R5 and M1. Underside [i]golden to reddish brown[/i] with veins picked out in [i]yellow ochre[/i]; hind wing has a [i]bright silvery white streak[/i] in M2; sometimes also fainter streak along CuA2. Similar to Unique Ranger [i]Kedestes lenis[/i] and Wallengren's Ranger [i]K. wallengrenii[/i] but those species have a white streak in area 1A+2A of the hind wing underside, not M2. Cilia plain greyish white.
 
Sexes similar, female paler than male, rounder, more elongated wings, abdomen stouter, forewing upperside spots [i]more developed[/i].
 
Found in moist Grassland, usually near streams and marshes. Male has very fast, sustained flight; is very wary; if disturbed, disappears, not to be seen for a time. Female in same area; more sedentary, searching for oviposition sites.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Female underside showing forewing. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland and wooded Savanna from KwaZulu-Natal Drakensberg foothills near Kokstad, Midlands and thorn belt to hills of c Mpumalanga, e Limpopo Province, e Free State and s Gauteng.

Habitat
Forest edges, wetlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded; spring brood Aug–Nov, summer Feb–Apr, sometimes overlapping.
Back to Top

Natal Tree Nymph
[i]Sevenia natalensis[/i]

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Biblidinae
Genus: [i]Sevenia[/i]
Species: [i]natalensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male female 40–48mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized, golden brown Tree Nymph. More of a [i]tawny[/i] colour than Boisduval's Tree Nymph [i]Sevenia boisduvali boisduvali[/i] or Morant's Tree Nymph [i]S. morantii[/i]. [i]Larger, paler[/i], than [i]S. boisduvali[/i], underside flatter, pale grey with submarginal black spots [i]tiny or absent[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. The male has vaguely defined forewing apical spots of ground colour on a dark brown wing tip; female larger, with [i]pale buff to orange[/i] marks on black forewing tip, spreading into cell.
 
Fond of sitting on tree bark, also roosts under leaves. Flipping, short flight from tree trunk to tree trunk. Very wary and hard to approach closely. Occurs in smaller numbers than [i]S. boisduvali[/i], but much more numerous than [i]S. morantii[/i]. Shy, difficult to approach; sits on tree trunks, darting away when disturbed. Strongly attracted to fermenting fruit and sap leaking from wounded trees. Comes readily to baited traps.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common in forests along coastal plain from Alexandria Forest to Kosi Bay; also in Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province (Lowland Forest to e Soutpansberg).
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Feb–May.
Back to Top

[i]Sclerocroton integerrimum[/i] and [i]Shirakiopsis elliptica[/i].
Back to Top

Identification
Small yellow spotted black-brown Skipper. Upperside [i]spots brilliant golden-yellow[/i] on dark brown-black ground. Very conspicuous. [i]Much brighter[/i] than Grassveld Sylph [i]Metisella malgacha[/i]. Cilia plain.
 
[i]M. metis paris[/i] larger than nominate, with smaller yellow forewing cell spot.
Sexes differ slightly; yellow spot at CuA1 is single in female, double in male. Male underside hind wing [i]flat brown-black[/i], female underside hind wing has upperside pattern of yellow spots [i]repeated in red-brown[/i] on brown-black ground.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Slow, hopping flight around low vegetation, settling often, wings usually held open. Males and females fly together.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Female upperside. (G) Male underside. (H) Female underside.

Bushveld Purple Tip
[i]Colotis ione[/i]
alternative common name: Common Purple Tip
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Colotis[/i]
Species: [i]ione[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–50mm female 48–52mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized white Pierid with coloured or black forewing tips. Very similar to Coast Purple Tip [i]Colotis erone[/i]. Male upperside always white; black forewing apical tip with [i]four[/i] not [i]three[/i], discrete metallic purple cells; has dusting of grey scales in black margin. Some specimens have a tiny extra spot of purple on costal edge of tip. Shade of purple [i]shiny and iridescent[/i], but not to the same extent as Queen Purple Tip [i]C. regina[/i]. That butterfly has a distinct two-tone purple-green 'flop' in the wing tip. Underside varies from pinkish white in all dry season forms [i]but greyer and dingier[/i] than Coast Purple Tip; white through cream to yellow in wet season forms; distinctive dark markings remain the same.
 
Sexually dimorphic; males always have a [i]purple[/i] upperside forewing tip; females
have several colour morphs - [i]orange-tipped, black-tipped and some have brown or cream patches in the black[/i]. They generally have [i]five to six spots[/i] in the wing tip, compared to [i]three to four[/i] in female f. [i]erone[/i].
 
Fast, erratic flight, settling seldom except to feed at flowers. In cloudy weather may stop to bask in sunny patches. Females are less often seen than males because they are more retiring, but also often come to flowers.
 
Seasonally polymorphic. Male nominotypical wet season f. [i]ione[/i], found mainly in KwaZulu-Natal, has extensive black veins on hind wing upperside and on edge of forewing upperside tip, and underside has [i]heavy black veining[/i] on white or cream ground colour, with a dark band crossing the hind wing postdiscal area. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Wet season male in the rest of Southern Africa is f. [i]phlegyas[/i], which has [i]reduced[/i] black veining in the forewing and [i]faint or absent[/i] black underside veining on white or cream ground colour. (C) Male upperside. (D) Male underside.
 
There are several wet season female forms. F. [i]ione[/i] has [i]orange[/i] forewing tips outlined in black, with some red at the basal edge, and [i]heavy black[/i] upperside marginal borders, a [i]dark band[/i] along the forewing inner margin, dark wing bases, and a dark line crossing the postdiscal area of the hind wing. Underside marked with yellow and buff and has [i]dark marks[/i] corresponding to those on upperside. (E) Female upperside. (F) Female underside.
 
Female f. [i]xanthosana[/i] resembles f. [i]ione[/i] but all white areas are replaced by [i]bright yellow[/i]. This form is very rare in South Africa. (G) Female upperside. (H) Female underside.
 
Female f. [i]woodi[/i] has the dark upperside marking of f. [i]ione[/i] and f. [i]xanthosana[/i] but has a [i]black upperside forewing tip[/i] containing [i]white spots[/i]. (I) Female upperside. (J) Female underside.
 
Female form [i]pepita[/i] resembles f. [i]woodi[/i] but has the [i]white replaced by yellow[/i] as in f. [i]xanthosana[/i]. (K) Female upperside. (L) Female underside.
 
Dry season male f. [i]jalone[/i] has [i]extensive grey scaling[/i] in black border to forewing upperside tip: [i]almost no[/i] black veins in forewing upperside white area, and [i]reduced[/i] hind wing upperside black veins. Underside hind wing ground colour [i]pink, irrorated with darker brown striae[/i], and crossed by a brown postdiscal stripe. (M) Male upperside. (N) Male underside.
 
There are several dry season female forms. F. [i]jalone[/i] has [i]orange[/i] forewing tips edged in brown, with other dark markings [i]restricted or absent[/i]. Underside resembles male f. [i]jalone[/i]; ground colour [i]pink, irrorated with darker brown striae[/i], basal and discal areas darker brown divided from rest of wing by postdiscal stripe. (O) Female upperside. (P) Female underside.
 
Rare female f. [i]leda[/i] resembles f. [i]jalone[/i] but upperside white is tinged with a greater or lesser degree of [i]primrose yellow[/i]. Underside resembles that of f. [i]jalone[/i]. (Q) Female upperside. (R) Female underside.
 
Female f. [i]xerophila[/i], also rare, is the dry season counterpart to the wet season f. [i]woodi[/i]; forewing tips [i]brown-black[/i] containing small spots. Underside resembles that of f. [i]jalone[/i]. (S) Female upperside. (T) Female underside.
 
Rare female f. [i]erubescens[/i] has the black wing markings of f. [i]xerophila[/i] replaced by [i]rich pinkish brown[/i]. Underside resembles that of f. [i]jalone[/i]. (U) Female upperside. (V) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread in open woodland and Savanna from E Cape (Port St. Johns), through KwaZulu-Natal thorn belt to Maputaland, north to Mpumalanga, Gauteng and Limpopo and NW provinces, stragglers reach Arid Savanna in N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall. WSF mainly Oct–Mar, DSF mainly Feb–Nov. Peaks late summer and autumn.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Boscia[/i] spp., including [i]B. albitrunca, Maerua rosmarinoides[/i] and [i]Capparis[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Tips.
Back to Top






Hyperion Opal
[i]Chrysoritis swanepoeli hyperion[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]swanepoeli[/i]
Subspecies: [i]hyperion[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 23–26mm female 24–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Bright red-orange Opal, male upperside blue wing patches [i]small[/i], and extent of shifting electric lustre [i]limited[/i]. Has similar habits to Beulah's [i]Chrysoritis beulah[/i] and Irene's [i]C. irene[/i] Opals but they fly in different areas and [i]C. swanepoeli[/i] is a darker insect with a [i]variegated underside[/i]. Hind wing upperside dark spots [i]limited or absent[/i]. Forewing upperside dark borders [i]variable in width[/i]; specimens from higher altitudes have [i]more extensive[/i] dark markings. Male has [i]large spot at end of forewing cell[/i], which is widely separated from the postdiscal row of spots. Both sexes have [i]prominently chequered[/i] cilia. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside [i]strongly variegated[/i] with prominent pale costal and discal marks, a pale postdiscal band and well-defined silvery sagittate marks.
 
High altitude subspecies [i]C. s. hyperion[/i] has [i]darker, broader[/i] upperside marginal borders, often merging with the forewing submarginal black spots. Sexes differ. Female has [i]little or no[/i] basal blue, similar black spotting to other female [i]Chrysoritis[/i] spp., and rounded wings.
 
2 subspp., altitudinally separated. Lives in scattered colonies in gullies and dry riverbeds, from the base to the summits of high mountains. Males perch on prominent rocks or plants, periodically taking off to patrol their territory. Females are more sedentary, found on flowers and close to the host plants.
 
Nominate [i]Chrysoritis swanepoeli swanepoeli[/i]: (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside. (G) Female upperside.

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Paralethe[/i]
Species: [i]dendrophilus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]junodi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–60mm, female 55–70mm.
Back to Top
Identification
A shade-loving butterfly that is usually seen fluttering among undergrowth along forest paths, and settling on leaves or tree bark. Its upperside is brightly coloured and conspicuous in flight; underside is well camouflaged against dead leaves and bark. The sexes are similar; females are slightly larger and paler on the upperside.
 
Four subspecies, geographically separated.
 
The largest subspecies of [i]Paralethe dendrophilus dendrophilus[/i] with the most extensive white markings. (H) Male upperside. (I) Female underside). The forewing spots are always all-white and are the largest of all the subspecies.
Models
[i]Danaus chrysippus orientis[/i] (African Monarch).
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane and coastal forest fringes. Sometimes in alien pine plantations. [i]P. d. junodi[/i] along Drakensberg in Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province.

Forest edges, mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, late Dec–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae grasses, including [i]Ehrharta erecta[/i], [i]Panicum deustum[/i], and [i]Setaria sulcata[/i].

Lipara Buff
[i]Baliochila lipara[/i]
Contents

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Baliochila[/i]
Species: [i]lipara[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 20–25mm female 22–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny to small buff butterfly. Resembles female Common Buff [i]Baliochila aslanga[/i] which is [i]sexually dimorphic[/i]; underside hind wing orange marks [i]tiny or absent[/i], not prominent as in [i]B. lipara[/i]. Also resembles Pennington's Buff [i]Cnodontes penningtoni[/i] and Pallid Buff [i]C. pallida[/i] but underside orange marks are discrete spots in [i]B. lipara[/i]; form indistinct bands and are often absent in [i]Cnodontes[/i] spp. Also, both sexes of [i]Cnodontes[/i] carry one dark costal mark just outside the forewing cell and do not have dark costal marks at the base of the forewing as in [i]Baliochila[/i] spp.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Weak, fluttering flight. Usually flies high in canopy, but sometimes found lower down. Settles on twigs, wings closed; periodically suddenly opening them. When doing this it resembles a tiny yellowed leaf waving in the breeze. Occasionally found roosting communally. Female flies lower, searching for oviposition sites. Often found in small groups, imbibing honeydew from scale insects on twigs or leaves.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Restricted to sand forest areas in Tongaland area of northern KwaZulu-Natal; Manguzi and Tembe Forests.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Oct–Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Buffs.

Identification
Large [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Only one of the Koppie Blue group to have a [i]blue[/i] male and [i]grey-black[/i] female. Underside ground colour [i]darker[/i] in tint than others of the group. The various spots and lunules are darker still, and the white circles surrounding them are [i]very narrow but clear cut[/i]; postdiscal sagittate marks [i]sharply pointed[/i] and narrow.
 
Sexes differ. Male upperside resembles a dark Peninsula Blue [i]Lepidochrysops oreas[/i], but with [i]broader[/i] wing margins. Female resembles the female Monkey Blue [i]L. methymna[/i]. As in that butterfly, the upperside sometimes carries traces of blue.
 
Male has fast, erratic flight; ascends low ridges and koppies at midday where it circles around, chasing other butterflies and settling, usually in the same place. Female flight slower; skulks; around in thick vegetation at the base of hills, visiting flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

False Chief
[i]Pseudacraea lucretia expansa[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Models

Habitat

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Limenitidinae
Genus: [i]Pseudacraea[/i]
Species: [i]lucretia[/i]
Subspecies: [i]expansa[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 60–72mm female 65–78mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized canopy butterfly, dark with prominent paler markings. Resembles distasteful members of the genus [i]Amauris[/i] but generally so, the resemblance is not exact and the colours do not exactly match. [i]P. l. expansa[/i] has two discrete forms. Wing markings white in f. [i]expansa[/i], dark orange in f. [i]heliogenes[/i].
 
Sexes alike, female with markings identical to male, but with rounder wings.
 
Floating, sailing flight, wings open flat, with infrequent rapid wingbeats. This distinguishes them from the more fluttering flight of the models. If disturbed they can put on a turn of speed. Male territorial, perching on prominent forest-edge leaves, chasing intruders. If chased away he usually returns to the same perch. The female is less active. Both sexes are often seen nectaring on flowering trees. Occasionally found low down, drinking at mud puddles.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(A) Male upperside f. [i]expansa[/i]. (B) Male upperside f. [i]heliogenes[/i]. (C) Male underside f. [i]expansa[/i]. (D) Male underside f. [i]heliogenes[/i].
Models
Although the [i]pattern[/i] of the forewing markings is reminiscent of both the Chief [i]Amauris echeria echeria[/i], and Layman [i]A. albimaculata albimaculata[/i], these two models have colours distinctive to the species.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common in Lowland Forest and riverine bush; marginally penetrates Savanna. [i]P. l. expansa[/i] Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province, along Soutpansberg and Drakensberg foothills.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Jan–Jul; scarce in spring and early summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Mimusops obovata, M. zeheri, M. caffra, Chrysophyllum viridifolium[/i] and [i]Englerophytum magalismontanum[/i].
Back to Top
Group
False Acraeas.

Swanepoel's Brown
[i]Pseudonympha swanepoeli[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Pseudonympha[/i]
Species: [i]swanepoeli[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 46–50mm female 44–48mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Similar in wing shape and habits to Vàri's Brown [i]P. vàrii[/i], but [i]only two[/i] ocelli in anal angle of hind wing underside. Populations vary in amount of dark marking on hind wing underside; some have a dark transverse band and submarginal line but never as heavy as in [i]P. vàrii[/i]. This butterfly was described from a wetland surrounded by forest at about 1500m altitude near Houtbosdorp in Limpopo. That population appears to have died out, but similar butterflies have been found in high altitude marshes over a wide range of country to the south. These fly at altitudes from just over 2000m on Long Tom Pass in Mpumalanga to over 2300m atop Platberg near Harrismith in the Free State. Opinions vary as to whether these are true [i]P. swanepoel[/i], a subspecies of it, or a hitherto undescribed new species. The photographs shown here are from these populations.
 
Sexes similar. Female smaller, with wings more rounded. Male hind wing underside can be spectacular, resembling [i]beaten pewter[/i]. Crooked discal band crossing wing is more prominent in female.
 
May fly in huge numbers in vleis and marshes. Flight bouncing, slow; female reluctant to take wing.
 
(A) Male upperside. (Platberg, Harrismith). (B) Male underside. (Long Tom Pass). (C) Male underside. (Verloren Valei, Dullstroom).
Back to Top
Distribution
Populations exist near Houtbosdorp, Limpopo Province, and Whisky Spruit (Long Tom Pass), Verloren Valei and Mount Sheba, and Pilgrim's Rest, Mpumalanga. South along escarpment to Platberg above Harrismith, Free State.
Back to Top
Habitat
Wetlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Feb and Mar in the north, Nov–Feb in south.
Back to Top
Larval food
Probably Poaceae grasses, or Cyperaceae sedges.
Back to Top
Group
Grass Browns.

Emperor Swallowtail
[i]Papilio ophidicephalus entabeni[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Papilionidae
Subfamily: Papilioninae
Genus: [i]Papilio[/i]
Species: [i]ophidicephalus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]entabeni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 90–140mm female 100–160mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very large, conspicuous black and yellow butterfly with well-developed spatulate tails. Largest South African butterfly. Closest in markings to Citrus Swallowtail [i]Papilio demodocus[/i] but [i]much larger and has hind wing tails[/i]. Constantine's Swallowtail [i]P. constantinus[/i] and Bush Kite [i]P. euphranor[/i] are both superficially similar but [i]lack large blue hind wing postdiscal lunules on both wing surfaces[/i]. The forewing discal band of spots varies in shape and width between the subspecies.
 
The nominate subspecies is not found in South Africa. [i]P. ophidicephalus entabeni[/i] has a [i]curved forewing discal band[/i] as in [i]P. o. ayresi[/i] or [i]P. o. transvaalensis[/i] but [i]much wider[/i] and [i]the male's spots[/i] are weakly joined from R3 to M3, in the female as far as CuA1 or CuA2. Sexes similar; male has [i]bands of shiny scent scales[/i] on forewing between postdiscal and submarginal yellow spots. Females have varying degrees of irroration with yellow scales in these areas.
 
5 subspp., geographically distinct. Flies fast with powerful wingbeats; may stoop low
to investigate flowers. Follows gullies and roads in thick forest. Males are often seen
mud puddling; females on flowers and host plants.
 
(K) Male upperside. (L) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane and Riverine Forest in Soutpansberg, Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded; spring brood (Aug–Dec) less abundant and smaller specimens than summer brood (Jan–Apr). Broods may overlap in summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Clausena anisata, Zanthoxylum capense, Z. davyi, Z. delagoense[/i] and [i]Calodendron capense[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Swallowtails.

Unique Ranger

Identification
Small brown Skipper. Upperside dark brown; hind wing plain, forewing has small discal whitish spots, which may be absent in the male of the nominate subspecies. Underside golden to ochreous red-brown with veins picked out in paler ochre. Resembles Dark Ranger [i]Kedestes niveostriga[/i] but upperside [i]darker[/i], forewing spots [i]much smaller or absent[/i]; underside ground colour [i]darker, a more reddish shade[/i]; pale streak along hind wing underside vein M2 [i]fainter[/i]. Can be distinguished from Wallengren's Ranger [i]K. wallengrenii[/i] by the position of the hind wing underside white stripe, which follows the inner margin. Cilia plain ochreous cream to greyish white.
 
Nominate subspecies [i]Kedestes lenis lenis[/i] upperside has reddish brown tinge; cilia ochreous cream, forewing pale spots [i]very small[/i], in the male often [i]absent[/i]. Underside golden brown. Sexes similar, female larger and paler than male, rounder, more elongated wings, abdomen stouter, forewing upperside spots [i]better developed[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fast and skipping. Male does not hilltop, stays close to host plants in wet places, perching and patrolling, chasing away any other male. Female slower flying, also found among host plants, seldom on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

Rossouw's Blue
[i]Lepidochrysops rossouwi[/i]
alternative common name: Rossouw's Nimble Blue, Rossouw's Giant Cupid

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]rossouwi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 33–43mm female 42–50mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, bright blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. On the wing, the most brilliant and glittering of the Twin-spot Blue group. Male upperside is [i]grey shot with turquoise-blue[/i]; fuscous-grey marginal borders [i]wider[/i] than Patrician [i]Lepidochrysops patricia[/i] or Silvery [i]L. glauca[/i] Blues. Underside of both sexes similar to Patrician Blue; usually a [i]paler[/i] ground colour. Forewing upperside distal spot in cell is [i]distinct[/i]. Both surfaces of both sexes' hind wings have [i]prominent[/i] orange lunules above large black spots at the anal angle. The largest spot is in area CuA1; sometimes the black spot in area 1A+2A is absent but the orange lunule still present. Hind wing carries a small tail at end of vein CuA2. Cilia plain whitish grey.
 
Sexually dimorphic; female larger, upperside blue markings better defined than male, [i]whitish-blue[/i] submarginal row of spots and pale postdiscal row of sagittate marks following those on underside.
 
Rapid, erratic flight. At midday, males ascend high grassy ridges, and fly around territories near prominent features such as isolated trees. Female are found lower down the slopes near host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top

Restricted to grassy escarpments near Stoffberg, Dullstroom and Lydenburg (Mpumalanga).

Hillsides, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Two broods, Oct–Dec and Jan–Mar, with some overlap.
Back to Top

[i]Lantana rugosa[/i]. From third instar, brood of [i]Camponotus maculatus[/i] ants.
