Forest White
[i]Belenois zochalia zochalia[/i]
alternative common name: Large Caper White; Forest Caper White
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Belenois[/i]
Species: [i]zochalia[/i]
Subspecies: [i]zochalia[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
40–50mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized white butterfly. Forewing upperside pattern similar to other [i]Belenois[/i] species such as Brown-veined White [i]B. aurota[/i], and African Veined White [i]B. gidica[/i] that have [i]dumbbell-shaped[/i] bars at the distal end of the cell. It can be distinguished by the [i]shiny, pearlescent white[/i] upperside and [i]thin, dark lines[/i] along hind wing underside wing veins.
 
There is considerable seasonal and geographical variation. Males are fairly constant in
upperside colour and markings, but on the underside the forewing apex and hind wing
ground colour can vary from pale cream to yellow, or grey-white. Females vary from
the nominate form [i]zochalia[/i], which resembles the male, to the yellow hind wing form
[i]hyoma[/i]. The rare form [i]agrippinides[/i] has a creamy yellow forewing and deep
yellow hind wing (not illustrated). In Gauteng and NW Province the dry season forms approach f. [i]immaculata[/i]; females never have yellow hind wings. The underside markings are [i]reduced or absent[/i] in these butterflies.
 
Flight fluttering, not usually sustained, along forest edges. Both sexes are often seen nectaring at flowers. In hot weather they may drink from mud puddles.
 
Nominate form: (A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. f. [i]hyoma[/i]: (D) Female upperside. (E) Female underside. Dry season nr f. [i]immaculata[/i]: (D) Female upperside. (E) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Edges of coastal Lowland and Riverine Forest, along rivers from Knysna, W Cape, to KwaZulu-Natal, Afromontane Forest patches (Amatolas to Soutpansberg) and suitable woodland in Limpopo Province, NW Province and Gauteng.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, gullies, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peak Nov–Feb.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Boscia oleioides, Maerua racemulosa, M. cafra[/i] and [i]Capparis[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Whites.
Back to Top






Scarce Forest Charaxes
[i]Charaxes etesipe tavetensis[/i]
alternative common name: Scarce Forest Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]etesipe[/i]
Subspecies: [i]tavetensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 55–65mm female 62–72mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium to large sized Charaxes. Male could be confused with male Blue-spangled Charaxes, [i]C. guderiana guderiana[/i], female with White-barred Charaxes, [i]C. brutus natalensis[/i], but undersides very different.
 
Sexes dimorphic. Male upperside with [i]pale blue spangling[/i] over deep metallic-blue ground colour. Female with upperside duller, no blue; compared to White-barred Charaxes [i]C. brutus natalensis[/i], white median bands often tinged [i]creamy yellow[/i]. Underside of both sexes superficially similar to Bushveld Charaxes [i]C. achaemenes[/i], but more [i]colourful and variegated[/i], with [i]white flash[/i] along hind wing costa.
 
Fast flight, males territorial, perching high up in the forest canopy on tree tops. They pursue any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly lower, along the fringes of forests where they settle on tree leaves.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees. They are also often seen drinking from wet mud.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Locally common in remote northern Lowland Forest, from n KwaZulu-Natal (Sodwana Bay to Kosi Bay), inland to Tembe Elephant Park, and Limpopo Province (eastern Soutpansberg, near Thohoyandou).
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, Aug–Oct, Mar–Jun.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Afzelia quanzensis, Dalbergia nitidula, Securidaca longipeduncularis[/i] and [i]Margaritaria discoidea[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Charaxes.

Classification

Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]

Back to Top

Male 28–34mm female 34–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, golden brown [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Closely resembles Wineland Blue [i]Lepidochrysops bacchus[/i], but slightly larger, upperside more [i]golden bronze brown[/i]; pale mark (not always present) above the dark spot at the hind wing on underside tornus [i]dull, with orange shade[/i], not bright white.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Scarce, seldom seen, found in colonies. Flight low and undulating, difficult to follow among low bushes in a high wind. Sexes fly together.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top

Rare. In Succulent Karoo of N Cape, north of Steinkopf; also in Kamieskroon and Garies areas.

Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Aug–Oct, emerging only after good rains.

Larval food
No data.

Group

Deceptive Widow
[i]Tarsocera imitator[/i]
Contents

Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Tarsocera[/i]
Species: [i]imitator[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 42–52mm, female 50–57mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Similar to Spring Widow, from which it can only be reliably distinguished by genitalic dissection. Tends to have slighter build, with [i]more brightly coloured[/i] subapical patch ([i]orange-red[/i], as opposed to rust-red); also, forewing underside usually darker in both sexes.
 
Sexes similar. Male has distinct dark forewing discal band, sometimes present in Spring Widow; female of the 2 spp. are very similar. Overlap in distribution in southern part of this species' range.
 
Low, wandering flight; settles occasionally; wary and easily flushed.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Succulent Karoo; Namaqualand from Steinkopf, N Cape, south to Lambert's Bay area, W Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, coast, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single brood in Sept and Oct.
Back to Top
Larval food
Probably Poaceae grasses.
Back to Top
Group
Widows.

Classification

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 29–54mm female 54–62mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to medium-sized Bitter Acraea. Similar to Orange Acraea, but [i]darker[/i] ground colour, black spots on forewing [i]sparser[/i], and with prominent [i]black[/i] forewing tips.
 
Sexually dimorphic. The male is more brightly coloured than the female, and the female is more heavily marked with black.
 
Flight sailing, with slow wingbeats, but soars when disturbed. Male patrols rocky ridges. Female more often seen on flowers near the host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.

Bamboo Sylph
[i]Metisella syrinx[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Heteropterinae
Genus: [i]Metisella[/i]
Species: [i]syrinx[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–34mm female 32–37mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small cream spotted black-brown Skipper. Upperside resembles Grassveld Sylph [i]Metisella malgacha[/i], but ground colour [i]duller brown[/i], markings [i]pale buff, not yellow[/i]. Underside [i]distinctive golden brown[/i], hind wing with [i]ray of cream-white[/i] from base through cell along vein M2 to margin; white streak at anal fold. Cilia plain.
 
Sexes similar, female with stouter abdomen.
 
Flight darting and zigzagging, faster than other [i]Metisella[/i] spp., difficult to follow. Male territorial among clumps of host plant. Female less frequently seen in the same places, ovipositing, feeding on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare, highly localised; protected in E Cape. Only near clumps of mountain bamboo among large rocks at or near summits of Grassland mountains from E Cape (Amatolas) through s Lesotho to extreme s KwaZulu-Natal (Mzimkulu Wilderness and Drakensberg Gardens).
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Jan–Feb.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Thamnocalamnus tessellatus[/i].
Back to Top
Group

Darker Commodore
[i]Precis antilope[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Precis[/i]
Species: [i]antilope[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–55mm female 50–60mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized butterfly. It has two seasonal forms, which are different in appearance. Wet season (summer) form is deep orange with black bands and rows of spots, similar in appearance to Gaudy Commodore [i]Precis octavia sesamus[/i] but smaller, of a [i] less pink[/i] hue, and with [i]more extensive[/i] dark markings on both wing surfaces. Dry season (winter) form has a [i]leaf[/i]-like wing shape. Upperside similar to summer form but darker; underside similar to Dry-leaf Commodore [i]P. tugela tugela[/i] or Soldier Pansy [i]Junonia terea elgiva[/i], but uppersides very different and not found in same habitat. Could be confused on the wing with Pirate [i]Catacroptera cloanthe[/i] or one of the Jokers, [i]Byblia[/i] spp. It lacks the [i]plain underside[/i] of the former and the [i]pale bands and spots[/i] of the latter, which are smaller butterflies.
 
Sexes similar within the forms; females slightly larger.
 
Flies at low height to a metre or two above the ground, in grassy Savanna and woodland. Short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Flies away rapidly if disturbed; males strongly territorial, sitting on prominent point, chasing away intruders. and if chased away, usually returning to where first seen.
 
Wet season form f. [i]simia[/i] deep bright orange with dark wing bases, marginal bands and complete submarginal row of black spots. Underside similarly marked to upperside. Dry season form f. [i]antilope[/i] similar upperside markings to f. [i]simia[/i] but ground colour [i]duller, darker[/i]. Underside is a convincing dead leaf mimic, varying greatly in colour from red-brown to black and greenish buff.
 
(A) Female upperside f. [i]simia[/i]. (B) Female underside f. [i]simia[/i]. (C) Male upperside f. [i]antilope[/i]. (D) Male underside f. [i]antilope[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
Scarce and localised. Lowland Forest, Savanna and lowveld areas from E Cape (Port St. Johns area), KwaZulu-Natal (Eshowe area and Maputaland) to Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo, NW and n Gauteng provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Form [i]antilope[/i] Dec–Mar, f. [i]simia[/i] Apr–Aug.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Plectranthus[/i] sp.; [i]Platostoma[/i] sp.
Back to Top
Group
Commodores.
Back to Top

Male 29–38mm female 34–44mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small broad winged butterfly. Resembles Zulu Buff, but [i]a redder shade of buff, more densely speckled[/i] with black. [i]P. t. fuscipunctata[/i] has [i]larger[/i] dark apical patch and submarginal black spots on forewing upperside than nominate.
 
Sexes similar. Females larger and paler than males. Weak, fluttering flight. Flies slowly in the shade of trees and high under the forest canopy, settling on exposed twigs and the ends of tendrils, slowly opening and closing its wings.
 
(C) Male upperside. (D) Female underside.

Sheltered riverine Lowland Forest of eastern Limpopo Province (Soutpansberg) and further north.

Mouse Blue

alternative common name: Mouse Nimble Blue, Mouse Giant Cupid
Contents

Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]puncticilia[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 27–29mm female 27–30mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small dark brown [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Distinctive, dark species, [i]conspicuously white-spotted[/i] cilia. Underside also dark, white markings [i]diffuse and less well-defined[/i] than other 'brown' [i]Lepidochrysops[/i].
 
Sexes similar.
 
Colonies scattered, may be locally plentiful. Flight slow and low, circling and wandering around low vegetation and rocks. Found from low hills to tops of large mountains. Males ascend to the tops in morning and remain through the day.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos in W Cape, near Mamre and Malmesbury, Riebeek-Kasteel, Piketberg, mountains from Michell's Pass, Du Toit's Kloof, Mont Rochelle above Franschhoek, to Shaw's Mountain Pass and hills behind Hermanus. Also Gifberg near Vanrhynsdorp.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single Sept–Oct brood at low elevations, Oct–Dec on high mountains.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Selago fruticosa[/i] and [i]Dichisma ciliatum[/i].
Back to Top

Cape Brown
[i]Cassionympha detecta[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Cassionympha[/i]
Species: [i]detecta[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 33–37mm, female 34–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Similar to, but [i]smaller, darker[/i] than Rainforest Brown [i]C. cassius[/i], flight faster. Where [i]C. cassius[/i] has hind wing upperside ocelli, [i]C. detecta[/i] has a ochre-red patch. Hind wing underside lacks the red-brown bands of [i]C. cassius[/i].
 
Bobbing flight, settling often, open wings at first then closing them. Found more often in the open than [i]C. cassius[/i], compared to which its flight is more purposeful. It keeps low among the shrubs and can be difficult to follow.
 
Sexes similar, female more brightly coloured, with hind wing slightly squarer.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Thick Fynbos and Nama Karoo scrub, in W Cape mountains from Cederberg to Swartberg and down to the coast (Stilbaai). Spreads along south-east coast and hills to E Cape (Uitenhage) and into Great Karoo (Nuweveldberge).
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Sept–Apr (peaks Oct and Mar).
Back to Top
Larval food
Sedges, including [i]Ficina ramossissima[/i] and possibly [i]F. acuminata[/i]; and restios, possibly [i]Ischyrolepis[/i] spp. and probably [i]I. tenuissima[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Grass Browns.
Back to Top






Janse's Widow
[i]Dira jansei[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Satyrinae
Genus: [i]Dira[/i]
Species: [i]jansei[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 48–55mm, female 52–58mm.
Back to Top
Identification
This rare species flies in high altitude Grassland in the mountains, usually high on the sides of valleys below rocky crags. It is the only Widow found in its localities, so its large size makes it unmistakable. It is often found flying with Secucuni Shadefly [i]Coenyra rufiplaga[/i].
 
The marginal row of [i]five closely spaced small forewing ocelli[/i] distinguish this species. Sexes similar, female paler.
 
Usually found in groups of three to six, in the shade of trees. Sometimes difficult to flush from the long grass it favours. Flight is fast and sailing, easily eluding pursuit in rocky haunts. Females are less active, sitting inside grass clumps.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Wooded hillsides in the Savanna/Grassland ecotone in Limpopo Province's Strydpoortberg and Drakensberg, and Makapans Cave (Mokopane) to Mariepskop.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, wooded hillsides, rocky ledges, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, late Feb to mid-Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae grasses. Bred on [i]Ehrharta erecta[/i] and [i]Cenchrus clandestinus[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Widows.
Back to Top






Speckled Sulphur Tip
[i]Teracolus agoye agoye[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Teracolus[/i]
Species: [i]agoye[/i]
Subspecies: [i]agoye[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 30–40mm female 32–45mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small white Pierid with orange-yellow wing tips edged basally with black. Forewings [i]elongated and pointed[/i]. Smallest of the [i]Teracolus[/i] genus found in South Africa, with paler colouring than Banded Gold Tip [i]Teracolus eris[/i] and [i]no black bands on upperside[/i]. Slight seasonal dimorphism; underside usually white to cream, but may be brown in dry season specimens of [i]T. agoye agoye[/i].
 
Nominate [i]T. agoye agoye[/i] is the larger subspecies; male [i]upperside has dusting of black scales[/i] and black veins. Upperside forewing tip golden yellow [i]edged basally with black[/i]. Even fresh female specimens have a worn appearance: upperside forewing tip [i]grey[/i]-brown with dull orange centre. Sexually dimorphic; males are smaller than the females and have [i]brighter, better defined coloured wing tips[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Rapid, fluttering flight, usually close to host plants, in open country.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Savanna from Swaziland and n KwaZulu-Natal (Maputaland) to Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province lowveld.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Dec–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Boscia[/i] spp., including [i]B. albitrunca[/i], and [i]Cadaba[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Tips.
Back to Top






Scarce Mountain Copper
[i]Trimenia malagrida paarlensis[/i]
alternative common name: Paarl Mountain Copper
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Trimenia[/i]
Species: [i]malagrida[/i]
Subspecies: [i]paarlensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–27mm Female 29–33mm.
Back to Top
Identification
[i]More dainty[/i] than other [i]Trimenia[/i] species. The wings are less [i]acutely pointed[/i], especially in the male; there is less difference between the sexes. The typical [i]Trimenia[/i] upperside pattern of more or less bright fulvous-orange on the upperside with dark borders, and black-and-white chequered cilia, is continued in this species. The undersides are slightly different, in that the hind wing silvery marks are [i]cursive[/i] as in Wallengren's Silver-spotted Copper, but form a more coherent pattern with a [i]large '3'- or 'W'-shaped postdiscal line[/i] and a central roughly triangular blotch. There are two underside colour morphs, brown-and-tan, and wine-red.
 
[i]T. malagrida paarlensis[/i]: has no dark veining and the ochreous orange on the upperside is paler and more extensive than the nominate subspecies. Sexes very similar, females generally larger, paler orange, heavier bodied.
 
4 subspp., geographically distinct, all rare. Found in small, discrete colonies; flight rapid but not sustained; males select a prominent perch on a low plant or rock and chase away intruders. Females are found more at random, often on flowers.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Male underside (red morph). (F) Male underside (brown morph).
Back to Top
Distribution
W Cape Fynbos on Paarl Mountain and Paardeberg.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges; hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, late Jan–Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data.
Back to Top
Group
Silver-spotted Coppers.
Back to Top






Pennington's Opal
[i]Chrysoritis penningtoni[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]penningtoni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 18–22mm female 20–24mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, brightly coloured Opal. Similar to Eastern Opal [i]Chrysoritis orientalis[/i] and Machacha Opal [i]C. pelion[/i], but male upperside black borders [i]narrower[/i]; hind wing postdiscal spots [i]smaller or absent; pinkish opalescent sheen[/i] distal to blue patches. Cilia [i]strongly chequered[/i] in orange, black and white. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing variegated in [i]brown and ochreous buff[/i], with [i]conspicuous[/i] brassy sagittate markings.
 
Sexes similar; both have basal blue [i]more extensive[/i] than Eastern Opal.
 
Very fast and elusive flight, hard to follow. Found in small colonies (3–6 individuals) around rocky outcrops overgrown with bushes. Males defend territories around hollows in the outcrops, patrolling regularly. Females found more at random.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare. Grassland in E Cape, on high slopes of Amatolas (Gaika's Kop, Elandsberg and Hogsback).
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Multi-brooded, Oct–Mar, peak Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.
Back to Top






Royal Blue
[i]Orachrysops regalis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Orachrysops[/i]
Species: [i]regalis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 34–40mm female 30–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Bright blue butterfly. Habits and appearance similar to Karkloof Blue [i]Orachrysops ariadne[/i] but their localities are far apart. Royal Blue is generally a [i]paler insect[/i]; both sexes' upperside blue [i]brighter[/i] than most [i]Orachrysops[/i] species. Underside of both sexes [i]pale dove grey[/i], hind wing discal and forewing postmedial black spots [i]well-defined[/i]. Has black spot at hind wing tornus, edged with metallic blue. Cilia white, not chequered.
 
Sexually dimorphic; female has blue only at upperside wing bases, and [i]well-defined[/i] submarginal row of white-blue lunules on hind wing.
 
Flight rapid and direct; male patrols steep rocky slopes, female sedentary, found lower on slopes.

Mountains, hillsides.

Grassveld Sandman

Classification

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 20–22mm female 22–24mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very small pied Skipper with black-and-white chequered upperside and forewing underside. One of a group of very similar little butterflies, which are difficult to tell apart from the upperside markings. To be reasonably sure of identification a clear view of the hind wing underside is necessary. Similar to Star Sandman [i]S. asterodia[/i], but upperside and underside [i]more heavily marked with white[/i]. Irregular hind wing underside white median band, unlike Star Sandman, [i]does not run parallel[/i] to basal spots. Hind wing underside median band connected to large submarginal spot by [i]thin white line[/i] in cell, similar to the much smaller Mite Sandman [i]S. paula[/i]. Cilia chequered.
 
[i]S. agylla bamptoni[/i] has [i]more extensive white markings[/i], particularly on the underside hind wing which is essentially [i]white with bands of brown spots[/i]. Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Fast, buzzing, low flight, settling often, wings open. Male more often on ledges and ridges than hill tops, female near host plants. Both sexes fond of flowers, particularly [i]Mesembryanthemum[/i] vygies.

Identification
Large, with pale blue spots on a black ground, it flies high but comes to flowers and to wounded plants exuding pyrrolizidine alkaloids. Flight pattern similar to African Monarch [i]Danaus chrysippus orientis[/i], or Friar [i]Amauris niavius dominicanus[/i]. Sexes similar.
 
This is common in west and central Africa, but a very rare butterfly in southern Africa. It is uncommon even in northern Zimbabwe and Namibia, and there are only a handful of South African records. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Mimic
Male Forest Queen [i]Charaxes wakefieldi[/i], and both sexes of Veined Swordtail [i]Graphium leonidas[/i]. Easy to distinguish from mimics on the wing, as flight pattern and habits are similar to [i]Danaus[/i].

Marsh Hottentot Skipper
[i]Gegenes hottentota[/i]
alternative common name: Latreille's Skipper
Contents

Classification

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Gegenes[/i]
Species: [i]hottentota[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 31–34mm female 31–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small yellow or brown Skipper with yellow underside. Upperside [i]brown or yellow[/i] with markings depending on sex. [i]Yellow-ochre[/i] underside of both sexes conspicuous at rest, when wings closed. Hind wing underside has [i]two series of dark spots[/i], and a dark spot in the cell. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Similar to Water Watchman [i]Parnara monasi[/i] but upperside very different, and hind wing underside has [i]only one series of postdiscal dark marks[/i]. Underside identical to that of Common Hottentot Skipper [i]Gegenes hottentota[/i], as is the female upperside. The male lacks the conspicuous sex brand of Marsh Hottentot Skipper.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside [i]bright yellow[/i] with brown forewing tips and a [i]conspicuous triangular black discal sex brand[/i] on the forewing; hind wing yellow. Female upperside [i]dark brown[/i] with discal series of creamy buff spots on [i]both wings[/i]. Spots shifted distally from the rest of the series in areas M, and R5. Essentially identical to that of Common Hottentot Skipper.
 
Flight rapid and erratic; low down, no more than 1m above the ground, settling often on grass, and low vegetation. Found in marshy wet areas. Males form territories along grassy stream and pond edges; females are found more at random.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
 
Back to Top

Marshes in coastal Lowland and Riverine Forest edges, Savanna and Grassland from E Cape (Cwebe), KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland, Gauteng, Limpopo Province and e NW Province.

Habitat
Forest edges, wetlands, flatlands, gullies.

Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peak Apr–May.
Back to Top

No data, probably same Poaceae grasses as Common Hottentot Skipper.

Veined Skipper

Classification

Identification

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Abantis[/i]
Species: [i]venosa[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 36–41mm female 35–45mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized, Skipper with distinctive [i]black-veined ochre-yellow[/i] upperside. The only species with which it might be confused is Bicolored Skipper, [i]Abantis bicolor[/i], which is [i]brighter yellow[/i] with [i]black, not hyaline[/i] forewing spots and [i]lacks[/i] the hind wing underside white patch.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger and paler than males, with [i]more elongated wings[/i].
 
Males show strong territorial behaviour; they choose a prominent twig or leaf, usually on a hilltop shrub or tree. On this they perch and on occasion fly rapidly around their territory, with buzzing wings a blur. Other butterflies are attacked with vigour. Females are more sedentary and are usually found near the host plants. Both sexes perch wings-open.
 
There are two seasonal forms. wet season nominate form [i]venosa[/i], and dry season form [i]umvulensis[/i]. Nominate form [i]venosa[/i]: (A) Female upperside. (B) Female underside. Form [i]umvulensis[/i] is paler and has finer black lines: (C) Male upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Lowland Forest and Savanna from Swaziland, to KwaZulu-Natal (Maputaland), Mpumalanga, e Limpopo Province and further north.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, forest edges, hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks late summer (Feb–Apr) and spring (Aug–Nov).
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Pterocarpus rotundifolius[/i] and [i]P. brenanii[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Paradise Skippers.

Small sapphire. Upperside superficially similar to Red-line Sapphire [i]Iolaus sidus[/i], but dark median line crosses hind wing, and forewing blue [i]less extensive, not as bright[/i]. Underside has [i]conspicuous black-edged orange-yellow bands[/i] crossing underside of both wings. Very similar on both surfaces to Natal Yellow-banded Sapphire [i]Iolaus diametra natalica[/i] and close to Zimbabwe Yellow-banded Sapphire [i]I. nasisii[/i]. The three butterflies have very different ranges. The difference to [i]I. diametra natalica[/i] is the tiny black marginal line at the inner marginal side of the anal angle. In [i]I. aphnaeoides[/i] it is [i]single[/i]. The underside bands are much narrower than those of [i]I. nasisii[/i].
 
Sexes differ; female with wings more rounded, and white edge to forewing upperside blue; area distal to hind wing upperside postdiscal transverse dark stripe [i]white[/i], not [i]blue[/i] as in male.
 
Upper-canopy dweller, male adults seldom seen unless bred from larvae, but latter not difficult to find. Female usually flies near host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.

Rossouw's Skolly

Contents

Identification

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]rossouwi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 27–32mm female 30–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small butterfly, upperside ground colour varying from dull buff to bright buff. Upperside and forewing underside widely bordered with [i]grey-brown[/i] and having [i]conspicuous dark-and-white[/i] chequered cilia. Upperside and forewing underside have [i]heavier black spotting[/i] than Boland Skolly [i]T. protumnus[/i]. Hind wing underside has cryptic pattern of basal, postdiscal and marginal bands of darker scaling on a grey-brown ground. Has a submarginal series of black 'V'-shaped marks.
 
Slight sexual dimorphism. Male smaller than female; upperside usually [i]darker[/i] than female. Male forewing has [i]indistinct sex brand[/i] in basal part of veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2, where the veins are coloured dark brown to grey-brown.
 
[i]T. rossouwi[/i] lives in large colonies, usually in flat sandy ground. It appears [i]darker in flight[/i] than [i]T. protumnus[/i]. Flight is low and fluttering but can be fast and sustained, they settle often on low vegetation or rocks, where they may be approached with patience. Males are territorial and congregate around patches of bare gravelly or sandy soil; females fly around inspecting plants for the presence of their host ants. Should she find this she will lay one or two eggs.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) (E) Female undersides.

Small blue lycaenid. Underside ground colour pale grey with darker grey bands and blotches, outlined in white. Only distinguishable from other [i]Leptotes[/i] species in the Common Blue group ([i]L. brevidentatus, L. jeanneli[/i] and [i]L. babaulti[/i]) by genitalic dissection.

Palm-tree Night-fighter
[i]Zophopetes dysmephila[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Zophopetes[/i]
Species: [i]dysmephila[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–49mm female 45–52mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large brown Skipper. Upperside [i]rich grey-brown[/i] becoming grey at the apical outer margins; forewing has [i]hyaline discal and cellular spots[/i]. Underside [i]grey-brown[/i] with discal and postdiscal series of black spots. Antennal club conspicuously [i]white[/i]. Cilia plain pale brown. Similar to larger Strelitzia Night-fighter [i]Moltena fiara[/i] but has [i]forewing hyaline spots[/i]; Strelitzia Night-fighter antennal shaft [i]and club[/i] all white, and the underside hind wing lacks strong patterning.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Female has stouter abdomen; wings rounder, underside hind wing with [i]white streak[/i] along length of vein M1, [i]lacking[/i] in male.
 
Male territorial near host plants, fast buzzing flight at dusk or in dull cloudy weather, resembling a Hawk Moth (Sphingidae), with which it is sometimes confused. As its common name suggests it is crepuscular or nocturnal; sometimes attracted to lights. Females seen less frequently.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D), (E) Female undersides.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Coastal Lowland and Riverine forest from W Cape (Knysna) along coast to KwaZulu-Natal (Maputaland), Swaziland, and in lowveld Savanna Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province. Migrant; has also penetrated areas such as Gauteng and Cape Town, where host plants are grown as park and garden subjects.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, coast, parks and gardens.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Nov–May.
Back to Top

Indigenous [i]Phoenix reclinata[/i]; also exotic Arecaeae: [i]Phoenix sylvestris, P. dactylifera, P. canariensis, Cocos[/i] sp., [i]Raphia[/i] sp., [i]Dypsis lutescens[/i].

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Cacyreus[/i]
Species: [i]marshalli[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 15–23mm female 18–27mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown lycaenid. Cilia chequered in both sexes. Underside similar to that of Water Geranium Bronze [i]Cacyreus fracta fracta[/i]; ground colour similarly pale brown suffused with white; crossed by bands of [i]white-edged darker brown[/i]; underside has [i]two[/i] dark costal blotches. A triangular patch at the anal angle of the hind wing has a [i]double[/i] 'tooth' pointing towards the outer margin, at the apex of the triangle, in area M3. Also resembles Dickson's Geranium Bronze [i]Cacyreus dicksoni[/i] but the upperside ground colour is [i]less coppery[/i]. Hind wing underside is [i]lighter[/i] with the 'double tooth' less prominent. Hind wing has a small tail at the end of CuA2.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Very common and widespread anywhere that [i]Geranium[/i] or [i]Pelargonium[/i] plants grow; a familiar garden butterfly. Slow, fluttering flight not more than 1.5 to 2metres above the ground. Does not specialise in wetlands as does Water Geranium Bronze.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Very widespread due to adaptation to cultivated pelargoniums; probably originally only in sw South Africa, but has spread to the rest of the country and even to Europe (pest in Spain, has reached UK). In all areas except the most arid central Karoo - from W Cape (Cape Peninsula) along N Cape hills to Namibia; all over E Cape; at varying altitudes along Drakensberg chain into KwaZulu-Natal, Lesotho, Free State, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, and Limpopo and NW provinces.

Guineafowl
[i]Hamanumida daedalus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Limenitidinae
Genus: [i]Hamanumida[/i]
Species: [i]daedalus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 55–65mm female 60–78mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Distinctive medium-sized grey butterfly with tiny white spots edged with black. Its colouring resembles the Guinea Fowl, hence its common name. Well-worn specimens may appear dull and unattractive, but freshly emerged butterflies are striking. The only species that could be confused with it (habits are similar) is Mottled-green Nymph, [i]Euryphura achlys[/i], but that butterfly is much rarer and has a [i]metallic green[/i] upperside with a pattern of [i]regular, black[/i] blotches. Some seasonal variation. Wet season form f. [i]meleagris[/i] has prominent pattern of underside white spots mirroring upperside black spots.
 
Sexes similar, female larger, with wings more rounded.
 
Low, fast, gliding flight a few centimetres above the ground, wings open with occasional rapid wingbeats. Usually seen on bushveld paths and bare ground. Flies off rapidly to avoid pursuit. They settle readily, wings-open but are very wary and difficult to approach. Attracted to fallen fruit and animal faeces, and wet mud. They come to fruit baited traps.
 
(A) Male upperside, f. [i]meleagris[/i]. (B) Male underside, f. [i]meleagris[/i]. (C) Female upperside, f. [i]daedalus[/i]. (D) Female underside, f. [i]daedalus[/i].
 
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread in Savanna, Arid Savanna and Lowland Forest. From E Cape and KwaZulu-Natal Midlands to Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, and warmer parts of Gauteng.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuously brooded; peaks in midwinter and midsummer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Combretum molle[/i] and [i]Terminalia sericea[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Guinea Fowl.

Star Blue or Brilliant Blue
[i]Lepidochrysops asteris[/i]
alternative common name: Star Nimble Blue, Star Giant Cupid, Brilliant Nimble Blue, Brilliant Giant Cupid
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]asteris[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–40mm female 27–44mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, bright blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. One of the most brilliantly coloured members of the genus; similar to Patrician Blue [i]Lepidochrysops patricia[/i] but [i]deeper, richer blue[/i] and underside of both sexes [i]boldly patterned[/i], dove grey ground with white rings around [i]very large[/i] darker brown-grey markings. Also resembles (and used to be confused with) Trimen's Blue [i]L. trimeni[/i]; that species' upperside is deeper, [i]duller blue[/i] and the underside ground colour [i]much darker, almost black[/i], with [i]dark spots thinly ringed with white[/i]. Both surfaces of both sexes' hind wings have a [i]single prominent orange lunule[/i] above a large black spot at the anal angle in area CuA1. Hind wing carries a small tail at end of vein CuA2. Cilia plain whitish grey.
 
Sexually dimorphic; female upperside resembles female Patrician Blue in having blue discal and basal areas inside wide dark fuscous-grey margins, but blue is [i]brighter, deeper[/i]. Male upperside is [i]iridescent azure[/i] with a fine black marginal line.
 
Males - often a dozen or more - ascend hills at midday but seldom to summits, circling prominent trees or rocks, or flying along contours. Also found in flat country near prominent trees and shrubs. Flight rapid, jinking and erratic. They settle occasionally on low vegetation where they can be approached with stealth. Female flight more random; usually found on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos from W Cape, along Riviersonderendberge above Greyton, and Roodeberg near Worcester, along coastal ranges to E Cape (Vanstadensberg) and Grassland in KwaZulu-Natal Midlands.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, mountains, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Two broods from Port Elizabeth northwards, Sept–Nov and Feb–Mar, some overlap. Southern populations single-brooded, Nov–Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Selago[/i] spp., including [i]S. serrata, Ocimum burchellianum[/i] and [i]Plectranthus grandidentatus[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Ant Blues.

Identification
Small bright metallic blue sapphire. Paler blue than the larger Southern and Straight-line Sapphires [i]Iolaus silas[/i] and [i]I. silarus silarus[/i], with which it often flies. Easily identified by [i]thin, bright red underside lines[/i]. Male has conspicuous [i]sex brand[/i] at hind wing upperside costa.
 
Sexes differ. Female lacks the sex brand. Has white suffusion distal to basal blue, [i]less metallic[/i] than male, red submarginal lunules at anal angle of hind wing upperside.
 
Males perch atop hilltop shrubs and trees during midday hours, preferring those with glossy leaves against which their pale underside is not easy to spot. But the white and blue combination is conspicuous in flight. Females are seldom seen; found closer to host plants, and nectaring at low flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.

Coastal woodland from E Cape (East London) through Savanna and thorn belt to Tongaland and Bedford, KwaZulu-Natal coast and thorn belt (Weenen area) to Swaziland and Mpumalanga (Komatipoort).

Small butterfly with [i]coppery, bronzy-brown[/i] upperside and mid-grey

Fond of rocky slopes and low ridges from sea level to high mountain peaks. Low, zigzagging flight. Easy to confuse with other small brown lycaenids frequenting rocky Karoo and fynbos scrublands. Males very aggressive and territorial; females found on flowers and near host plants.

Mimosa Sapphire
[i]Iolaus mimosae rhodosense[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Iolaus[/i]
Species: [i]mimosae[/i]
Subspecies: [i]rhodosense[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–31mm female 30–32mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small sapphire. Superficially similar to Red-line Sapphire [i]Iolaus sidus[/i], but powder blue, not metallic blue upperside. Underside [i]darker grey[/i] than other blue sapphires found in South Africa; crossed by brown lines reminiscent of those on White-spotted Sapphire [i]I. lulua[/i], but these are [i]wavy[/i] and the median hind wing line has a strong white distal suffusion.
 
Sexes similar, male with [i]more angular[/i] wings than female, which is a lighter, less intense blue. Male has conspicuous [i]sex brand[/i] at hind wing upperside costa. [i]I. m. rhodosense[/i] has [i]paler, shinier upperside blue[/i] and [i]paler grey[/i] underside than nominate, and the female has fewer dark submarginal marks on the upperside hind wing.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Slow flight, similar to Bowker's Sapphire. Male perches alert on or inside prominent bushes, chasing intruders; female more sedentary, usually near host plants. Both sexes attracted to flowers.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread in Savanna across KwaZulu-Natal, to Mpumalanga, Gauteng (Magaliesberg), Limpopo and NW provinces, and N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, rocky ledges, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
One or more broods, Sept–Mar, peak Oct–Nov.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Actinanthella wyliei, Agelanthus dichrous, A. natalitius, Moquinella rubra[/i], and [i]Plicosepalus kalachariensis[/i].

Basuto Skolly
[i]Thestor basuta capeneri[/i]
alternative common name: Basuto Magpie
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]basuta[/i]
Subspecies: [i]capeneri[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 30–39mm female 35–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown butterfly with black upperside markings. Large for a [i]Thestor[/i]; unique and unmistakable; does not fit into any of the Skolly groups. [i]Brown[/i], as opposed to buff or grey; build [i]more robust[/i] than other Skollies and female has distinctive white forewing upperside black and white markings. Underside is pale grey-buff with discal area of forewing whitish, with black basal and postdiscal spots. Hind wing basal and postdiscal series are a darker buff-grey.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Males have acutely [i]pointed[/i] forewing and [i]straight[/i]
outer margin. Females have blunt-ended forewings and [i]convex[/i] outer margin Extent of
white on both wings of female is extremely variable. Some specimens are distinctly
[i]pied[/i]; others have hardly any white and are all dun-brown with heavy black forewing
blotches. [i]T. b. capeneri[/i] males have [i]more pointed[/i] forewing tips and both
sexes have more extensive white in the upperside discal areas of both wings than nominate.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Male flies fast, settling often on the ground or on stones. Females are sluggish and usually seen flying slowly, close to the ground, seeking out oviposition spots. Usually seen in small groups of a dozen or so, but occasionally much bigger numbers are seen, huge colonies covering large areas of Grassland.
 
(G) Male upperside. (H) Female upperside. (I) Male underside. (J) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland and Savanna in Gauteng, Limpopo Province and Mpumalanga.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, Oct–Nov and Feb–Apr.

No data.

Large, conspicuous black and yellow butterfly with well-developed spatulate tails. Both sexes visit flowers in the morning, particularly red ones. Attracted to brightly coloured shiny objects such as red signs, or cars with metallic paint.

Identification
Small dark butterfly. Very similar to Riley's Skolly [i]Thestor rileyi[/i] and Peninsula Skolly [i]T. yildizae[/i], but upperside darker. Underside forewing usually only has a single mid-cell spot; sub-basal spot absent. Discal band [i]broader[/i] than in [i]T. Yildizae[/i] and evenly oblique, with no pronounced break at area M2.
 
Sexes similar. Male darker, with squarer wings than female. Forewing tridentate sex brand is [i]large and dark grey-brown[/i] so that it is difficult to pick up against the ground colour; covering basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. [i]T. p. tempe[/i] has forewing underside discal spots [i]less elongate[/i] than in [i]T. p. petra[/i] and they are more offset at M3.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
[i]T. petra[/i] occupies large areas of hillsides at high altitude. Sometimes found in vast numbers. Flight weak, easy to follow, settling often on the ground or on low plants.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Female upperside. (G) Male underside.

Straight-line Sapphire
[i]Iolaus silarus silarus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Iolaus[/i]
Species: [i]silarus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]silarus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–38mm female 35–40mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of the larger sapphires; upperside [i]intense metallic blue[/i] with black margins and [i]shiny white[/i] underside. Underside hind wing crossed by submarginal [i]thin red line[/i] that is usually, but not always, straight, not curved toward the body as in Southern Sapphire [i]Iolaus silas[/i] or [i]jagged and black[/i] as in Trimen's Sapphire [i]I. trimeni[/i]. Upperside black margins narrower than in [i]I. silas[/i], particularly on the hind wing. Forewing tips [i]more pointed[/i] (in both sexes) than [i]I. silas[/i]. In males, the upperside red hind wing anal lunules that are conspicuous in [i]I. silas[/i] are [i]reduced or absent[/i].
 
Sexes differ slightly; female duller blue than male, hind wing upperside marginal band narrow; red only at anal angle, black-edged blue as far as M1, compared to very broad and red to M1 in [i]I. silas[/i]. Distal part of forewing upperside blue patch [i]suffused with white[/i] to lesser degree than in [i]I. silas[/i], sometimes absent. Male has conspicuous [i]sex brand[/i] at hind wing upperside costa.
 
Males perch atop tall forest trees or hilltop shrubs during midday hours, preferring those with glossy leaves against which their white underside is not easy to spot. But the white and blue combination is conspicuous in flight. Females are found closer to host plant, and nectaring at low flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Warm, wooded Savanna in n KwaZulu-Natal (coastal forest in Zululand); Savanna from Swaziland to Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, and further north. Afromontane Forest on Wolkberg and n Drakensberg.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas. Sept–Jan in cooler, western part of range.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Moquinella rubra, Erianthemum dregei[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Sapphires.
Back to Top






Rayed Blue
[i]Actizera lucida[/i]

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Actizera[/i]
Species: [i]lucida[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 15–23mm female 17–25mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny, blue or brown 'Blue'. Underside similar to other small Blues in that it has a brownish-grey ground colour with basal and discal series of [i]white-edged black spots[/i]; marginal and submarginal series of [i]white sagittate marks[/i], and a chevron-shaped, grey line in the cell edged in white. The hind wing underside has marginal black spots in CuA2 and 1A+2A. What sets it apart from most similar species is the [i]bright-white diagonal streak[/i] on underside hind wing along vein M3, from which the common name originates. Its relative, Red-clover Blue [i]Actizera stellata[/i], is the only other small 'Blue' to have this; but not all specimens show it, and that butterfly has an unmistakable brown-black upperside with [i]rows of white spots[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic on upperside. Male [i]dull blue[/i], female [i]brown[/i] with variable amount of basal blue.
 
Flight low, weak. Usually found singly or in small groups in thick grass.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.

Widespread from W Cape (Hermanus area) and grassy edges of Karoo, to Grassland, Forest and Savanna in Free State, KwaZulu-Natal, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, and Limpopo and NW provinces.

Flatlands, hillsides, forest edges, parks and gardens, coast.

Year-round, more numerous in summer.
Back to Top

Sexes differ in that the female upperside, as in many of the genus [i]Lepidochrysops[/i], has a row of [i]dark postdiscal spots[/i] on the forewing, and a [i]dark band[/i] crossing the hind wing, corresponding to the dark underside spotting. In some specimens these spots are absent. Male is bright blue with wide dark marginal borders.
 
Fast, erratic flight. Males congregate on hill tops and ridges, female flight random, lower down the slopes; seen less often.

Riley's Skolly

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]rileyi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–36mm female 32.5–40mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small dark grey-brown butterfly. Very closely resembles Knysna Skolly [i]Thestor brachycera[/i]. Usually has a [i]small white apical patch[/i]. Underside forewing has spots in median band disjointed: spot in CuA1 elongated, [i]protruding distad[/i] to the rest of the series, [i]missing[/i] in others of the Knysna Skolly species group; mid-cell spot often [i]double[/i]. Hind wing submarginal 'V'-shaped markings reduced; median line dark and well-defined.
 
Sexes similar. Male darker than female; tridentate sex brand is [i]large and grey-brown[/i]; covering basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2. Wings less rounded than female, which is a duller, more uniform shade of brown.
 
[i]T. rileyi[/i] lives in colonies on steeper, higher hillsides than [i]T. protumnus dukei[/i]. Fast, low flight, settling on rocks or low plants. Males form territories in open areas. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.

Fynbos. W Cape, from Helderberg (Somerset West) and Paarl Mountain, to Kouebokkeveldberg, Piketberg and Paardeberg ranges.

Larvae found inside Pugnacious Ant [i]Anoplolepis custodiens[/i] nests; trophallaxis from the ants, possibly also nest detritus.

Small butterfly with [i]bronzy-brown[/i] upperside and mid-grey underside crossed by darker grey or brown lines and bands. Forewing on both surfaces has black spot at anal angle, typical of [i]Leptomyrina[/i] black-eyes, usually [i]a basal-marginal series of two or three[/i] on the upperside. [i]Larger[/i] than Cape Black-eye [i]L. lara[/i], with more [i]angular[/i] wings; upperside colour a duller brown. Unlike Henning's Black-eye [i]L. henningi[/i], has [i]bright silvery grey to mauve[/i] basal colouring, more evident in the male, but visible in the female.
 
Sexes similar; male smaller with more angular wings. Male upperside carries pale row of hind wing postdiscal marks proximal to submarginal black spots. Male has stronger silvery grey to mauve basal flush than female.
 
Fond of rocky country where its host plants grow; common garden species. Low, zigzagging flight. Easy to confuse with other small brown lycaenids. Males very aggressive and territorial; females found on flowers and near host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Savanna, Arid Savanna, Grassland from E Cape to KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga and w Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, rocky ledges, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Nov and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Cotyledon barbeyi, C. orbiculata[/i], and [i]Kalanchoe, Crassula[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Black-eyes.

Perseus Opal
[i]Chrysoritis perseus[/i]

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]perseus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–28mm female 26–30mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, orange Opal. Range overlaps with Pan Opal [i]Chrysoritis pan[/i] and Trimen's Opal [i]C. trimeni[/i]. Both sexes with hind wing upperside silver-blue [i]more extensive[/i] than Pan Opal; variable amount and extent of black forewing spotting and dark marginal borders. Lacks the [i]pointed forewings and narrow marginal bands[/i] of [i]C. trimeni[/i]. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing variegated in shades of brown and cream; the brown varies from dark brown to tan, and the silvery streaks vary between being well-defined and almost absent.
 
Sexes differ. Female basal blue [i]less extensive[/i] and [i]darker[/i] than male, wings rounder, ground colour [i]paler orange[/i].
 
Lives in colonies on sand dunes and low hills. Flight very fast, usually higher off the ground than Trimen's Opal, Males on prominent features and low bushes; females lower down, on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
N Cape, on coastal dunes with Succulent Karoo in Hondeklip Bay/Groenriviermond area, inland to Wallekraal.
Back to Top
Habitat
Coast, flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
More than two broods, Aug–Mar, peak Nov.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Atriplex bolusii, Osteospermum oppositifolium, Roepera flexuosa, R. teretifolia, Tetraena[/i], and [i]Thesium[/i] spp. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster melanogaster[/i] and [i]C. capensis[/i] ants.

Identification
Bright blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue, upperside [i]brighter blue[/i] than most of the Koppie Blue group. Underside of both sexes [i]conspicuous pale grey ground colour[/i]. [i]Lepidochrysops oreas junae[/i] is larger than the nominate, and the underside has more extensive white markings, accentuating the contrast between dark and light markings.
 
Sexes differ in that the female upperside, as in many of the genus [i]Lepidochrysops[/i], has a row of [i]dark postdiscal spots[/i] on the forewing, and a [i]dark band[/i] crossing the hind wing, corresponding to the dark underside spotting.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Male ascends at midday to higher mountain slopes and flies rapidly around tops of ridges, and summits, with other lycaenids, settling often on the ground or on low vegetation. Female found lower down the slopes, usually near the host plant.

Identification
Smaller than [i]Serradinga bowkeri, S. kammanassiensis[/i]. White postdiscal markings small and not always distinct. Ground colour [i]shiny, coppery brown[/i]. Compared to [i]S. bowkeri[/i], outer margin of forewing notably [i]convex[/i]. White postdiscal markings small and not always distinct. Males appear black on the wing. Females redder and paler than males, white-ochre postdiscal spots on forewing extending more towards the base, white markings on underside much broader.
 
[i]Serradinga clarki dracomontana[/i] is larger than [i]S. c. clarkii[/i] with a more rounded wingshape. Postdiscal spots whiter and larger than in [i]S. c. clarkii[/i]. Usually found on hillsides with coarse [i]Merxmuellera[/i] grasses. Flight low, slow, fluttering; sometimes found in huge numbers. 4 subspp., geographically distinct.

Brooks's Opal

Classification

Species: [i]brooksi[/i]

Back to Top

Male 26–30mm female 28–32mm.

Identification
Orange Opal with opalescent blue upperside wing bases and [i]elongated, squared-off forewing tips[/i], outer margin strongly angled outwards at vein M3. Upperside orange much [i]darker[/i] on the upperside than nominate; hind wing blue basal patch [i]edged with black[/i]. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside [i]strongly variegated[/i] with 'streaky' markings and dark lines along veins in marginal area. Cilia heavily chequered with dark scaling along vein ends, and white patches in between. Similar wing shape to Dark Opal [i]Chrysoritis nigricans[/i], but [i]lacks the dark upperside borders[/i] of that species; also Brauer's Opal [i]C. braueri[/i] which also has extensive upperside orange, but occupies a totally different range.
 
Sexes similar. Female upperside paler, blue less extensive than male.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Found in scattered colonies in flat ground, among low vegetation. Males perch on top of plants or rocks, sallying forth to search for females. Both sexes found on flowers.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside.

Fynbos (rare) in W Cape, from Bredasdorp and Riversdale areas.

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Colotis[/i]
Species: [i]celimene[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–40mm female 34–40mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small Pierid with distinctive forewing tips. Distinctive, [i]broad deep lilac-purple[/i] apical half of male upperside forewing. Underside has some similarity to Veined Tip [i]Colotis vesta argillaceus[/i] in that it is brightly coloured with [i]dark bars crossing the wings[/i], but the forewing tip has a [i]pink-red patch at the base[/i].
 
[i]C. celimene amina[/i] female has [i]no purple in upperside forewing tip[/i]. Both sexes have [i]pointed[/i] forewing tips. Sexually dimorphic. Female different to male, depending on the subspecies.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Nominate male has distinct sexual behaviour: hovers
in circles, 2–4m up, close to a prominent tree, seldom settling, only moving away to
mate or chase off other males. At other times flies across the veld as do other Tips,
including the western subspecies [i]C. c. pholoe[/i]. Both sexes of both subspecies are found on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside.

Localised, uncommon in Arid Savanna in KwaZulu-Natal thorn belt (Weenen and parts of Umvoti, Umgeni and Bushman's River valleys), Limpopo Province from Sekhukhuneland north in rain shadow of Drakensberg to Zimbabwe and north of the Soutpansberg.

Pale Hairtail

Classification

Genus: [i]Anthene[/i]

Wingspan
Male 23–28mm female 25–32mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Dull coloured Hairtail with grey upperside, [i]flushed with metallic blue[/i]. Resembles Millar's Hairtail [i]Anthene millari[/i] but [i]larger[/i], upperside blue [i]less vivid, spreads across entire upperside[/i]. Often has [i]dark grey spots[/i] on both wings. Hind wing underside only has dark spots along costa. Both sexes' undersides have black-and-orange lunules at anal angle, and [i]short, bristle-like tails[/i] at the ends of the cubital veins.
 
Sexes similar; female has [i]deeper, stronger blue[/i] upperside markings than male. Underside similar to Common Hairtail [i]Anthene definita[/i] but [i]paler[/i] in male, [i]darker[/i] in female, with grey spots ringed with darker grey and white.
 
Males congregate at hilltops, perching on prominent shrubs and periodically taking off to pursue other butterflies. Females are found lower down, on flowers and close to the host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.

Widespread in Savanna and Grassland in N Cape, E Cape, KwaZulu-Natal, Free State, Gauteng, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, and further north.

Year-round, peak in warmer months.

Small, brilliant red-orange Copper. Similar to Western Sorrel Copper [i]Lycaena orus[/i]; the main difference being the hind wing underside, which has basal and postdiscal rows of [i]grey-black spots, much[/i] darker than the ground colour, with a [i]white ring[/i] surrounding each spot.

Usually found in vleis and along watercourses where host plant grows. Congregates in damp spots along streams even in the driest Karoo and Savanna. Slow, circling flight, settling often. Males and females fly together.

Angola White Lady

Classification
Family: Papilionidae
Subfamily: Papilioninae
Genus: [i]Graphium[/i]
Species: [i]angolanus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]angolanus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–70mm female 70–75mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized black-and-white butterfly, one of the tailless 'Swordtails'. Upperside ground colour black, with white spots and discal patches; underside suffused yellow-ochre with red at wing bases. Similar to the slightly smaller White Lady [i]Graphium morania[/i], but has [i]three large white spots[/i] in forewing cell, the central one being 'L'-shaped.
 
Sexes very similar; male has buff to pink hair pencils in a pouch on the inner hind wing margin. These are only exhibited when he is fluttering before a female during courtship.
 
Fast-flying, often rapidly traverses country. Flight faster than White Lady, settles less often. Found on wet mud and flowers; male also found flying along high ridges, where he seldom settles.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Warm wooded Savanna from lowveld of n and e KwaZulu-Natal, spreading further west
in the north, into Mpumalanga, Gauteng, and Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer months, peaks Nov and Feb.
Back to Top

[i]Annona senegalensis, Friesodielsia obovata, Hexalobus monopetalus[/i], and [i]Sphedamnocarpus pruriens[/i].

Buxton's Hairstreak
[i]Hypolycaena buxtoni buxtoni[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Hypolycaena[/i]
Species: [i]buxtoni[/i]
Subspecies: [i]buxtoni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 25–30mm female 28–33mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very easy to mistake for an [i]Iolaus[/i] sapphire, with bright white underside crossed
by straight dark lines. But lines [i]thinner[/i] than in any sapphire, and underside
brighter than Azure Hairstreak [i]Hemiolaus caeculus[/i] or Purple-brown and Coastal
Hairstreaks [i]H. philippus, H. lochmophila[/i]. The lines crossing the underside are [i]blackish-brown[/i], not [i]orange or pale brown[/i]. The hind wing tails are much longer, in proportion to the wing, than any [i]Iolaus, Hemiolaus[/i], or [i]Hypolycaena[/i] species found in South Africa. They approach the tail length found in tropical Hairstreaks. [i]Bright white[/i] underside of both sexes conspicuous in flight.
 
The sexes are very dimorphic. Male upperside iridescent [i]steel blue[/i], as opposed to the [i]sapphire or powder blue[/i] of an [i]Iolaus[/i]. Female has conspicuous upperside [i]white discal bands[/i] on grey-black ground.
 
Fairly slow flight along forest edge, settling frequently on shrubs. Males defend small territories near prominent leaves and twigs. Females fly low among the vegetation, feeding on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Lowland and Riverine Forest from Kei River to Kosi Bay (KwaZulu-Natal) and north.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, Sept–May, peak Oct/Nov, and Feb–May, peak Mar/Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
No data from South Africa.
Back to Top
Group
Hairstreaks.

Mite Sandman
[i]Spialia paula[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Spialia[/i]
Species: [i]paula[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 20–24mm female 23–27mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny dark Skipper with black-and-white chequered upperside and forewing underside. One of a group of very similar little butterflies, which are difficult to tell apart from the upperside markings. To be reasonably sure of identification a clear view of the hind wing underside is necessary. Hind wing underside has pearly white median band made up of joined spots. That in the cell and submarginal spot in area M2 are [i]joined by a dark edged thin silvery line[/i]. In this respect resembles Star Sandman [i]S. asterodia[/i] and Grassveld Sandman [i]S. agylla[/i] but those are larger and the hind wing marks are plain white, not pearly. Cilia chequered.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
Fast, buzzing, low flight, settling often, wings open. Male hilltops, but usually not at main summit. Also in flat country. Favours patches of stony ground among low vegetation. Male circles these areas with low, rapid flight, fast wingbeats. Female sometimes near the males, more usually looking for host plants. Both sexes feed on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare and localised in Arid Savanna and grassy areas of Savanna, from w N Cape to n E Cape, sw Free State, NW Province, w Gauteng, and central Limpopo Province (Waterberg, Strydpoortberg, Wolkberg).
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, hill tops, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods, Jul–Mar, peaks Sept–Nov (WSF) and Feb (DSF).
Back to Top
Larval food
No data.
Back to Top
Group
Sandmen.

Identification
A widespread, large [i]Pseudonympha[/i]. Similar to Gaika Brown [i]P. gaika[/i] and Golden Gate Brown [i]P. paragaika[/i], but [i]duller, paler[/i] and with [i]more restricted[/i] orange markings. Lacks the fine dark line inside the upperside margin, of [i]P. poetula[/i].
 
[i]Pseudonympha trimenii nieuwveldensis[/i], like [i]P. t. namaquana[/i] has reduced forewing reduced orange-red, and brighter silver-grey on the hind wing underside. Sexes similar, female more brightly coloured, wings longer than male. Hind wing with [i]white marginal line[/i] on underside.
 
Flight fast and jinking; settles often on the ground or to feed on flowers; female tends to stay hidden in the coarse [i]Merxmuellera[/i] grass whose clumps they frequent.
 
4 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(L) Male upperside. (M) Male underside. (N) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Found in coarse Grassland at high altitudes. [i]P. t. nieuwveldensis[/i] in Nama Karoo in Nuweveldberg near Beaufort West, W Cape.

Habitat
Mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, usually early Sept to late Nov.
Back to Top
Larval food
Poaceae grasses, including [i]Merxmuellera stricta[/i], and other coarse, wiry grasses.

Marieps Battling Glider
[i]Cymothoe alcimeda marieps[/i]
Contents

Wingspan
Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Limenitidinae
Genus: [i]Cymothoe[/i]
Species: [i]alcimeda[/i]
Subspecies: [i]marieps[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–50mm female 45–55mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized butterfly. Battling Glider is the smaller of South Africa's two [i]Cymothoe[/i] species; the other being Blonde Glider [i]Cymothoecoranus coranus[/i]. Compared to that species, apart from size, [i]C. alcimeda[/i] has [i]more angulate[/i] wings and, usually, a more [i]heavily marked[/i] underside.
 
[i]C. a. marieps[/i] male has a distinct, dark trilobed mark in the middle of the forewing upperside cell. Two female forms named. Sexually dimorphic: male upperside creamy white; both sexes' underside cryptic.
 
Both sexes have the typical Limenitidinae gliding flight with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Males perch high up on forest edge trees and shrubs, and sally forth to chase away all other insects. When there is more than one male in a forest clearing, constant aerial battles take place, hence the common name. Females are found close to the host plants. Both sexes regularly drink at wet mud, and nectar from flowers. They are also attracted to fruit bait.
 
5 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(O) Male upperside. (P) Male underside, light form. (Q) Male underside, dark form. (R) Female f. [i]marieps[/i] upperside has [i]pale ochre[/i] discal band. (S) Female f. [i]marieps[/i] underside. (T) Female f. [i]penningtoni[/i] upperside has [i]dull ochreous-orange[/i] discal band. (U) Female f. [i]penningtoni[/i] underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane Forest south of Olifants R, Mariepskop to Barberton (Mpumalanga).
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, mainly summer from Oct; peak Nov and Feb–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Kiggelaria africana[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Gliders.

Identification
Small, green-grey Skipper with black hind wing carrying white discal bar. Common name descriptive of forewing upperside, which is mid grey-brown with bands of moss-green edged in black and paler grey, with small hyaline spots at the end of the cell and in the apex. Underside markings mirror upperside in white on a mid-brown ground. Cilia plain.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
[i]Roosting posture[/i] distinctive, wings folded downwards, moth-like, abdomen curled upwards towards thorax. Seldom found on hill tops. Low flight skipping and circling, not very fast. Male patrols territory, settling momentarily on vantage points with open wings. Both sexes found on flowers and wet mud.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.

Widespread but uncommon. On E side of South Africa, in woodland clearings and rides, open grassy bush, vleis and riverine bush, coast and wooded hillsides from W Cape and N Cape, to E Cape, Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal, Free State, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, and Limpopo and NW provinces, and further north.

Medium–small yellow-orange Pierid. Upperside [i]orange with black borders[/i]. Underside hind wing of both sexes green, forewing underside green where upperside is black. The only other small bright yellow Pierids, Grass Yellows genus [i]Eurema[/i], and Spiller's Sulphur Yellow [i]Dixeia spilleri[/i], lack the forewing black cell spot, and are [i]yellow, not orange[/i].

Female is polymorphic. Normal form [i]electo[/i] has ground colour pale orange-yellow with dark marginal borders, within which are pale yellow spots; f. [i]aurivillius[/i] has yellow replaced by [i]grey-white[/i] on upperside and underside.
 
Low, fluttering flight, usually close to host plants, never far from flowers.

Throughout South Africa in all biomes.

Identification
Small white butterfly with black borders, hind wing spots and a forewing bar stretching from the costa but not crossing the wing. Legs [i]bright yellow[/i]. Has some similarity in flight pattern to similar-sized African Wood White [i]Leptosia alcesta inalcesta[/i], with which it flies. But that butterfly [i]lacks[/i] the broad dark margins and has a [i]single forewing discal spot[/i], not a band.
 
Sexes similar. Females larger than males.
 
Weak, fluttering flight. Flies slowly in the shade of trees in the forest understorey, settling on exposed twigs and the ends of tendrils, slowly opening and closing its wings. Often found flying with Zulu Buff [i]Teriomima zuluana[/i] and Spotted Buff [i]Pentila tropicalis[/i]. When handled, exudes bitter smelling fluid from the thorax, so it is probably a distasteful model, but it is not certain which species of lepidoptera mimic it.

Medium–large, pied Skipper. Upperside [i]dark brown to black; forewing elongated[/i]. Forewing has series of discal and apical [i]semi-hyaline white[/i], sharp-edged spots. Small butterfly, but large for a black [i]Thestor[/i]. Very dark upperside ground colour, with white cilia [i]prominently chequered with black at vein ends[/i]. [i]T. stepheni[/i] occurs in large colonies spread over large areas of mountainside. Male fast-flying, usually low down, settles often on low rocks or plants. Female less often encountered; flight slower.

Classification

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 55–70mm female 65–85mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium to large sized Charaxes. Superficially similar to Foxy Charaxes [i]Charaxes saturnus saturnus[/i], but upperside is [i]much darker[/i], and has unmistakable [i]silvery underside[/i]. [i]C. d. solitaria[/i] is the smallest subspecies; wings are shorter and less elongate at the wing tip. The male has narrower, darker upperside median band than [i]C. d. entabeni[/i]; female has deep orange bands like [i]C. d. entabeni[/i]. Both sexes have [i]greatly extended[/i] underside silvery white bands and the submarginal lunules almost cover the entire outer area of the wings. It is a pure forest butterfly, as opposed to a Savanna dweller.
 
Sexes similar; female similar to male but larger, paler, with less angular wings.
 
Powerful, high flight in the canopy and around tree tops. Males territorial, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
4 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(H) Male upperside. (I) Male underside.

Confined to Afromontane Forest on Blouberg range, Limpopo Province.
Back to Top

Forest edges, flatlands, coast, mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top

[i]C. d. entabeni[/i] and probably [i]C. d. solitaria[/i] year-round, more common late summer to autumn; [i]C. d. moerens[/i] and nominate Sept–May, weak peak Oct, stronger peak Mar–Apr.

Myrtaceae spp., including [i]Syzygium cordatum[/i] and S. [i]guineense[/i].

Identification
Small, dull grey-buff butterfly. Two distinct colour morphs - yellow-buff and mouse brown. Forewing more [i]acutely angled[/i] than Mountain [i]Thestor montanus[/i] and Rooiberg [i]T. rooibergensis[/i] Skollies. [i]Duller[/i] than [i]T. pictus[/i]. Submarginal row of 'V'-shaped marks [i]elongated and dark[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. Female paler, sometimes [i]much larger[/i] than male; both sexes variable in size. Male forewing has dark brown sex brand in basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2.
 
[i]T. vansoni[/i] lives in colonies, usually on high, north-facing mountain slopes, in flat, rocky depressions. The females fly more slowly than the males. Flight is low, fast and sustained, dodging between rocks. They settle often on low vegetation or rocks, but are wary and difficult to approach. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.

Friar
[i]Amauris niavius dominicanus[/i]

Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Danainae
Genus: [i]Amauris[/i]
Species: [i]niavius[/i]
Subspecies: [i]dominicanus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 80–85mm, female 78–82mm.
Back to Top
Identification
The largest black-and-white Danaine found in South Africa. A widespread shade-loving butterfly seen in forests. Seldom found in the open, except at attractive flowers; occasionally seen high in forest canopy. Generally solitary but sometimes swarms on wounded plants exuding pyrrolizidine alkaloids. Largest South African [i]Amauris[/i]; conspicuously marked black and white. Sexes similar. Male has less white on wings than female. Female has more rounded wings. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Mimic
Female Mocker Swallowtail (f. [i]hippocoonides[/i]), both sexes of Variable Diadem (f. [i]wahlbergi[/i]), and female Forest Queen [i]Charaxes wakefieldi[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
More common in north than Novice. Coastal and inland Riverine Forest, dense lowland forest. KwaZulu-Natal (Umkomaas), Swaziland, north to Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round (peak late summer/autumn).
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Cynanchum[/i] and [i]Tylophora[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Friars.
Back to Top

Peninsula Skolly
[i]Thestor yildizae[/i]

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]yildizae[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 25–32mm female 28–36.5mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small dark butterfly. The only black [i]Thestor[/i] on Cape Peninsula. Compared to Knysna Skolly [i]Thestor protumnus[/i] has much darker upperside in both sexes - black discal spots [i]difficult to discern[/i] from background - and [i]distinctly chequered[/i] cilia. Very similar to Riley's Skolly [i]T. rileyi[/i]. Forewing underside discal band of spots narrow, evenly oblique with no break at area M2; only a faint mark in area 1A+2A.
 
Sexes similar. Male darker, with squarer wings than female. Forewing tridentate sex brand is [i]large and pale grey-brown[/i]; covering basal part of CuA1 and CuA2, spreading along veins M3, CuA1 and CuA2.
 
[i]T. yildizae[/i] lives in large colonies on high mountain slopes and ledges. Fast, low flight, settling often on rocks or low plants. Males form territories in open areas. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) (D) Male undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos. Only found high up on slopes of Cape Peninsula mountains, particularly Muizenberg, W Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, late Nov to early Feb.
Back to Top
Larval food
Larvae found in Pugnacious Ant [i]Anoplolepis custodiens[/i] nests, but no data on food.
Back to Top
Group
Skollies.

Garden Acraea

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Heliconiinae
Genus: [i]Acraea[/i]
Species: [i]horta[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–50mm female 49–53mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Popular, familiar garden butterfly. Closely resembles male Wandering Donkey Acraea [i]Acraea neobule neobule[/i]. Black spots larger and more numerous, the red is [i]deeper[/i], and the forewing hyaline area [i]more suffused with black[/i]. The female of [i]A. n. neobule[/i] is red like the male. Also similar to Machequena Acraea [i]A. machequena[/i], but hind wing upperside marginal lunules are not dentate, and Rainforest Acraea [i]A. boopis[/i] but does not have wide hind wing upperside black marginal band.
 
Sexually dimorphic: male bright brick red, female variable, from dull brown-red to tawny buff. Hind wing margin of both sexes a continuous dark band with lunules of ground colour.
 
Slow, fluttering flight, usually close to host plant; flowers visited often. May swarm locally when conditions are right.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.
Mimic
(Possibly) Boisduval's False Acraea [i]Pseudacraea boisduvali trimenii[/i] f. [i]colvillei[/i], which is much larger.
Back to Top
Distribution
Usually in large, concentrated colonies. Afromontane Forest fragments from W Cape (Cape Town) along escarpment into E Cape, KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga, Limpopo Province, Gauteng and NW Province, also Riverine Forest.
Back to Top
Habitat
Parks and gardens, forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, more common Oct–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Kiggelaria africana, Passiflora coerulea, P. mollissima[/i] and [i]P. manicata[/i]; absent from [i]P. edulis[/i].

Limpopo Battling Glider
[i]Cymothoe alcimeda transvaalica[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
