Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Limenitidinae
Genus: [i]Cymothoe[/i]
Species: [i]alcimeda[/i]
Subspecies: [i]transvaalica[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–50mm female 45–55mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized butterfly. Battling Glider is the smaller of South Africa's two [i]Cymothoe[/i] species; the other being Blonde Glider [i]Cymothoecoranus coranus[/i]. Compared to that species, apart from size, [i]C. alcimeda[/i] has [i]more angulate[/i] wings and, usually, a more [i]heavily marked[/i] underside. [i]C. a. transvaalica[/i] male has a series of discrete dark postmedial angular marks on the upperside of both wings. Two female forms named. Male upperside creamy white; both sexes' underside cryptic.
 
Both sexes have the typical Limenitidinae gliding flight with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Males perch high up on forest edge trees and shrubs, and sally forth to chase away all other insects. When there is more than one male in a forest clearing, constant aerial battles take place, hence the common name. Females are found close to the host plants. Both sexes regularly drink at wet mud, and nectar from flowers. They are also attracted to fruit bait.
 
5 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(V) Male upperside. (W) Male underside, light form. (X) Male underside, dark form. (Y) Male underside, brown form. (Z) Female f. [i]transvaalica[/i] upperside has [i]cream to ochreous-yellow[/i] discal band. (AA) Female f. [i]transvaalica[/i] underside. (AB) Female f. [i]aurantifascia[/i] upperside has [i]bright orange[/i] discal band. Female f. [i]aurantifascia[/i] underside as (AA) upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane Forest in Limpopo Province escarpment - Lekgalameetse, Woodbush, to Duiwelskloof.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, mainly summer from Oct; peak Nov and Feb–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Kiggelaria africana[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Gliders.

Brown Playboy
[i]Virachola antalus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Virachola[/i]
Species: [i]antalus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–34mm female 22–40mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Probably our largest Playboy, but the size varies greatly, probably depending on the size of the seeds the larvae fed on. Males are rich brown above with a strong purple gloss when viewed at an acute angle.
 
Underside mid grey in both sexes; submarginal and postdiscal rows of [i]brown[/i] lines are 'cut' into segments by the wing veins, and basal hind wing spots [i]also brown, but sometimes with a red tinge[/i]. Both sexes have a single white-tipped tail at the hind wing anal angle.
 
Sexes differ on the upperside. The female has [i]bright, pale blue[/i] discal patches, brighter than other Playboy females; appears blue on the wing.
 
Males are strongly territorial, on hill tops, prominent trees and shrubs, or rocks; rapid, whirring flight. Female flies more slowly. Both sexes found on flowers near host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside.(E), (F) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Most widespread and common [i]Deudorix[/i] sp. w, s and ne South Africa; absent from the arid interior and high mountains.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, hill tops, flatlands, coast, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Sept–Oct and Mar–May.
Back to Top

Swaarweerberg Opal
[i]Chrysoritis beaufortia sutherlandensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]beaufortia[/i]
Subspecies: [i]sutherlandensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–36mm female 32–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, bright orange Opal. Closely resembles Pyramus Opal [i]Chrysoritis pyramus[/i]. Upperside orange colour [i]less red[/i]; dark borders and hind wing spotting [i]narrower, more variable[/i] in extent. Male shiny opalescence [i]paler[/i], more [i]greenish[/i] in shade. Forewing dark borders vary from narrow to so broad as to cover one-third of the wing. Cilia boldly chequered. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing [i]pale sandy[/i] colour variegated with darker postdiscal band in both sexes; few silver sagittate marks. Specimens from higher rainfall areas have darker basal markings.
 
[i]C. b. sutherlandensis[/i] is [i]paler with less conspicuous cilia[/i] on all wing surfaces than nominate. Dark suffusion between basal blue and marginal border of forewing upperside between CuA1 and CuA2, prominent in nominate, usually [i]absent[/i] in [i]C. b. sutherlandensis[/i]. Sexes dimorphic; female with basal blue [i]limited[/i], in some specimens only a few scales.
 
4 subspp., geographically or altitudinally distinct. Fast, low flight. Sometimes seen in huge numbers, swarming on pink mesembryanthemum flowers. Males are usually found on hilltops, perching on prominent rocks and low plants.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Male underside. (F) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Nama Karoo near Sutherland on Roggeveld escarpment, W Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, flatlands, hill tops, hillsides, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood, Aug–Feb depending on locality.
Back to Top

[i]Dimorphotheca cuneata, Osteospermum moniliferum, Norlindhia amplectens[/i], Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster capensis[/i] ants.

Identification
Bright blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Similar to Southern Blue [i]Lepidochrysops australis[/i], upperside [i]deeper, purer blue[/i], forewing upperside marginal borders [i]narrower. Has more pointed[/i] forewing apex. [i]Paler[/i] underside ground colour, all markings dusted with white scales; [i]broader[/i] submarginal row of white sagittate marks on hind wing.
 
Sexes differ in that the female upperside, as in many of the genus [i]Lepidochrysops[/i], has a row of [i]dark postdiscal spots[/i] on the forewing, and a [i]dark band[/i] crossing the hind wing, corresponding to the dark underside spotting. In many specimens however, the forewing has no dark spots.
 
Male flies fast over coastal sand dunes; territories around large clumps of shrubs, dune peaks and clearings in dense vegetation. Female flight random; usually found on flowers.

Small Orange Acraea
[i]Telchinia serena[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Mimic
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Heliconiinae
Genus: [i]Telchinia[/i]
Species: [i]serena[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–40mm female 36–44mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright orange Bitter Acraea. The male is quite distinctive compared to other small butterflies in this genus. In wetlands the male may be mistaken for Marsh Acraea [i]T. rahira rahira[/i], but the solid black marginal border with ground colour spots is diagnostic. Some of the female forms with white forewing patches may be mistaken in flight for other Bitter Acraeas with such markings, but the hind wing underside marginal series of black-edged lunules is also diagnostic.
 
Sexes dimorphic. Male consistently orange, with characteristic spotted black margins, and black blotch at end of forewing cell on upperside. Females are very variable (a range is illustrated), from being similar to the male, to greater or lesser suffusion of black, white, buff and brown, to transparent. The sexes' undersides are similar.
 
Slow, low, fluttering flight among grass and low shrubs. Often seen in huge numbers. Roosts communally on long grass stems.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside, male-like. (C) Female upperside, light colour form. (D) Female upperside, dark colour form. (E) Male or female underside.
Mimic
(Possibly) Waterberg Copper [i]Erikssonia edgei[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread in wooded Savanna, riverine bush and forest edges north from E Cape (East London) to KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga and Limpopo and NW provinces. Also, more arid areas in w Free State.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, more common in the warmer months.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hermannia[/i] spp., [i]Triumfetta rhomboidea, T. annua[/i] and [i]T. pilosa[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Bitter Acraeas.

Clark's Rocksitter
[i]Durbaniella clarki clarki[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbaniella[/i]
Species: [i]clarki[/i]
Subspecies: [i]clarki[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 18–24mm female 18–26mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very small butterfly with patterns of orange or orange-red and black on the upperside; 
 has a greater or lesser amount of black in the centre of the forewing depending on sex and
subspecies. Underside irrorated with black, grey and white with tiny submarginal spots on
the hind wing. The other Rocksitters that fly in the same areas are Boland Rocksitter
[i]Durbaniopsis saga[/i] and two of the races of Amakosa Rocksitter, [i]Durbania amakosa
amakosa[/i] and [i]D. a. penningtoni[/i]. [i]Durbaniella clarki[/i] is generally smaller
than either, although small males of [i]D. saga[/i] can be in the same size range. It can
immediately be distinguished from that species by the underside; [i]D. clarki[/i] lacks
the [i]conspicuous dark and light bands[/i] of [i]D. saga[/i]. Compared to [i]D.
amakosa[/i], the differences are sex-related. Females of [i]D. amakosa[/i] are always much
larger and have more extensive, better defined patterns of orange or orange-red and black
on the upperside. [i]D. a. amakosa[/i] males have [i]discrete[/i] orange-red spots on the
upperside. [i]D. a. penningtoni[/i] males have very similar upperside markings to [i]D.
clarki[/i] but they are more of a [i]yellow-buff[/i] colour and the hind wing base is
[i]dark[/i].
 
Variable degree of sexual dimorphism depending on subspecies. Nominate subspecies [i]D. c. clarki[/i] upperside colouration varies from light orange to brick red; discal black patch well developed in both sexes but female has a broader postdiscal orange band than the male.
 
4 subspp., geographically distinct; varying in markings and colour.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos from Langeberg (above Riversdale) along Swartberg to Kammanassieberg (above Uniondale), Schoemanspoort, and along Witteberge to Willowmore (E Cape).
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, rocky ledges, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Sept–Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.
Back to Top






Gaudy Commodore
[i]Precis octavia sesamus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Precis[/i]
Species: [i]octavia[/i]
Subspecies: [i]sesamus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–60mm female 55–63mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized butterfly. It has two seasonal forms, which are very different in appearance and habits. Dry season (winter) form has blue upperside and green-black underside. Wet season (summer) form is orange-pink with black bands and rows of spots. Winter form is unique; summer form could be confused on the wing with Pirate [i]Catacroptera cloanthe[/i] or one of the Jokers, [i]Byblia[/i] spp. It lacks the [i]plain underside[/i] of the former and the [i]pale bands and spots[/i] of the latter, which are smaller butterflies.
 
Sexes similar within the forms; females slightly larger.
 
Flies at low height to a metre or two above the ground. Short glides interspersed with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Flies away rapidly if disturbed; males strongly territorial, sitting on prominent point, chasing away intruders. and if chased away, usually returning to where first seen. Summer form is a very active butterfly, usually found on open hillsides and summits. Winter form is more skulking, found more often gardens and woods near montane Grassland, or along stream banks. It hibernates in deep gullies and under banks and rocks; roosts gregariously. Several dozen may be disturbed from such secluded shelters. Both forms are often found nectaring on flowers.
 
Wet season form f. [i]natalensis[/i] bright orange-red with dark wing bases, marginal bands and complete submarginal row of black spots. Dry season form f. [i]sesamus[/i] deep blue with bands of black and paler blue spots; a submarginal row of red spots, and white submarginal spots at the forewing apex. Occasional intermediates occur, which vary greatly in colour, from red and blue, to purple, with varying extent of dark markings.
 
(A) Male upperside f. [i]natalensis[/i]. (B) Female underside f. [i]natalensis[/i]. (C) Male upperside f. [i]sesamus[/i]. (D) Female underside f. [i]sesamus[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread in Grassland, Savanna and Afromontane Forest, from e W Cape to KwaZulu-Natal, Lesotho, Free State, Gauteng, Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces, and further north.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, hill tops, hillsides, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Form [i]natalensis[/i] mainly Aug–Mar, f. [i]sesamus[/i] Mar–Aug.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Plectranthus[/i] spp., including [i]P. esculentus, Rabdosiella calycina, Pycnostachys reticulata, P. urticifolia[/i]. In captivity, cultivated [i]Coleus[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Commodores.
Back to Top

Identification
Similar to Vàri's Brown [i]P. vàrii[/i] but upperside [i]dull grey-brown[/i], with [i]smaller[/i] orange-red markings restricted to wing tips, and [i]small[/i] ocelli. Underside similar to darker [i]P. vàrii[/i] specimens, but variable amount of [i]pale scaling[/i] along the veins of the hind wing, discal brown band [i]less distinct[/i].
 
Sexes similar. Female paler, wings more rounded than male, stouter abdomen.
 
May fly in huge numbers in marshy Grasslands and hillside stream beds. Flight bouncing, slow; female reluctant to take wing.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.

Cool, wet high-altitude Grassland from E Cape (Witteberge to Amatolas), to Lesotho, e Free State (Golden Gate Highland NP), the KwaZulu-Natal Drakensberg, and very high Mpumalanga mountains (eg Verloren Valei near Dullstroom).

Identification
Medium-sized dull blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Underside [i]warm grey[/i] with distinctive regular discal pattern of [i]darker brown spots[/i], easily recognisable when sitting.
 
Sexes dimorphic; male upperside [i]steel blue[/i], female [i]dark brown-grey[/i]; darker forewing discal spots, [i]basal blue flush[/i]. Specimens from Limpopo Province are [i]brighter blue[/i], wings [i]shorter, more pointed[/i], and underside spots [i]smaller, more sharp-edged[/i].
 
Difficult to follow and identify on the wing due to extremely rapid and sustained flight, and dark colour. Male patrols hillsides, visiting summits. Female lower on slopes, usually on flowers of host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside, Limpopo population.(C) Female upperside. (D)
Female underside, KwaZulu-Natal population.
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland. From Drakensberg foothills (Mbashe River), E Cape, to KwaZulu-Natal Midlands, Swaziland, along escarpment hills to Mpumalanga (Volksrust, Verloren Valei, Barberton hills), Gauteng (Suikerbosrand NR). Also, Limpopo Province (Wolkberg near Haenertsburg and Soekmekaar, and Soutpansberg).

Hillsides, hill tops.

Identification
A widespread small brown butterfly that superficially resembles Silver-bottom Brown [i]Pseudonympha magus[/i] and Cape Brown [i]Cassionympha detecta[/i]. Compared to [i]P. magus[/i] it lacks the hind wing underside ocelli and dark transverse line. Compared to [i]C. detecta[/i], it has a darker brown hind wing underside, which usually carries a submarginal row of tiny cream-white dots.
 
[i]Melampias huebneri steniptera[/i] has narrower and more pointed forewings than nominate, especially in the male. Sexes similar, female with longer, more rounded wings. The rusty orange-red forewing colouring that surrounds the apical ocellus in the male upperside extends into the cell and sometimes to the wing base in the female.
 
Low, slow fluttering flight; settles with wings open before suddenly closing them. Can sometimes found in huge numbers.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct.

Medium–small dark reddish brown Skipper with discal and postdiscal rows of darker spots. Female of nominate form has a white hind wing underside and may be mistaken on the wing for Clouded Flat [i]Tagiades flesus[/i], but it is smaller and has a large hyaline blotch in forewing area CuA2.

Identification
Very similar to Common Sailer [i]Neptis laeta[/i], but with a [i]larger white spots[/i] in forewing upperside cell, and the black veins in the hind wing upperside white band do not penetrate far into the white. Another diagnostic feature from populations further north, is a [i]wider[/i] hind wing white patch, but that does not seem to hold for South African specimens.
 
Specimens previously allocated to [i]N. penningtoni[/i] have been found by genitalic dissection to be Serene Sailer [i]N. serena[/i].
 
Slow, sailing, gliding flight, wings open flat, with infrequent rapid wingbeats. Flies fairly low along forest edges. Male perches on prominent twigs or leaves and sallies forth to inspect intruders. Attracted to flowers and wet earth. Female usually stays close to host plant.
 
Sexes similar.

Small dark Skipper with distinctly chequered cilia, dark grey to brown underside has [i]arrowhead-shaped[/i] glossy white streak in area M, of hind wing, forms broken line with elongated submedian white mark of cell. [i]Kedestes barberae bunta[/i] is the smallest and rarest of the three. As in [i]K. b. bunta[/i] the underside hind wing lines do not form such a distinct arrowhead, and the ground colour is [i]rich brown[/i]. Sexes similar, females paler, wings more elongated, abdomen stouter.
 
3 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight low, circling and zigzagging over grass, settling on vegetation or ground. Usually only found close to concentrations of the host plant.

Classification

Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]

Male 65–72mm female 80–90mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large black butterfly with white or blue spots and bands. Unique among South African Charaxes in having [i]rounded wings[/i] and [i]no tails[/i]. Was until recently placed in the genus [i]Euxanthe[/i], but DNA studies showed no reason for maintaining this as a separate taxon. Distinctive pied patterning. [i]Bright yellow[/i] abdomen often visible in flight.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male has pale narrow forewing band and hind wing basal patch with small hind wing submarginal spots. These have a blue sheen that appears white when viewed at an acute angle. Female has [i]much broader[/i] white forewing band, and [i]better developed[/i] hind wing submarginal spots.
 
Strong, soaring flight. Males gather around tree tops and small hills, where three or four may chase each other around. Female seen flying around forest edges, and around the host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.

Paradise Skipper
[i]Abantis paradisea[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Abantis[/i]
Species: [i]paradisea[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–45mm female 43–55mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Conspicuous, distinctive medium-sized, [i]black[/i] Skipper with [i]buff to white forewing patches[/i] and black-veined white hind wing patch. Not easy to confuse with other Skippers. When settled may resemble certain diurnal moths in the Arctiinae, such as Splendrous Hornet, [i]Euchromia folletii[/i], but flight [i]much faster[/i], more direct.
 
Sexes similar; female larger than male, wings more elongated, white upperside spots [i]more coloured[/i], abdomen stouter.
 
Males show strong territorial behaviour; perching on a prominent twig or leaf, usually high on a hilltop tree. They fly rapidly around their territory, with buzzing wings a blur. Other butterflies are attacked. Females are more sedentary and are usually found on flowers. Both sexes settle wings-open. Large emergences occur very rarely, with both sexes common on flowers close to forests.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread but local. Lowland Forest from E Cape, along KwaZulu-Natal coast to Maputaland, lowveld Savanna of Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Limpopo Province and n Gauteng.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, forest edges, hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks autumn (Apr–Jun) and spring (Aug–Nov).
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hibiscus tiliaceus, Cola natalensis, Annona[/i] spp., [i]Bridelia micrantha, Pseudolachnostylis maprouneifolia, Philenoptera violacea, Lecaniodiscus fraxinifolius[/i] and [i]Xylopia longipetala[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Paradise Skippers.

Small brightly coloured Skipper. Upperside dark brown with prominent [i]orange bands[/i]. Cilia plain yellowish white. Underside orange-yellow; forewing has [i]black spot at end of cell[/i], row of black marginal spots, and [i]dark blotch at tornus that does not extend to the inner margin[/i]. Hind wing has [i]distinct double rows of black marginal and discal spots[/i]. Upperside similar to Morant's Orange [i]Parosmodes morantii[/i], but forewing upperside orange cell spot is [i]merged with postdiscal orange band[/i]. Upperside also resembles that of larger Orange-spotted Hopper [i]Zenonia zeno[/i] but the forewing base is [i]not solid orange[/i] and the orange discal band is [i]not fused[/i]. Underside resembles Macomo Ranger [i]Kedestes macomo[/i] but has [i]fewer spots[/i] and they are [i]arranged in rows[/i]; resembles Morant's Orange but has [i]more spots[/i].
 
Sexes similar, female paler than male, rounder, more elongated wings, abdomen stouter, forewing upperside spots [i]more developed[/i].
 
Flight low, skipping and erratic; flies around shady clearings in [i]Brachystegia[/i] woodland, settling often, wings open, on rocks and low vegetation.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Only found in shady areas of small patches of [i]Brachystegia[/i] (miombo) woodland at eastern end of Soutpansberg, Limpopo Province, where recently discovered. Common in forested areas of Zimbabwe and Mozambique.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, hillsides, wetlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak late summer/autumn in Zimbabwe and Mozambique, so far only in Dec in South Africa.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Brachystegia spiciformis[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Rangers.

Small bright yellow Pierid. Unique among [i]Dixeia[/i] in that the males are bright sulphur-yellow. Underside, like others in the genus, is plain coloured with a [i]faint row of postdiscal dark spots[/i] on the hind wing underside.
 
Sexually dimorphic and polymorphic. Male upperside and underside always same bright yellow colour, with upperside forewing tip margin lined in [i]black[/i]. Females vary from being the same colour as the male, to pale yellow or creamy white. Females' forewing upperside marginal border is broader, usually [i]brown-black[/i]; extends further down margin, almost to tornus; hind wing underside has postdiscal row of dark smudges. (D) Female underside (yellow form). (E) Female upperside (white form). (F) Female underside (white form).
 
Fluttering flight along edges of forest, quite slow and settling often on vegetation or flowers; usually found in large concentrations close to the host plant.
 
Seasonally dimorphic, the normal wet season form is [i]spilleri[/i], (illustrated). In dry conditions form [i]gallenga[/i] may be found, which is very similar to the wet season form, but slightly [i]smaller[/i] with a [i]buff hind wing underside[/i].

Southern Pied Woolly Legs
[i]Lachnocnema laches[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Lachnocnema[/i]
Species: [i]laches[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 23–32mm female 22–32mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny to small butterfly. Males have brown-black upperside, female [i]distinctly pied in
 dark grey and white[/i]. Undersides are cryptic with patches of beautiful metallic
scales. Male very similar to that of Common Woolly Legs [i]Lachnocnema bibulus[/i] from
which it can only be separated by genitalic dissection. Male has some similarities to D'Urban's Woolly Legs [i]L. durbani[/i] but that butterfly is a denizen of Grassland, the upperside is a [i]dull grey-brown[/i] and the underside has a [i]regular[/i] pattern of buff or pale brown on a grey ground.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside brown-black, female [i]dark grey[/i] with [i]well-defined[/i] white discal patches, and [i]basal pale grey suffusion[/i]. Large dark patch at distal end of forewing cell. Male underside hind wing median band [i]always dark brown[/i], median band wider than in Common Woolly Legs; [i]lacks copper sheen[/i] but only reliably separated by genitalic dissection.
 
These butterflies are always found close to concentrations of aphids, plant Hoppers or scale insects (Homoptera), on which the larvae prey. There are also always ants present, because the larvae shelter during the day in ants' nests. Males are territorial and sit atop bushes or on prominent plants, sallying forth to confront intruders. They fly fast, rapidly circling trees and shrubs harbouring larval prey. Female are sedentary and seldom leave the twigs where the scale insects are feeding.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Coastal forest from E Cape (Port Elizabeth), along KwaZulu-Natal coast, inland to Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW provinces along wooded hills and valleys.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, gullies, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peaks spring and late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
Insects (Homoptera nymphs).
Back to Top
Group
Woolly Legs.

Dark-banded Scarlet
[i]Axiocerses croesus[/i]
Contents

Identification

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Axiocerses[/i]
Species: [i]croesus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 25–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, brilliant scarlet-red lycaenid. Male Dark-banded Scarlet similar to Common Scarlet [i]Axiocerses tjoane tjoane[/i] but has [i]line of dark submarginal spots[/i] on hind wing upperside. Compared to Black-tipped Scarlet [i]A. coalescens[/i] the absence on the male upperside forewing of discal black spots sets that species apart. Bush Scarlet [i]A. amanga amanga[/i] has a [i]plain hind wing underside[/i] with [i]no brassy spots[/i]. The wing edges are [i]more sharply angled[/i] than other Scarlets, in both sexes.
 
The underside is deep reddish brown, tending to blackish, with [i]enlarged brassy spots[/i]. The forewing has a similar spotting pattern to most Coppers; the hind wing has rows of dark spots with brassy centres.
 
Sexes differ; females are [i]more orange than red[/i] on the upperside with a varying extent of rows of dark spotting. They are very difficult to distinguish from the other two similar species, but the angled wing edges may assist.
 
Males are extremely pugnacious hilltoppers. Rapid flight with very fast wingbeats, especially in males. Male perches at midday on low bushes, often upside down, with half-open wings. Females are more often found on flowers and close to host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Flies with Common Scarlet in southern part of range, but usually in less arid areas. Wooded Savanna and Riverine Forest in E Cape as far west as Port Elizabeth, spreading into s KwaZulu-Natal.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in the north, peaks Sept–Oct and Feb–May; double-brooded in the south, Sept–Oct and Feb–May.

[i]Vachellia[/i] spp.

Identification
Similar to, but much [i]smaller[/i] than Western [i]Stygionympha vigilans[/i] or Eastern [i]S. scotina[/i] Hillside Browns. Wings of both sexes, but especially female, more [i]angular[/i]. [i]Brown[/i] ground colour varies between subspecies; specimens from higher altitudes, or wetter habitats, become darker on the upperside and more greyish-brown, the hind wing undersides can have distinct reddish discal and postdiscal bands.
 
Hind wing underside sometimes with [i]large ocelli[/i] in apical and anal areas, underside forewing basal rust-red patch reaches as far as apical ocellus; hind wing underside grey-brown ground colour irrorated with tiny short dark red-brown striae grouped into ill-defined bands.

The antennae are pale reddish-brown unlike the dark antennae of the other subspecies. Sexes similar, female heavier, with stouter abdomen, and wings more elongated. Female has more sedentary habits.
 
Slow, jinking flight, settling often on rocks, jerkily opening and closing wings. Visits flowers, where it tends to be less wary.
 
3 geographically distinct subspp.

Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized white Pierid. Male resembles that of Sabine Albatross White [i]Appias
 epaphia contracta[/i]. but is [i]smaller[/i]; the critical difference being the yellow
costal streak at the base of the underside hind wing. In Diverse Albatross White [i]both
fore- and hind wings have yellow streaks[/i]. Both species are sexually dimorphic, but
their females are totally different and easy to distinguish.
 
Sexually dimorphic, male with [i]brilliant white[/i] upperside, dark forewing marginal border [i]broken into spots at vein ends[/i]; black spots at hind wing vein ends. Underside of both wings white with [i]yellow costal edge[/i]. Female has [i]broad dark borders in both wings[/i].
 
Flies fairly rapidly along the edges of forests, settling often on low vegetation or on flowers.
 
Seasonally polymorphic. Normal wet season form [i]contracta[/i] male like a smaller Sabine Albatross White; black upperside marginal spots [i]more diffuse[/i], but [i]present on both wings[/i]; underside yellow costal streak [i]in both wings[/i]; underside hind wing ground colour [i]plain white[/i]. Female has [i]broad dark borders in both wings[/i]; in addition has [i]heavy dark suffusion[/i] in forewing cell. (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
 
There is a rare female wet season form [i]limbophora[/i] whose upperside white is [i]suffused with yellow[/i]. (E) Female upperside.
 
The intermediate female form is [i]malatha[/i], which resembles the dry season form [i]albida[/i] but [i]slight dark suffusion[/i] in forewing cell. (F) Female upperside. (G) Female underside.
 
Normal dry season form [i]albida[/i] male has upperside hind wing marginal spots [i]much reduced or absent[/i], and underside hind wing ground colour [i]plain cream or yellow[/i]. Female [i]lacks any dark suffusion in forewing upperside cell[/i]; dark marginal borders [i]much narrower[/i] than in wet season forms. (H) Male upperside. (I), (J) Male undersides. (K) Female upperside. (L) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
More widespread and less localised than Albatross White. E Cape coastal forest, Mbashe River north to KwaZulu-Natal, Lowland and Riverine Forest in eastern foothills of Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province Drakensberg, as far north as Soutpansberg. Invades nearby Savanna, sometimes in wooded parts of Gauteng.

Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands, forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, mainly Mar–May.
Back to Top

[i]Capparis[/i] spp., including [i]C. sepiaria[/i], [i]Cadaba[/i] sp., [i]Maerua racemulosa[/i] and [i]M. kirkii, Boscia albitrunca, Salvadora persica[/i].

Medium-sized Charaxes. Male could be confused with male Scarce Forest Charaxes [i]Charaxes etesipe tavetensis[/i], female with Foxy Charaxes [i]C. saturnus saturnus[/i] or female Bushveld Charaxes [i]C. achaemenes achaemenes[/i], but there are easily spotted differences.

Flight powerful but males do not seem to frequent hilltops to the same extent as other Charaxes. They settle often on tree trunks and fly around clearings in woodland, or streams.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.

Classification

Genus: [i]Sevenia[/i]

Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 50–60mm female 52–62mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large colourful butterfly. [i]Lilac[/i] upperside and [i]orange[/i] underside are diagnostic. Unlikely to be mistaken for any other species in Southern Africa.
 
Sexually dimorphic; female darker, bluer shade of lilac than male, with two black postdiscal forewing bands, larger dark submarginal spots on hind wing upperside.
 
Fond of sitting on tree bark, also roosts under leaves. Flipping, short flight from tree trunk to tree trunk. Very wary and hard to approach closely. Like [i]Sevenia boisduvali[/i], sometimes undergoes large population explosions. Swarms may rest in one area for months before moving off [i]en masse[/i]. It is such 'migrations' that reach South Africa from further north. Fond of fallen fruit; comes readily to baited traps.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D), (E), Female underside.

Rare migrant; erratically from Riverine and Lowland Forest in KwaZulu-Natal.

Rooiberg Skolly
[i]Thestor rooibergensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan

Habitat

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]rooibergensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–28mm female 27–29mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small butterfly, with [i]bright, deep buff[/i] upperside and [i]more rounded[/i] wings than the Brauns's Skolly group. Wings rounder, forewing upperside markings [i]less angulate, more exaggerated[/i] contrast between light and dark than Mountain Skolly [i]Thestor montanus[/i]; [i]not as bright[/i] as [i]T. pictus[/i]. [i]Less variable[/i] than [i]T. montanus[/i] or Van Son's Skolly [i]T. vansoni[/i], but the extent and shade of buff does vary somewhat between specimens. Underside hind wing of both sexes has [i]dark, contrasting[/i] basal and discal bands of marks; submarginal row of 'V'-shaped marks forming a [i]strongly sagittate[/i] line.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Females [i]paler[/i] than males, distal edges of buff patch [i]noticeably sagittate[/i] along veins. Male upperside shows [i]prominent dark scaling[/i] along veins. Forewing has an indistinct grey-brown sex brand at the basal juncture of veins M3 and CuA1.
 
[i]T. rooibergensis[/i] lives in colonies, usually on mountain slopes covered with scattered large rocks. The females fly more slowly than the males. Flight is low, fast and sustained, dodging between rocks and plants. They settle often on low vegetation or rocks, but are wary and difficult to approach. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.

Rare and localised. Fynbos-covered mountain slopes in Rooiberg, above Ladismith, W Cape.

Greyton Dark Ranger
[i]Kedestes niveostriga schloszi[/i]
alternative common name: Greyton Dark Skipper

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Kedestes[/i]
Species: [i]niveostriga[/i]
Subspecies: [i]schloszi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 31–35mm female 33–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown Skipper. Upperside dark brown, hind wing plain, forewing has discal white spots in CuA2, CuA1 (a large square spot) and M3; a double white spot in the cell and two small subapical white spots in R5 and M1. Underside [i]golden to khaki brown[/i] with veins picked out in [i]yellow ochre[/i]; hind wing has a [i]bright silvery white streak[/i] in 1A+2A along the anal fold, which continues along the side of the body to the thorax. Also has a fainter pale streak along vein M2. Similar to Unique Ranger [i]Kedestes lenis[/i] but that species' [i]forewing spots are tiny or absent[/i] and its underside ground colour is [i]darker and redder[/i]. Also similar to Wallengren's Ranger [i]K. wallengrenii[/i] but that butterfly has a white streak in area M2 of the hind wing underside, not 1A+2A. Cilia plain white to cream.
 
Sexes similar, female larger and paler than male; more elongated but rounded wings.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Male occupies territories in clumps of Tamboekie grass. Numbers never large. Flight fast and jerky, difficult to approach or follow. Female usually found near clumps of grass. Both sexes attracted to flowers.
 
[i]Kedestes niveostriga schloszae[/i]: has [i]more elongated, pointed forewing apex[/i] and underside ground colour a [i]duller, more khaki shade of pale brown[/i]. (D) Female upperside showing hind wing. (E) Female underside. (F) Male underside showing forewing.
Back to Top
Distribution
Thick stands of grass in fynbos at foot of Riviersonderend Mountains in W Cape near Greyton, and Bastiaanskloof in Bain’s Kloof.

Roodepoort Copper

Male 22–26mm female 24–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Bright orange [i]Aloeides[/i] copper with [i]well-defined[/i] narrow black borders. Underside ground colour from fawn-brown to bright crimson-pink. Serrated discal fascia well marked; lines of basal spots and distinct scalloped submarginal line of merged spots all [i]silver, distally edged black[/i]. Other [i]Aloeides[/i] coppers have dentate underside hind wing markings. Tite's Copper [i]A. titei[/i] has a [i]darker[/i] upperside forewing costa and the silvery underside markings are [i]greyer[/i] and less well-defined. Giant Copper [i]A. pallida[/i] is a larger insect with [i]broader[/i], less well-defined dark upperside marginal borders. Rossouw's Copper [i]A. rossouwi[/i] has [i]more rounded wings[/i] and a [i]broader forewing costal dark margin[/i], forming a dark apical patch which usually contains small orange spots.
 
Sexes similar, female with wings rounder.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fairly fast, fluttering close to the ground; settling often, usually on the ground or on low vegetation. Lives in small, concentrated colonies; found in flat country or on mountain slopes. Reluctant to open wings.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside (brown morph). (C) Male underside (crimson morph).

Rare and localised in sandy grassveld of Gauteng - Ruimsig, Roodepoort, where a reserve has been established to protect the species, and Suikerbosrand NR near Heidelberg.

Eastern Battling Glider
[i]Cymothoe alcimeda trimeni[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Limenitidinae
Genus: [i]Cymothoe[/i]
Species: [i]alcimeda[/i]
Subspecies: [i]trimeni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–50mm female 45–55mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium-sized butterfly. Battling Glider is the smaller of South Africa's two [i]Cymothoe[/i] species; the other being Blonde Glider [i]Cymothoecoranus coranus[/i]. Compared to that species, apart from size, [i]C. alcimeda[/i] has [i]more angulate[/i] wings and, usually, a more [i]heavily marked[/i] underside. [i]C. a. trimeni[/i] males are very similar to those of [i]C. a. clarki[/i], but the named female forms are different. Sexually dimorphic: male upperside creamy white; both sexes' underside cryptic.
 
Both sexes have the typical Limenitidinae gliding flight with bursts of rapid wingbeats. Males perch high up on forest edge trees and shrubs, and sally forth to chase away all other insects. When there is more than one male in a forest clearing, constant aerial battles take place, hence the common name. Females are found close to the host plants. Both sexes regularly drink at wet mud, and nectar from flowers. They are also attracted to fruit bait.
 
5 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(AC) Male upperside. (AD) Male underside, light form. (AE) Male underside, dark form. (AF) Male underside, brown form. (AG) Female f. [i]trimeni[/i] upperside has [i]white[/i] discal band. (AH) Female f. [i]trimeni[/i] underside. (AI) Female f. [i]griseoligata[/i] upperside has [i]dull ochre-yellow[/i] discal band. (AJ) Female f. [i]griseoligata[/i] underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Coastal and moist Afromontane Forest from East London (E Cape), inland along Drakensberg escarpment to KwaZulu-Natal Midlands.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, mainly summer from Oct; peak Nov and Feb–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Kiggelaria africana[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Gliders.

Identification
Beautiful, conspicuous, easily recognised, medium-sized white Skipper with fine black lines in forewing tip and along margins. Sexes similar, female more elongated wings, stouter abdomen. Conspicuous white wings veined and banded with black; yellow-ochre body hair on underside of thorax and wing bases. May be mistaken for Buff-tipped Skipper [i]Netrobalane canopus[/i] on the wing, but the [i]plain black and white wings[/i] with no brown on the wing tips or bases, sets it apart.
 
Sexes similar, female larger, wings more elongated, abdomen stouter.
 
Usually found singly. Male prominent hilltopper, pursuing intruders; perches on bare twigs with forelegs raised, exposing black scent hairs. Both sexes may be found on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.

Langeberg Skolly
[i]Thestor pictus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]pictus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–28mm female 27–29mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small butterfly, with [i]bright, pale buff[/i] upperside and [i]more rounded[/i] wings than the Brauns's Skolly group. Some specimens are a slightly darker buff. Forewing discal area [i]narrower[/i] than others of the Mountain Skolly species group. On the forewing underside, the discal band of dark marks is [i]more prominent[/i] than in Mountain Skolly [i]Thestor montanus[/i] and fused into a band. Both wings have a submarginal row of 'V'-shaped marks.
 
Sexually dimorphic; females [i]paler[/i] than males, which have an extensive brown to grey-brown sex brand at the basal juncture of veins M3 and CuA1.
 
[i]T. pictus[/i] lives in colonies, usually on mountain slopes covered with scattered large rocks. The females fly more slowly than the males. Flight is low, fast and sustained, dodging between rocks and plants. They settle often on low vegetation or rocks, but are wary and difficult to approach. Usually found in groups of three or four, but in the right conditions can occur in large numbers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) (D) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare and localised. Fynbos-covered mountain slopes above Garcia's Pass, Langeberg (Riversdale, W Cape).
Back to Top
Habitat
Mountains, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, end of Sept to Nov, peak Oct.
Back to Top
Larval food
Larvae and pupae found in Pugnacious Ant [i]Anoplolepis custodiens[/i] nests; trophallaxis from the ants, possibly also nest detritus.
Back to Top
Group
Skollies.

Monkey Blue
[i]Lepidochrysops methymna methymna[/i]
alternative common name: Monkey Nimble Blue, Monkey Giant Cupid, Dickson's Monkey Nimble Blue, Dickson's Monkey Giant Cupid, Dickson's Monkey Blue
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]methymna[/i]
Subspecies: [i]methymna[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–40mm female 33–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Nominate subspecies is a large, [i]dark brown Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Underside typical of brown [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]; dark spots large and well-defined on both wings; hind wing postdiscal sagittate marks large but slender. There are many similar brown [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] species, but in its zone the only ones that may be confused with it are Robertson's Blue [i]L. robertsoni[/i] and Variable Blue [i]L. variabilis[/i]. These are smaller species and are a less dark brown on the upperside. Duke's Blue [i]L. dukei[/i] is much smaller, does not hilltop and is even darker on the upperside.
 
Ssp. [i]L. methymna dicksoni[/i] tends to have a degree of blue on the upperside and the only species that may be mistaken for it is Peninsula Blue [i]L. oreas[/i], but that is much paler blue and is not found in the same localities (or [i]was[/i] not, because [i]dark brown Lepidochrysops[/i] is officially extinct.).
 
Sexes similar; nominate female forewing upperside has faint blue-edged dark discal marks.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Rapid, whirling flight. Male territorial on mountain tops, circling around, chasing other Blues and perching on low vegetation. Female scarcer, slower flying, found near host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos-covered hills in Cape Peninsula (W Cape) and from Groot Winterhoek along Hottentots Holland range to Langeberg and Helderberg.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, hillsides, mountains, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded Sept–Jan, most common Nov and Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Pseudoselago spuria[/i] and [i]P. serrata[/i] From third instar, brood of [i]Camponotus maculatus liengmei[/i] ants.
Back to Top
Group
Ant Blues.

Cupreous Blue
[i]Eicochrysops messapus messapus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Eicochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]messapus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]messapus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 17–22mm female 17–24mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny blue or black butterfly. Underside resembles that of Common Smoky Blue [i]Euchrysops malathana[/i] but a [i]much smaller butterfly[/i]; orange anal lunule in CuA1 and sometimes CuA2 has a marginal black spot [i]edged with pale metallic blue-green on both wing surfaces[/i]. The orange may spread into M3 and 1A+2A, but is not well-defined. On the underside the basal black spots are [i]smaller than in Common Smoky Blue[/i], the white-edged spots in the cell are reduced to [i]white-edged lines[/i], and the postdiscal series of marks are [i]narrower[/i] and appear as a [i]broken white-edged line[/i]. Where [i]Euchrysops[/i] have a well-defined row of postdiscal white sagittate marks, Cupreous Blue has blunt white arches. Females resemble both sexes of Grass Jewel, [i]Chilades trochilus[/i], but that butterfly has [i]three well[/i]-defined orange lunules with black spots in M3, CuA1 and CuA2, and sometimes a fourth in M2.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Males are blue on upperside; female upperside [i]black[/i], hind wing has [i]black and orange[/i] anal lunule varying in size. Underside of both sexes and both subspp. grey with black spots.
 
Flight slow among grass and low vegetation; settles often on flowers and stems, but is wary and difficult to approach closely.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos from W Cape (common in Cape Peninsula) north into Nama Karoo and east along coast and mountain chain to Free State (Springfontein).
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands, mountains.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peaks Oct and Mar, absent from cooler areas Apr–Sept.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Thesium[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Blues.

Confusing Sandman
[i]Spialia confusa confusa[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Spialia[/i]
Species: [i]confusa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]confusa[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 19–23mm female 23–25mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny dark Skipper with black-and-white chequered upperside and forewing underside. One of a group of very similar little butterflies, which are difficult to tell apart from the upperside markings. To be reasonably sure of identification a clear view of the hind wing underside is necessary. Only South African [i]Spialia[/i] besides Bushveld Sandman to have hind wing upperside submarginal spots in M1 and M2 out of line, shifted basally. Forewing apex [i]short and blunt[/i], hind wing underside median band [i]straight, contiguous[/i]. Tapers from costa to inner margin as in Delagoa [i]S. delagoae[/i], Boland [i]S. sataspes[/i] and Wandering [i]S. depauperata australis[/i] Sandmen, but edges [i]jagged[/i] as in Forest Sandman [i]S. dromus[/i]. Can be told from that species by [i]tiny size[/i] and [i]wavy hind wing underside submarginal line[/i].
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
Tiny; with its buzzing flight, easily mistaken for a small fly. Male found on sandy patches at edge of bush, among low grass and herbs, often along paths. Usually in flat country although found on hill tops and hillsides further north. Both sexes on flowers, but female very seldom seen.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare and localised. Lowland Forest and Savanna in e Swaziland, Maputaland (KwaZulu-Natal), and Kaapmuiden/Barberton area (Mpumalanga). Single record from Musina, Limpopo Province, but may be more widespread there.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, hillsides, forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Oct–Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
Probably [i]Melhania[/i] spp. and [i]Triumfetta[/i] spp.
Back to Top
Group
Sandmen.

Small sapphire. Superficially similar to Red-line Sapphire [i]Iolaus sidus[/i], but powder blue, not metallic blue upperside. Vine-leaf Vagrant
[i]Eronia cleodora[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Eronia[/i]
Species: [i]cleodora[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 45–60mm female 50–62mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, distinctive Pierid. White upperside with [i]bold black marginal borders[/i],
underside hind wing has [i]dead-leaf[/i] pattern in bright yellow and
greyish-brown irrorated with darker scaling. A very good imitation of a dead yellow
leaf, rotting at the edges. There is a range of seasonal forms, as shown. Wet season forms are larger, with broad continuous borders on upperside. Dry season forms are smaller, borders narrower, breaking into dots.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Flight fast and direct, stopping seldom, unless at flowers (usually orange or red but they are fond of [i]Plumbago[/i]) to nectar.
 
Nominate form [i]cleodora[/i] is the usual dry season form, found all over Southern Africa: (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Dry season form [i]semipunctata[/i] is from the south-eastern Cape; has narrower dark borders, the forewing apical patch may split into two parts and the upperside ground colour is often [i]lemon-yellow[/i]: (C) Male upperside.
 
Dry season form [i]punctata[/i] is the extreme dry season form, also from the south-eastern Cape; the margins break up into dots, as does the forewing apical patch: (D) Male upperside.
 
Wet season form [i]erxia[/i] is the normal summer form with wide borders: (E) Male upperside. (F) Female underside.
 
Wet season form [i]dilatata[/i] is the extreme summer form with very wide borders: (G) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fairly common in wooded Savanna and Riverine Forest from E Cape (Cape St. Francis), along coast and inland through KwaZulu-Natal to Swaziland; also Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province in escarpment forests and Riverine Forest penetrating Savanna.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, flatlands, coast, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, depending on rainfall. Generally two peaks, spring and late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Capparis fascicularis[/i] and [i]C. tomentosa[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Vagrants.

Black-branded Swift
[i]Pelopidas mathias mathias[/i]
Contents

Identification

Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Pelopidas[/i]
Species: [i]mathias[/i]
Subspecies: [i]mathias[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 36–38mm female 38–41mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small dark Skipper. Upperside blackish brown with greenish yellow hairs and pale spots. Upperside ground colour brown. Has [i]three tiny hyaline subapical spots[/i], and small hyaline spots in areas M2 and M3. Usually, but not always, has [i]two small hyaline spots in forewing cell[/i]. Sexes differ in markings in CuA1 and CuA2. Underside medium brown, suffused with white; [i]seven small white discal spots[/i] on hind wing in areas 3A to Sc+R1. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Similar to some of the [i]Borbo[/i] Swifts that have yellow or green hairs on the upperside. Rusty Swift [i]Borbo detecta[/i] has distinctly [i]reddish yellow ochre[/i] hairs. Olive-haired Swift [i]B. borbonica[/i] has olive-green hairs but the hind wing underside black-ringed white spots are distinctive. Twin Swift [i]Larsenia gemella[/i] has yellowish to greenish ochre hairs, but has [i]only three[/i] hind wing underside discal spots.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male has [i]black[/i] forewing discal sex brand diagonally crossing CuA1 and CuA2. Female [i]lacks sex brand[/i]; larger than male, wings more elongated, forewing upperside has [i]hyaline discal spot[/i] in CuA2, [i]white spot[/i] in CuA1. Apart from the different colour of the male sex brand, the number of discal hind wing underside spots distinguishes this species from the very similar White-branded Swift [i]Pelopidas thrax[/i].
 
Males are territorial on hilltops, at edges of forest, along roads, paths or streams, chasing intruding males. Flight rapid, but settling often on low shrubs, grass stems or rocks; fairly easy to approach. Females are more sedentary, around flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread in coastal Lowland and Riverine Forest, wooded Savanna and river valleys from E Cape (Port Elizabeth), KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland to Mpumalanga, Gauteng, all of Limpopo Province. Isolated records from the Cape Peninsula (W Cape). Also found sporadically in e N Cape and NW Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, gullies, flatlands, coast, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, scarcer in winter.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Zea mays, Ehrharta erecta, Megathyrsus maximus, Saccharum officinarum, Sorghum bicolor[/i], and [i]Triticum aestivum[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Swifts.

Medium-sized orange-tawny Bitter Acraea with pinkish hind wing. [i]Whitish abdomen[/i] is conspicuous in flight.

Identification
Small butterfly, largest of Brauns's Skolly group. Upperside ground colour buff. Both sexes have wings more pointed than Boland Skolly [i]Thestor protumnus[/i] group. Upperside and forewing underside widely bordered with [i]grey-brown[/i] and having [i]conspicuous dark-and-light[/i] chequered cilia. Has a characteristic [i]squarish hind wing underside dark discal mark[/i] containing a hooked pale line.

3 subspp., geographically distinct. The males show more differences than the females.
 
[i]T. dicksoni[/i] lives in large colonies, usually in terrain dotted with low 'bossies' or large rocks. Flight is low, fast and sustained, dodging between rocks and plants. They settle often on low vegetation or rocks, but are wary and difficult to approach. The females fly more slowly than the males.

Clouded Mother-of-pearl
[i]Protogoniomorpha anacardii nebulosa[/i]

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Nymphalinae
Genus: [i]Protogoniomorpha[/i]
Species: [i]anacardii[/i]
Subspecies: [i]nebulosa[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 55–68mm female 65–75mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, whitish butterfly with iridescent sheen on wings. One of two species of Mother-of-pearl butterfly found in South Africa. Clouded Mother-of-pearl, [i]Protogoniomorpha anacardii nebulosa[/i], is white to cream, with gold to mauve iridescent sheen, black-edged wings. Black spots on both surfaces but black-centred red ocelli on [i]upperside[/i] only. [i]Smaller[/i] than Common Mother-of-pearl [i]P. parhassus[/i], which has forewing tips [i]less heavily marked with black[/i]. Lacks the greenish gloss of [i]P. parhassus[/i].
 
Sexes similar in all forms but females are [i]more heavily marked[/i] in black, with broader dark margins, sometimes with a golden sheen as in wet season form female f. [i]lurida[/i].
 
Males perch at medium height on forest edges, and sally forth to pursue other males. Both sexes roost among the foliage of large-leafed plants in the dry season. Often flies with similar Common Mother-of-pearl. Follows wooded river valleys into dry Savanna, where it feeds on flowers.
 
Two main seasonal forms. Dry season form f. [i]trimeni[/i] and female dry season form f. [i]lurida[/i] larger, wings more angular than f. [i]nebulosa[/i].
 
(A) Male upperside f. [i]nebulosa[/i]. (B) Male underside f. [i]nebulosa[/i]. (C) Female upperside f. [i]nebulosa[/i]. (D) Female underside f. [i]nebulosa[/i]. (E) Female upperside f. [i]trimeni[/i]. (F) Female underside f. [i]trimeni[/i]. (G) Female upperside f. [i]lurida[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
Lowland and Riverine Forest, Savanna. E Cape (Port St. Johns) along KwaZulu-Natal coast to Kosi Bay, Emanguzi and the Lebombo Mountains. Also along escarpment foothills to Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province.

Soutpansberg Forest King Charaxes
[i]Charaxes xiphares bavenda[/i]
alternative common name: Soutpansberg Forest King Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]xiphares[/i]
Subspecies: [i]bavenda[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–80mm female 70–95mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, dark Charaxes. In certain parts of its range, males can be confused with Blue-Spotted Charaxes, [i]Charaxes cithaeron cithaeron[/i]. However, that species has [i]much broader[/i] hind wing upperside pale patch, almost totally white. The postdiscal series of forewing royal blue marks are [i]smaller[/i] in [i]C. xiphares[/i]. Females are distinctive. [i]C. x. bavenda[/i] male, with [i]C. x. staudei[/i] is distinguished by the suffusion of white into the hind wing upperside discal patch, and broad marginal lunules. The female has the spots near the inner forewing upperside [i]enlarged[/i]. There are three female forms. Nominate upperside has white forewing discal spots and yellow hind wing discal patch. In f. [i]ochreomacula[/i] the forewing discal spots are tinged with yellow-ochre, and in [i]cyanescens[/i] the forewing spots are white but the hind wing patch is white suffused with lavender.
 
Sexes strongly dimorphic, male with [i]royal blue[/i] spots and bands on metallic navy ground, female with [i]white discal forewing band[/i] (of variable width) sometimes invaded by yellow-ochre. Most females have a pale yellow hind wing upperside patch, but in some populations, it is blue-white or pale mauve. Differences between females is usually of more value than subtle differences between the males in distinguishing subspecies.
 
Powerful, high flight in the canopy and around tree tops. Males territorial, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly rapidly along the fringes of forests where they settle on tree leaves.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
8 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(AB) Male upperside. (AC) Male underside. (AD) Female upperside f. [i]bavenda[/i]. (AE) Female upperside f. [i]ochreomacula[/i]. (AD) Female upperside f. [i]cyanescens[/i]. (AG) Female underside (all forms the same).
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane Forest on Soutpansberg watershed (Limpopo Province).
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, weak peak Oct–Nov, stronger Mar–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Cryptocarya woodii, Scutia myrtina, Rhamnus prinoides[/i] and [i]Chaetachme aristata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Charaxes.

Bampton's Opal
[i]Chrysoritis thysbe bamptoni[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]thysbe[/i]
Subspecies: [i]bamptoni[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 23–35mm.
Back to Top
Identification
One of a large group of [i]Chrysoritis[/i] Opals with [i]blue wing bases[/i] and a [i]shimmering, electric opalescent sheen[/i] over a varying area of the wings. For [i]Chrysoritis thysbe[/i], amount of blue on upperside varies, in some subspecies almost covering the forewing. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside varies from plain sandy tan to dark brown, to [i]variegated[/i] with striae in various shades of reddish-brown, with bands of paler colouring and brassy postdiscal streaks. 'Plain' underside specimens usually have unicoloured cilia; 'variegated' ones dark cilia with pale interneural flecks, appearing 'chequered'.
 
[i]C. t. bamptoni[/i] underside may be the plain or variegated form, but the dark striae are always visible. The upperside blue in the male extends beyond the forewing cell to the apex and may cover most of the wing. Margins always dark, but the wing apex usually has some orange. Sexes differ. Female has [i]rounder wings[/i], upperside blue [i]restricted to basal 25% of wings[/i], no opalescent sheen. The females of the various races are almost impossible to separate on wing patterns and identification usually requires comparison with males seen at the same locality.
 
7 subspp., not always geographically distinct. Rapid, sustained flight, settling on prominent bushes or rocks. Male intensively territorial on hill tops or sand dunes, regularly patrolling and chasing intruders; Females are found more at random, often on flowers.
 
(I) Male upperside. (J) Male underside, variegated form. (K) Female upperside. (L) Female underside, plain form. This butterfly flies in the same areas as Lyndsey's Opal [i]C. lyndseyae[/i], but the latter occupies flat areas between prominences - whereas [i]C. thysbe bamptoni[/i] is found atop sand dunes.
Back to Top
Distribution
Succulent Karoo in Hondeklipbaai area, inland to Wallekraal (N Cape).
Back to Top
Habitat
Dune tops in coastal flats.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Oct and Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Lebeckia plukenetiana, Roepera flexuosa, R. teretifolia[/i], and [i]Tetraena[/i] spp. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogasteri[/i] sp. ants.
Back to Top
Group
Opals.

Natal Amakosa Rocksitter
[i]Durbania amakosa natalensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Poritiinae
Genus: [i]Durbania[/i]
Species: [i]amakosa[/i]
Subspecies: [i]natalensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–35mm female 29–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small black-and-orange/red butterflies; uppersides are black with varying degrees of red/orange spots and blotches. Undersides are beautifully camouflaged against their habitat; intricate patterns of black or dark grey on a white or pale grey ground, with submarginal spots in varying shades of red to orange, yellow or white. There are some similar species to Amakosa Rocksitter; Natal Rocksitter [i]Durbania limbata[/i] upperside has outer half of hind wing [i]broad[/i] red; sexes similar and flies in late summer to autumn, not spring and early summer. And Clark's Rocksitter [i]D. clarki[/i] is much smaller and its range does not overlap with that of [i]D. amakosa[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. [i]D. a. natalensis[/i] has the deepest red upperside markings on both wings and in both sexes; the females have very broad orange-red patches. The submarginal hind wing underside dots are red.
 
7 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Rocksitters, as their name suggests, like to sit on rocks; they do this for long periods with wings closed, their cryptic undersides hiding them well against lichen growing on the rock. Occasionally one will take off and patrol the area searching for mates. The flight is weak and fluttering, and they have trouble with headwinds, so they keep low, in the boundary layer. They lack a proboscis and cannot feed as adults, so they are never seen on flowers.
 
(L) Male upperside. (M) Female upperside. (N) Male (R) and Female (L) undersides.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Grassland in KwaZulu-Natal Midlands and Drakensberg foothills.
Back to Top
Habitat
Rocky ledges, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single-brooded, Nov–Dec.
Back to Top
Larval food
Cyanobacteria.
Back to Top
Group
Rocksitters.
Back to Top

Genus: [i]Anthene[/i]
Species: [i]liodes[/i]
Subspecies: [i]bihe[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 21–25mm female 21–27mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small Hairtail with prominent [i]whitish underside[/i]. Underside markings similar to other Hairtails but [i]poorly defined[/i] against ground colour. Both sexes' undersides have black-and-orange lunules at anal angle, and [i]short, bristle-like tails[/i] at the ends of the cubital veins.
 
Sexually dimorphic Male has upperside [i]plain pale metallic blue[/i], female upperside blue [i]duller, restricted to base and discal area[/i], sometimes tinged [i]whitish[/i].
 
Slow, elusive flight through thick vegetation. Found along forest edges and around treetops.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Rare in South Africa. Lowland and Riverine Forest from KwaZulu-Natal (Pongola River below Jozini Dam) to Swaziland, Mpumalanga (Komati River, Malelane) and Limpopo Province (Pafuri), and further north.

Forest edges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak in summer.
Back to Top

Male 20–24mm female 22–30mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, brightly coloured Opal. Highest flying [i]Chrysoritis[/i], 3 000m and higher. [i]Bright brick-orange[/i] upperside pattern similar to Eastern Opal [i]Chrysoritis orientalis[/i] and Pennington's Opal [i]C. penningtoni[/i], but [i]more reddish in shade[/i]; both sexes' basal [i]blue restricted; in male, to basal 30% of wing[/i]. Cilia [i]strongly chequered[/i] in orange, black and white. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing variegated in [i]brown, cream and ochreous buff[/i], with [i]conspicuous[/i] brassy sagittate markings.
 
Sexes similar, female upperside spots [i]larger, more well-defined[/i]; basal blue [i]greatly restricted[/i], or almost absent.
 
Very fast and elusive flight, hard to follow. Found in large scattered colonies between rocky outcrops in karoo-type scrub. Males defend territories around hollows in the outcrops, patrolling regularly. Females found more at random.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Mainly in Drakensberg Grassland; E Cape (Ben MacDhui and above Lundean's Nek), Lesotho, KwaZulu-Natal (Langalibalele Pass), Free State (Generaalkop, Golden Gate Highlands NP, Clarens). In Nama Karoo-type vegetation above the Grasslands.

Mountains, rocky slopes, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood, Nov–Feb, peaks Dec.

Larval food
No data.

Emperor Swallowtail
[i]Papilio ophidicephalus zuluensis[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Papilionidae
Subfamily: Papilioninae
Genus: [i]Papilio[/i]
Species: [i]ophidicephalus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]zuluensis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 90–140mm female 100–160mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Very large, conspicuous black and yellow butterfly with well-developed spatulate tails. Largest South African butterfly. Closest in markings to Citrus Swallowtail [i]Papilio demodocus[/i] but [i]much larger and has hind wing tails[/i]. Constantine's Swallowtail [i]P. constantinus[/i] and Bush Kite [i]P. euphranor[/i] are both superficially similar but [i]lack large blue hind wing postdiscal lunules on both wing surfaces[/i]. The forewing discal band of spots varies in shape and width between the subspecies.
 
The nominate subspecies is not found in South Africa. [i]P. ophidicephalus zuluensis[/i], like [i]P. o. phalusco[/i], is also very large; this species is found very close to the populations of [i]P. o. phalusco[/i] that are largest in size, in the Tugela Valley. It may be that size is determined by environmental conditions and not genetics. The forewing discal band of yellow spots is [i]nearly straight[/i] but [i]narrower than in P. o. phalusco and does not widen as much towards the apex[/i]. In males the spots in areas R3 to M1 are usually [i]joined[/i]; in females the spots may be joined as far down the wing as CuA1. Sexes similar; male has [i]bands of shiny scent scales[/i] on forewing between postdiscal and submarginal yellow spots. Females have varying degrees of irroration with yellow scales in these areas.
 
5 subspp., geographically distinct. Flies fast with powerful wingbeats; may stoop low
to investigate flowers. Follows gullies and roads in thick forest. Males are often seen
mud puddling; females on flowers and host plants.
 
The nominate subspecies is not found in South Africa.
 
(D) Male upperside. (E) Male underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane and Riverine Forest forests in Eshowe district, KwaZulu-Natal.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, gullies.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded; spring brood (Aug–Dec) less abundant and smaller specimens than summer brood (Jan–Apr). Broods may overlap in summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Clausena anisata, Zanthoxylum capense, Z. davyi, Z. delagoense[/i] and [i]Calodendron capense[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Swallowtails.
Back to Top

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Pyrginae
Genus: [i]Netrobalane[/i]
Species: [i]canopus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 26–44mm female 42–45mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Unmistakable medium-sized white Skipper. [i]Upperside mottled buff-brown on white, with prominent discal hyaline bands[/i]. Underside similar, dark markings fewer, [i]prominent black dot at hind wing anal angle[/i]. Superficially resembles Ragged Skipper [i]Caprona pillaana[/i] but ground colour white, not [i]grey-brown[/i]. Habits similar to White-cloaked Skipper [i]Leucochitonea levubu[/i] but has buff and brown markings; [i]not purely white and black[/i].
 
Sexes similar, female larger, wings more elongated, abdomen stouter.
 
Usually found singly. Flight medium fast, dancing, usually 1–4m above the ground. Both sexes usually rest with wings open. Male selects a prominent twig or leaf perch, patrols forest edge or hill top. When courting, male flight has buzzing, clicking sound. Both sexes found at flowers.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Female underside. (C) Male underside.
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Thick woodland, bush and Lowland Forest, from E Cape (Port Alfred, King William's Town) coastal and riverine bush to KwaZulu-Natal (Maputaland), warmer Savanna in Swaziland, lowveld of Mpumalanga, and Limpopo Province (Soutpansberg and Wolkberg).
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, forest edges, hillsides, flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Sept–Nov and Feb–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Grewia[/i] spp., including [i]G. occidentalis, G. similis[/i] and [i]G. flavescens, Dombeya cymosa, D. calantha[/i], and [i]Pavonia burchellii[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Skippers.

Small blue lycaenid. Underside ground colour pale grey with darker grey bands and
blotches, outlined in white. Only distinguishable from other [i]Leptotes[/i] species in
the Common Blue group ([i]L. pirithous pirithous[/i], [i]L. jeanneli[/i] and [i]L. babaulti[/i]) by genitalic dissection.
 
Sexes differ. Male upperside plain blue, female with wide grey-brown margins, blue crossed by white-edged grey-brown bands.
 
Slow, fluttering flight around host plants, may fly higher around flowering trees. Males may perch high up on prominent twigs and chase away other butterflies. Females found on flowers and close to host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside.

Identification
Dark reddish-brown colouring makes this species conspicuous against green spring grass. Appears to be black on the wing.
 
Sexes similar, female with stout abdomen, but more elongate wings, and slightly broader postdiscal forewing band of ochreous orange, more or less contiguous blotches.
 
May be found in large numbers in its preferred localities, but this is a very rare and local butterfly. Flies in the cool of the morning; usually off the wing by 13h00. Flight is fluttering and sailing; male patrols patches of hillside; female less active, more often seen on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Male underside. (D) Female underside.

Nominate [i]Trimenia wallengrenii wallengrenii[/i] is very rare and has not been seen in its old haunts for some time. Powerfully built lycaenid; upperside [i]black-and-orange with conspicuously black-and-white chequered cilia[/i]. Hind wing has short bristly tails at the anal angle. Underside has [i]thin, cursive[/i] silvery marks on a ground colour varying from brown to wine red. Other members of the genus have less fine, more rounded silvery marks.
 
Sexes similar, but female larger, heavier bodied with broader wings, and wider orange patches.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Rapid flight with fast wingbeats, low down, but not sustained; settling often on the ground or on rocks. Both sexes are occasionally seen on flowers.

False Swift
[i]Borbo fallax[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Borbo[/i]
Species: [i]fallax[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 36–43mm female 41–44mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small dark Skipper. Upperside blackish-brown with small hyaline spots on both wings. Has [i]two spots in the forewing cell[/i]. Hind wing underside ground colour brown overlaid with greenish-grey scales; may have [i]small, insignificant white spots[/i] in areas Rs and M1 to CuA1, but sometimes there are only spots in M1 and M2. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Very similar to Long-horned Swift [i]Borbo fatuellus fatuellus[/i] but that species has [i]no hyaline spots in forewing cell[/i], and does not have upperside hind wing spots.
 
Sexes similar; female has more rounded wings and stouter abdomen.
 
Very rapid, zooming flight no more than 1–2metres above the ground. Males form territories along forest edges and paths, in clearings and along stream beds. Females fly near the males but are slower; found more at random, searching for places to lay their eggs.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Swaziland, coastal E Cape and KwaZulu-Natal Lowland and Riverine Forest (from Port St. Johns to Maputaland), into Savanna of Mpumalanga, w Gauteng and Limpopo Province, to extreme ne NW Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast, hill tops, parks and gardens.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, scarcer in winter.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Ehrharta erecta, Saccharum[/i] spp. and other Poaceae grasses.
Back to Top
Group
Swifts.

One of the larger Lycaenids. Unmistakable [i]broad red bands[/i] on black-brown ground; underside also colourful. Most brightly coloured [i]Capys[/i] found in South Africa.

Polka Dot
[i]Pardopsis punctatissima[/i]

Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Heliconiinae
Genus: [i]Pardopsis[/i]
Species: [i]punctatissima[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 30–34mm female 33–36mm.
Back to Top
Identification
This little species is unique among butterflies in SA because of its regular pattern of black dots on a yellow-buff ground. However not unmistakable because it closely resembles a diurnal moth, Leopard Magpie, [i]Zerenopsis lepida[/i] (Geometridae; Ennominae). This moth's larvae feed on a Grassland cycad, [i]Stangeria eriopus[/i], which occurs in the butterfly's habitat.
 
Sexes similar.
 
Low, fluttering flight among grass stems. Favours moist grassy areas; often found at forest edges.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
Mimic
(Possibly) Muellerian mimic of Leopard Magpie, [i]Zerenopsis lepida[/i] (Geometridae; Ennominae). Also closely resembles the lycaenid Spotted Buff, [i]Pentila tropicalis[/i], but this is a true forest species so they are unlikely to interact.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos, Lowland and Afromontane Forest, and Grassland. From E Cape (Van Staden's Pass) along eastern escarpment foothills into Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province, and further north.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peak Oct–Mar.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hybanthas capensis[/i].
Back to Top

Pyramus Opal

Classification

Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]pyramus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]pyramus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–36mm female 32–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, red-orange Opal. [i]Deeper red-orange[/i] upperside ground colour than Beaufort Opal [i]Chrysoritis beaufortia[/i], male basal silvery blue covered by [i]electric blue sheen[/i] stretching at forewing base as far as margin. [i]Broad, black[/i] marginal borders, merging with submarginal spots in some specimens, making shifting blue lustre more prominent. Cilia strongly chequered with white. Occasional specimens from the Swartberg have [i]narrower[/i] dark borders and are closer to the Kammanassie subspecies, [i]C pyramus balli[/i]. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Underside hind wing variegated in [i]deep red- or ochre-brown[/i], with [i]conspicuous[/i] brassy sagittate markings.
 
Sexes dimorphic; female has typical [i]Chrysoritis[/i] markings, noticeably [i]deep, rich colouring[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Found in large scattered colonies. Frequents bare rocky ribs on fynbos-covered hillsides and summits. Males perch on prominent rocks or plants and patrol their territories, chasing away intruders. Females are more sedentary.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top

Fynbos, Nama Karoo in W Cape, high up northern slopes of Swartberg at Swartberg Pass and surrounding mountains, above Seweweekspoort.

Mountains, rocky ledges, hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood, Oct–Jan, peak Nov.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Osteospermum[/i] spp. including [i]O asperulum, O. incanum, Thesium[/i] spp. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster capensis[/i] ants.
