Small to medium-sized, golden brown Tree Nymph. [i]Larger[/i] than Boisduval's Tree Nymph [i]Sevenia boisduvali boisduvali[/i], and upperside [i]lacks[/i] submarginal black spots. [i]Duller[/i] colour than Natal Tree Nymph, [i]Sevenia natalensis[/i].

Purple-brown Hairstreak
[i]Hypolycaena philippus philippus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution

Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Theclinae
Genus: [i]Hypolycaena[/i]
Species: [i]philippus[/i]
Subspecies: [i]philippus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 22–28mm female 23.5–31mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Similar to a sapphire but upperside [i]brown[/i], with [i]purple sheen[/i] in male. Underside superficially resembles certain [i]Iolaus[/i] species such as White-spotted and Mimosa Sapphires [i]I. lulua, I. mimosae[/i], but lines narrower and more curved. And of course the upperside is not sapphire blue. The underside is very similar to Coastal Hairstreak [i]Hypolycaena lochmophila[/i]. The forewing underside postdiscal line (the middle of the three vertical lines) is [i]evenly curved[/i] and does not angle inwards then outwards.
 
Sexes differ on upperside. Female [i]lacks[/i] purple sheen of male, and has [i]two[/i] white hind wing upperside submarginal white bands, [i]larger[/i] anal lunules, tails longer.
 
Males defend territories on forest edges and open bush country, perching on prominent leaves and twigs, and chasing off other butterflies. Females are found on flowers and near the host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread in Savanna, Lowland and Riverine Forest from E Cape (East London), along coast and inland to Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, and Limpopo and NW provinces, and beyond.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peaks Nov and Mar/Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Clerodendrum glabrum, Ximenia caffra[/i] and [i]X. americana, Kraussia floribunda, Maytenus gracilipes, Deinbollia oblongifolia, Pachystigma venosum, Vangueria[/i] spp. and [i]Gymnosporia senegalensis[/i]. Has also been recorded feeding on fungal growths infesting [i]Ziziphus mucronata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Hairstreaks.

Common Grass Yellow
[i]Eurema hecabe solifera[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Coliadinae
Genus: [i]Eurema[/i]
Species: [i]hecabe[/i]
Subspecies: [i]solifera[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 32–41mm female 34–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small bright yellow Pierid. Differs from African Clouded Yellow [i]Colias electo electo[/i] in upperside ground colour [i]yellow, not orange[/i], and Spiller's Sulphur Yellow [i]Dixeia spilleri[/i], in that it has [i]broad black borders[/i]. Black forewing upperside marginal band [i]scalloped[/i], which sets it apart from other [i]Eurema[/i] species except Malagasy Grass Yellow [i]E. floricola[/i]. This is a very similar species but Common Grass Yellow can be told from it as follows: underside hind wing cell spot seldom widens towards the apical end, to not more than twice the width of the narrow portion. The hind wing margin is [i]continuously black[/i], or if it is reduced as in dry season individuals, the [i]marks at the end of the veins are linear smudges, not spots[/i]. Best identifying feature is where the scalloped edge of forewing upperside black border bends inwards along vein M3, not halfway up area M2 as in Malagasy Grass Yellow (see arrow in (A)).
 
Sexes similar, female [i]paler yellow[/i] than male, has grey scaling at upperside wing bases.
 
Fluttering flight, fairly low, along thick forest vegetation, or in open Savanna country. Settles often on flowers or vegetation. Can fly fast if disturbed.
 
Seasonally dimorphic. Dry season form has dark smudges at the hind wing upperside margin vein ends; underside forewing tip carries a [i]square dark patch[/i]: (A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.
 
Wet season form has a [i]continuous dark hind wing upperside marginal band[/i] and the underside forewing tip is [i]plain yellow[/i]. (C) Male underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Savanna, open woodland, Riverine and Lowland Forest, through KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland, Mpumalanga, and Limpopo Province. After this map was made, some populations of this species were found to be Malagasy Grass Yellow, so that butterfly's range is included. However, the ranges overlap considerably so this is of little concern.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Continuous broods, year-round, depending on rainfall. WSF Sept–May, DSF Mar–Oct. Peaks in late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Hypericum aethiopicum[/i] and [i]Chamaecrista mimosoides[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Yellows.
Back to Top






Swanepoel's Opal
[i]Chrysoritis swanepoeli swanepoeli[/i]

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chrysoritis[/i]
Species: [i]swanepoeli[/i]
Subspecies: [i]swanepoeli[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 23–26mm female 24–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Bright red-orange Opal, male upperside blue wing patches [i]small[/i], and extent of shifting electric lustre [i]limited[/i]. Has similar habits to Beulah's [i]Chrysoritis beulah[/i] and Irene's [i]C. irene[/i] Opals but they fly in different areas and [i]C. swanepoeli[/i] is a darker insect with a [i]variegated underside[/i]. Hind wing upperside dark spots [i]limited or absent[/i]. Forewing upperside dark borders [i]variable in width[/i]; specimens from higher altitudes have [i]more extensive[/i] dark markings. Male has [i]large spot at end of forewing cell[/i], which is widely separated from the postdiscal row of spots. Both sexes have [i]prominently chequered[/i] cilia. Forewing underside has typical 'Copper' pattern of black spots on a pale ground with dark borders. Hind wing underside [i]strongly variegated[/i] with prominent pale costal and discal marks, a pale postdiscal band and well-defined silvery sagittate marks.
 
Sexes differ. Female has [i]little or no[/i] basal blue, similar black spotting to other female [i]Chrysoritis[/i] spp., and rounded wings.
 
2 subspp., altitudinally separated. Lives in scattered colonies in gullies and dry riverbeds, from the base to the summits of high mountains. Males perch on prominent rocks or plants, periodically taking off to patrol their territory. Females are more sedentary, found on flowers and close to the host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Fynbos, Nama Karoo in W Cape on lower slopes of Swartberg and Schoemanskloof (near Cango Caves), and Huis Rivier Pass, Gamkaskloof.

Habitat
Gullies, mountains, rocky ledges.
Back to Top
Flight period
Single extended brood, Oct–Jan.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Thesium[/i] spp. and [i]Tylecodon paniculata[/i]. Larvae associated with [i]Crematogaster[/i] nr [i]liengmei[/i] ants.

Opals.

Common Meadow White

Classification

Back to Top

Male 35–40mm female 37–43mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small white Pierid with dark upperside spotting. Similar to Brown-veined White [i]Belenois aurota aurota[/i] and its relatives, but can be told apart by the forewing cellular spot, which is always [i]large and squarish[/i], never a bar- or dumbbell-shaped. Underside hind wing and forewing tips appear [i]green[/i] as a result of heavy irroration of [i]black and yellow scales[/i] and not [i]grey- or brown-black[/i]. There are extensive [i]pure yellow[/i] markings on the underside, which run into the dark areas. Not seasonally dimorphic but winter specimens have [i]fainter, smaller dark markings[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. Female upperside more [i]heavily marked[/i] with brownish black; has a submarginal spot just above forewing tornus, [i]lacking in male[/i]. Female hind wing has [i]broader brown-black marginal band with white interneural spots[/i].
 
Slow, fluttering flight across open country; males often visit hilltops. Both sexes are fond of flowers; females regularly found near host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside.(C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Common and widespread, often in old farmlands. Throughout South Africa, from high mountains to Arid Savanna.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, flatlands, coast, mountains, wetlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Sept–Nov and Mar.
Back to Top

[i]Brassica juncea, Heliophila[/i] spp., including [i]H. linearis[/i], and [i]Lobularia maritima, Lepidum capense, L. bonariense, L. sativum, Rapistrum rugosum, Reseda odorata, R. lutea, Sisymbrium capense, S. lyratum, S. officinale[/i].

Very pale coloured [i]Aloeides[/i] copper. Orange upperside [i]very pale[/i], dark borders more [i]grey[/i] than black. Identification
Small butterfly with [i]bronzy-brown[/i] upperside and mid-grey underside crossed by darker grey or brown lines and bands. Forewing on both surfaces has black spot at anal angle, typical of [i]Leptomyrina[/i] black-eyes, usually [i]a basal-marginal series of two or three[/i] on the upperside. [i]Larger[/i] than Cape Black-eye [i]L. lara[/i], with more [i]angular[/i] wings; upperside colour a duller brown. Unlike Common Black-eye [i]L. gorgias gorgias[/i], [i]dull[/i] basal colouring but with some shiny scaling in male.
 
Sexes similar; male smaller with more angular wings. Male hind wing upperside carries pale row of postdiscal marks proximal to submarginal black spots.
 
Fond of rocky country where its host plants grow; common garden species. Low, zigzagging flight. Easy to confuse with other small brown lycaenids. Males very aggressive and territorial; females found on flowers and near host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Female underside.

Identification
Small to medium-sized sapphire. Distinctive species with pointed wings and [i]grey-mottled[/i] underside. Cannot easily be confused with any other sapphire. May fly together with Mimosa Sapphire [i]Iolaus mimosae[/i] and Trimen's Sapphire [i]I. trimeni[/i], but is easily told apart from the undersides.
 
Sexes differ slightly; female outer edge of blue patches [i]suffused with white[/i], hind wing upperside has [i]dark submarginal stripe[/i].
 
Male flies rapidly around prominent hill tops (usually seen after 14h00), settling on exposed twigs; chasing intruders. Female also visits hill tops in search of a mate (as late as 17h00); at other times of day more likely to be found around host plant, or on flowers.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.

Back to Top

Male 22–26mm female 24–28mm.
Back to Top
Identification
[i]Aloeides[/i] copper with red upperside. Markings variable - upperside dark veins sometimes reduced, underside hind wing ground colour varies from grey-brown through red-brown, to purplish crimson on underside. Hind wing underside discal spots large and partly joined into roughly X-shaped discoidal fascia. The outer edge of this is uneven and not parallel to the outer margin. Submarginal serrated row of spots present but broken and discontinuous.
 
[i]A. thyra orientis[/i] has forewing tip blunter; outer margin more rounded than nominate. Upperside ground colour [i]more reddish[/i]; greater tendency not to have veins outlined in black; forewing discal band narrower and hind wing apical patch smaller. Sexes similar, female with wings rounder, orange marks penetrate post-cell area of forewing upperside.
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct. Flight fairly fast, fluttering close to the ground; settling often, usually on the ground or on low vegetation. Lives in large, scattered colonies on hillsides, beach margins and flatlands. Reluctant to open wings.
 
(E) Male upperside. (F) Male underside (brown morph). (G) Male underside (crimson morph).

Identification
The most widespread large Bitter Acraea found in South Africa.
 
Sexes similar, male generally brighter than female; more active.
 
Large, conspicuous, slow-flying unless molested; settles often, wings held open. Joins hordes of other butterflies on flowers during the dry season.
 
Seasonally dimorphic. Nominate f. [i]natalica[/i] is wet season form, hind wing margins wide. (A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C) Mating pair, male R, female L. (D) Male underside. (E) Female underside.
 
Extreme wet season form, f. [i]umbrata[/i], male has dark scaling in discal area of the forewing. Underside same as nominate (D). (F) Male upperside.
 
Dry season form f. [i]albiventris[/i] male has reduced black markings, narrow hind wing margins, upper abdomen surface whitish. Underside same as nominate (D). (G) Male upperside.
 
[i]mesoleuca[/i] is blackish, with white patch in hind wing cell. Underside same as nominate (E). (H) Female upperside.
 
f. [i]albida[/i] in both sexes has white patches in hind wing cell [i]and[/i] forewing basal area. Underside same as nominate (E). (I) Female upperside.

Identification
Blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Underside ground colour [i]darker grey[/i] than Koppie Blue [i]Lepidochrysops ortygia[/i], with [i]more prominent white markings, especially the postdiscal sagittate series[/i]. Cilia bright white with black chequering at the vein ends.
 
Sexes differ in that the female upperside, as in many of the genus [i]Lepidochrysops[/i], has a row of [i]dark postdiscal spots[/i] on the forewing, and a [i]dark band[/i] crossing the hind wing, corresponding to the dark underside spotting. Female resembles Koppie Blue, but blue flush [i]deeper, brighter[/i], often [i]more extensive[/i]. Male upperside [i]bluer[/i]; marginal borders [i]wider[/i], but like the female this is a variable characteristic.
 
Flight; fast and erratic, circling hill tops, settling on prominent rocks or shrubs. Found on fynbos-covered hillsides, male on peaks at midday.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
From hills above Greyton (Riviersonderendberge) and Caledon, along coastal ranges to E Cape (Vanstadensberg, west of Port Elizabeth).
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, mountains, hill tops.
Back to Top

Single- or double-brooded from Nov–Mar.

[i]Selago[/i] spp.

Rusty Swift
[i]Borbo detecta[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat

Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Hesperiidae
Subfamily: Hesperiinae
Genus: [i]Borbo[/i]
Species: [i]detecta[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 34–36mm female 36–38mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–small brown Skipper. Upperside pale brown with [i]ochreous yellow[/i] hairs in [i]radiating basal rust-ochre streaks[/i] on the forewing; hind wing suffused with same colour. Has small hyaline spots on both wings; single spot in forewing cell. Underside ground colour grey-brown overlaid with conspicuous [i]ochreous yellow[/i] scales; has irregular discal series of pale spots, similar to Long-horned Swift [i]Borbo fatuellus fatuellus[/i] but the ground colour is distinctive. Cilia plain pale grey-brown. Other Swifts have coloured hairs on the upperside. Black-branded Swift [i]Pelopidas mathias mathias[/i] and White-branded Swift [i]P. thrax[/i] can be told apart by the males' forewing sex brands, but the undersides of both sexes are [i]more conspicuously spotted[/i] in the discal area. Olive-haired Swift [i]B. borbonica[/i] can be immediately told apart by its [i]black-ringed white[/i] underside hind wing discal spots. Twin Swift [i]Larsenia gemella[/i] has a [i]grey-brown underside[/i] with [i]larger white spots[/i] than Rusty Swift.
 
Sexes similar. Female paler than male, with markings similar, but hind wing markings more distinct; wings rounder, more elongated.
 
Rapid, zooming flight. Male territorial at edges of open patches of water or shorter vegetation. Female flight random in the same areas.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside.
Back to Top
Distribution
E Cape (Port Alfred), KwaZulu-Natal and Swaziland Lowland and Riverine Forest and Savanna hinterland, to Greytown, Maputaland and Pongola, into se Mpumalanga (De Kaap area) and ne Limpopo Province.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, flatlands, coast, hill tops.
Back to Top

Year-round, scarcer in winter.

[i]Ehrharta erecta, Saccharum officinarum[/i] and other Poaceae grasses.

Swifts.

African Veined White

Classification
Family: Pieridae
Subfamily: Pierinae
Genus: [i]Belenois[/i]
Species: [i]gidica[/i]
Subspecies: [i]abyssinica[/i]

Male 40–55mm female 40–53mm, varying with seasonal form.
Back to Top
Identification
Medium–large white or yellow Pierid. Superficially resembles Brown-veined White [i]Belenois aurota[/i], at least in the male and the white form female. The male has a [i]falcate forewing tip[/i]; both sexes' underside hind wings have [i]a postdiscal row of sagittate dark marks[/i]. Unlike Brown-veined White, there is a yellow female form, and strong seasonal dimorphism. May also be confused with Forest White [i]B. zochalia[/i] but is [i]larger[/i] and [i]lacks the upperside pearlescent sheen[/i].
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male forewing tip is [i]pointed, falcate[/i]. Female has [i]square[/i] forewing tips. Male dark markings are confined to the tips and margins; females have extensive basal dark patches (in wet season forms) and [i]postdiscal spots[/i].
 
Wet season male form [i]doubledayi[/i] has [i]extensive black marginal forewing marks[/i]; underside hind wing ground colour [i]white with thin black veins and interneural black postdiscal sagittate marks[/i]. Female form [i]doubledayi is buff-yellow[/i] on both wing surfaces; [i]heavy black hind wing upperside marginal bands[/i]; upperside basal areas [i]strongly marked with dark scaling[/i]. (A) Male upperside. (B), (C) Male undersides. (D) Female upperside. (E) Female underside.
 
Female wet season form [i]westwoodi[/i] has [i]white[/i] ground colour; dark markings as in female form [i]doubledayi[/i]. (F) Female upperside. (G) Female underside.
 
Dry season male form [i]abyssinica[/i] has [i]restricted upperside dark marking[/i]. Both sexes' underside hind wing [i]strongly suffused with grey or coffee-brown[/i] over a white or cream base colour, which is [i]almost totally obscured[/i] except for a diagonal pale streak through the cell and into area M3. The sagittate postdiscal interneural hind wing marks are present but not as distinct as in the dry season forms. Female dry season form [i]abyssinica[/i] has pale lemon upperside. (H) Male upperside. (I), (J) Male undersides. (K) Female upperside. (L), (M) Female undersides.
 
Form [i]masculina[/i], not illustrated, is as sparsely marked as male form [i]doubledayi[/i].
Back to Top
Distribution
Woodland from near Swellendam (W Cape), east in Savanna and valley bushveld along rivers and coast into KwaZulu-Natal, Maputaland, Swaziland, and lowveld of Mpumalanga, Limpopo and NW Provinces in Savanna.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands, forest edges, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, more common in late summer and autumn (Jan–May); seasonal forms depending on rainfall: WSF Sept–Apr, DSF Mar–Oct.

Common Woolly Legs
[i]Lachnocnema bibulus[/i]
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Lachnocnema[/i]
Species: [i]bibulus[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 21–27mm female 21–30.5mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny to small butterfly. Males have brown-black upperside, female [i]grey to grey-brown[/i]. Undersides are cryptic with patches of beautiful metallic scales. Male very similar to that of Southern Pied Woolly Legs [i]Lachnocnema laches[/i]. Male has some similarities to D'Urban's Woolly Legs [i]L. durbani[/i] but that butterfly's male has a [i]dull grey[/i]-brown upperside and is a denizen of Grassland. Its underside has a [i]regular[/i] pattern of buff or pale brown on a grey ground.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Male upperside brown-black, female [i]soft grey to grey-brown[/i] with [i]ill-defined[/i] blue-grey discal patches, and postdiscal white streaks. Dark spot at distal end of forewing cell. Male underside hind wing has more or less distinct median band of variable width.
 
These butterflies are always found close to concentrations of aphids, plant Hoppers or scale insects (Homoptera), on which the larvae prey. There are also always ants present, because the larvae shelter during the day in ants' nests. Males are territorial and sit atop bushes or on prominent plants, sallying forth to confront intruders. They fly fast, rapidly circling trees and shrubs harbouring larval prey. Female are sedentary and seldom leave the twigs where the scale insects are feeding.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Lowland Forest edges and wooded Savanna from E Cape (Port Elizabeth) to KwaZulu-Natal, Swaziland, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, parks and gardens, flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round in warmer areas, peaks spring and late summer.
Back to Top
Larval food
Insects (Homoptera nymphs).
Back to Top
Group
Woolly Legs.

Very similar to Blue-spotted Emperor [i]Charaxes cithaeron cithaeron[/i], but [i]smaller[/i] and has [i]straight[/i] (not crenellated) discal lines crossing the underside of the hind wing. The pale upperside markings on the male are [i]more purple[/i] than blue.

The largest [i]Dira[/i] species; similar in flight pattern and habits to [i]D. oxylus[/i] but the huge gap in range between the two species makes it unmistakable. Medium-sized bright blue lycaenid. Underside (both sexes) with distinctive [i]white lines on fawn ground colour[/i], which is unique to this butterfly and distinguishes it from the many species of blue that fly with it.

Silvery Blue
[i]Lepidochrysops glauca[/i]
alternative common name: Silvery Nimble Blue, Silvery Giant Cupid
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Polyommatinae
Genus: [i]Lepidochrysops[/i]
Species: [i]glauca[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 35–40mm female 38–48mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, bright blue [i]Lepidochrysops[/i] Ant Blue. Both sexes' uppersides are similar to those of Patrician Blue [i]Lepidochrysops patricia[/i], but are a [i]paler, silvery greenish-blue[/i], not [i]mauve-blue[/i]. Some specimens, especially those found near stands of [i]Ocimum americanum[/i] are [i]sky blue[/i] with no green tint. Underside of both sexes as Patrician Blue, usually with a [i]paler grey[/i] ground colour. Both surfaces of both sexes' hind wings have [i]prominent[/i] orange lunules above large black spots at the anal angle. The largest spot is in area CuA1; sometimes the black spot in area 1A+2A is absent but the orange lunule still present. Hind wing carries a small tail at end of vein CuA2. Cilia plain whitish grey.
 
Sexually dimorphic; male upperside plain blue with [i]thin fuscous-grey margins[/i]. Female upperside has variable extent of basal and discal blue on a [i]fuscous-grey[/i] ground, [i]whitish[/i] sagittate hind wing submarginal marks. Female also has [i]larger dark spot at the distal end of the cell[/i] than the male, and in some specimens there is a postdiscal row of faint white-edged grey spots corresponding in position to those on the underside.
 
Rapid flight across open bushveld, settling occasionally on flowers. Male may hilltop. Some populations exhibit high density, colonial behaviour, usually where [i]Ocimum americanum[/i] is host plant.
 
(A) Male upperside (sky blue [i]Ocimum americanum[/i] type, on host plant). (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside (ice-blue type).
Back to Top
Distribution
Savanna and Arid Savanna over Limpopo and NW provinces, and part of Gauteng.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, hill tops, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Two broods, Sept–Dec and Jan–Apr, with some overlap.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Orthosiphon thymiflorus, Ocimum americanum, Lantana rugosa[/i] and [i]L. viburnoides[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Ant Blues.

Eastern Scarlet
[i]Axiocerses tjoane tjoane[/i]
alternative common name: Common Scarlet
Contents

Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Axiocerses[/i]
Species: [i]tjoane[/i]
Subspecies: [i]tjoane[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 24–32mm female 25–34mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small, brilliant scarlet-red lycaenid. Male Common Scarlet similar to Dark-banded Scarlet [i]Axiocerses croesus[/i] but has [i]no dark submarginal spots[/i] on hind wing upperside. Compared to Black-tipped Scarlet [i]A. coalescens[/i] the absence on the male upperside forewing of discal black spots sets that species apart. Bush Scarlet [i]A. amanga amanga[/i] has a [i]plain hind wing underside[/i] with [i]no brassy spots[/i].
 
The underside ground colour varies from pale sandy buff to a deep reddish brown. The forewing has a similar spotting pattern to most Coppers; the hind wing has rows of dark spots with brassy centres.
 
Sexes differ; females are [i]more orange than red[/i] on the upperside with a varying extent of rows of dark spotting: they are virtually impossible to distinguish from the other two similar species.
 
Males are extremely pugnacious hilltoppers. Rapid flight with very fast wingbeats, especially in males. Male perches at midday on low bushes, often upside down, with half-open wings. Females are more often found on flowers and close to host plants.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside, dark morph. (C) Male underside, pale morph. (D) Female upperside. (E) Female underside, dark morph. (F) Female underside, pale morph.
Back to Top
Distribution
Widespread and abundant. Grassland and wooded Savanna from E Cape (Lusikisiki area) to KwaZulu-Natal, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, and Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops, flatlands, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Sept–Nov and Mar–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Senegalia polyacantha, Vachellia karroo[/i] and [i]Vachellia sieberana[/i].

Brilliant Gem
[i]Chloroselas pseudozeritis pseudozeritis[/i]
Contents

Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Aphnaeinae
Genus: [i]Chloroselas[/i]
Species: [i]pseudozeritis[/i]
Subspecies: [i]pseudozeritis[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male and female both 20–24mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Tiny lycaenid; when examined close up the only species that can be confused with it is Purple Gem, [i]Chloroselas mazoensis[/i]. Apart from the differences in the male uppersides, the undersides of both sexes can be told apart by the [i]deep buff[/i] colour of Brilliant Gem, carrying [i]larger, better defined[/i] brassy centred spots. Each hind wing carries a pair of thin tails with white tips at the anal angle.
 
Sexually dimorphic. The male upperside has a shifting, metallic [i]brilliant electric iridescence[/i] that shifts from [i]blue to green[/i], over a blackish brown ground colour. This is very beautiful, but only visible when viewed under light coming from the correct acute angle. Female is [i]dull-brown[/i] above, sometimes with buff patch in middle of forewing on upperside, and sparse blue scaling, but [i]no electric sheen[/i].
 
Habits similar to Bars, High-fliers and Scarlets but small size and rapid flight makes them difficult to spot amongst the hordes of tiny Babul Blues ([i]Azanus[/i] sp.) and Hairtails ([i]Anthene[/i] sp.) with which they habitually fly. Occasionally in strong colonies, but more often in groups of 6–8.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Male underside. (C) Female upperside. (D) Female underside.
Back to Top
Distribution
Wooded Savanna from E Cape (Grahamstown area) to KwaZulu-Natal (Kosi Bay), inland across thorn country to Estcourt, Mpumalanga, and Limpopo and NW provinces.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hill tops.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round, peaks Sept–Nov and Mar–May.
Back to Top

[i]Vachellia nilotica[/i]. Further north, larvae live in tunnels in twigs of [i]Julbernardia globiflora[/i].

African Joker
[i]Byblia anvatara acheloia[/i]
alternative common name: Common Joker
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Biblidinae
Genus: [i]Byblia[/i]
Species: [i]anvatara[/i]
Subspecies: [i]acheloia[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 40–45mm female 43–48mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small to medium-sized orange butterfly with black bands. One of two species of Joker found in South Africa. Conspicuous, bright orange, small butterfly. Can be told apart from Spotted Joker [i]Byblia ilithyia[/i] by [i]lack of black spotting[/i] in hind wing upperside discal band. Underside shows considerable seasonal variation; Nominate dry season form hind wing underside crossed with chocolate-brown bands and yellow-white spots. More common wet season form f. [i]similata[/i] has [i]yellow-ochre[/i] hind wing on underside, basal spots black, submarginal band black with small white spots. Other superficially similar species are Gaudy Commodore [i]Precis octavia sesamus[/i] f. [i]natalensis[/i], and Pirate [i]Catacroptera cloanthe[/i]. The former lacks the [i]pale underside markings[/i] and the latter has a [i]plain[/i] underside.
 
Sexes similar in markings: male [i]much brighter orange[/i] than female, edges of black marks [i]better defined[/i].
 
Active, erratic flight, usually not more than 1–2m above the ground, in open grassy areas and between bushes. Frequently settles on plants but seldom flowers, wings open, slowly 'pumping' them. Like [i]B. ilithyia[/i] and [i]Danaus chrysippus[/i], commonly seen sucking grass flowerheads, behaviour that is not currently understood as grasses do not produce nectar. Both sexes are attracted to fallen fruit and come readily to traps baited with this.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside. (C), (D) Male underside f. [i]anvatara[/i]. (E) Male underside f. [i]similata[/i].
 
Back to Top
Distribution
Abundant in warm Savanna, Grassland, coastal and Lowland Forest from E Cape (East
London), to KwaZulu-Natal, Free State, Gauteng and NW Province, lowveld of
Swaziland, Mpumalanga and Limpopo Province, and further north.
Back to Top
Habitat
Flatlands, coast.
Back to Top
Flight period
Year-round; two main overlapping broods, summer (Nov–Mar) more numerous than winter (May–Aug).
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Tragia glabrata, Dalechampia capensis[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Jokers.

Basuto Skolly
[i]Thestor basuta basuta[/i]
alternative common name: Basuto Magpie
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Lycaenidae
Subfamily: Miletinae
Genus: [i]Thestor[/i]
Species: [i]basuta[/i]
Subspecies: [i]basuta[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 30–39mm female 35–42mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Small brown butterfly with black upperside markings. Large for a [i]Thestor[/i]; unique and unmistakable; does not fit into any of the Skolly groups. [i]Brown[/i], as opposed to buff or grey; build [i]more robust[/i] than other Skollies and female has distinctive white forewing upperside black and white markings. Underside is pale grey-buff with discal area of forewing whitish, with black basal and postdiscal spots. Hind wing basal and postdiscal series are a darker buff-grey.
 
Sexually dimorphic. Males have acutely [i]pointed[/i] forewing and [i]straight[/i] outer margin. Females have blunt-ended forewings and [i]convex[/i] outer margin Extent of white on both wings of female is extremely variable. Some specimens are distinctly [i]pied[/i]; others have hardly any white and are all dun-brown with heavy black forewing blotches. Nominate subspecies [i]T. b. basuta[/i] males have pointed wing tips and the forewing discal area is usually pale grey-brown with darker brown or black marks. The female varies greatly as described, and very dark individuals can be found flying with pale pied examples that would answer to the description of [i]T. b. capeneri[/i].
 
2 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
Male flies fast, settling often on the ground or on stones. Females are sluggish and usually seen flying slowly, close to the ground, seeking out oviposition spots. Usually seen in small groups of a dozen or so, but occasionally much bigger numbers are seen, huge colonies covering large areas of Grassland.
 
(A) Male upperside. (B) Female upperside (close to [i]capeneri[/i]. (C) (D) Male undersides. (E) (F) Female undersides.
Back to Top
Distribution
Most widespread [i]Thestor[/i]; only species in the genus to be found north of South Africa. Found from E Cape (Cathcart), in Grassland and Savanna to Lesotho, KwaZulu-Natal Midlands, Free State, NW Province and N Cape.
Back to Top
Habitat
Hillsides, flatlands.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, Oct–Nov and Feb–Apr.
Back to Top
Larval food
Larvae have been reared to third instar on psyllids (Homoptera), in nests of Pugnacious Ants [i]Anoplolepis custodiens. Thestor b. capeneri[/i] larvae feed on [i]Pulvinaria iceryi[/i] (Homoptera - Coccidae) until third instar; fourth and final instar larvae live inside nests of Pugnacious Ants, which feed them by trophallaxis; they also consume detritus and ant brood.
Back to Top
Group
Skollies.
Back to Top

Identification
Small cream spotted black-brown Skipper. Markings unique; difficult to mistake for any other species. Upperside forewing [i]black-brown with pale cream markings[/i] along outer margin and at wing tip. Cream-white hind wing underside with black-brown veins [i]crossed by thin black bands[/i], appearing 'netted'. Cilia plain.
 
Sexes similar, female has stouter abdomen.
 
Found in groups of 5 to 20 individuals in shade along streams and rivers, at the base of hills or patches of trees on hillsides and flat country. Both sexes on flowers, male on wet mud. Flight slow, skipping and zigzagging just above the ground. Males form territories in shade of trees, perching on grass stems or leaves, periodically making short, fairly fast flights to chase intruders.

Wolkberg Forest King Charaxes
[i]Charaxes xiphares kenwayi[/i]
alternative common name: Wolkberg Forest King Emperor
Contents

Classification
Wingspan
Identification
Distribution
Habitat
Flight period
Larval food
Group

Classification
Family: Nymphalidae
Subfamily: Charaxinae
Genus: [i]Charaxes[/i]
Species: [i]xiphares[/i]
Subspecies: [i]kenwayi[/i]
Back to Top
Wingspan
Male 65–70mm female 70–80mm.
Back to Top
Identification
Large, dark Charaxes. In certain parts of its range, males can be confused with Blue-Spotted Charaxes, [i]Charaxes cithaeron cithaeron[/i]. However, that species has [i]much broader[/i] hind wing upperside pale patch, almost totally white. The postdiscal series of forewing royal blue marks are [i]smaller[/i] in [i]C. xiphares[/i]. Females are distinctive. [i]C. x. kenwayi[/i] is a small race. The male has [i]enlarged[/i] blue marks on the upperside. There are two female forms. Nominate has a white hind wing upperside discal patch. f. [i]lutea[/i], which is the dominant form, has a yellow patch.
 
Sexes strongly dimorphic, male with [i]royal blue[/i] spots and bands on metallic navy ground, female with [i]white discal forewing band[/i] (of variable width) sometimes invaded by yellow-ochre. Most females have a pale yellow hind wing upperside patch, but in some populations, it is blue-white or pale mauve. Differences between females is usually of more value than subtle differences between the males in distinguishing subspecies.
 
Powerful, high flight in the canopy and around tree tops. Males territorial, perching high up and pursuing any butterfly (or other flying creature) that ventures nearby. Females fly rapidly along the fringes of forests where they settle on tree leaves.
 
Both sexes are attracted to rotting fruit, animal dung and sap leaking from wounded trees.
 
8 subspp., geographically distinct.
 
(W) Male upperside. (X) Male underside. (Y) Female upperside f. [i]lutea[/i]. (Z) Female upperside f. [i]kenwayi[/i]. (AA) Female underside (both forms the same).
Back to Top
Distribution
Afromontane Forest along eastern escarpment in Limpopo Province (Wolkberg).
Back to Top
Habitat
Forest edges, mountains, hillsides.
Back to Top
Flight period
Double-brooded, weak peak Oct–Nov, stronger Mar–May.
Back to Top
Larval food
[i]Cryptocarya woodii, Scutia myrtina, Rhamnus prinoides[/i] and [i]Chaetachme aristata[/i].
Back to Top
Group
Charaxes.

Classification

Male 22–27mm female 26–28mm.

Identification
Very small dark brown-black Skipper with irregular bands of white spots on both wings. Upperside dark brown; forewing has small white basal and postdiscal spots. Hind wing upperside carries faint postdiscal white spots, sometimes absent. Hind wing underside has [i]two white bands[/i] separated by a dark brown median fascia, [i]thin white striae[/i] at base and submarginal areas. Namaqua Dancer has hind wing underside median fascia [i]more strongly irrorated with white scales[/i], appearing grey. Cilia chequered.
 
Sexes similar; females usually larger than males, with [i]larger abdomen[/i].
 
Low, buzzing flight a few centimetres above ground, jinking and swerving between rocks and low vegetation. Settles with wings held open on rocks or low vegetation; wary and difficult to approach closely.
 
(A) Female upperside. (B) Male underside.
